The management plan includes close monitoring of seizure frequency and symptomatology, with adjustments as necessary based on the patient’s response and response to treatment. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist may be necessary depending on the outcome of the review.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent seizures with associated gastrointestinal symptoms, likely exacerbated by the recent onset of seizures and promiscuity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures, but these are less likely given the current symptoms and history. The prognosis depends on the management of the seizures and the progression of symptoms.
P: Continue current medication regimen and monitor seizure frequency closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to reassess seizure status and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of gastrointestinal symptoms. Consider consultation with a psychiatrist for further management of seizures.

S: The patient reports progressive headaches for two months, a fever for two weeks, blurred central vision, and restricted visual fields. The patient also experiences nausea and recent vomiting. Past medical history includes treatment for latent tuberculosis and a treated urinary tract infection.
O: Physical examination revealed a low-grade fever of 38.5°C, somnolence, and oriented to self when aroused. Neurological testing was non-focal. CT scan and MRI revealed a large cystic mass in the brain displacing the pituitary gland, with contrast enhancement of the cyst wall, overlying chiasm, and adjacent hypothalamic region. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed elevated opening pressure at 30 cm H2O, high protein at 104, and low glucose at 29. White blood cells were 835, with 56% neutrophils. Hormonal assays were negative for infectious agents. CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis were unremarkable for metastatic etiology.
A: The primary diagnosis is pan-hypopituitarism, likely secondary to infectious meningoencephalitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of central nervous system dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the absence of metastasis.
P: The management plan includes continued antiviral therapy with fluconazole and pituitaries hormone replacements. The management of symptoms and adherence to the treatment plan will be crucial for managing the mass and preventing further recurrence. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on recognizing symptoms of potential recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a resident of a forest dwelling near the river Comté, presents with a few days of mild symptoms including fever, body aches, and myalgia. The patient has a history of acute dengue-like viral infection, treated with a diagnosis of a viral infection on the 5th of August.
O: Physical examination revealed a fever of 102 bpm, body pain, and a high fever. Laboratory tests showed renal and hepatic failure. Serological tests confirmed Yellow Fever, with six potentially co-exposed individuals vaccinated against Yellow Fever.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute degue-related viral infection with complications including renal and liver failure. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the disease and the patient's lack of immunosuppressive therapy.
P: The management plan includes transfer to a specialized transplant centre in Paris for a hepatic transplant. Post-transplant, the patient will be closely monitored for potential complications such as infection or infectious disease. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old male with no comorbidities, no history of alcoholism, smoking, or regular medication use. He reports a history of fever, myalgia, anorexia, vomiting, jaundice, and colure starting July 14, 2016, accompanied by a high fever, weakness, vomiting (paleothenia gravis), and yellow skin and eyes. He has been on antiviral drugs including monohydrate dipyrone (750 mg/day), chlorpheniramine maleate (6 mg/ day), and paracetamol (>4 g/day). He denies taking other drugs.
O: Initial CBC showed hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL, hematocrit 39.6%, platelets 343,000/mm3, white blood cells 5200/mm2, AST 39.8 U/L, ALT 40.1 U/l, GGT 346 U/ L, alkaline phosphatase 98.5 U/dL. NS1 test for dengue was negative. Abdominal ultrasound indicated mild/moderate steatosis. Hemoglobin 10.2 mg/dL showed hematocytosis, heparin 30.7%, red blood cells 4.16 million/mm4, and platelets 200,000-mm3.
A: The primary diagnosis is hepatitis B, evidenced by the patient's symptoms, lab results, and elevated liver enzymes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver enzymes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of hepatitis B.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of liver function and liver function. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and advised to report any new or worsening symptoms promptly. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the management plan as necessary. Education on the importance of reporting new or deteriorating symptoms will be provided to the patient.

S: The patient is an 86-year-old male with a history of arterial hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, peripheral arterial disease, and arthrosis of the knees. He has been treated with enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, nifedipine, aspirin, simvastatin, finasteride, cilostazol, and tamsulosin. He reports a recent hypertensive emergency and severe dyspnea, which was managed with methylene blue. He also experienced hemoglobinuria and positive markers for hemolysis.
O: Recent laboratory results show elevated reticulocyte count, macrocytosis, transient leukocytosis with 60% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, 8% monocytes, 2% eosinophils, and normal platelet count at 250,000/mm3. Hemoglobinuria was 4701 U/L, total bilirubin was 1.6 mg/dL (normal 0.3-1.2 mg/L), unconjugated bilirubsin was 0.9 mg/dl (normal <1 mg/l), and haptoglobin was less than 6 mg/mL (normal 44-215 mg/ml). Coombs test was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is hemolytic anemia, likely secondary to a chronic inflammatory process, given the patient's history of hypertension, chronic kidney diseases, and liver dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia such as hemangiocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and his condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the progression of the anemia and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the hematological anemia is recommended.

S: The patient reports feeling pretty good following a recent checkup. The patient was previously diagnosed with multiple metastases from an unknown primary tumor.
O: Initial examination revealed a small nodule in the lower lobe of the right lung. Laboratory tests were within normal limits. A CT scan revealed a lytic lesion in the fifth lumbar vertebral bone and a small lesion on the left transverse process of the left lung, separated from the spinal canal. Biopsy of both lesions showed spindle cell neoplasms with a bland appearance. Five years later, a CT scan showed a slightly increased pulmonary nodule and increased lytic lesions in the left-sided process. Video-assisted thoracic surgery was performed for the pulmonary lesion and curettage of the lytic bone lesion. The vertebral lesion was exposed on the posterior surface but not on the anterior surface.
A: The primary diagnosis is multiple metastatic lung tumors, likely secondary to a primary tumor, given the patient's history and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lung lesions, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up visits to monitor for any changes or recurrence of the lesion or other malignancies. The plan includes continued monitoring and regular followups to assess for any recurrence or progression of the disease. The treatment plan will include continued adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen and supportive care for any potential complications.

S: The patient, a male, presented with sudden onset of severe mid-sternal chest pain radiating to the back, described as intense and spreading to his back. He denied experiencing dysphagia lusoria or hoarseness during this time. He has a history of a bicuspid aortic valve and yearly cardiac echocardiography.
O: Physical examination was hemodynamically stable. Laboratory tests showed no significant deviations in laboratory results. Contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a contained rupture of a saccular aneurysm at the base of the left subclavian artery, approximately 7 x 8.5 cm in diameter, extending to the transverse Aortic arch, with a large diffuse mediastinal hematoma, small left pleural effusion, and a bovine aorticus arch. Cardiac echography indicated moderate aortical regurgitation grade 2+. The patient's LV EF was 50%.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured saccula of the right subclava artery, complicated by a bacuspid valve rupture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain and chest pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and monitoring of cardiac function. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery progress and adjust as necessary. Further surgical interventions may be considered if there is no improvement in cardiac function or progression of symptoms.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old female athlete with four years of FFT experience, presenting with a body fat percentage of 14%. She reports no major issues with her training and has signed a written informed consent. She is aware of the lack of controlled food intake and supplementation during the study, maintaining a well-balanced diet and maintaining regular eating habits.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be 67 kg and 155 cm tall, with a BMI of 14% and a 1-repetition maximum of 130 kg for back squat, 112 kg for front squat, 95 kg for the clean and jerk, and 77 kg for snatch. No significant weight loss was noted.
A: The primary assessment is the patient's lack of dietary control during the FFT study. The absence of dietary restrictions and adherence to the protocols and procedures were noted. The patient's health is generally good, and she has a solid understanding of her training regimen.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of her diet and supplementation, with follow-up appointments to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in her condition. She should maintain regular follow-ups to ensure she is compliant with the treatment plan and follow up appointments. Education on the importance of adherence to dietary restrictions should be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a healthcare professional for further evaluation and management of her condition is recommended.

S: The patient reports sudden onset of blurred vision in both eyes a day ago. The patient has a history of hypertension treated with paracetamol, caffein, artificial cow-bezoar, and chlorphenamine. No prior ocular disease or myopia was reported. The medication was administered three times the recommended dose.
O: Ocular examination revealed uncorrected vision at 20/400 and corrected to 20/100 OD and 20/60 OS, respectively. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was high at 54 mmHg OD and 55 mmHG OS. Slit lamp examination showed mild hyperemia of the bulbar conjunctivas and transparent corneas. anterior chambers were shallow, and pupils were round. Central anterior chamber depth was 1.97 mm in the right eye and 2.05 mm in left eye, with a lens thickness of 4.43 mm OD and 4.40 mm OS. OCT results showed normal nerve fiber layer thickness. C/D ratio was 0.33 in both eye and 0.53 in the left eye. Ultrasonography revealed a highly reflective band in the vitreous cavity and posterior wall of the eye, but no major abnormalities were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is blurred vision secondary to flu medication, likely exacerbated by the high intraocular pressure and separated band on ultrasonography. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual disturbances, but these are less likely given the absence of specific abnormalities. The prognosis depends on the management of the blurred vision and the effectiveness of the flu medication.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or changes in the condition. Further treatment options may be considered based on further evaluation and management. Referral to an ophthalmologist for specialized care and a retinal specialist may be necessary if the patient does not improve vision. Education on the importance of adherence to the prescribed medication regimen and follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports increasing weakness and pain in both hips and thighs, particularly in the last two weeks, requiring crutches to walk. The patient has been on paracetamol daily for pain management and has a history of epilepsy treated with valproate for 11 years. No other comorbidities or past family history of fractures, irregular menstruation, or osteoporosis were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed massively reduced hip movement on both sides due to severe pain. Serum laboratory examination was normal. Previous seizures occurred at age 15, treated with Valproate, which was discontinued two years ago.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral femoral neck fractures, likely exacerbated by the patient's epilepsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pain such as fractures or irregular menstrual cycles, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the hip movement and pain management. The management will include supportive care for the pain and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the fractures is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old male with a negative family history of FMF, presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, chills, and limbs pain starting at age 23. He has a history of MEFV gene mutations at M680I (G/C) and is currently on colchicine 1 mg twice daily from 7 years ago. He reports a decrease in attacks to one attack every month with a high severity score. No side effects have been reported from the treatment.
O: The primary diagnosis is FMF with a history and symptoms of MEV gene mutation. The patient's attack intervals are almost every 10 days, with an average of 3-4 days. The treatment has been effective with a reduction in attacks from one to one every month. No known side effects from the therapy are reported.
A: Primary diagnosis is a benign FMF (FMF) with associated symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding and gastrointestinal bleeding. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the current response to the treatment and the absence of side effects.
P: Continue current regimen of colchacine 50 mg daily. Monitor symptoms and symptoms closely. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the therapy and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or new side effects immediately. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports noticing a breast lump a few weeks ago, which has been bothering them. The patient has been diagnosed with oestrogen and progesterone receptor positive, HER2 negative, T1cN1bM0 moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma.
O: Physical examination and imaging revealed a platelet count of 600 thou/cu mm. Bone marrow biopsy showed increased megakaryocytes. Iron panel and liver function tests were unremarkable. No splenomegaly was noted on ultrasound.
A: The primary diagnosis is oestrogens and progestrogen receptor positive HER2 positive, T-cell-positive moderately differentiated ductal cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the diagnosis and the patient's history.
P: The management plan includes continuation of aspirin and continuation of low-molecular weight heparin as a thromboprophylaxis until fully ambulatory. Postoperative chemotherapy will continue with letrozole and radiotherapy, followed by hydroxyurea (500 mg) and zoledronic acid to prevent osteoporosis. Post-chemotherapy, the patient will be treated with adjuvant docetaxel and cyclophosphamide, with aspirin 81 mg for the entire duration of chemotherapy. Follow-up chemotherapy will be scheduled to assess response to the chemotherapy and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain, redness, floaters, and decreased vision in the right eye for approximately two days. The patient has a history of anterior uveitis treated with prednisolone acetate eye drops and an intravenous drip of dexamethasone and cephalosporin for seven days, with a decrease in visual acuity from light perception to light perception. No history of systemic diseases, infectious diseases, trauma, surgery, or chronic medication use.
O: Current eye exam findings include light perception in the left eye and 6/6 in the other eye. Slit-lamp examination shows mild injection, anterior chamber cells of 2+ with a hypopyon of 1.4 mm, pupillary hypopyons, posterior iris synechia, and fibrinous exudates covering the anterior lens capsule. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Color ultrasound reveals dense vitreous opacities and an avascular homogeneous hyperechoic mass. Vital parameters are within normal limits with a blood pressure of 132/80 mmHg, pulse at 76/min, and temperature at 36.7°C. Serologic tests for various infections are negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is anterior uvitis with complications including vitreus opacity, vitreosophageal involvement, and vitreal involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of abstaining from alcohol and regular monitoring of his condition. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition promptly.

S: The patient is a 25-year-old female with a long-standing psychiatric disorder, presenting with abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and failure to pass stool and flatus for one week. She reports feeling uncomfortable and bloated for a week.
O: Physical examination revealed disorganized speech, abnormal motor behavior, and lack of emotional expression. Abdominal examination revealed abdominal distention to below the umbilicus, irregular hard multiple masses palpable below umbilical, and exaggerated bowel sounds. Abnormal materials were noted in the abdominal cavity, with the stomach located in the pelvic brim and stenosis in other parts of the gastrointestinal tract. Laparotomy was performed, revealing the stomach to be distended, reaching the pelvis. Gastrotomy revealed metallic and nonmetallic materials in the stomach and proximal part of the small intestine, weighing 780 mg. The longest instrument weighed approximately 80 mm.
A: The primary diagnosis is metalophagia, a compulsive consumption of metal objects. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal discomfort, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the absence of perforation or ulceration.
P: The management plan includes referral to a psychiatric hospital for further psychiatric evaluation and management of the psychiatric disorder. The patient will be monitored closely for any signs of recurrence or complications and advised to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, a 71-year-old woman, presented with progressive left hip pain for approximately 8 months, which has been worsening with analgesics. She reports that her walking distance has been affected and painkillers are ineffective.
O: Physical examination revealed normal walking with no scar on the left hip or buttock, but lateral rotation and abduction are markedly diminished. Radiographs of the pelvis and left hip showed signs of hip osteoarthritis. Post-total hip arthroplasty, a well-circumscribed shell was found within the adipose tissue, revealing a purulent collection. Histological examination of the resected shell showed a greasy appearance with epithelial and lymphocytic cells, but no visible germs.
A: The primary diagnosis is symptomatic symptomatic left hip osteosarcoma, likely exacerbated by the patient's obesity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hip pain such as osteosarcinoma, but these are less likely given the histological findings.
P: The management plan includes total hip arthropplasty (THA) by posterolateral approach to alleviate symptoms. The patient will continue to be monitored for response to the treatment and implantation of the prosthesis. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the nature of the disease and the importance of adhering to the therapy regimen will be provided to the patient.

S: The patient reports intermittent low-grade fever for four months, night sweats, loss of appetite, and a weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms. The patient also experiences decreased urine output and generalized swelling.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be febrile with an enlarged right axillary lymph node measuring 1cm x 1cm, ascites, and an 8cm palpable spleen. Fundus examination was normal. Laboratory tests showed pancytopenia, deranged liver function, and kidney function. Hemoglobin was 7.4g/dl, total leucocyte count was 1200/mcl, platelet count was 20000/mmcl, aspartate transaminase was 209 U/l, alanine transaminases were 117 U/L, urea and creatinine levels were 78 and 1.7 mg/dl respectively. Non-contrast CT of the abdomen revealed multiple enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes, with the largest measuring 47 x 22 mm. Blood and urine cultures were sterile. Peripheral smear showed normocytic normochromic anemia. Vitamin B12 levels are normal, folate levels are low at 2.2ng/ml, Serum LDH is elevated at 834 IU/l. Rk39 antibody test was negative. ascitic fluid analysis showed protein 1.9 g/dl (normal range: 0.9-1.2 g/dL), albumin 0.1 g/l (normal: <0.5 g/L), serum-ascitic albumin gradient of 1.1g/dL, and adenosine deaminase levels 40 IU/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is disseminated tuberculosis (DTB) with complications including acute lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and lymphoma, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Initiate treatment with antiviral therapy and consider referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of DTB. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Schedule a follow up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient reports experiencing blistering and soreness in the mouth for approximately 8 months, accompanied by small erosions and ulcers on the soft palate and both sides of the buccal mucosae. The patient has been under Dermatology since 2003 for an itchy rash on the legs, scalp, and chest. Previous treatments included Mycophenolate Mofetil 500 mg twice daily and Prednisolone 10 mg once daily. The oral involvement began in January 2008, necessitating hospital admission for a short period. The management plan included increased MMF dose to 1 g in the morning and 500 mg in the evening for 2 weeks, and thereafter 1 g twice a day for 2 months.
O: Physical examination revealed small erosalions and an ulcer on the right soft palate. Immunofluorescence studies indicated IgG positivity around the upper epidermal cells. The absence of significant erosion/ulcers was noted, and the patient was on Nifedipine and Ranitidine for osteoporosis protection. No oral biopsy was performed.
A: The primary diagnosis is Pemphigus Foliaceus (PF) with complications including oral involvement and ulceration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of mouth blistering or ulcers, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful management of PF and the absence of systemic therapy.
P: Continue current regimen of MMF 500 mg daily and 500 g twice daily. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the response to systemic therapy and manage any potential complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports sudden onset of jerky movements in both upper limbs, accompanied by changes in posture and gait. The patient describes these symptoms as axial, gait apraxia, with difficulty in speech and inability to speak. The symptoms have worsened, leading to the patient becoming almost mute and withdrawn.
O: Physical examination revealed abnormal posture, narrow and shuffling gait, and axial and Gait Apraxia. Visual hallucinations and exaggerated startle responses were noted. MRI brain findings indicated asymmetrical cortical ribboning with a left-sided emphasis and bilateral anterior basal ganglia diffusion restriction, generalized periodic complexes, and generalized periodic complex. Cerebrospinal fluid cell count and routine biochemistry were normal. No protein 14.3.3, S100B, or real-time quaking-induced conversion assay was identified.
A: The primary diagnosis is progressive neurodegenerative diseases, likely exacerbated by the patient's neurological symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of neurological disorders, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of neurological symptoms and neurological status, with a focus on symptom management and symptom management. Further genetic testing may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of neurological deficits. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be crucial.

S: The patient is a 61-year-old woman with a BRCA1 gene mutation, presenting for a prophylactic total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. She reports no history of cancer.
O: Physical examination revealed a solid, firm nodule on the fimbriated end of the right fallopian tube, frozen, with small, tightly packed tubules and nests of epithelioid cells in a fibrous background with many psammoma bodies. A Mucicarmine stain was negative for mucin in the vacuolated cells. Immunohistochemical studies showed positivity for WT1, calretinin, PAX8, D2-40, negativity for p53, estrogen, and progesterone receptors.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign adenomatoid neoplasm, characterized by mucin and thread-like bridging. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies or malignancy, but these are less likely given the negative Mucimine stain.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any signs of recurrence or recurrence. The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any unusual changes in her body. Further consultations with oncology may be necessary if new symptoms arise.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis complicated by hepatocellular carcinoma, Liver Cancer, transcatheter arterial embolization, laparoscopic radiofrequency ablation, esophageal and gastric varices, and endoscopic variceal band ligation due to bleeding esophagal varicealis. He reports a history with smoking 20 cigarettes per day and an average of 100 g of alcohol daily for 40 years without quitting.
O: On admission, the patient's vital signs were blood pressure 116/74 mmHg, pulse 80 beats/min, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min. Hemoglobin level was 8.3 g/dL, significantly below the baseline of 9.2 g/dl. Abdominal CT scan showed cirrhotic and recurrent hepatocellsular carcinomas (HCC) in S4, S6, and S7, with thrombosis in the right posterior branch of the portal vein. Hematology confirmed cirrhoses and recurrent HCC in S6 and S6. Anterograde SBE confirmed ectopic jejunal varices.
A: The primary diagnosis is ectopic jovunal variceas, likely secondary to liver cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cirrhopathy such as hepatic disease or acute coronary syndrome, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and his condition. The patient will be educated on the importance of quitting alcohol and reducing alcohol intake to prevent further complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the signs of complications and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided.

S: The patient presented with sudden, intense substernal chest pain that began 30 minutes prior to arrival. The pain was described as sudden and intense.
O: Initial ECG revealed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and a rate of 147. There was minimal ST depression within the lateral leads but no ST-segment elevation. A chest X-ray showed no gross abnormalities. Cardiac ultrasound confirmed right heart strain secondary to pulmonary embolism. During the bedside cardiac ultrasound, the patient experienced ventricular fibrillillation, a life-threatening heart rhythm, managed with CPR and pulseless ventricular Fibrillation ACLS algorithm. Treatment included multiple rounds of epinephrine, 450 mg of amiodarone, and three conventional defibrillations with increasing joules at 150 J, 200 J, and 200 J. The patient was treated with Lidocaine, which was administered with wide-complex tachycardia and apparent non-responsiveness to amiodara.
A: The primary diagnosis is right heart stress secondary to aortic dissection. Differential diagnoses considered included other causes of heart failure, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the successful conversion of ventricular function.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms or changes in condition. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac symptoms.

S: The patient reports a history of a possible tonic-clonic seizure and a reduction of vision in the right eye since 2015. The patient has been living in a rural area in Heilongjiang Province for the last 10 years, without travel to other areas. Recently, the patient noticed white tapeworm segments in feces.
O: Brain MRI revealed multiple parietal cysts at the vesicular stage with edema in the frontal, parietal, and occipital white matter. MRI of the orbits showed one well-defined ring-enhancing cystic lesion involving the right superior rectus. X-ray imaging of the chest revealed multiple nodular calcifications. Anticysticercal IgG antibodies by ELISA were positive in serum and CSF. CSF biochemical, cytological, and microbiological examinations showed normal WBCs, normal protein levels (23.52 mg/dL), normal glucose levels in the CSF and blood, and negative bacterial culture.
A: The primary diagnosis is a parasitic infection of the brain and eyes, complicated by the presence of multiple parabolic cysts. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits and systemic infections, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The treatment plan includes systemic oral albendazole and steroid treatment, followed by intravenous dexamethasone and an oral antiepileptic drug. Post-operative management will include monitoring for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension and erosive gastritis, presents with lightheadedness for the past 2 days, abdominal pain, and melena. He reports a mass at the head of his pancreas diagnosed two weeks ago. He has been on prednisone 20 mg twice a day and diltiazem and tramadol. He denies any history of drug or alcohol abuse and has no use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
O: On examination, the patient is afebrile with a blood pressure of 175/39 mm Hg, pulse 140 bpm, and respiratory rate 18. Physical examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds, soft abdomen without guarding or rigidity, significant epigastric tenderness, no splenomegaly, negative Castell sign, and tympanic Traub Space percussion. Melena is present on rectal examination. Complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 46,000/mL, hemoglobin of 9.2 mg/dL, platelets of 96,500/mL. Metabolic panel reveals creatinine of 1.8 mg/L, AST of 40 U/L (normal range: 0.7-1.2 U/dL), ALT of 59 U/l (normal ranges: 0-1 U/mL), total bilirubin of 0.8 U/dl (normal: 0–1 UL), serum glucose of 300 mg/dl, and lipase of 31 U/LD.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatitis (AIP) with associated gastrointestinal bleeding. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The differential diagnosis could include complications related to AIP, steroid therapy, or a gastrointestinal bleed.
P: The management plan includes admission to the hospital for further management and monitoring. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen. Further consultations with gastroenterology and hepatology will be necessary to determine the best course of treatment for AIP and gastrointestinal bleed, with emphasis on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports a history of total nephrectomy for RCC 10 years ago, now experiencing back pain. The patient also has ankle clonus in both ankles.
O: Physical examination was within normal limits except for the ankle clonal. MRI and CT scans revealed spinal metastases involving the T1-T3 vertebrae, pathological fracture of T2 causing spinal cord compression, and metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC) in the right adrenal gland, sternum, left clavicle, and sacrum. CT-guided biopsy of the T2 vertebral lesion confirmed metastatic RCC. Pathology confirmed metastases in the T3 vertebral region, with a Spine Instability Neoplastic Score of 16 indicating instability.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic rheumatoid arthritis (rheumatoma) of the spine, with differential diagnoses including other forms of rheumatic arthritis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of metastatic disease.
P: The management plan includes initiation of zoledronic acid 4 mg/month for treatment and a TES with reconstruction using cryo-treated tumor-bearing bone graft. The surgery will involve resection of the first, second, and third ribs, and removal of the posterior elements of the cervical spine via pediculotomy using a flexible multifilament thread wire saw. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications, and regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old obese woman, gravida five, para 3104, with a history of preterm contractions and preeclampsia. She presents with persistent pelvic pain and a fever of 103.1 F since delivering her baby girl four days ago. She reports fever and chills.
O: Physical examination revealed foul-smelling lochia. Laboratory tests showed elevated white blood cell count and anemia. Pelvic x-ray showed diastases of the pubic symphysis measuring 3.75 cm. MRI of the pelvis and lumbar spine showed no pelvic abscess or hematoma. Blood cultures identified Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) and Proteus mirabilis, susceptible to ampicillin, cefazolin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, levofloxacins, and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, but resistant to nitrofurantoin. Chest CT indicated bilateral patchy opacities.
A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis secondary to endometritis, likely secondary to the infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying infection.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely. Initiate intravenous antibiotics for sepsitis and clindamycin. Maintain current antibiotic regimen and monitor for any signs of infection. Educate the patient on the importance of rest and adherence to the prescribed medication regimen. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 28-year-old right-handed female presenting with a history of severe depressive episodes starting 10 years ago, accompanied by panic attacks. She reports alternating phases of depression and sporadic episodes of elation, which have worsened during autumn or winter. She also mentions low consumption of alcohol in social circumstances and sporadic use of cannabis during adolescence. She has been experiencing binging behaviors since her first diagnosis of Bipolar Disorder-II.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests confirm Binge Eating Disorder (MADRS) and HAMD (HAMD). The patient's depressive symptoms are severe according to MADRS. Current medications include clomipramine (150 mg daily) and pregabalin (225 mg daily).
A: The primary diagnosis is Bipolar Depression-II, complicated by the patient's history of binge eating, which has been exacerbated by her current medication regimen. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of depressive symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to the current medications and the management of her current depressive symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the patient’s depressive symptoms and adjust the medication regimen as necessary. Maintain current medications as prescribed. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the current medication and adjust as necessary based on ongoing assessments. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and the potential side effects of medication changes.

S: The patient is an 81-year-old male who reports bilateral groin and thigh pain following an accidental fall from a height of 5 meters. He has a history of Vancouver type-B2 periprosthetic femoral fracture.
O: Clinical examination revealed an inability to actively move legs and pain on passive movement. Radiographic studies revealed a bilateral fracture of the femoral shaft and a bilateral Robert Mathys (RM®) cementless total hip arthroplasty. Bone lesions were classified as Vancouver type B2. The patient's BMI is 33 kg/m2, indicating comorbidities. The right hip showed a RM® cementless arthropeplasty, followed by anteroposterior radiographs showing a RM¥ cementless complete hip arthioprosthetic fracture. The left hip showed an RM® and a RM' cementless partial hip arthropplasty with 21-years follow-up.
A: The primary diagnosis is a Vancouver type b2 peripoprosthetic hip fracture, complicated by a biological process of acetabular polyethylene wear, instability of the Femoral stem with broken femoral screws, and Paprosky type II femoral osteolysis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of hip fractures or fractures, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's mobility and adherence to the rehabilitation program. The plan includes regular follow-ups to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of compliance with the rehabilitation plan and the importance for compliance with treatment will be provided. Referral to an orthopedic specialist for specialized care and rehabilitation support will be arranged.

S: The patient reports a foreign body in the left eye for approximately 8 months, retained since a gunshot injury. The patient experienced a small wound on the left eyelid but normal eye movement, a normal visual field, and no pain. Recently, the patient developed pain in their left eye but no sinonasal symptoms.
O: Physical examination revealed no restricted left orbit movements, normal visual acuity (20/20), and no signs of proptosis or chemosis. CT scan of the left orbit revealed a round-shaped metallic foreign body and lateral attachment of the posterior ethmoid sinus measuring 6 mm. A transnasal endoscopic approach with navigator assistance was used to remove the foreign body.
A: The primary diagnosis is a retained foreign body with associated complications including orbital foreign body retention. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of orbital foreign bodies, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of signs of infection or other complications.
P: The management plan included surgical removal of the foreign foreign body using an endoscopic transnal approach. Post-procedure, the bullet was surgically excised and delivered to the patient's left nostril using probes and curetted. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the effectiveness of the procedure and manage any potential complications. Education on the importance of follow-up care and the importance for compliance with the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient, a 68-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease diagnosed in 2009, reports a 10-year history of cognitive symptoms, including concentration and memory deficits. He has been active in his community, participating in Bridge games, and has noticed subjective benefits in his concentration, reasoning, decision making, and memory. The patient has been playing Bridge for almost 10 years.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests revealed no significant changes in the patient's cognitive function since diagnosis. No new symptoms were noted during the consultation.
A: The primary diagnosis is Parkinson's Disease, with a differential diagnosis of Hoehn and Yahr Stage III. The prognosis depends on the management of the cognitive challenges and compliance with the prescribed therapies.
P: Continue playing Bridge games to maintain cognitive function. Regular monitoring of symptoms and cognitive function is essential. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in their condition. Encouragement the patient and his spouse to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient, admitted for a fever persisting for 20 days, reports persistent symptoms of a fever that does not go away.
O: A CT scan revealed signs of a pulmonary infection and cytopenia in the peripheral blood. Hemoglobin levels were low at 74.0 g/L (normal range: 0.8-1.2 g/dL), and ferritin levels were elevated at 3602.5 g/l (normal: <0.1 g/dl). Anti-inflammatory antibodies were negative. Bone marrow aspiration confirmed hemophagocytosis. Laboratory tests showed low activity of NK cells (30% of the low limit of healthy controls), and bone marrow aspiration indicated hemophagyocytotic activity.
A: The primary diagnosis is HLH-2004, likely due to Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) or CMV infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of HLH, but these are less likely given the specific findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and immunocompromised state. A targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel will be performed to explore the genetic cause of the condition. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism, presents with increasing diplopia and nausea persisting for six days, and a significant weight loss of 10 pounds over the last two weeks.
O: Physical examination revealed bony tenderness localized to the ribs and right CN VI palsy, causing impaired right eye abduction. The remainder of the exam was unremarkable. Hemogram with differential showed a white count of 10,700 k/µL, elevated absolute neutrophil count at 7.5 k/^L, and normal absolute lymphocyte count at 2.42 k/ µL. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum Ca2+ at 15.8 mg/dL, ionized Ca2+, elevated glucose level at 7,7 mg/dl, and elevated parathyroid hormone at <10 pg/mL. Urine analysis and urine protein electrophoresis were unremarkable, with no evidence of Bence-Jones protein. Total protein was 6.8 g/dL and serum globulin was 2.8 G/dL. Albumin/gamma globulin ratio was 4.0. Serum immunoglobulin levels were faint at 1150 mg/L, IgG at 1160 mg/l, IgA at 200 mg/mL, and IgM at 41.
A: The primary diagnosis is type 2 Diabetes mellitus with associated complications including impaired right CNVI palsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of diabetic insufficiency, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or progression of symptoms. The patient is advised to continue medication adherence and monitor for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Further consultations with a hematologist may be necessary to further evaluate the cause of the symptoms and the patient’s condition.

S: The patient reports using "lian-serpent" for detoxification of the liver. He consumed a piece of T. crispa stem twice over two days, with a two-week gap in between. He experienced a fever, weakness, and dark urine, leading to emergency hospital admission.
O: Upon admission, the patient was found to have acute hepatitis with cholestasis and cytolysis, jaundice, and normal vital signs. Laboratory tests showed hepatocellular damage with ALT at 1923 U/L, AST at 873 U/l, and γGT at 155 U/dL. Abdominal ultrasonography showed no hepatomegaly or lithiasis. Laboratory testing for viral hepatitis was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute hepatitis secondary to the herbal remedy, likely exacerbated by the patient's use of the remedy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of the herbal treatment and close monitoring of liver function tests. The patient is advised to avoid consuming any more of the traditional herbal remedy and consult a healthcare professional before trying any alternative treatments. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor liver function and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports severe pain and deformity in the left arm, forearm, and wrist following a waterslide accident at an amusement park. The patient describes the injury as extremely painful and described the pain as "horrifying."
O: Physical examination revealed closed and soft compartments in the arm and forearm compartments, with neurovascular integrity. Radiographs showed a left distal third humeral shaft fracture and a left Galeazzi fracture, with a midshaft radius fracture and disruption of the distal radioulnar joint. A well-padded long arm posterior plaster splint was placed from the posterior shoulder to the fingers, with an additional coaptation component for stabilization. Post-operative care included open reduction and internal fixation of both humeral and radial shaft fractures, followed by removal of both and fixation with an extraarticular locking plate.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right humeral fracture with associated complications including a midright quadrant fracture, a midhand radius fracture, and a distal radius fracture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb deformities and fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and healing process, with appropriate follow-up care to ensure proper healing and prevent further complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care is crucial. Referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of potential complications is recommended.

S: The patient, an 81-year-old woman with a diagnosis of solid tubular carcinoma, reports experiencing a lump in her breast and feeling tired and weak. She has a history of similar symptoms, which led to her diagnosis.
O: Vital signs and lab results were not provided in the dialogue. Laboratory tests including voltage at 29 kV, tube current at 48 mm, and thickness at 41 mm were performed. The AGD was 1.29, and 15 projections were used to visualize the carcinoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is solid tubuloblastoma, with differential diagnoses including tubular and solid tumors. The prognosis depends on the stage of the cancer and the patient's overall health.
P: The management plan will involve careful evaluation of the tumor's size and location. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment as soon as possible to discuss treatment options and formulate a treatment plan. She is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including eating well, staying active, and getting enough rest. She will also be encouraged to join a support group or speak with a counselor to help cope with emotional aspects of cancer treatment.

S: The patient reports experiencing right upper pain and a palpable mass in the right upper abdomen, accompanied by a slight tenderness and a semimobile mass. The patient has no significant medical or surgical history and is otherwise normal.
O: Physical examination revealed slight abdominal tenderness, a semimusobile mass, and no persistent weak abdominal pain and mass. Abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a 130 × 100 × 90 mm huge cystic mass in a right upper peritoneal cavity, with a thickened wall and many enhanced nodules. Gadolinium MRI confirmed intra-cystic fluid with a connection to the pancreatic head, suggesting a pancreatic origin. Post-operative findings included a hemorrhagic cyst.
A: The primary diagnosis is a pancreatiacoduodenectomy due to a pancreatal tumor originating from the pancreas, with differential diagnoses including MCN, mucinous cystic adenocarcinoma, and hemorrhagic ovarian tumor. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan included a partial pancreatectomy to resect the tumor, which was performed. Postoperative recovery was good, and the patient was discharged on post-operative day 9. The plan includes regular monitoring of recovery and any new symptoms or concerns. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are planned to assess the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing sharp pain and claudication in the left lower limb since 2008, which has persisted despite surveillance in the private sector. The patient was initially referred to the Family Medical Unit and later to the Emergency Unit for Traumatology and Orthopedics, where a bone biopsy and curettage were performed. In 2013, osteolysis of the left iliac bone was noted, leading to a referral to the UMAE at Pediatrics Hospital National Medical Center.
O: Initial imaging in 2013 showed an aneurysmal bone cyst, which was later ruled out by imaging and radiographic studies. Post-treatment, the patient experienced improvement in symptoms, with a new biopsy in June 2014 showing necrosis and reabsorption of spongy bone tissue and vascularized fibrous connective tissue with osteoclastic giant cells. A second biopsy was performed in 2014, using lyophilized cadaveric tricortical bone grafts.
A: The primary diagnosis is an anorexia with associated osteolytic lesions, likely a malignant process. Differential diagnoses initially included infectious or inflammatory bone disease, which were ruled out based on imaging and histopathological findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the recent improvement in pain and symptom resolution.
P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and manage any new symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in symptoms promptly. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a rheumatologist if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old South Asian male presenting with a 14-day history of high-grade fever, malaise, and anorexia, accompanied by a significant weight loss of 10 pounds. He reports no recent medications, contact with sick people, or travel.
O: Vital signs show a blood pressure of 110 bpm, resting sinus tachycardia of 110 beats per minute, and pulse oximetry of 98% on room air. Mild pyrexia is noted at 38.8°C. Physical examination reveals bilateral conjunctivitis with chemosis, strawberry tongue glossitis, palmar desquamation, and ichthyosis, with no lymphadenopathy or dermatologic manifestations such as rash. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis and notable thrombocyticosis, while the comprehensive metabolic panel is normal. Elevated inflammatory markers including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are noted. Immunological panel tests for vasculitides, rheumatological diseases, lupus, rhemumatoid arthritis, or Sjogren's syndrome are negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is incomplete presentation of Kawasaki disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and anemia, but these are less likely given the negative infectious disease diagnostic workup. The absence of recent therapeutic or complementary alternative agents suggests an incomplete presentation.
P: Initiate high-dose enteric-coated aspirin as a treatment for Kawasaki. Monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects.

S: The patient, admitted to another hospital, presented with edema in both lower extremities, abdominal fullness, and shortness of breath upon exertion. The patient reported swelling in the legs, stomach full, and difficulty catching breath upon exercise. The condition was initially diagnosed with Chronic Myeloid Lupus (CML), which was later treated with dasatinib. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the condition and the patient's history of chronic conditions.
O: Physical examination revealed a giant splenomegaly in the pelvic cavity and hepatomegalia. Blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count of 480,000/μL. Bone marrow examination confirmed CML with a proteinuria of 8.93 g/g creatinine and a low serum albumin level of 2.3 g/dL. Laboratory tests showed a blood pressure of 121/70 mmHg, pulse 56/min, temperature 36.5°C, respiratory rate 16/min. Complete blood count showed white blood cells at 11,500/μl, hemoglobin at 13.2 mg/dL, platelet count at 132,000-μL, and serum creatininine at 0.87 mg/L (estimated glomerular filtration rate 78.4 mL/min/1.73m2). Serology tests showed serum creatine 0.88 mg/dl (estimate glomerulonephritis rate 78,4 g/min-1.74m2), albumin 3.08 g/dl, total cholesterol 287 mg/mL, and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol 166 mg/l.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic myeloid lupus, complicated by nephrotic syndrome and the presence of a giant spleen. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myelodysplastic syndrome, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and his condition with regular follow-ups. The management of his chronic conditions will focus on managing his condition effectively and addressing any new or worsening symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of reporting new symptoms and adherence to the treatment regimen will be reinforced. Referral to a nephrologist for specialized care and a hematologist for further evaluation of his condition is recommended.

S: The patient reports severe pain, swelling, redness, and mucopurulent discharge in the right eye. The patient has a history of HIV and HCV positive for 11 years and habitual marijuana smoking.
O: Clinical examination revealed severe nonreducible exophthalmos with dislocation of the eye, eyelid chemosis, and decreased vision in the left eye. MRI findings included an intraorbital mass, inhomogeneously hypointense on T2-weighted images, and hypointe on T1. Histology from the H&E stain of the orbital mass showed monomorphic proliferation of plasmablastic cells suggestive of a thrombocytopenia.
A: The primary diagnosis is thromboembolic thrombus (THS) with involvement of the orbit and the brain. Differential diagnoses include neoplastic diseases, infections, and mycotic origin, such as aspergillosis. The prognosis was poor, leading to the patient's death within a week of diagnosis.
P: The management plan included surgical resection of the tumor, followed by biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment options included chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and possibly targeted therapy based on histology results. The family was informed about the patient and the condition, and the patient was informed of the death and the importance of follow-up.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling and facial asymmetry on the left side of the face since age 13. The patient has a history of craniofacial monostotic disease (FD) diagnosed at age 13, treated with general anesthesia at age 18. At age 20, the patient noticed a swelling on the mid face region, suggesting a lesion was growing back.
O: Clinical extra-oral examination revealed significant facial asymmetral asymmetry. CT scan revealed a dysplastic dense mass affecting the maxillary and zygomatic bones, with a canting of 5.5 mm downwards. Preoperative cephalometric analysis indicated a canted canting at 5.0 mm. A Le Fort I osteotomy was performed at age 20 to correct the occlusal canting. The mandibular sagittal split ramus osteotomy (BSSRO) was performed to correct compensatory mandibulvic occlusion.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe maxillary occlus canting with a gummy smile and a symmetrical mandibulocele. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial asymmetricness such as malignancy or malignant bone disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes continued presurgical orthodontic treatment for 14 months, continuation of presurgical treatment, and close monitoring of the patient's condition. Postoperative care will include regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient reports feeling fine and has no symptoms in the left mandible area. The patient has a history of uneventful medical and dental history.
O: Initial examination revealed unremarkable findings and no paresthesia. Intraoral examination showed no redness or tenderness in the right mandibular mucosa. Panoramic radiography showed an extensive multilocular radiolucent area with imprecise borders and a "soap bubble appearance." CT scan identified an approximately 39 × 19 × 11 mm odontogenic tumor extending to the roots of four teeth (#33 - 36). An incisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of odontogenogenic myxoma. Postoperative follow-up included monthly clinical examinations for the first year, then every two months during the second year, and panoramic X-rays and CT imaging for eight years.
A: The primary diagnosis is odontogenesis of the mandible, based on histopathological findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnosis initially included benign spindle-shaped cells in a myxoid fibrous stroma. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan included conservative surgical intervention with endodontic treatment of teeth #33 – 36, followed by conservative surgical resection of the second premolar and total enucleation. Post-operative care included regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's progress and ensure ongoing well-being. Regular monitoring of vital signs and physical activity was essential. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: The patient is a 21-year-old Mexican mestizo woman with a family history of SLE. She reports a history of malar rash, fever, anemia, fatigue, malaise, and constant disease flares throughout her childhood. She also has a history with septic monoarthritis in her right knee, treated with surgical drainage and antibiotics. She has had seizures starting at 8 years old, characterized by a visceral aura, fixed gaze, altered consciousness, oral and buccal automatisms, somnolence, and amnesia of the event at the postictal phase. At age 19, she developed generalized fatigue, localized pain, hyperthermia, pruritus, and hyperemia of the right lower extremity. She was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis with a Doppler ultrasound extending from the right popliteal vein to the right femoral vein.
O: Physical examination revealed a low hemoglobin level of 4.83 g/dL, a reticulocyte count of 5.6%, and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 54.6 fL. She tested positive for the lupus anticoagulant test, leading to secondary APS and microcytic hypochromic anemia. She is currently on hydroxychloroquine, prednisone, azathioprine, warfarin, calcium, and vitamin D supplements.
A: The primary diagnosis is secondary acute myeloid leukemia (APS) with complications including secondary microcytoxemia (MSH) and microcephaly. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myelitis and hemolytic anemia secondary to SLE, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Continue current medications and monitor her condition closely. Schedule regular follow-ups with her healthcare team to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in her condition. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of her underlying conditions.

S: The patient reports a sore on the right foot that is not healing. He has a history of trauma to the foot two to three weeks ago and a new pair of shoes due to neuropathy. The wound has not healed. The patient has been wearing the same shoes for the past two weeks without improvement. He denies any fever chills, fever, or drainage from the wound. He is upset about the new shoes and expresses concern about the condition.
O: Physical examination reveals a one by two inch circular wound proximal to the right fifth to the fifth mtp joint, with minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no necrosis, and no odor. Vascular exam shows palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses without palpable dp or pt pulses. Right foot x-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right foot wound with complications including a diabetic foot ulcer. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of foot pain such as infection or infection. The prognosis depends on the extent of the wound and the management of the infection.
P: Order an ankle brachial index abi to determine the blood supply to heal the foot. Perform a debridement of the left foot to prevent further infection. Educate the patient on the importance of wound care and the signs of infection to watch for. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 2 weeks or sooner if no improvement is observed.

S: The patient reports a three-month history of right-sided neck swelling, which has been progressively enlarging. The patient has a history of painless swelling on the scalp for 20 years but has not experienced other unusual lumps or swellings.
O: Physical examination revealed a firm, fixed, non-tender mass on the right side of the neck at level II, measuring 3 x 3 cm, with a soft, mobile, and 4 x 4 cm scalp lump. An excisional biopsy of the right nodal mass suggested hidradenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining showed positivity for cytokeratin 7, epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), and p63. Panendoscopy showed no abnormalities in the pharynx, nasal cavity, or larynx. CT scan of the head and neck showed multiple enlarged lymph nodes, a well-defined lobulated cystic mass, and negative CT scans of the chest and abdomen. Histopathology confirmed malignant tumor with a size of 4.2 x 3.5 x 2.2 cm.
A: The primary diagnosis is malignant hidradenginoma of the scalp, with differential diagnoses including other forms of lymphoma or malignancies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful removal of the tumor and absence of distant metastasis.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and potential recurrence. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor's progression and detect any recurrence of the disease. The management team will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health status.

S: The patient reports swelling below the tongue and pain during meals.
O: Physical examination revealed a hard swelling on the left submandibular gland duct. An occlusal radiograph confirmed radio-opacity medial to teeth 46 and 47. Radiograph confirmed left submolar salivary gland duct sialolithiasis.
A: The primary diagnosis is left submalibular salivar gland duct Sialolithi, a stone in the salivaries duct. The patient underwent a minor surgical procedure to remove the stone, which was successfully removed.
P: The management plan included placing a stay suture to prevent the stone from gliding posteriorly, and making an incision over the stone to expose the calculi. Post-procedure, the stone was approximately oval and measured 10.4 mm, suturing the duct at the level of the mucosa on the floor of the mouth. Follow-up evaluations were scheduled to ensure no postoperative complications were noted. The assistant scheduled an appointment for the patient to contact the office if any discomfort or issues arise.

S: 
- Patient reports a history of type 2 diabetes, currently at 6.7 mg/dL.

O:  

A: - Patient has been on 10 mg/L of melatonin.
 
 - Previous visit to the emergency room was last week with a 1.5 mg/dl dose.
- Current medications: Percocet, Percovit, and Medication.
 - Current medications are on 5 hundred mg daily.

S: The patient, referred to the AIDS Clinical Center at the National Center for Global Health and Medicine in Tokyo, reports protracted dyspnea on effort, or DOE, following pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) treatment. The patient has a history of HIV-1 infection confirmed by western blotting.
O: Physical examination revealed Velcro rales in the bilateral lower back. Laboratory tests showed a cluster of differentiation-4 counts of 45/μL (7.3%), HIV-RNA loads of 56,000 copies/mL, and elevated β-D glucan levels at more than 300 pg/mL. Bronchoscopy identified Pneumocysts jirovecii in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, with elevated beta-D glucose levels (450 pg/dL). Physical examination showed "Velcro Rales" in the lower back upon auscultation. Arterial blood oxygen pressure was within normal limits at rest (93.5 mmHg), but it decreased rapidly to 44.5 mg/mL after 30 seconds of slow walking. Respiratory function tests showed severe restrictive ventilator impairment with a vital capacity of 36.5%, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (107.4%). Chest CT showed severe fibrotic changes at the bilateral basal parts and diffuse fibrosis changes.
A: The primary diagnosis is HIV-related PCP with complications including pulmonary fibrosis, respiratory failure, and respiratory failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of COPD, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the pulmonary condition.
P: Continue current regimen of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) with corticosteroids. Monitor respiratory function closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and ensure understanding of the patient's condition. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust treatment as needed. Consider consultation with a pulmonary specialist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports experiencing left hemiparesis and dysarthria for approximately 5 hours. The patient has a history of hypertension.
O: NIHSS score is 3, indicating a minor stroke. PCT scan shows a perfusion delay in the right MCA territory, severe stenosis in the superior portion of the right minor branch, and moderate stenosis. The average right cerebral rSO2 is 69.01% and 71.28%, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is a minor cerebral artery blockage, likely secondary to hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral artery stenosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes administration of Endovascular Therapy (EVT) to restore blood flow to the affected area. The treatment will involve monitoring the patient's response to the treatment and adjusting the treatment as necessary. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient reports a mass in the back region, which has been growing progressively, with multiple drainage attempts for a suspected abscess but no relief. The patient has a history of non-oncological surgical resection and bilateral vision loss for the past month, which was noted during clinical examination.
O: Initial clinical examination revealed normal vital signs but disorientation with regard to space and time, poor communication with the examiner, and a hyperpigmented tumor measuring 10 x 8 cm, with a scarred postsurgical lesion without inflammatory signs. Biopsy confirmed high-grade sarcoma compatible with myxofibrosarcoma. Abdominal CT scan showed diffuse density alteration of subcutaneous cellular tissue without lesions. Chest CT scan with contrast showed an undefined heterogeneous mass dependent on soft tissues in the posterior thorax wall, with infiltration signs in the muscular plane, and density alteration in the subcutaneously cellular tissue and skin.
A: The primary diagnosis is high grade sarcomas with complications including myx ofibros sarcomacism, myxosofibrosis, and bilateral retinal detachment. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of sarcomatic tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive care for symptoms such as consciousness deterioration, and oral cavity bleeding. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to assess the progression of the tumor and response to chemotherapy. The family will be provided with support and counseling to address any concerns or concerns during the treatment process.

S: The patient, admitted for anemia and thrombocytopenia, presented with a 3-week history of a febrile erythematous rash, fever, fatigue, vomiting, and non-bloody diarrhea. The patient has no family history of kidney or hematological disorders.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be pale, with bruises on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Laboratory findings included hemolytic anemia with marked reticulocytosis, schistocytes, profound thromboembolic thrombus, and elevated uric acid. Serum creatinine levels were normal. Plasma haptoglobin was undetectable, LDH was elevated, and the direct Coombs test was negative. Anti-streptolysin titers were marginally elevated. D-dimers were increased to 2.49 μg/mL fibrinogen-equivalent units with a normal range of 0.02–0.47 μg/L. Prothrombin, INR, partial thrombulboplastin time, fibrinal, and C3 and C4 concentrations were normal, but sC5b-9 was increased to 653 ng/mL. Urinalysis revealed microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria. Hemoglobin (Hb) dropped to 48 g/L, and platelet count dropped to 5 × 10^9/L within 2 days. Eculizumab was administered approximately 900 mg/m2 2 days post-admission.
A: The primary diagnosis is atypical hemolysis uremic syndrome (aHUS), based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of hemoglobin levels, platelet counts, and renal function. A multidisciplinary team consultation will be necessary to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and importance of follow-up will be provided. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of aHUS is recommended.

S: The patient, a 61-year-old male on steroid therapy, reports a gradual decline in renal function and renovascular hypertension, which has been a complication of TA. He has been on peritoneal dialysis (PD) for over 5 years, with well-preserved residual renal function, only one episode of peritonitis, and no signs of other inflammatory diseases including malignancies, infections, or autoimmune diseases including TA reactivation.
O: Recent labs show a low C-reactive protein (CRP) level, indicating inflammation. The patient has undergone a living-related kidney transplant (KTx) seven years post-transplant. Immunological profile of the KTx is ABO incompatible (from B+ to O+), with six HLA mismatches, negative complement-dependent cytotoxicity, negative flow cytometric lymphocyte crossmatch test, and positive donor-specific antibodies (DSA) against HLA-DQ4 with a mean fluorescence intensity of 3683.
A: The primary diagnosis is renal failure secondary to PD reactivation, with differential diagnoses including malnutrition, inflammation, and MIA syndrome. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the progression of renal function decline and the absence of any significant complications from PD.
P: The management plan includes transitioning to hemodialysis or combination therapy with PD to manage TA reactivation. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and regular monitoring for any new symptoms or changes in condition will be provided.

S: The patient reports severe right lower abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient denies any history of abdominal surgery or trauma.
O: Physical examination revealed deep tenderness at McBurney's point without abdominal distension. Blood tests showed slight leukocytosis (9840/μl) with no elevation of the C-reactive protein level (0.01 mg/dl). Enhanced CT scan showed a slightly enhanced, thickened appendiceal wall, a slightly dilated ileum, and ascites at the recto-vesical pouch. Laparoscopic surgery identified strangulated small bowel obstruction caused by trapping of ileal bowel loops by a band. No ischemic changes were detected in the trapped ileums. The appendix showed slight inflammatory changes.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild acute appendicitis with complications including strangulated bowel obstruction and a band-related obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these were ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's pain and symptoms, with follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any potential complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial.
