The mother reported noticing a tooth on her lower left gum and an ulcer under her tongue that sometimes bleeds. The patient has tried alternative methods of breastfeeding, including infant formula milk.
O: Physical examination revealed a normal, lactating breast with no inflammation, engorgement, mild eczema, or palpable cervical and axillary lymph nodes. A neonatal tooth was found over the left anterior region of the mandibular ridge, measuring 2 mm × 1 mm in size, whitish opaque, Grade II mobility, and a whitish ulcer over the ventral aspect of the tongue measuring 1 mm × 0 mm. No infection was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is Riga-Fede disease causing difficulty in breastfeeding. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nipple pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to the pediatric dental surgery department for the extraction of the tooth. The tooth will be extracted under local anesthesia, with the tooth having a crown but lacking a root. Post-extraction, the wound will heal well within 2 days, and the patient will resume breastfeeding successfully. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the healing of the wound and ensure no complications arise from the extraction.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma diagnosed in October 2015. He reports moderate weight loss, pain in the right hypochondrium, loss of appetite, and asthenia. He underwent four courses of chemotherapy, including two courses of Gemcitabine and one course of Cisplatin, which were ineffective. The patient's Karnofsky scale index was 70% initially.
O: Initial treatment included chemotherapy with two courses and two courses. MRI revealed metastatic nodules in both the left and right lobes, with a significant increase in tumor size and tumor aggressiveness. Serum gamma glutamyltranspeptidase (GGT) level was significantly elevated at 60%, leading to switch to TKI inhibitors. Genetic analysis revealed gene expression in a formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) biopsy sample. Total RNA extracted using Ambion's RecoverAll™ Total Nucleic Acid Isolation and Sigma for reverse transcription and library amplification. Hybridization was conducted according to CustomArray ElectraSense Hybridization and Detection protocol.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated interstitial lung cancer (IUCK) with metastatic lung cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lung cancer, given the aggressive nature of the tumor and the high tumor size. The prognosis is poor, and the patient's aggressive nature is likely contributing to the tumor's metastatic nature.
P: The management plan includes switching to a TKI inhibitor based on the results of the biopsy. A multidisciplinary team discussion will be conducted to explore potential treatment options for the tumor, including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy based on genetic findings. Patient education regarding the nature of his disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management of the disease is recommended.

S: The patient reports worsening back pain for one week, accompanied by tingling and numbness in the lower limbs and difficulty walking. The patient also experiences decreased sensation on the upper back.
O: Physical examination revealed moderate muscle weakness in the upper limbs and superficial hypesthesia below the T5 level, suggestive of dorsal cord disorder. Laboratory tests and plain radiography showed no abnormalities. MRI revealed a dorsally located epidural lesion between the Th5 and Th8 vertebrae, isointense on T1 and slightly hyperintense on the T2-weighted imaging, suggesting an epidural hematoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is an epidurally located, heterogeneous epidural tumor, likely a spinal angiolipoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal numbness and limb weakness, but these are less likely given the MRI findings and imaging characteristics.
P: The management plan includes an emergent surgical excision of the epidural lesions. Postoperative management will include close monitoring of the patient's neurological status, pain management, and recovery from surgery. Postoperatively, the patient will be monitored for recurrence and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Follow-up examinations will be scheduled to monitor the recovery and ensure no recurrence.

S: The patient reports experiencing unusual pain in the left carotid area for the past 24 hours, radiating to the ear.
O: Initial Colour Doppler ultrasound revealed eccentric hypoechoic thickening in the proximal bulbar internal carotin area and partially in the carotids bifurcation, with thin hyperechoic atheromatous fibrous plaque and no significant stenosis. Contrast-enhanced ultrasound showed normal capillary distribution of microbubbles in the hypoechic thickened area, with avascular fibrous plaques also demonstrated. Unenhanced Axial T1-weighted MR imaging showed hypointense tissue around the proximally internal carotaid, with intense enhancement of the tissue on fat-saturated contrast.
A: The primary diagnosis is Carotidynia or TIPIC syndrome. The patient's symptoms and the perivascular inflammatory sheath are managed effectively with non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs.
P: The management plan includes treatment with nonsteroid drugs to manage inflammation and pain. The treatment plan will include continued monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment and potential side effects. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of low spirit, bad mood, suicide behaviors, and suspicion prior to hospitalization, presents with a 4-week history of feeling down, thoughts of suicide, and suspicious behavior. The patient has been on sertraline and olanzapine for severe depression, which did not alleviate symptoms.
O: Initial CSF pressure was 240 cmH2O, leukocyte count was 10 × 10^9/L, anti-NMDAR antibodies were elevated at 1:32, and EEG showed epileptic activity with sharp-slow waves in the right anterior frontotemporal region. B-ultrasound and CT scan of the chest and abdomen were normal. Treatment included intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG; 25 g/day, 5 days), methylprednisolone (1,000 mg, 3 days + 500 mg/3 days), and prednisole (0–60 mg, 12 weeks). The patient developed severe heart and respiratory failure, visual hallucinations, auditory hallucination, and delusion.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe depression with associated psychiatric symptoms including severe heart failure, psychotic symptoms, and psychotic symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's psychiatric symptoms and the potential for complications.
P: Initiated treatment with IVIG and methylpredisolone, followed by levetiracetam and valproic acid (500 mg, bid) to manage symptoms of psychotic symptoms and hallucinations. Initiated on clonazepam (2 mg/h, 45 days) for clinical improvement. Subsequent treatment with quetiapine (50 mg/day) and aripiprazole was discontinued due to severe psychiatric symptoms. Close monitoring of psychiatric status and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment regimen was provided.

S: The patient, with a history of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), treated for prostate cancer with external beam radiation therapy, reports experiencing weakness and tiredness, and enlargement of the right testicle.
O: Clinical examination revealed hypercalcaemia. Serum biochemistry showed hypercalcemia. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed a large right-sided scrotal mass with soft tissue extending through the inguinal canal and along the right gonadal vein to the insertion point into the inferior vena cava, with bilateral lung nodules up to 14mm. Ultrasound-guided biopsy of the testicular lesion confirmed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype. Histology confirmed the diagnosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse large biliary cholangioma (BCHL) with associated lymphoma. Differential diagnosis initially included sarcoma or lymphoma but was ruled out based on imaging and histology. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the complete response to chemotherapy.
P: The management plan includes chemotherapy to treat BCHL, with close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and ensure no recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, admitted to the emergency department with a 12-hour duration history of abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting, reports no similar attacks before.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be dehydrated and afebrile, with a pulse of 98 per minute and blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg. Abdominal X-ray revealed multiple fluid levels without free air. An abdominal and pelvic CT scan with intravenous contrast identified a small bowel obstruction (SBO) with a transitional zone in the right lower abdomen, a saclike mass of clustered dilated bowel loops descending downward into the prevesical space, compressing the anterolateral wall of the bladder. Radiological findings suggested an internal hernia. A laparoscopic approach was performed, using a 12mm trocar at the navel and two 5mm trocars at bilateral abdominal flank.
A: The primary diagnosis is an obstructive supravesical hernia involving the terminal ileum. Differential diagnosis initially included a hernia, which was ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis was cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan included the use of a laparoscopy to confirm the diagnosis and repair the hernia using a three trocars technique. The patient underwent a successful surgical repair of the inguinal hernia with a direct inguininal herniation. Post-operative recovery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on the fourth post-operative day with a bulging mass and repair of a direct hernia two months later. Further follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old male, asymptomatic and nonsmoker with a BMI of 37.7, presenting with a history of class II obesity. He reports no symptoms related to the right middle lobe nodule.
O: A high-resolution chest CT scan revealed a 1.5 cm mixed ground glass opacity (GGO) with a larger solid component in the right upper lobe (RML). The nodule increased in size at the follow-up CT scan. Subcostal resection was performed using subcostal access. The patient underwent general anesthesia with double lumen endotracheal intubation and lateral decubitus placement at dorsal decubititus 40 degrees. A 5 cm oblique incision was made parallel to the costal arch, dissecting subcutaneous tissue and rectus abdominis, and detached the xiphoid process and pericardiophrenic fatty tissue. A covidien wound protector (WPLGR914) was placed. A thoracoscopic lens with a 30° angle was used to examine the interlobar fissure. A systematic mediastinal lymph nodes dissection was performed, using long and sturdier VATS instruments and curved tip stapler technology. A 28 F chest tube was inserted through the same sublobar wound.
A: The primary diagnosis is right middle lobectomy with complications including a nodule in the middle lobe and a nodular nodule at the RML. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nodule enlargement, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's recovery and follow up on any necessary appointments. Educate the patient on signs of complications and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms or concerns. Consider referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the nodule and nodules. Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports that his vision in the left eye is not as clear as the one in the right eye. He also notes that his intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes.
O: Physical examination revealed a circumscribed lesion measuring 0.6 mm in horizontal basal diameter and 0.5 mm in vertical basal diameter, with a dilated feeding retinal arteriole and a bi-lobulated "butterfly" appearance. Near-infrared reflectance imaging showed intrinsic hyperreflectivity, short-wavelength autofluorescence, and red-free filter photography showed a blocked signal. Fluorescein angiography (FA) showed mild ring-shaped fluorescence in the lesion in the arteriovenous phase without leakage into the late phase. Indocyanine green angiographic showed weak cyanescence on the superior boundary.
A: The primary diagnosis is CSHRPE, a benign condition characterized by a small, pigmented lesion with no macular edema, exudation, hemorrhage, traction, or subretinal fluid. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the eye during routine evaluations. The patient is advised to report any changes in vision or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports persistent left-side chest pain for 2 months and hemoptysis for 1 month. The pain has been persistent and started about a month ago. The patient denies any medical comorbidities or familial history of malignancies.
O: A baseline PET/CT scan revealed two metabolically active soft tissue masses in the left suprahilar region and the left lower lobe, with enlarged prevascular and left hilar lymph nodes, a metastatic lesion of the left fourth rib, and moderate left pleural effusion. Biopsy from the lung mass showed adenocarcinoma positive for ALK gene rearrangement and negative for epidermal growth factor receptor gene mutation. Pleural fluid cytology confirmed metastatic adenoma. Post-treatment imaging showed partial response to palliative radiotherapy, 20 Gy in five fractions over 5 days, and tablet crizotinib 250 mg twice per day.
A: The primary diagnosis is advanced NSCLC stage IV, stage IV. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancer, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the patient's history of smoking and alcohol use.
P: The management plan included palliatively radiotherapy 20 Gy per 5 days and tablet Crizotinab 250 mg once per day, with a liver function test once per week to monitor liver toxicity. The treatment plan included monitoring liver function tests, which were within normal limits. The plan includes continued monitoring of liver function and response to treatment. The management team will continue with regular follow-up appointments to assess response to therapy and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing fever of 38°C, weakness, lumbar pain, and small red spots on the skin. The patient also mentions petechiae.
O: Blood cultures confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection. Blood cultures indicated septic infection. Intravenous catheter extension was noted, with severe petechia and severe bleeding from the insertion points of catheters. Hemofiltration treatment with Cytosorb showed significant improvement. Lactate values and inflammation stabilized with a decrease in PCT to 16.52 ng/ml, and disseminated intravascular coagulopathy improved to demarcating areas.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic-induced neisseria-meningitis infection, complicated by neissery-related complications including neissie-related neissia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of septic infections, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes transfer to the ICU for close monitoring and management of sepsis. The treatment plan includes continuation of norepinephrine infusion and epinephrine infusion. The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and response as needed. The management of hypotension and pleural hypotension is recommended, with an increase in norephrine up to 0.75 μg/kg/min. Continuous monitoring of blood cultures and hemofiltration treatments is necessary. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old primigravida with a history of pregnancy-induced hypertension. She was referred to a tertiary care hospital with a suspicion of a chorioangioma of the placenta or a placental teratoma. She reports no known comorbidities but was diagnosed with pregnancy induced hypertension.
O: Ultrasonography at our institution showed a single intrauterine fetus with normal interval growth and a multiloculated cystic mass with septations and calcifications. Color Doppler examination showed no vascularity. At 36 weeks and five days of gestation, the mass was identified as 104 x 53 mm, originating from the anterior wall of the uterus. A repeat scan in the third trimester showed the same mass, but a second congenitally malformed fetus was delivered, with no cephalic end structures. Histopathological examination showed placental discs measuring up to 19.5 x 14 x 4 cm, placental membrane 30 x 16 cm, with two umbilical cords, gross malformation with absence of the head and upper limbs, partially formed lower limbs, and heel to rump length of 18 inches.
A: The primary diagnosis is placental and placental disorders, with differential diagnoses including placental Teratoma, chorionic placental degeneration, or degenerating fibroid. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the case and the complexity associated with the delivery.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and supportive care. The patient will be educated on the signs of complications and encouraged to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the prognosis and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old multiparous woman, admitted at 37 2/7 weeks for induction of labor due to abnormal antenatal testing. She reports a history of a previous cesarean delivery at 7 cm dilation, during which she experienced moderate vaginal bleeding. She expresses concern about the possibility of uterine rupture or placental abruption.
O: Initial cervical exam showed 2 cm dilated and 50% effacement. An amniotomy was performed at 5 cm with clear fluid. The patient's progression from 2 cm to 5 cm took approximately 10 hours, followed by a 3.5-hour delay to 6 cm. Post-operative findings included a spontaneous detachment of the anterior rim of the cervix from approximately 9 to 3 o'clock, necrotic cervix, and no bleeding noted at the site of cervical detachment. Vaginal exam revealed a spontaneous vaginal detachment from approximately 10 to 3, necrosis of the cervical cervix with no bleeding, and complete detachment of cervix.
A: The primary diagnosis is a spontaneous uterine detachment, likely due to uterine or uterine abnormalities, post-cesareal delivery. Differential diagnoses could include placental abnormalities, but these were ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is stable with ongoing monitoring and supportive care.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and post-operative care. Further consultations with obstetrics and gynecology may be necessary depending on the progression of labor and postoperative recovery. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for specialized care and a gynecologist for ongoing management of placental issues is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing multiple cords in the eye following phacoemulsification and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, Raynaud's syndrome, and B-cell CLL, treated with rituximab and chlorambucil, followed by ibrutinib for 6 months. During the surgery, the lens had 2-3+ nuclear sclerosis without pseudoexfoliation or phacodonesis. A retrobulbar block of 2% lidocaine and 0.75% Marcaine (bupivacaine) was administered preoperatively, and dexamethasone and cefazolin were applied to the ocular surface.
O: Visual presentation shows a 20/100 vision with no signs of hypopyon, hyphema, significant corneal edema, or cellular reaction. Intraocular pressure is 43 mmHg. No hypopyons, hyphemias, or other systemic symptoms are noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is fibrinoid syndrome with complications including nuclear sclerosis and a retrobulbbar block. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual deficits such as optic nerve damage or optic nerve compression, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical history.
P: Initiate topical prednisolone and brimonidine every 2-4 hours, brimonidone three times per day, timolol-dorzolamide two times daily, and orally administered acetazolamide. Continue monitoring intraocular pressure and monitor for any worsening of symptoms. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate care.

S: The patient reports experiencing numbness and weakness in the right leg, which has been progressively worsening. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperthyroidism, and mammary gland hyperplasia, but no diabetes, heart disease, hepatitis, tuberculosis, or drug allergy.
O: Physical examination revealed a decrease in calculation capacity, instability in the nose with the right finger, and instability during tibial experiment with the knee. Laboratory findings showed a leukocyte level of 13.52 × 10^9/L, glucose (2.93 mmol/L), sodium (124 mmol/l), chlorine (87 mmol/dL), and fibroproteinogen (1.62 g/L). CSF examination showed yellow and clear cerebrospinal fluid with a yellow and distinct appearance, total CSF cells of 514/μl, leukocytes 14/μL, high CSF protein (82.54 mg/dl), and increased IgG intrathecal synthesis rate (13.54). Cytomegalovirus IgG was positive, but neuronal antigen spectrum antibody IgG (CSF and blood) were negative. Tumor markers (female) were also negative. Autoimmune antibody tests and protein electrophoresis were conducted.
A: The primary diagnosis is concentric sclerosis, likely exacerbated by a demyelinating disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of leg numbness or weakness. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the disease.

S: The patient reports a disseminated vesicular rash on the trunk and extremities, initially diagnosed as a sequela of infectious mononucleosis, which resolved within 10 days. The patient has a history of Splenomegaly, first noted at 5 years old. The rash was treated with a varicella zoster virus vaccine strain disseminated infection.
O: Physical examination revealed splenomegalia, selective IgA deficiency, and CD4 lymphopenia, with a range of 111-118 cells/μL. Imaging confirmed splenomaly with a 17 cm cranio-caudal length, modest mesenteric and retroperitoneal adenopathy, CD4 at 189 cells/ μL, normal CD8 T cells (383 cells), and an increased proportion of CD3+TCRαβ+CD4−CD8− double negative T cells at 4.3% or 33 cells/µL. Other tests showed high cycling of CD4 T-cells and increased PD-1 expression in CD4 cells. IgG and IgM levels were moderately elevated at 1,716 mg/dL, while IgM was within normal limits at 54 mg/dl.
A: The primary diagnosis is Idiopathic CD4 Lymphopenia (ICL), based on imaging and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lymphopenias, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. Further treatment options may include immunosuppressive therapy (IVT) based on the patient’s immunological status and immunological findings. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects of the treatment will be provided. Referral to a pediatric infectious disease specialist for specialized care and a pediatric endocrinologist for ongoing evaluation and management of infectious disease is recommended.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old girl, presented with sudden loss of consciousness and abdominal pain, accompanied by pallor, cyanosis, loss of muscle tone, and ocular revulsion. The parent reports that the child has been experiencing abdominal pain and short episodes of absence for the past few months, along with a frequent cough and a reduction in exercise tolerance.
O: Physical examination revealed a systolic regurgitant murmur. Lab tests showed slight metabolic acidosis, Troponin T levels at 65 ng/l, elevated liver transaminases (ASAT 82U/l and ALAT 48U/ls), and elevated NT-Pro-BNP levels at 1,024 ng/L (normal range 12–214 ng/ml). Electrocardiogram indicated an incomplete right bundle branch block, right ventricular hypertrophy, slight enlargement of the right ventricle and right atrium, tricuspid regurgitation, elevated systolinesis (SOP) at 45 mmHg, and pulmonary artery dilatation. Echocardiography confirmed partial epileptic seizures. Cerebral MRI showed normal results. Follow-up ECG confirmed dilatations of right cardiac cavities and a tricyclic edema III.
A: The primary diagnosis is secondary pulmonary hypertension and myocardial cell damage due to hypoxemia and acidosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the child's vital signs and cardiac function. Treatment with valproic acid will be adjusted based on the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education regarding the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, prior stress cardiomyopathy with normal coronaries on left heart catheterization, and hypertension, presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sinus tachycardia, premature atrial complexes, biatrial enlargement, right axis deviation, and prolonged QT interval.
O: Upon admission, an EKG revealed sinus Tachycardias with a heart rate of 104 bpm, premature heart rate, biastrial enlargements, right axes deviation, right-sided QT, and atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate of 147 bpm and a prolonged duration of QT. Troponin I level was elevated at 9 ng/ml (normal range 0-0.03 ng/mL). Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% (low normal), and a right ventricle apical thrombus measuring 0.95 x 0.7 cm (normal 0.5-0% range). A transthocardiograph indicated a left-sided ejectional fraction of 56% (normal <0.5 ng/mm), and regional wall motion abnormalities including hypokinetic to akinetic basal myocardial segments, an akinetic apex, and hyperdynamic midventricular segments.
A: The primary diagnosis is reverse midvariant takotsubo cardiacopathy, evidenced by the patient's symptoms and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included administration of IV 5 mg metoprolol and amiodarone 150 mg, administration of amiodare, and administration of heparin drip. The patient was treated with aspirin, atorvastatin, metopol, and apixaban. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on recognizing symptoms of heart failure and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: 77-year-old male with a history of NHL/SLL diagnosed 10 years ago presents with abdominal swelling, altered mental status, and difficulty urinating with blood in it. He reports no recollection of oncologic history and treatment regimens.
O: Physical examination revealed diffuse bulky lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Laboratory workup showed hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. CT scan showed negative findings for acute events. Repeat CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed diffuse bulky, bilateral iliac, inguininal, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathies. Bone marrow biopsy indicated a cluster of differentiation 5 (CD5) and CD23 positive B-cell population, 37% of the lymphoid gate, lambda-restricted, with immunophenotypic expression of CLL/SLS with lambda light chain restriction. Kappa light chain restricted population of monoclonal plasma cells co-expressed with CD56.
A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse bulky Lymphadenopathy (NHL/SSLL) with associated metabolic disturbances. Differential diagnoses could include toxic and metabolic encephalopathy, considering the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the NHL/SSL.
P: The patient will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to discuss treatment adjustments and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any changes or new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with urology and urology will be arranged to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient reports no symptoms related to the discovery of a round tumor in the nasal area. The patient has a history of renal cancer and underwent surgery 5 years ago.
O: Physical examination revealed a 10 mm round tumor located at the posterior end of the nasal septal mucosa. Imaging and regional biopsy under local anesthesia identified an inverted ductal papilloma of the salivary glands, but no definitive diagnosis was made. Plain CT scan revealed a soft tissue shadow tumor approximately 10 mm in size in the vault of the nasopharynx at the junction of the nacopharyngeal septum and roof. MRI showed a similar mass at the same location. PET scan showed no abnormal uptake of 18F-fludeoxyglucose. Surgical excision of the tumor was performed under general anesthesia using an endoscopic endonasal approach. Hematoxylin-eosin staining confirmed a negative tumor margin.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign malignant tumor of the right nasal septic mucosa, with no evidence of malignancy or other systemic involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other malignancies, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and potential recurrence of the malignant cells. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and ensure no recurrence. Patient education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of malignant conditions is recommended.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of bilateral posterior uveitis (CME) treated with nivolumab and Opdivo. He reports a best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 20/70 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye, which improved to 20/30 after 6 months of treatment. He experienced foveal thinning and a full-thickness macular hole (FTMH) which reduced his BCVA to 15/60. He underwent macular holes surgery (MHS) but was unable to wait for spontaneous resolution.
O: Initial OCT showed a closed macularhole with residual subretinal fluid. The patient's BCVA remained stable until three months post-surgery, when the macular opening reopened. Ongoing monitoring of the patient's vision and ophthalmological findings is recommended.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral posterior Uveitis and CME, with differential diagnoses including other causes of visual impairment and macular degeneration. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the stable BCVA and recent improvement in vision.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vision and regular follow-ups with ophthalmology to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Education on recognizing symptoms of worsening vision and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial.

S: The patient, admitted to the Respiratory Diseases Unit, reports experiencing hemoptysis for the past 30 days, accompanied by coughing up blood and feeling very weak. The patient denies any recent episodes of bleeding or chest discomfort.
O: Physical examination revealed severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dl and hemodynamic instability with a shock index of 1.4. Past medical history includes cardiac surgery for aortic coarctation at age 18 without complications. Chest X-ray showed no significant abnormalities. Fiber bronchoscopy showed limited blood in the bronchial tract afferent to the left upper lobe, with no active bleeding. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest revealed an aneurysmal dilatation of the descending thoracic aorta communicating with the right upper bronchus. An upper posterior hemorrhagic leak indicated initial left-upper lobe compression and ground-glass opacities with scissural delimitation. Thoracic endovascular aorti repair (TEVAR) was successfully performed without complications, and the patient made a good recovery in less than 30 days.
A: The primary diagnosis is aortobronchial fistula, complicated by persistent hemodynamics instability and aortophagitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the absence of complications.
P: The management plan includes initiating a strict follow-up plan to monitor the patient's progress and ensure continued recovery. The plan includes referral to the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit for further evaluation and management of hemodynamic issues. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor recovery and detect any new or concerning symptoms. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on patient's response to treatment and any new symptoms.

S: The patient is an 81-year-old Caucasian male with a history of melanoma on the right anterior chest wall, diagnosed four months post-diagnosis. He reports feeling weak and tired lately. He was previously treated with dabrafenib and trametinib, which led to a second cycle of pembrolizumab. Recently, he experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure.
O: Vital signs were not provided. MRI findings revealed multiple metastatic lesions in the brain. Neurological examination revealed a strength of 2/5 in bilateral upper extremities and 0/5 on bilateral lower extremities, with areflexia and no bulbar muscle weakness. Lumbar puncture indicated albuminocytologic dissociation with elevated CSF protein (56 g/L). Electromyography indicated motor and sensory neuropathy. Infectious workup showed negative CSF cultures and VDRL. Antibodies to ganglioside GM1 for GBS were negative. Post-treatment, the patient developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation. CT scan of the brain showed a hemorrhage within one of the metastatic lesion lesions and associated vasogenic edema.
A: The primary diagnosis is AIDP, evidenced by MRI findings, neurological findings, and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient's advanced age.
P: The management plan included initiating methylprednisolone and IVIG treatment for five days, followed by plasmapheresis. The patient was initially treated for acute hypoxia, which was managed with mechanical ventilation, and was later discontinued due to severe neurological deterioration. The family was informed and offered condolences and support during the bereavement process. Further consultations with oncology, neurology, and possibly a neurologist were recommended.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old male, presented with a one-day history of left flank pain and dysuria. He also reported mild low back pain from a car accident. He has a family history of cervical cancer.
O: Initial CT scan revealed diffuse lumbar spinal osseous lesions with osteoblastic and osteolytic features. Subsequent CT scans showed mild tenderness to palpation on thoracic and lumbars spine, slightly more prominent right orbital rim, and a dark skin mark on the right front thigh along the L1-2 distribution. Laboratory tests were significant for bacteriuria and vitamin D deficiency. Serum protein electrophoresis was negative for M protein, and tumor markers like CEA and PSA were negative. Chest, abdominal, and pelvic CT scans with contrast showed additional similar thoric spinal lesions, with no primary tumor lesion except for a small 4 mm non-specific pulmonary nodule. Single photo emission computed tomography (SPECT) and whole-body nuclear scan identified ground-glass sclerotic lesions on the maxillofacial region and right calvarium, indicative of fibrous dysplasia.
A: The primary diagnosis is fibrous osteolysis of the right orbital spine, evidenced by the presence of multiple bone lesions and a stable right orbital lesion over the past 14 years. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of osteolytosis, but these are less likely given the absence of a primary tumor.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately. Further consultations with oncology and possibly a pulmonologist may be necessary to manage his condition effectively. Education on the importance of regular medical check-ups to monitor his condition and manage any potential side effects is crucial.

S: The patient, a female with a history of liver disease, presented with a chief complaint of abdominal mass, nausea, and gastric compression. She refused open liver resection due to the severity of her condition. The patient expressed concerns about the risk of surgery, which led to her refusal.
O: CT-Scan and MRI revealed a more aggressive disease in segments 2 to 8 of the liver, leaving only a portion of the caudate lobe with visible parenchyma. Physical examination revealed a palpable mass involving almost all abdominal quadrants. A subsequent emergency room admission led to a double incarcerated hernia, which was successfully repaired. Post-operative follow-up showed no other complications.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large, aggressive liver disease with complications including a large palpable mass in the abdomen and severe bilateral lower limb varicose veins and edema due to IVC compression. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal masses, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included a left open liver surgery, with non-anatomic resections and fenestrations, and a bilateral sub-costal incision to make space for future remanent parenchymias. Postoperative care included a re-laparotomy for lavage due to hemorrhagic liquid in the abdominal abdomen, followed by a relaparectomy for lavages. The surgery was successful, and the patient is now free of digestive symptoms, weight loss, and lower limb edema. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain following a CT scan revealing a hypervascular mass lesion in the pancreas. The patient was referred for a 68Ga DOTATATE PET/CT scan to identify potential metastatic disease.
O: The PET scan revealed a hyper-vascular lesion on somatostatin receptors (SSTR) on neuroendocrine tumors (NETs). The PET images indicated uptake in the pancreatic region, moderate tracer uptake foci in several areas of the spine and right iliac wing, and a "Corduroy sign" on the sagittal planes. The presence of thickened trabeculae on the axial slices is consistent with hemangiomas, not bone metastases.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign, non-cancerous tumor on the pancrails, specifically hemangiacomas. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging characteristics.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the pancral mass and hemangicomas, with regular follow-ups to monitor for any new or worsening symptoms. The plan includes regular monitoring and follow-up with the primary care physician to ensure no recurrence or metastasis of the lesion. Further consultations with a nephrologist may be necessary if new symptoms arise.

S: The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese male presenting with right-sided pleuritic chest pain and a fever. He reports persistent fever.
O: Laboratory tests revealed a total leukocyte count of 7690/mm3, serum C-reactive protein level of 17.8 mg/dL, and normal liver and kidney function tests. Sputum culture was negative. Chest CT revealed right basilar peripheral opacity and ipsilateral reactive pleural effusion. Contrast-enhanced CT showed increased right pleural and aggravated infiltration. A filling defect in the inferior lobar artery of the right lung was noted, suggesting pulmonary embolism with reactive pleurisy.
A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary embolic pneumonia with reactive pulmonary effusion secondary to bacterial pneumonia. Differential diagnosis initially included bacterial pneumonia, which was ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes anticoagulation therapy, thoracic drainage of the affected side, meropenem administration, and escalation of antibiotic therapy. The patient will be treated with ceftriaxone, which has been adjusted to 1.0 g twice per day. A resection of the pulmonary parenchymal embolisms site will be performed, with the patient advised to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient is a 90-year-old male presenting with lower abdominal pain, described as tenderness in the lower abdomen and uncomfortable. He denies other symptoms such as peritoneal irritation. He has comorbidities of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. No history of surgery or trauma was reported.
O: Physical examination revealed tenderness and tenderness. Laboratory findings showed anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.3 g/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/dl) and an eGFR of 35 mL/min/1.73m2. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT indicated a 120 mm mass with coexisting low- and high-density areas in the arterial phase and spread in the portal phase. On the 2nd day of admission, anemia progressed, with hemoglobin volume dropping to 9.5 g/L (normal: <0.1 g/l). Abdominography confirmed mesenteric hematoma with anemia and mild anemia.
A: The primary diagnosis is mesenterical hematomas of the abdomen, with differential diagnoses including other causes of abdominal pain and bleeding. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of fever or abdominal pain.
P: The management plan includes conservative therapy with conservative therapy, which has been effective. The patient will continue to be monitored closely for any signs of infection or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing casual headaches, which are not related to the patient's past medical history. The patient has a history of functional endoscopic sinus surgery and septoplasty in 1998, which led to chronic sinus issues.
O: Neurological examination and MRI revealed a mass on the left side of the clivus, suspected to be a primary neoplasm. PET-CT confirmed the presence of the mass. Post-transsphenoidal endoscopy, the mass was completely removed, isolated from the sellar and suprasellar area, with no connection to the pituitary gland or stalk. Histopathology identified the mass as an ectopic pitucary adenoma, null cell type.
A: The primary diagnosis is ectopic right clival mass, with a differential diagnosis including primary or secondary neoplasms. The prognosis is good with no neurological deficits post-surgery.
P: The management plan includes admission to the hospital for biopsy and resection of the left clival masses. Postoperative care includes monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. The management team will continue with regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, presenting with a four-month history of pelvic pain. She reports a history of uterine prolapse treated with ventro-suspension 25 years ago and a laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy three years ago. She has noticed changes in her abdomen recently.
O: Physical examination revealed a pelvic mass fixed to the left anterolateral abdominal wall. Abdominal magnetic resonance imaging showed a large mass in the pelvic cavity behind the bladder with irregular borders. Tumor markers were elevated at 269.7 kU/L (normal range: 0-35 kU-L). CT scan revealed a large pelvic mass in a pelvic cavity with irregular border borders. The patient's tumor markers showed elevated CA-125 levels at 269-7 ku/L, while the reference value is 0-40 kU. Post-surgery, the tumor was successfully resected, with no visible tumor left. Histology showed a proliferation of small, round, primitive cells with a diffuse growth pattern, scant cytoplasm, irregularly-shaped and hyper-chromatic nuclei with coarse chromatin, and a brisk mitotic rate.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign uterine tumor with associated cervical intraepithelial grade 3 neoplasia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pelvic pain and abdominal discomfort. The prognosis depends on the successful resection of the tumor and the management of any potential complications.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's recovery closely with regular follow-ups to assess the tumor's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of recurrence or complications to watch for and ensure understanding of the procedure and treatment plan. Consider referral to a gynecologist for further evaluation and management of the ovarian mass. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 15-year-old female, underwent surgery for concomitant exotropia under local anesthesia. Initially, she reported a foreign body sensation in her eye six months postoperatively. Two years later, she experienced a conjunctival cyst measuring 5 x 5 mm at the right middle temporal side of her eye, causing discomfort.
O: Physical examination revealed a 5x5 mm conjunctal cyst at the site of the cyst, which was surgically excised. Pathological examination confirmed the presence of a conjointival cyt wall coated with stratified squamous epithelium and fibrous connective tissue.
A: The primary diagnosis is conjunctual exotropias, likely secondary to the cyster's presence post-surgery. The prognosis is good with surgical excision of the conjunctial cyst.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the cystic for any signs of infection or complications. The patient is advised to maintain eye cleanliness and attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence of the condition. Education on the nature of the disease and the importance of regular eye check-ups is crucial.

S: The patient, with a history of pigmentary changes at the macula starting in 1985, reports a best corrected visual acuity of 6/9 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. The patient underwent multiple IVFA examinations and was diagnosed with glaucoma in 2001, hypertension with a reading of 186/110 mmHg, cotton wool spots, and haemorrhages, and hypertension with elevated serum urea and creatinine levels. He has undergone bilateral cataract surgery in 2003, which led to a posterior capsule rupture in his left eye, leading to a BCVA of only 6/36 in each eye.
O: Fundoscopy revealed pigmentary change and drusen, with no choroidal neovascular membrane on IVFA images. Further IVFA tests showed no active leak. Retinal examination showed cotton wool and hemorrhage, consistent with hypertensive retinopathy. Serum urea levels were elevated at 20.5 mmol/L (normal 2.8–7.2 mmol/l) and 474umol/L respectively, indicating end-stage renal failure. A dual renal transplant was performed in 2009.
A: The primary diagnosis is hypertensive parathyroidism, likely secondary to the patient's history of glau coma and hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal changes and intraocular pressure changes. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in vision and overall health.
P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in vision. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of his condition. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of hypertension.

S: The patient is a 28-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, with a history of a medical termination of a miscarriage at seven weeks in 2008, with no dilation and curettage. She delivered a baby via caesarean section in the breech position, weighing 3900 g. She reports no pain or vaginal bleeding during contractions and has no significant past medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed a body temperature of 36.7 °C, blood pressure of 102/65 mmHg, pulse rate of 100 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Laboratory tests showed mild leucocytosis (16.61 × 10^9/L), normal platelet count, normal coagulation test, and haemoglobin 102 g/L. Vaginal examination showed a tightly closed cervix with no bleeding or fluid. Ultrasonography indicated a foetal head above the uterine cavity, the foetus size consistent with the gestational age, normal placental position, and normal scar thickness of 0.2 cm. Blood tests showed a slow decline in hemoglobin levels to 93 g/dL and 87 g/l, respectively. Ultrasound showed no ruptured abdominal fluid. A massive haemoperitoneum was identified during a laparotomy, which recovered approximately 1 liter of blood from the abdomen.
A: The primary diagnosis is a massive hemorrhagic hemorrhagic event, likely due to a ruptured uterine posterior wall. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemorrhagic events, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and stable condition of the hemorrhagic mass.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and postoperative care. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up with her obstetrician for further care and monitoring. She is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with an oncologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient reports a history of lymphadenopathy in the form of a left-sided cervical mass, which has been causing discomfort for the past few months.
O: Physical examination revealed partial effacement of normal nodal architecture by a lymphoma with a marginal zone pattern. No proliferation centers were found. Flow cytometry showed a B-cell clone expressing CD19, CD20, CD5, CD79a, and bcl-2, negative for CD10, CD23, partial FMC7, and moderate kappa light chain cells. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive B-lymphocytes in the widened marginal zone regions, positive for CD20 (positive for CD79), CD79 (weak), and bCL-2. Molecular testing showed no MYD88 L265P mutation. Karyotype analysis from both lymph node and bone marrow biopsy was performed using the Vysis CLL probe set.
A: The primary diagnosis is nodal MZL with aberrant CD5 positivity. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the immunohistochemistry and molecular findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes discussing the diagnosis with a multidisciplinary team of specialists, including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects.

S: The patient, with a history of rhabdomyolysis, COPD, and occasional methamphetamine use, presents with severe, constant, sharp pain in the right pectoral muscle, starting 5 days ago. The pain has progressed to include the right chest, the right shoulder, and a nonproductive chronic cough and red, swollen skin changes. The patient also mentions minor superficial abrasions and a fever the night before arrival. No blunt trauma, intravenous drug use, recent travel, or weight loss were reported.
O: Upon examination, the patient was febrile and tachycardic with stable condition. Physical examination revealed erythematous and tenderness to palpation along the distal right pectororal insertion and right shoulder. Sensitivity to light touch along the right arm was noted. A nontender induration was noted on the right flank, but no discrete mass or abscess was observed. Laboratory tests showed elevated procalcitonin, c-reactive protein, and white blood cell count. A chest x-ray was unremarkable, and an ultrasound confirmed skin induration with tiny anechoic areas. CT scan of the chest revealed fat stranding of the right Pectoral.
A: The primary diagnosis is cellulitis of the left pector, likely secondary to rhabdysplastic syndrome (CDS), given the patient's history of COPD and methamphetamine use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain such as chronic cough or chronic cough, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient’s condition and adjustment of antibiotic therapy as necessary. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and possibly a cardiologist may be necessary to manage the condition. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments is crucial. Referral to a pulminologist for further evaluation and management of COPDS and methamphetamine abuse is recommended.

S: The patient reports being ashamed of smiling due to the malposition of maxillary canines. The patient has a history of dental issues including a complete Class II molar and canine relationship, a 4-mm overjet, a 3-mm underbite, and a negative tooth-size discrepancy of 5 mm in the maxillary arch and 8.5 mm at the mandibular arch, with a 2-mm deviation of the midline to the right side and crossbite on the left side.
O: Facial and intraoral photographs reveal a complete class II molars relationship, 4-m overjet and a 3mm overbite, negative tooth size discrepancy in the mandible arch, 5 mm deviation in the left maxillary midline, and 2 mm deviation on the right. Panoramic radiograph shows all teeth except for the third molars, significant horizontal bone loss for age at the premolar region, and impairment of dental health due to large restorations in several teeth. Cephalometric analysis reveals a skeletal Class I relationship (ANB = 1o) and hyperdivergent skeletal pattern, considering occlusal plane angle values (SN.Ocl = 33o), mandibularity plane (S.GoGn = 42o), and Y axis (Y-axis = 62o). The patient's maxillary incisors are buccally tipped and protruded, with well positioned mandibulins.
A: The primary diagnosis is dental malignancy, evidenced by the patient's symptoms of facial and canine symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial deformities such as dental abscesses or malignancies. The prognosis depends on the response to orthodontic treatment and the management of dental conditions.
P: Plan to schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss orthododontics and bone loss management. Monitor bone loss and dental health to ensure proper care and maintenance. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring compliance with the treatment regimen. Discuss potential adjustments to the dental treatment plan as needed based on ongoing assessments and patient feedback.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old male farmer presenting with right hypochondriac abdominal pain for five days, accompanied by decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and yellowish discolouration of sclera for the last two days. He reports no fever, diarrhoea, blurring of vision, or pain while swallowing. He has a history of pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonitis (PJP) treated with co-trimoxazole and prednisolone. He was previously diagnosed with HIV-1 infection in 2000 and treated with HIV/1.
O: Physical examination revealed icterus and tender hepatomegaly, but fundoscopy did not reveal CMV retinitis. Liver enzymes are as follows: total bilirubin is 9.2 mg/dl (reference value: 0-1 mg/dL), AST is 109 U/L (15–37 U/l), ALT is 41 U/dL (14–59 U/°C), and ALP is 90 U-L (normal range: 0–1 U/mL).
A: The primary diagnosis is elevated liver enzymes, likely due to PJP, given the patient's history of HIV-2 infection and recent treatment with HAART. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver enzymes and bilirbin levels, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Continue current HAART regimen and monitor liver enzymes closely. Maintain current regimen of ZDV, lamivudine, and nevirapine. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor liver function and adjust treatment as necessary. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of PJP.

S: The patient, with a history of Crohn's disease and previously on tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy, presents with a chief complaint of weakness and inability to do anything.
O: Recent laboratory tests revealed low fibrinogen at 43, elevated ferritin at 108,416 ng/mL, elevated liver enzymes, and hyperbilirubinemia. Viral testing was negative for EBV and HIV. The patient underwent dialysis on day 2 of hospitalization due to worsening oliguric renal failure. Hemophagocytic histiocytes were identified on bone marrow biopsy, leading to the diagnosis of HLH-94, which led to multiple transfusions and subsequent severe gastrointestinal bleeding requiring multiple interventions.
A: The primary diagnosis is HLH, complicated by multiple transfusion complications including severe gastrointestinal bleed and hemorrhagic shock. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal failure, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and biopsy results.
P: The management plan includes continuation of dialysis and close monitoring of the patient's renal function. The family will be advised to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists may be necessary depending on the progression of the disease and response to treatment.

S: The patient, recently diagnosed with stage IIIB (T4bN1aMx) superficial spreading melanoma on the right distal thigh, reports feeling okay but experiencing weird sensations and weakness in the legs and arms. The patient has undergone surgery, right inguinal SLN biopsy, and right inguerinal lipoproliferative disease (CLND). The patient denies any bladder or bowel incontinence or speech difficulties.
O: MRI findings revealed abnormal enhancement involving the bilateral 5th, 7th, 8th cranial nerves, cauda equina nerve roots, and the conus surface and peripheral nerves at the thoracolumbar junction. CSF studies were negative for malignant cells but showed lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated CSF protein at 175 mg/dL (normal range 15-45 mg/dl). Laboratory tests showed concomitant adrenal insufficiency. Electrophysiologic evidence indicated generalized, sensory and motor, length-dependent, predominantly axonal peripheral polyneuropathy. Electrolytes showed electrophysiological evidence consistent with generalized, motor, and motor axonal polyneurpathy.
A: The primary diagnosis is ipilimumab-related acute inflammatory demyelinating polynepathy (AIDP). Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune and paraneoplastic etiologies, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient's history.
P: Continue current regimen of Methylprednisolone 1.5 mg/kg twice daily, followed by gradual reduction in steroids to 10 mg weekly over a 12-week period. Maintain hydrocortisone as needed to manage ipilimalimumab. Monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia, reports experiencing uncontrollable movements on the left side of the body for approximately 10 years, worsening over time. The patient describes these movements as "abnormal, uncontrollable" movements that make the arm reach around or fling out, accompanied by distraction or anxiety. No movement issues on the right side or facial movements were noted.
O: Physical examination revealed episodic movements in the left hand, forearm, arm muscles, and leg, with quick and moderate-amplitude movements, worsening with distraction. Neurological examination was unremarkable. CT scan of the head showed asymmetric calcification in the right caudate nucleus and anterior putamen, and normal lab work for parenchymal calcification. MRI of the brain with contrast showed both hypointense gradient echo (GRE) signal in the caudates nucleus and putamen and an underlying developmental venous anomaly (DVA).
A: The primary diagnosis is a congenital brain anomaly, likely exacerbated by the patient's claustrophobic nature and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the congenital anomalies. A multidisciplinary team of specialists will be involved to discuss the diagnosis and treatment options. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of morbid obesity, diabetes mellitus, end stage renal disease, and osteomyelitis, presents with a chief complaint of penile swelling, which began nine days ago following a bite injury to the penis during oral intercourse. The patient reports worsening symptoms, including increased tenderness and induration of the penis, phimosis, purulent drainage, and necrotizing soft tissue infection.
O: Initial treatment with Keflex and fluconazole for suspected balanitis was ineffective. CT scan revealed subcutaneous emphysema involving the dorsal aspect of the penile. Subsequent examination under anesthesia revealed phimotic drainage from the Phimotic ring and purulent drainage of the Penile shaft. Post-operative examination revealed necrotic, nonviable tissue involving the proximal shaft and ventral aspect, with remaining tissue viable.
A: The primary diagnosis is necrotized soft tissue infections, likely secondary to an infection from a recent bite injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of penis swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate follow-up care.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence of infection or complications related to the infection. The management of the infection will include regular monitoring of infection response and symptomatology. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of infection is recommended.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old female with a history of afebrile focal seizures, intractable generalized seizures, and convulsive status epilepticus. She reports a history starting at 5 months of age, with normal pre- and neonatal periods. She developed afebriele focal and intractability generalized seizures (myotonic, tonic, and tonic-clonic) and convulsions with convulsive seizures. She has developed autistic traits and has developed midline rubbing hand stereotypies, bruxism, and sleep disturbances. She also developed sleep disturbances, night time screaming spells, and occasional laughing spells. She is currently experiencing severe sleep disturbances and has a slight scoliosis.
O: Clinical examination at 19 years showed intense eye contact, stereotypic hand movements, hand dyspraxia, broad-based ataxia, and a broad-spectrum gait with notable ataxias. The patient's musculature is generally hypotonic, and she has slight scoling. She exhibits hypotonic musculatures and slight scolliosis. No other abnormalities were noted during the clinical examination.
A: The primary diagnosis is classic Retts syndrome (RTT), characterized by aggressive seizure activity and neurological deficits. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure activity, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the progression of her condition.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's seizure activity closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Maintain current anti-epileptic therapy as needed. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on her response to therapy.

S: The patient, diagnosed with stage I disease, reports recent symptoms of adenocarcinoma, including extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy, bone metastasis, and left-sided malignant pleural effusion. The patient underwent a left lower lobectomy for T1bN0M0 stage, and genetic analysis showed no mutation in EGFR exon 19 or 21, polymerase chain reaction, or anaplastic lymphoma kinase re-arrangement. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the disease and the presence of small lung nodules.
O: Recent CT scans showed no predominance in the lobe and no dominant pulmonary mass. The nodules were treated with nivolumab, followed by single-agent vinorelbine, which showed near-complete effect on the tiny diffuse lung metastases. No other mutations were identified in the EGFR-TKIs.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage I lymphoma with associated mediastal lymphadenitis and bone metastases, with differential diagnoses including other forms of lymphoma or metastatic disease. The presence of nodules and the rapid progression of disease are concerning.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression and response to new treatments. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in the condition. Consider referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of the lymphoma. Consider consultation with a geneticist for further genetic counseling and a nephrologist for management of metastatic lung disease.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old smoker with a history of hepatic transplantation 13 years ago for hepatocellular carcinoma. He reports experiencing hemoptysis and dyspnea.
O: A chest CT scan revealed a solid lesion in the apical segment of the right lower lobe, with multiple confluent mediastinal adenopathies and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy. A videobronchoscopy showed two small sessile lesions about 4.5 cm from the carina on the right lateral wall of the trachea, removed with biopsy forceps. A subsequent chest x-ray and CT scan showed deterioration of the radiological picture with stenosis of the left tracheal lumen, and a vegetative neoformation obstructing the lumen about 6.5cm from the true vocal cords. Intubation was performed with a rigid bronchoscope Storz n°14.
A: The primary diagnosis is hepatocarcinoma metastases, confirmed by anatomopathological findings. Differential diagnoses initially included other forms of metastatic cancer, but these were ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential treatment options. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old male with schizophrenia, presenting with a second suicide attempt. He reports a history of schizophrenia starting at age 23, with symptoms of paranoia, paranoia, and self-medication. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia at age 27, treated with medication, and later worked at a convenience store and a nursery. He has a family history of mental illness.
O: Physical examination and vital signs were normal. The patient's first overdose involved 76 tablets of brotizolam and 30 tablets of eszopiclone, and he was found unconscious and brought to the hospital with empty medicine containers.
A: The primary diagnosis is schizophrenia, evidenced by the patient's history of paranoid schizophrenia, medication use, and symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of schizophrenia, but these are less likely given the patient and his family history. The prognosis is guarded due to the patient’s history of multiple suicide attempts.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring and supportive care, including regular follow-ups with the healthcare team to assess treatment efficacy and manage any new symptoms. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a psychiatrist for further evaluation and management of schizophrenia is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing left hip and knee pain and limping for the past three weeks. The pain is particularly painful when attempting to flex or rotate the hip. The patient denies any fever or recent trauma.
O: Physical examination revealed range of movement in the hip, including flexing and rotating the hip in different directions. A point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) was performed to assess the hip area. A pelvic radiograph confirmed the diagnosis of a certain condition.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute hip pain, likely exacerbated by the patient's inability to flex the hip or do internal and external rotation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hip pain such as infection or infection.
P: The management plan includes expedited immobilization and pain control. The treatment plan will involve pelvic radiographs to confirm the diagnosis and discuss the appropriate treatment plan. Referral to a pain management specialist for further evaluation and management of the hip pain will be arranged. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 13-year-old male with a history of hypothyroidism diagnosed 13 years ago, presents with a painful mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, which has been increasing in size over the last 2 years. He denies fever, diarrhea/constipation, nausea, or vomiting. He has a past medical history of laparoscopic adjustable gastric band (LAGB) surgery 10 years ago and revision surgery 5 years ago due to weight loss failure. No significant family history or smoking is reported.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be afebrile with soft, non-distended abdomen and healed surgical scars. A 4 × 4 cm, symmetric mass with normal overlying skin is present in the abdomen and pelvis, with no bruit or lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests including complete blood count, liver function tests, and renal function tests are within normal limits. A CT scan of the abdominal and pelvic area with oral contrast reveals a subcutaneous spherical foreign body, likely the port, with a connected tube extending 10 cm into the abdominal cavity.
A: The primary diagnosis is a port site hernia or retained foreign body. Differential diagnosis initially included a port-site hernia, which was ruled out based on imaging and laboratory findings. The absence of bruit and lymphadomatosis suggests a non-infectious nature.
P: The management plan included surgical resection of the foreign body and removal of the connected tube. The patient was discharged on the same postoperative day. The plan includes monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms or complications, and regular follow-up appointments are recommended to assess recovery and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, a school teacher, reports persistent epigastric pain despite therapy. He underwent a laparoscopic partial gastrectomy six months ago, followed by laparoscopy six months later. His son reports new-onset jaundice four days ago. He denies any prior alcohol consumption, intravenous drug use, tattoos, non-sterile piercings, transfusions of blood or blood products, sexual promiscuity, or living in a developing country. No family history of liver diseases.
O: On examination, the patient appeared icteric with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclera, afebrile with a temperature of 97.4°C, hemodynamically stable with a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/85 mm Hg. Physical examination revealed soft, not distended abdomen with no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Laboratory tests showed significantly elevated transaminases with AST 1450 U/L and ALT 1680 U-L.
A: The primary diagnosis is a high-grade GIST with a mitotic rate of more than 5/50 per high-power field, negative margins, and positive tumor cells for CD34, CD117, and DOG-1. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver enzymes, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's liver function and response to further diagnostic tests. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor liver function, blood pressure, and overall health. Education on the signs of liver disease and the importance of follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a recent fall while walking down the stairs and experiencing pain and difficulty moving the elbow. The patient has a history of a similar injury one year ago.
O: Initial tests revealed a coronoid process fracture, specifically a Regan-Morrey type 2, in the right elbow. Subsequent tests showed a Reorgan-Morreys type 2 fracture. The treatment plan includes performing arthroscopic osteosynthesis, which is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to repair the fracture.
A: The primary diagnosis is a Coronoid Process Fracture, specifically Regan Morrey type2. Differential diagnoses could include other types of fractures or ligament damage, but these are less likely given the clinical history and successful surgical outcomes.
P: The management plan includes a minimality invasive surgical intervention (AROS) for the reconstruction of the fracture, using two 3.5 mm CCSs to secure the bone. Post-surgery, the patient will be scheduled for 5 days post-injury to ensure optimal healing conditions. Follow-up appointments will be necessary to monitor recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, who underwent aortic valve replacement 3 years ago, reports recent symptoms of fatigue. The patient has a history of duodenal ulcer perforation treated with warfarin, angiotensin receptor blocker, and proton pump inhibitors. The liver function disorder is unknown.
O: Physical examination revealed a body temperature of 36 °C, blood pressure of 164/65 mmHg, and pulse rate of 66/minute. Laboratory findings included mild anemia and liver-renal injury. Hemoglobin was 9.7 g/dL, platelet count was 18.9 × 104/dL (normal range: 4.5-11.2 × 104.0 × 10^9/L), ALP was 1138 U/L (normal: 4-5.0 u/L, normal range: 0-1.0 U/l), AST 40 U/ L (normal 0-2 U-L for men), ALT 37 U/LL, γ glutamyl transpeptidase (γ-GTP 298 U/dL), blood urea nitrogen (BUN 22.4 mg/dL) creatinine 1.14 mg/L per day, APTT 45.6 seconds, PT-INR 2.67, and PT-II 2.68.
A: The primary diagnosis is hilar cholangiocarcinoma of the liver and kidneys. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction and liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes insertion of endoscopic nasobiliary drainage (ENBD) to reduce jaundice and surgical resection of the bile duct.
