Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient and liver function, with supportive care provided by the healthcare team. Further consultations with oncology and hepatology are planned to manage the liver dysfunction. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 23-month-old male, presented with four episodes of tonic seizures over 10 days at age 16, enamel hypoplasia, and hypotonia in trunk and limb muscles. The parent reports that the patient's developmental quotient (DQ) and mental index (MI) scores were significantly low.
O: Brain MRI revealed long T1 and long T2 signal changes in white matter adjacent to the anterior and posterior horns of both lateral ventricles, indicating dysplasia in these regions. EEG monitoring showed abnormal brain waves during sleep. Liver function tests showed increased plasma alanine aminotransferase (ALT) at 117 IU/L and AST at 50IU/L, with normal ALT and AST levels. Plasma bilirubin levels were within normal limits, but plasma citrulline levels were elevated at 220.94 μmol/L. Follow-up brain MRI showed ventricular dilation and cerebral atrophy of the left hemisphere with malacia.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe brain injury secondary to a severe infection, likely exacerbated by a genetic disorder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of brain injury, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan included a restricted protein diet and arginine supplementation, which led to a decrease in plasma ammonia levels to 70 μmol-L. The patient's condition was managed with ongoing monitoring and supportive care. Genetic counseling was provided to the parents to ensure understanding and compliance with the genetic study.

S: The patient, a 27-year-old male with a history of diverticulitis, has a 27 year history of abdominal pain, sigmoid resection, appendectomy, and end colostomy with a mucous fistula. He has anxiety and takes alprazolam as needed. He also has mitral valve prolapse and diltiazem daily. He underwent surgery to repair an anal fistula with a rectal advancement flap. He reports no significant issues with his skin in the past.
O: Physical examination revealed eight keratotic plaques on the face, arms, and legs in sun-exposed areas. No nail plate changes were noted. The patient's fingernails and toenails showed diffuse whitening, alternating horizontal bands of white and red, and a nail flag sign.
A: The primary diagnosis is psoriasis with complications including allergic contact dermatitis to bandaid adhesive and leukonychia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to cryotherapy and the management of psoriatic arthritis.
P: Continue cryotherapy for actinic keratoses. Monitor the patient for any signs of worsening skin conditions. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and the importance for regular follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the psoritis. Consider consultation with an oncologist if symptoms persist or worsen. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a painless, firm and immobile mass on the right side of the scrotum, which has been slowly enlarging.
O: A CT scan revealed a right inguinal hernia with intraperitoneal fat extending inferiorly into the sac and a 14 × 10.5 cm membranous sac. Microscopic examination revealed nine separate lobulated masses ranging from 2 to 8 cm in size, along the spermatic cord, with varying coloration from light brown to red brown. Microbiological examination confirmed a well-differentiated liposarcoma mixed type with lipoma-like and sclerosing type, grade 1. PET-scan confirmed a nonhypermetabolic fatty mass along the distal anterior aspect of the right psoas.
A: The primary diagnosis is a well–differentiated Liposarma mixed type of lipoma, grade1. Differential diagnosis initially included other lipomas but was ruled out based on imaging and PET findings.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options including surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy depending on the specific circumstances. The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of the tumor.

S: The patient reports decreased vision in the right eye and pain around the eye for about a week.
O: Ophthalmological examination revealed visual acuity of light perception/0.9 in decimals, a relative afferent pupillary defect of grade 3, diffuse disc swelling, and inferior disc hemorrhage. Neurological examination showed normal muscle strength in all extremities, no sensory deficits or signs of bladder or bowel dysfunction, and normoactive deep tendon reflexes. Orbit MRI revealed T2 high signal intensities and diffuse contrast enhancement along the right anterior and posterior optic nerve, and perineural enhancement. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed a red blood cell count of 0/μL, white blood cells count of 1/μl, and protein level of 27 mg/dL. CSF oligoclonal band measured by isoelectric focusing was negative, and IgG index was 0.64. Serum AQP4-IgG flow cytometry assay was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is right optic neuritis, evidenced by the absence of sensory deficits and normal muscle muscle strength. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of optic nerve dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Initiated intravenous methylprednisolone (1000 mg pulse therapy) for 5 days followed by oral prednisololone 60 mg daily. Initiated azathioprine 50 mg twice per day for the second and third attacks, with a remission state between the first and third. The average thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer measured by spectral-domain optical coherence tomography decreased to 51 μm and left 105 μm, respectively. Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and ensuring compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a 24-month-old female, was referred from Dracena's municipal hospital on February 22, 2014, and admitted with a chief complaint of fever for 10 days, accompanied by adynamia, pallor, inappetence, oliguria, and choluria. The parent reports severe liver injury, including hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia (4+/4+), hypoactive skin, and hypoactivity.
O: On examination, the patient appeared lethargic, discolored (4-4+)/4+, and hyperactive. Radiographic image suggested pneumonia. Laboratory and image examinations indicated marked anemia, thrombocytopenia, and significant hepatic enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography indicated pronounced hepatosplenomegaly. Tests confirmed Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL). The patient was treated with liposomal amphotericin B (5 mg/kg/day) for 5 days, positive for CMV antibodies IgG and IgM. At the end of treatment, liver injury was noted, presenting hyperbolic, hyponatremia, increased liver and canalicular enzymes (ALT 354 IU/mL, AST 354 IU-mL), and CMV infection.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe liver damage likely secondary to VL infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver injury such as infection or infection. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the liver injury.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of liver function and supportive care. The patient will continue to be monitored in the pediatric ICU with supportive care, with regular follow-ups to assess recovery and manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a 5-week-old male, presented with jaundice and failure to thrive. He was delivered via Cesarean section at 38 weeks of gestation, Apgar score 9/9, weight at 2600 g, length 49 cm, and cranial circumference 32.5 cm. The patient has a healthy 8-year-old brother.
O: Physical examination was unremarkable except for skin and scleral jaundices. Laboratory tests showed cholestatic jaundica with total bilirubin at 11.95 mg/dL, conjugated biliruberin at 6.69 mg/dl, and increased gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase at 221 U/L. ursodeoxycholic acid treatment (20 mg/Kg/day) was ineffective. Abdominal ultrasound revealed normal liver size and echogenicity, normal biliary intrahepatic and extrahepatics, regular liver vessel flow, and hyperechogenic kidneys with multiple bilateral cortical cysts of maximum size 2 mm. Serum creatinine was 0.59 mg/L, and estimated glomerular filtration rate was 35 ml/min/1.73m2. Chronic Kidney Disease KDIGO stage 3 with metabolic acidosis and tubular proteinuria was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is Chronic Kidneys Disease KDigO stage3, complicated by renal dysfunction and metabolic acidemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of jaundiness and renal impairment. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of chronic conditions.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's renal function and jaundic symptoms. Nutritional support will be adjusted to support growth and development. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for early detection of new symptoms will be provided. Referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for specialized care and a hematologist for ongoing management of renal function is recommended.

S: The patient is a 22-year-old unmarried South Asian female presenting with a four-month history of right eye issues. She reports experiencing a headache lasting one day and metamorphopsia in the right eye. She has a history of refractive errors in both her right (-1.00 dioptre sphere, DS) and left (-0.50 DS) eyes for three years.
O: Ocular examination revealed best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 6/24 in both eyes. Fundus examination showed 2+ vitreous cells and yellow-white active retinitis of two to three disc diameters over the macula in the left eye, with a BCVA level of 6. FFA showed a hyperfluorescent patch of increasing intensity of 2DD temporal to the optic disc in the same eye. Axial optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan revealed an irregular, thickened retina with loss of foveal contour and pigment epithelial detachment in the retina, suggestive of a choroidal neovascular membrane. OCTA showed a patch of abnormally dilated, hyperfluorescence vessels at the outer retina level of the right retina.
A: The primary diagnosis is choroid neovarum, likely secondary to systemic Toxoplasma infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal detachment such as ocular trauma, comorbid conditions, or blood transfusion. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of clinical manifestations and normal sleep.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and regular follow up appointments to monitor her condition and make necessary adjustments. Referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of choroids neovirum is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of kidney failure and multiple myeloma for approximately 10 years, reports recent onset of difficulty swallowing and breathing. The patient denies any signs of systemic amyloidosis.
O: Clinical examination revealed significant swelling on the neck. Ultrasound revealed increased thyroid volume with the right lobe measuring 49 × 38 × 100 mm and the left lobe 41 × 34 × 51 mm, with involvement of the mediastinum but no lateral cervical lymphadenopathy. CT and MRI scan indicated diffuse and multinodular enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid gland, with the left lobes reaching C2 and the brachio-cephalic trunk. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) indicated colloid and histiocytes. Post-total thyroidectomy, the thyroid was diffusely enlarged with a nodular external surface, soft, irregularly nodular, and salmon-colored parenchyma. Histological findings included diffuse stromal deposition of amorphous eosinophilic material, residual normal-sized or cystically dilated thyroid follicles, and variably fatty stroma component characterized by mature adipocytes. PAS staining was negative or weakly positive in the Amorphous Eosinopathilic Stromal material. Rosso Congo stain showed apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
A: The primary diagnosis is amyloidal goiter, a rare condition characterized by morphological and histochemical features suggestive of thyroid dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyroid enlargement, but these are less likely given the histological and morphological findings.
P: The management plan included total thyroidectomy to remove the thyroid. The treatment plan includes monitoring thyroid function and symptomatology closely, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and clinical findings. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess thyroid function, thyroid function tests, and thyroid hormone levels. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition and potential side effects of thyroidectomy will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a twenty-eight-year-old female, reports persistent headaches, which started yesterday. She denies any increased stress, changes in diet, or lifestyle. She has a history of migraines, which she denies. She also denies any new symptoms, fever, rash, vomiting, neck stiffness, or new symptoms.
O: Physical examination shows headache on the left side of her head, starting mid-morning. She takes Paracetamol and has been taking it regularly with food. No new symptoms or changes in her diet or lifestyle are reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute headache, likely secondary to a migraine, given the patient's history of migraine, and the recent onset of headaches. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headaches, but these are less likely given the history and symptomatology.
P: The management plan includes a referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the headache. The patient is advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or if new symptoms arise. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing nausea, vomiting, and a 7 kg weight loss over the past month. The patient has a history of Pica disorder since 2 years old and trichophagia.
O: Physical examination reveals stable vital signs but a large, firm, hard mass in the epigastric and left upper quadrant areas. Blood tests including complete blood count, electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, liver function tests, amylase, and lipase are unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a 30 × 17 × 12 cm heterogeneous, heterogeneously hyperdense mass extending from the gastric fundus to the pyloric canal, with no evidence of abnormal gastric mural thickening. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) reveals a large hairball occupying the entire lumen of the stomach from the fundus through the duodenum, reaching the duodoenum. Surgical intervention failed to retrieve the mass due to its large size and hard nature.
A: The primary diagnosis is a heterogeneous mass of gastric lumen, likely a gastrostomy, given the mass's heterogeneous nature and the absence of normal gastric walls. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and nausea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with a 7 cm longitudinal gastrotomy on the anterior gastric wall, 6 cm from the pylonorus, with the trichobezoar identified and removed. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's recovery and potential complications. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are planned to assess the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient is a 22-year-old female with a history of lower extremity crampus (CRPS) type-I in the left ankle and foot based on the International Association of the Study of Pain (IASP) Budapest Criteria. She reports no history of psychological disorder, seizure disorder, or neurological abnormality. She underwent a diagnostic left lumbar sympathetic block (LSB) procedure and 5 additional LSBs using the same technique and medications. She denies experiencing paresthesia during the procedure.
O: Physical examination revealed contracture of the left foot in a plantar-flexed position, with the only motor presentation of the CRPS being a reproducible tremor of the ipsilateral quadriceps muscles when the left knee was fully extended. No other involuntary motor movements were noted during the procedures. The patient was administered local anesthesia and lorazepam 1.5 mg orally. DPH 50 mg IV prophylactically was administered for the 6th block. The needle entry point was marked on the skin at the level of L3. Surgical preparation and draping were performed with 3 mL of Lidocaine 1% in 1 mL increments. Temperature measurements were monitored throughout the procedure, and the patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment to assess progress and determine if further treatment is necessary.
A: The primary diagnosis is CRPS type-II with complications including left ankle/foot contracture and right ankle cramps. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of CRPS, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the condition.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Maintain current medications and monitor for any potential complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen and follow up appointments. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of her CRPS. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath, reports ongoing respiratory distress. The patient has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, GERD, VLUs, and ambulatory dysfunction. The condition has worsened recently.
O: Physical examination revealed a large ulcer on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity, covered in fibrotic slough, and woody edema. Skin examination revealed two ulcerations on the right upper extremity. The larger ulceration measured 10 x 16 x 1.5 cm with 20 percent brown tissue, 40 percent pink tissue, and 40 percent tan tissue in the base. A malodor was noted. Treatment included intravenous cefepime, clindamycin, and vancomycin, pending wound culture results.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock with complications including a significant ulcer in the right subcutaneous area. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress such as infection or infection. The prognosis is guarded due to the current condition.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and wound healing. Treatment will continue with intravenous antibiotics and wound culture. The surgical team will be consulted to adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with the surgical team are planned to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient, an 18-year-old male, reports experiencing recurrent seizures for the past 3 months, starting with blurring of vision and head deviating to the right side, followed by tonic posturing and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He also experiences suboccipital and frontal tension headaches. No fever, weight loss, trauma, sensory or motor issues, or family history of similar issues or surgeries are reported.
O: Physical examination was within normal limits. Neurological examination showed no signs of neurofibromatosis. Brain MRI with contrast showed a right parieto-occipitical mass lesion measuring 1.5 x 0.5 cm, low signal intensity on T1 and intermediate signal intensity at T2 and FLAIR, with intense enhancement, peripherally, with small susceptibility artifacts on T2, and significant vasogenic edema and mass effect on adjacent sulci. Right occipital craniotomy was performed, revealing a small discoloration. cortical dissection and frozen section analysis were performed, confirming schwannoma with a differential diagnosis of meningioma. Post-surgery, the patient was discharged with no new neurological deficits.
A: The primary diagnosis is schwannisoma of the subcortical region, likely a granulomatous infection, given the presence of a granular mass lesional to the brain. Differential diagnoses considered included granuloma, TB, or metastasis. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the tumor and the absence of any new neurological symptoms.
P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the schwanioma with appropriate anticoagulation therapy (phenytoin 100 mg orally three times a day and Paracetamol 6 as needed). The patient will be monitored closely for any signs of recurrence or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports worsening vision over the past few years, now 20/400 in both eyes. The patient has a medical history of bilateral juvenile open-angle glaucoma (JOAG) and high myopia (− 8.0D) diagnosed at age 16, treated with dorzolamide 2%, latanoprost 0.005%, brimonidine 0.2%/timolol 0.5% fixed combination, and oral acetazolamide 500 mg/day. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was still around 25 mmHg, and the patient discontinued anti-glaucomas treatment a few months prior.
O: Gonioscopy showed normal iridocorneal angle and pachymetric measurements in the right eye and left eye. Axial length was 27.56 mm, and eye width was 26.46 mm. Fundoscopic examination showed bilateral enlarged disc cupping of the optic nerves with sectorial excavation and reduction of the neural rim in the left eye, and OCTA showed retinal nerve fiber layer thinning in several areas of both eyes, with vascularity of the peripapillary capillaries at 43.6% and 49.15% respectively. Visual field test indicated progressive central scotoma in both eye.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral progressive central schotoma, likely secondary to the patient's previous systemic disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes continuation of glucoma treatment and close monitoring of eye condition. Adjustments to the treatment plan will be made based on the patient response to the new treatment regimen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the medication as necessary. The management team will continue to manage the patient and his condition closely.

S: The patient, who underwent small bowel resection, reports severe abdominal pain and a blockage in the intestines, necessitating the removal of a part of the descending thoracic aorta. The patient underwent a procedure to replace the affected part of DTA.
O: Physical examination revealed a floating mass involving the descending Thoracic Aorta (DTA) and a blood clot in the aortium, which was identified as idiopathic. Postoperative recovery was slow, with no cerebrovascular accidents. However, within three weeks of surgery, the patient developed diffuse metastatic liver disease.
A: The primary diagnosis is idiopathyic thrombosis of the thoracium, likely secondary to a blood-clotting clot. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan included full cardiopulmonary bypass under deep hypothermic circulatory arrest. Post-operative care included a left thoracoabdominal incision and access with inflow cannulation of the left carotid and left femoral artery, and outflow cannulation. The aortal resection was performed with full cardiothoracic bypass. The plan includes transfer to hospice care, where the patient will receive appropriate support and care. The family will be informed about the treatment options and the importance of compliance with the care plan.

S: The patient, with a history of dilated ischemic cardiomyopathy and triple coronary artery bypass grafting in 1990, reports recent chest pain and shortness of breath.
O: Coronary angiography revealed a baseline GFR of 45 ml/min/1.73 m2 and Hs-Troponin T and CK-MB levels of 497 ng/l and 211 U/l, respectively. Coronation angiographic findings included tandem calcified lesions of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) on the distal right coronary artery and ostial stenosis of the SVG on the first obtuse marginal branch. The left internal mammary artery was patent. Ad Hoc PCI was attempted, but the non-compliant balloon was unable to break the hard and calcified plaque. Elective PCI with rotational atherectomy was performed, with two runs with a 1.25 mm burr and two with 1.5 mm burrs. A distal anchoring balloon was used for support and tracking. A drug-eluting stent was placed in the affected area.
A: The primary diagnosis is Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction, complicated by the patient's history of coronary artery disease and recent non-stenting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocarditis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient’s recovery and adherence to a prescribed medication regimen to prevent further complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the prescribed treatment regimen and monitoring for any signs of complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 42-year-old African American male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, coronary arterial disease, and atrial fibrillation, presented with new onset right-sided chest pain and a lump on his chest. He reported worsening symptoms and new onset chest wall numbness.
O: Ultrasound and CT scan revealed an anterior right chest mass measuring 7.5 × 6.5 x 4.8 cm, 0.6 cm deep to the skin. CT scan identified a 9x9x9cm necrotic mass arising from the pectoralis major. A CT-guided core biopsy was positive for high-grade spindle cell neoplasm. Post-CT scan, the mass increased in size to 21.4 × 17.8 × 13.7 cm without evidence of metastatic disease or invasion. MRI confirmed a 23 cm mass within the right pectorilateral fascia without vascular or bony invasion.
A: The primary diagnosis is a high-risk, metastatic tumor of the right Pectoralus major, complicated by multiple comorbidities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain, but imaging and clinical presentation support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes initiating neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and docetaxel for 2 cycles, followed by radiation therapy for 50Gy over 2 months to the tumor bed + 3 cm margins. A wide local surgical resection for definitive therapy will be performed, with resection to the intercostal fascia and pecture to the minor. The patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing cough, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and a loss of appetite. The patient denies any family history of autoimmune thyroid diseases and is not currently taking any medications.
O: Vital signs include a height of 145 cm, body weight of 40.0 kg, blood pressure of 137/81 mmHg, pulse rate of 116 beats/min, and body temperature of 37.0°C. Electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Laboratory tests show a normal white cell count of 8,290 cells/µL, slightly elevated C-reactive protein at 3.94 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase at 460 U/L. Thyroid hormone levels are elevated: free triiodothyronine 20.27 pg/mL, free thyroxine 6.53 ng/dL. Thyroglobulin 183 ng/mL. Ultrasonography of the thyroid shows heterogeneous and hypoechoic areas.
A: The primary diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis, indicated by elevated thyroid hormone levels, anti-TSH receptor antibody, and anti-thyroid-stimulating antibody positivity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyroid dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Initiate prednisolone (20 mg/day) for four weeks, followed by methimazole (10 mg-day). Monitor thyroid hormone and liver function closely, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of regular follow-ups and adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports experiencing right lower quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, decreased urination, and dysuria. The patient denies any history of kidney stones.
O: Physical examination revealed right lower extremity tenderness and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Vital signs showed hypotension (BP 77/46), tachycardia (117 bpm), and tachypnea (22 breaths per minute). The patient was afebrile with a high leukocyte count of 24,190/μL, creatinine of 3.90 mg/dL, and lactic acid of 7.49 mg/dl. Urinalysis showed 30 WBCs and 6 RBCs per HPF, positive leukocytes esterase, and negative nitrites. Urine culture grew Klebsiella pneumoniae. CT scan revealed an atrophic left kidney and a 4 mm stone in the right ureterovesical junction causing mild hydroureteronephrosis. Blood cultures were negative for bacteria. A URS-LL and right Ureteral stent placement were performed, and a laser lithotripsy was performed to remove the stone.
A: The primary diagnosis is a solitary right kidney infection, complicated by persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors, and persistent infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of kidney blockage and swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan included emergent cystoscopy with right urethal stenting and piperacillin-tazobactam for the infection. Postoperative care included monitoring for signs of infection and antibiotic resistance, with repeat blood and urine cultures negative for bacterial infection. The stone was surgically removed with a rigid uretersteroscope. The plan included surgical intervention for the stone removal, followed by laser lithotomy for the removal of the stone, which was performed using laser lithots. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and absence of infection. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 20-year-old male with a history of primary amenorrhoea, reports no symptoms of period but has been referred for further evaluation.
O: Physical examination revealed all secondary sexual features well developed. Abdominal sonography revealed complete non-visualization of the uterus, cervix, and vagina, with both ovaries in bilateral inguinal canals. Doppler study showed no significant vascular compromise in either ovary. CT urography and MRI of the pelvis confirmed complete agenesis of the uterine, cervical, and vaginal canals, with bilateral ureteroceles. A delayed CT KUB scan showed bilateral ballooning of the vesicoureteric junction. Genetic karyotyping indicated a 46XX chromosome pattern.
A: The primary diagnosis is Type I MRKH syndrome, characterized by bilateral urogenital anomalies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urogenesis, but these are less likely given the specific findings and genetic findings.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options with a specialist to discuss potential treatments and management strategies. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition.

S: The patient, a 15-month-old boy, presented with a scald burn from hot milk after accidentally pulling a tablecloth and spilling a mug of just-boiled milk onto him. The parent reported that the child was struggling with progressive stridor and laboured breathing, initially thought to be sputum stasis.
O: Upon examination at the Burn Centre, the patient's condition deteriorated, and oxygen saturation dropped to 80% despite maximal supplemental oxygen. No intra-oral redness or swelling was noted. Airway opening maneuvers and sputums evacuation were attempted, but the stridors persisted.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe second-degree burns to the lips, chin, neck, chest, left arm, and left foot, with a total of 12% of the total body surface area. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of burns such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the severity of the burns.
P: The treatment plan includes intravenous rehydration, lactated ringers, glucose, and intravenous analgesics. The patient will be monitored closely for respiratory distress and potential complications. Further interventions may be considered based on his response to treatment and recovery. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old male presenting with dysphagia. He reports difficulty swallowing.
O: Initial examination revealed a large submucous eminence lesion approximately 18-24 cm from the incisors. CT examination identified a 1.8 cm × 5.2 cm × 2.9 cm soft tissue mass in the upper esophageal wall. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed a hypoechoic lesion originating from the muscularis propria with a clear boundary. Postoperative findings included a hypochoic submukosal lesion, which was successfully resected using endoscopic submuccosal excavation.
A: The primary diagnosis is leiomyoma of the esophagus, confirmed by pathological findings and imaging. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagias such as other forms of esophagia, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan included full-thickness resection of the lesion and en bloc resection. The patient underwent a successful surgical resection using a 20-gauge needle and a gastroduodenal decompression tube. Postoperatively, the tumor was managed with surgical intervention and no esophagesal stricture was observed. Further follow-up care will be necessary to monitor the tumor's progression and manage any complications.

S: The patient, admitted to the Department of Respiratory Medicine at Peking Union Medical College Hospital, reports recurrent chest pain and transient syncope starting approximately nine months ago, accompanied by burning chest and back pain on the right side, sweating, fatigue, and dizziness. The patient has a history of recurrent periorbital nodules and a submaxillary mass over the past 12 years, treated with supportive treatment.
O: Physical examination revealed anemia, scars, and yellowish nodules on the skin. No history of hypertension, diabetes, hepatitis, or tuberculosis was reported. Blood pressure was elevated at 85/50 mmHg. Laboratory tests showed a significant decrease in hemoglobin from 93 g/L to 50 g/l. Thoracic ultrasound indicated right-sided pleural effusion with septa. Chest CT showed right-side encapsulated effusion. Biopsies of lesions indicated inflammatory pseudotumor, dacryoadenitis, and reactive lymph node hyperplasia.
A: The primary diagnosis is transient syncopation with associated chest pain, syncope, and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of syncope and syncope. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of the underlying condition.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's symptoms and hemoglobin levels. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to determine the cause of the syncope symptoms and the progression of the condition. Referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of syncopations is recommended. Patient education on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and regular follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a male with a history of gonococcal urethritis, presented with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain, described as constant pressure, worsening throughout the day. The pain was described as a constant pressure.
O: Vital signs were stable. Lab results showed leukocytosis at 11,200 and positive urinalysis. Computed Tomography (CT) scan revealed mild telescoping of loops of the small bowel and mesenteric fat in the left mid abdomen, with no obvious bowel obstruction or definitive masses. Diagnostic laparoscopy revealed intussusception of the mid jejunum. Pathology confirmed marked congestion and focal reactive lymphoid hyperplasia in the lamina propria of the invaginated bowel.
A: The primary diagnosis is intussussusception of the bowel, likely due to the nature of the intestinal folds. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or inflammation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms or concerns immediately. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, referred due to prehepatic portal hypertension caused by portal vein thrombosis, reports two episodes of acute pancreatitis, with the disease onset at 9.7 years. The patient has experienced severe abdominal pain and felt sick during those episodes. No recent injuries or other health issues were reported.
O: Abdominal ultrasound revealed chronic pancreatitis with a heterogeneous pancreas, and a dilated pancreatic duct. Genetic testing identified a heterozygous c.568G>A (p.Glu190Lys) variant in the PRSS1 gene, which was not identified in the 1000 genomes, dbSNP, genomic GNomad (version 2.0.2), ClinVar, and HGMD databases.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatis, likely secondary to a genetic variant of the PRS1 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatitis such as injury, anatomical anomalies, toxic-metabolic disorders, or biliary disease. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the absence of other pathogenic variants.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and monitor for any new symptoms or worsening of the condition. Education on the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle, avoiding alcohol consumption, and eating a low-fat diet is crucial. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the pancreatitis is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the management plan as necessary.

S: The patient, diagnosed with IgG lambda MM in November 2007, initially treated with lenalidomide and dexamethasone, relapsed and underwent multiple lines of chemotherapy. The patient has a history of IgG and lambda MM, treated with pomalidomid and pomadol.
O: Recent imaging and RNA analysis revealed CD138+ cells activation of the HDAC pathway, and the HDac inhibitor vorinostat was repurposed through drug repurposing. Previous treatment with venetoclax 400 mg PO once daily, HDAC inhibitor panobinostat 20 mg Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, 2 weeks on, 1 week off, and pomeralidomides 2 mg Monday to Friday, 3 weeks on. The current treatment plan includes venetoproliferative therapy (PO) once daily with panobinosterat 20mg Monday, Wed, and Fridays, 2 week on, and 1 week on.
A: The primary diagnosis is IgG-associated leukemia (IgG) MM, with differential diagnoses including other forms of immunosuppression or metastatic disease. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the effective treatment and the absence of side effects.
P: Continue the current regimen of venetocortic acid (PO), panobinastat, venetol, pomada, and venetoxidazole. Monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust as necessary based on the response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a oncologist for further evaluation and management of the disease. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: 
- Patient reports right shoulder pain, described as intermittent, all-time, with intermittent pain. Denies numbness or tingling in the arm or hand.
- Physical exam shows limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness to the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular joint, brisk capillary refill, and equal response to sensation and touch.

O:   iced the right shoulder, took advil, and took ibuprofen. No tylenol or advil was administered.  
A: The patient's right shoulder is currently experiencing pain. The pain is intermittent, but the pain is not severe.
P:  - Continue corticosteroid therapy for pain. Monitor pain levels closely. Schedule follow-up in 2 weeks. Educate patient on the importance of pain management and pain management. Schedule a follow-ups appointment in 2/3 to reassess shoulder condition.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease, presents with generalized body weakness and anorexia. He reports severe hyponatremia with a sodium concentration of 116 mmol/L, hypokalemia with potassium at 2.8 mmol/l, and magnesium at 1.2 mg/dL. He also mentions a fainter focus of tracer uptake in a soft tissue mass on the lateral aspect of the 7th right rib.
O: Physical examination revealed severe hyponicatremias with a total sodium concentration at 116 mmol-L and potassium at 4.8 mg/L. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum PTH at 3071.90 pg/mL and serum vitamin D at 35.52 ng/mL. Parathyroid scintigraphy was performed using a dual-tracer protocol with SPECT/CT. Post-parathyroid scan, planar imaging of neck and thorax was performed, and 769.6 MBq of 99mTc-sestamibi was injected. The patient's tracer activity was noted to be increased in the inferior pole of the right lobe but retained on subtraction.
A: The primary diagnosis is a parathyroid adenoma, likely causing primary hyperparathyrophy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyponaturia such as thyroid dysfunction or other autoimmune disorders, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging characteristics.
P: The management plan will include discussing the case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action. The treatment plan will involve surgical removal of the parathyrope, monitoring for any potential complications, and regular monitoring of electrolyte levels and electrolytes. Further treatment options will be considered depending on the patient's overall health status and response to treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a female, reports a 2-year history of sporadic abdominal pain, which has become sharp and frequent in the left lower abdomen. She denies nausea, vomiting, or history of abdominal trauma. She has a congenital anomaly of the kidneys and uterus, and menstruates. The patient has a history of appendectomy a few years ago.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient is afebrile with a white blood cell count of 7.13 × 10^9/L, neutrophilic granulocytes of 76.8%, hemoglobin of 120 g/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/dL), and platelet count of 322 × 10/L. A CT scan revealed an intestinal stromal tumor and pelvic kidneys. Digestive tract radiography indicated possible extraintestinal involvement. Abdominal laparotomy revealed a mass in the sigmoid flexure, exophytic without infiltration, measuring 6.0 × 5.0 x 3.0 cm, excised the tumor and a portion of the colon, and a solitary fibrous tumor (SFT). Colon anastomosis was performed, and the patient recovered in 7 days post-operatively.
A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic ovary with corpora lutea bleeding. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of abdominal pain such as appendicitis or other gastrointestinal malignancies, but these were ruled out based on imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up visits to monitor the patient's recovery and detect any new symptoms. The plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and blood counts to ensure no recurrence of symptoms. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to a gastroenterologist for specialized care and a gastroesophageal specialist for further evaluation and management of gastrointestinal symptoms is recommended.

S: The patient reports a history of right lumbago for about a month. Recently underwent B mode ultrasonography revealing a lower echo mass in the lower pole of the right kidney.
O: Recent ultrasonographic findings revealed a 5.4 × 4.8 cm tumor in the upper pole, with an irregular shape and uneven internal echo. A middle abdomen plain and enhanced CT scan showed a round tumor of 5.2 × 4,9 cm with a clear boundary and uneven density. A laparoscopic radical nephrectomy was performed, revealing pigmentation and a clear tumor boundary. Immunohistochemistry tests were positive for HMB45, Melan-A, S100, Ki67, and TFE3. Post-operative follow-up showed no recurrence of the tumor after 3 months.
A: The primary diagnosis is a translocation of XP11.2 tumor with low malignant biological behavior. The successful surgical removal of this tumor and its low malignancy suggest a less likely spread of the disease.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology may be necessary to manage any potential complications from the tumor.

S: The patient, a chef at an Indian restaurant, reports an injury to the left hand approximately one year ago, resulting in the amputation of the middle, ring, and little fingers. Six months post-accident, the patient has undergone hand reconstruction. The patient has experienced phantom pain post-implantations, with a Quick-DASH score of 81.82/100.00. No changes in pain or function have been reported post-operatively.
O: Radiographic examination revealed a preoperative visual analogue scale (VAS) score of 4/10, indicating phantom pain, and Quick DASH of 81/100, indicating a good prognosis for hand reconstruction without significant changes in function. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography showed bilateral STT compatible for the reconstruction of two fingers.
A: The primary diagnosis is a congenital left hand amputation with complications including phantom pain and phantom pain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb amputation such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and imaging.
P: The management plan includes transferring the bilateral second toes to the middle and ring fingers, with careful monitoring of the patient's recovery and pain management. Physical therapy will be necessary to regain function and manage pain. The recovery process will involve physical therapy to regain functional function and managing pain. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess recovery progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of infection or complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old Japanese woman who underwent root canal treatment on tooth #47 in 2005. She reports dull pain since the extraction of tooth #48 in August 2010, which has been ongoing since. She has experienced purulent discharge from the pocket of tooth No.48 since August 2010. The patient has been concerned about the expansion of the right posterior mandibular bone, which was noted in March 2016. No recent discomfort or other symptoms were reported.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests showed normal blood and chest X-ray findings, no lymphadenopathy or paralysis of the mental/lingual nerve, and epithelialized tooth #46 with a pocket depth of 3 mm. Panoramic radiography showed new bone formation at the equivalent sites of teeth #48 and #47, and a radiolucent region around the distal root of tooth#46. CT scans showed continuous absorption from the alveolar bone of the proximal root to the lingual cortical bone at tooth #45 and six granulated hard tissues. Magnetic resonance imaging showed low intensity on enhanced T1-weighted images.
A: The primary diagnosis is ongoing bone expansion in tooth #49 and #46, likely related to the extraction process. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tooth enlargement such as malignancy or malignant bone disease, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the bone structure around the teeth, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to the new findings and ongoing assessment. The management will include regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health status will be provided. Referral to an oncologist for further evaluation and management of the dental condition is recommended.

S: The patient, a male with a history of sarcoidosis and respiratory tract infections, presented with a 2-day history of right-sided lower abdominal pain, which began suddenly around the central abdomen and moved towards the right side, worsening with movement. He denies nausea, anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, or urinary or gynecological symptoms. The patient has a past medical history with sarcoids and respiratory infections.
O: Physical examination revealed marked tenderness in the RIF with rebound tenderness and localized guarding. The rest of the abdomen was soft and nontender with normal bowel sounds. Vital signs showed a pulse rate of 76 bpm, blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a WCC of 7.1 and a CRP of 16.6. Renal and liver function tests were within normal limits. Urinalysis was normal. A pregnancy test was negative. CT scan revealed epiploic appendagitis of the caecum with mild surrounding pericaecal fat stranding. The appendix appeared entirely normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute appendicitis, complicated by the patient's history and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is good with no recurrence of symptoms.
P: The management plan includes conservative management with analgesia and antibiotics for 2 days, followed by a follow-up visit to monitor for recurrence. The plan includes discharge from surgical care and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Referral to a pulmonologist for specialized care and a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of gastrointestinal symptoms is recommended.

S: The patient, a second-born child, reports a history of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (PRS), micrognathia, glossoptosis, cleft palate, triphalangeal thumbs, and a congenital perimebranous ventricular defect. The patient experienced neurodevelopmental delays, including head control at 4-5 months, sitting at 11 months, standing unassisted at 13 months, and learning to walk precariously at 20 months. In the first months of life, the patient was diagnosed with inherited hyporigenerative anemia, necessitating regular blood transfusion therapy.
O: Physical examination revealed a peculiar face, skeletal abnormalities in a complex malformation syndrome, and mental deficiency. Dysmorphic facial features include a prominent nose bridge, low-set ears, bilateral external auditory meatus abnormalities, ocular asymmetry with buphthalmos, intermittent exotropia with left eye dominance, severe myopia, tooth decay, and cavities.
A: The primary diagnosis is congenital hyposis (DBA), complicated by PRS and mental deficiencies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial abnormalities, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation.
P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and manage any new symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of developmental milestones. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, admitted to the Department of Thoracic Surgery in July 2018, reports a history of endometrial glandular squamous carcinoma with invasion of the uterine myometrium. The patient underwent a hysterosalpingooophorectomy and greater omentum resection in 2010, followed by radiation and chemotherapy. In May 2018, the patient experienced a new dull pain in the right hypochondrium. Previous imaging included abdominal ultrasound and contrast-enhanced MDCT of the chest and abdomen, revealing a large, well-circumscribed tumor in the SVIII of the liver. positron emission tomography combined with computed tomography showed a large hypermetabolic lesion of the right hemidiaphragm measuring 11.4 × 13.5 × 10.7 cm, invading the right liver lobe, deforming its upper contour in a wavy manner.
O: Physical examination and imaging studies revealed a liver lesion, a large hematopoietic tumor, and a fatty tissue layer separating the lesion from the liver lobe. Post-surgery, a video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery was performed, converting to open right lateral thoracotomy through the fifth intercostal space.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large tumor of the left hematological origin, likely originating from the diaphragmatic tumor and invading the liver, with differential diagnoses including metastatic disease or other causes of liver injury. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the patient's history of cancer.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and the multidisciplinary team to assess the progression of the tumor and manage any potential complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a hepatologist for specialized care and a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of metastases is recommended.

S: The patient reports chronic inflammation around teeth #24, #25, and #34, with endodontic treatments on tooth #16. The patient expresses concern about tooth #12, which is causing pain and is hopeless.
O: The management plan includes a strategic extraction and implant placement for teeth #12 and #24-26, respectively. The implant procedure will involve bone augmentation, sinus floor elevation in the second quadrant, and placement of a 7-mm bone ring in tooth #28. Post-extraction, the site will be measured using a trephine from the maxgraft® bonering surgical kit, and treated with a 7 mm bone ring. The procedure will include bone grafting with an Ankylos Implant from Dentsply Sirona.
A: The primary diagnosis is advanced bone loss in tooth 12, with associated palatal and buccal bone loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tooth pain and inflammation, but these are less likely given the patient's history and surgical findings.
P: The treatment plan includes bone augments, sinuses floor elevation, and implant placements in regions #12. The treatment for tooth 12 will involve surgical preparation, fixation of a dental implant, and external sinus elevation with a bovine bone substitute and a collagen membrane from botiss biomaterials in Berlin. A cylindrical bone block will be used for the mandible area. The mandible will be covered with cerabone® and a Jason® membrane, and the mandibles will be addressed with a cylindrable bone block to ensure proper support and stability. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of asbestos exposure and recurrent diverticulitis, presenting with persistent left lower quadrant pain despite multiple courses of antibiotic therapy. He reports no improvement in symptoms since a CT scan showing fluid near the sigmoid colon, suggesting nonspecific colitis.
O: Initial CT scan showed nodularity of the mesentery. A PET scan showed multiple hypermetabolic mesenteric lesions in the left paracolic gutter and portion of the pelvis, suggestive of carcinomatosis. Colonoscopy showed severe diverticular diverticulation. Tumor marker serology was negative. During exploratory laparoscopy, the patient developed extensive peritoneal carcinoma with partial involvement of the right diaphragm. Post-surgical pathology confirmed malignant epithelial mesothelioma with peritoneum seeding.
A: The primary diagnosis is malignant mesothelial carcinoma of the colon, likely secondary to asbestos exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of colon cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) and cytoreductive surgery (CRS). The patient will be referred to oncology for further evaluation and management. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a lack of defecation. The patient underwent a colonoscopy revealing a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum, 45 mm from the anal verge. The tumor was diagnosed as stage IIIb rectal cancer, specifically cT4bN2M0.
O: Initial treatment with XELOX plus bevacizumab included neoadjuvant therapy (NAT) for the tumor. Post-treatment, the tumor showed a complete clinical response (cPR) to NAT. Subsequent surgical intervention included a SEMS (Niti-S Colonic Stent) 6 cm in length by 18 mm across the stenosis, followed by Laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy. Postoperative findings included moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, T3 (SS), INFb, ly1, v1, PN0, pPM(−), pDM(−) pRM(−, pN0), and stage IIA. Histopathologically, the cancer cells were organized by atypical cells with growth of fibrous tissue and inflammatory cell infiltration. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged 20 days post-surgery without recurrence.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated rectal adenoma with a history of stage IIIB. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and absence of recurrence postoperatively.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the tumor's response to NAT and adjuvant chemotherapy to manage recurrence risk. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response to the treatment and adjust as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended.

S: The patient, a 20-day-old female, presented to the neonatal intensive care unit with a chief complaint of poor oral intake. The patient has been swallowing only about 10 to 20 mL of formula per day for the last two days. The parent reports no decrease in urine output during the prenatal and immediate postnatal periods. There is no evidence of vomiting or diarrhea. The child was born at 38+2 weeks of gestation with a weight of 3380 g via cesarean section. There was no abnormal prenatal and postnatal findings. The mother reports that the child is the first child of healthy, nonconsanguineous Korean parents.
O: At admission, the patient's weight was 3100 g, length was 53 cm, and head circumference was 36 cm. Vital signs were within normal limits: heart rate 150 bpm, blood pressure 78/50 mmHg, respiratory rate 48 breaths/min, and body temperature 36.5 °C. Physical examination revealed both thumbs in palms, frontal bossing, prominent upper lip, high arched palate, sparse frontal scalp hair, and bilateral 5th finger clinodactyly. Initial capillary blood gas analysis showed severe metabolic acidosis with pH 7.16, pCO2 28.3 mmHG, pO2 42 mmH g, HCO3−17.3 mmol/L, and base excess 17.3 mg/L. Laboratory tests showed serum sodium at 113.3 mEq/L and potassium at 8.79 mg/dL.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe metabolic disease, likely secondary to dehydration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of infant lethargy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of 20 mL/kg normal saline intravenously for over 1 hour to monitor for dehydration and electrolyte balance. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and electrolytes will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on laboratory results. The family will be educated on the signs of dehydration and the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the baby's condition and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a male, presented with worsening left upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder, which began the day after an outpatient colonoscopy. He reported no active extravasation.
O: CT scan revealed a grade III splenic injury in the abdomen and pelvis. Hemoglobin levels decreased to 7.4 grams per deciliter over 24 hours. Angiography indicated a subcapsular blush, which indicated a need for a splenic artery embolization. The patient was discharged from the hospital the following day.
A: The primary diagnosis is a grade IV splenic hemorrhage, likely secondary to a previous colonoscopies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the stabilization of hemoglobin levels post-embolization and the absence of any active complications.
P: The management plan includes admission to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and management of the hemorrhage. Hemodynamic management will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and hemoglobin level, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on hemoglobin recovery. Postoperative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and hemodynamic support will be provided to the patient and his family. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a car electrician, presented with a displaced comminuted right middle third clavicle fracture, which required surgical intervention. The patient reported no routine medications or allergies.
O: Physical examination revealed a displaced fracture with clavicular shortening. An X-ray of the right shoulder showed a displacement of the fixation clavicles. The fracture was repaired with a right-sided Acumed Locking Clavicle Plate, and the patient experienced a breaking sound when picking up two packs of sugar, 1 kg each.
A: The primary diagnosis is a displaced right middle 3 clavic fracture with associated clavical shortening, likely secondary to a car accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dislocation such as a fracture of the clavice, but these are less likely given the patient's age, physical activity, fracture pattern, and expectations.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with a left-sided acumed LOCK Clavicular Plate. Postoperative care will include analgesia, immobilization in a sling, and physical therapy with a restricted range of motion of < 80° abduction. Physical therapy will be initiated with a limited range of movement of <80° abduction, followed by a follow-up examination in 2 weeks to monitor the fracture and the locking plate. The shoulder will be immobilized and monitored with analgesia and a sling. No lifting of heavy weights is recommended at this time.
E: The initial examination showed the fracture to be fixated by the locking plates. A subsequent X-Ray showed breakage of the plate and displacement of fracture. The reconstruction plan includes removing the fixation plate and replacing it with a new, longer fixation plate, using a cancellous bone graft to refill the fracture site. The broken plate will be sent for inspection. The recovery plan will involve surgical intervention to repair the fracture, with the patient advised to avoid heavy lifting.

S: The patient, with a history of asthma, presented with serious respiratory distress. He was initially managed in the ICU for status asthmaticus, requiring heavy sedation and paralysis. Despite these complications, the patient developed bilateral segmental pulmonary embolism (PE).
O: Initial CTA revealed bilateral segmented pulmonary emboli (PE) with mild RV dilatation and normal RV function. TTE indicated mild RV and RV dilation. The patient was treated with low molecular weight heparin, tracheostomy due to respiratory weakness, and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement. Post-PEG placement, he became acutely hypotensive with systolic blood pressures between 70 and 80 mmHg, requiring a 2-liter normal saline bolus. CPR was performed for 6 minutes, and he was transferred back to the ICUs. Arterial blood gas showed a pH of 7.05 and pCO2 of 77 mmHG. Initial treatment included 20 mcg/min of norepinephrine, 2.4 mL/hr of vasopressin, 300 mg of phenylephrine, 5mcg/kg/min dobutamine, and 40 ppm inhaled nitric oxide. Follow-up TTE showed severe decreased RV function with bulging of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral segmentated PE with severe RV strain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac arrest, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in RV function and the management of PE.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of cardiac function and RV function, with adjustments to anticoagulation as needed. The management of the PE and anticoatalytic therapy will be emphasized to address the underlying pulmonary condition. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are necessary to assess the progression of the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient reports increasing asthenia and feeling extremely weak and tired all the time. The patient has a history of renal cancer and kidney cancer.
O: Initial peripheral blood count revealed severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.3 g/dL, severe neutropenia with neutrophils at 600/μL, and normal platelet count at 168,000/μl. Diagnostic tests revealed B-ALL with normal karyotype, negative for BCR-ABL rearrangement, and immature B-cell origin. CT-scan revealed a 7.0 cm solid lesion on the inferior pole of the right kidney, clear cell carcinoma. Post-chemotherapy, the patient reached morphologic complete remission with MRD negativity, confirmed by clonal rearrangements of the IgH gene study. After a year and a half of sustained MRD negative, blasts were noted at the peripheral blood smear. PET-CT showed multiple lesions, including a large pancreatic one. Pancreatic endoscopic biopsy confirmed CD19+ and CD22+ lymphoid cells.
A: The primary diagnosis is B-all, with a differential diagnosis including renal cancer metastasis or EM-ALL localizations. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the remission and the presence of multiple lesions.
P: The management plan includes administration of Inotuzumab ozogamicin (IO) weekly to target B-AL. The treatment plan includes monitoring the patient's response to the drug and managing any side effects. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, referred for a renal angiogram due to uncontrolled hypertension, reports severe headaches and fatigue. The patient denies any history of smoking, drinking alcohol, diabetes, or atherosclerosis.
O: Physical examination and neurological examination were unremarkable. Neurological examination showed alertness, attentive, oriented, and oriented. Speech was clear and fluent with good repetition, comprehension, and naming. Muscle bulk, tone, reflexes, and sensory were normal. Renal Doppler ultrasound confirmed renal artery stenosis with a renal resistive index of 0.58. Laboratory tests showed normal complete blood count, cholesterol, lipid profile, and renal function with a serum creatinine of 119 μmol/L, normal left kidney size (9.6 cm by 4.8 cm) and normal renal function (total weight 9.6 x 10^9 cm). Renal DEEP was negative for renal stenosis, with renal resistives index 0.57.
A: The primary diagnosis is uncontrolled uncontrolled hypertension with associated uncontrolled blood pressure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uncontrolled hypertension such as chronic kidney disease or other chronic conditions, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continuation of current medications and close monitoring of renal function and blood pressure, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on ongoing evaluation and follow-up. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a cardiologist are recommended to manage hypertension and prevent further complications. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the prescribed medications and regular follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of hypertension and cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones, currently on losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. He reports a mild productive cough recently. He has a mild-productive cough.
O: Pre-operative vital signs were within normal limits with a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 168/85 mmHg, respiration rate of 18 times per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Post-operative labs showed normal heart rate and blood pressure, with a pulse rate of 75 bpm and SpO2 of 94%. Oral tracheal intubation was performed using a 7.5 mm endotracheal tube with a video-assisted intubating stylet. Mechanical ventilation was set at volume-controlled mode with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 10 times per min, and PEEP of 4 cmH2O. An arterial line was established through a radial artery for continuous beat-to-beat monitoring.
A: The primary diagnosis is mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma with complications including airway secretion and airway obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of vital signs post-surgery, with adjustments to the anesthesia as necessary. The patient will be closely monitored for signs of infection or complications during surgery. Follow-up care will include follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, diagnosed with microscopic hematuria and proteinuria during a school urinary screening at 10 years old, reports no edema or hypertension. The patient developed hypocomplementemia with serum CH50 levels at 24 U/mL, C3 at 21 mg/dL, and C4 at 19 mg/dl. No other complications were reported at the time.
O: Previous renal biopsies showed increased mesangial cells and matrix with a lobular pattern and thick glomerular capillary walls with double contours. The Masson trichrome stain showed subendothelial deposits and no tubulointerstitial change. Immunohistochemistry (PAP) showed lumpy C3 deposits along glomerularies, weak staining of IgA, IgG, and IgM, but no glomeruli were included in electron microscopic studies. The immune-enzyme method showed lump-like C3 deposit along the capillaries. The immunohistochemical method showed weak C3 staining, but there were no glomersuli in electron microscopy.
A: The primary diagnosis is MPGN type I, with differential diagnoses including systemic lupus erythematosus, thrombotic microangiopathy, and malignancies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in renal function and the absence of systemic involvement.
P: Continue current regimen of Prednisolone 60 mg daily for 4 weeks, gradually reduced to 15 mg on alternate days over a 1-year period. Monitor renal function closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of regular check-ups and reporting any new symptoms. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing a generalized tonic-clonic seizure on the left side. The patient has a history of benign breast lesion.
O: Physical examination revealed mild left pyramidal hemiparesis and upper motor neuron signs. MRI revealed a 16-mm right parafalcine, extra-axial lesion with homogenous contrast enhancement, surrounding vasogenic edema in the adjacent parietal and posterior frontal white matter. CT scan of the body showed pretracheal and precarinal lymphadenopathy, with no primary primary lesion elsewhere. Histological examination of the neoplastic cells showed moderately pleomorphic nuclei, predominantly spindle in outline, with occasional plump and polygonal forms and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical tests were positive for desmin, anaplastic lymphoma kinase 1 (ALK1), vimentin, and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA).
A: The primary diagnosis is an atypical meningioma with a differential diagnosis of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT). The differential diagnosis initially included a benign breast tumor, which was ruled out by histological examination.
P: The management plan included parasagittal craniotomy and Simpson grade-two excision of the tumor, with a small component of residual tumor adherent to the wall of the superior sagittal sinus. Post-surgery, the patient underwent successful surgical resection of the residual tumor. Ongoing monitoring and follow-up care are necessary to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks without other symptoms. The patient denies any other symptoms besides the pain.
O: Physical examination and biopsy of the pelvis revealed a large mass extending from the right side of the uterine body to the adnexal region, solid and hypoechoic with sound attenuation. Serum levels of carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen 19-9, and carbohydrate antigen 125 were within normal ranges. CT and MRI showed a large solid mass with cystic areas, high signal intensity relative to the myometrium, and low signal intensity in T1-weighted MRI, with small areas of hyperintensity and a large cystic component. Diffusion-weighting imaging showed high signal intensities relative to that of the endometrium. Early-phase contrast-enhanced fat-saturated T1 and delayed-phase 3D imaging showed the mass with marked high signal and slightly high signal. Microscopy revealed multiple small cystic spaces containing mucinous fluid or hemorrhage, ovarian stromal intervening fibrous tissues, and vascular spaces.
A: The primary diagnosis is an endometrioma with a malignant tumor, possibly clear cell carcinoma or endometrial carcinoma. Differential diagnoses could include other malignant tumors or malignant malignancies. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the malignancy.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential surgical intervention to address the malignant nature of the mass. Further treatment options will be discussed, including surgical intervention, chemotherapy, and possibly radiation therapy depending on the tumor's response to therapy. Patient education on the nature of her condition and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a painless mass on the head for approximately one year, located under the midline parietal-occipital scalp.
O: Radiographic examination revealed erosion of the skull bone underneath the mass. MRI indicated a large parasagittal tumor with homogenous contrast enhancement, suggestive of hypervascular status. Angiography confirmed dense stains with distorted vessels in the same location. Post-surgical histopathology confirmed the tumor as a plasmacytic type plasmatetoma with positive lambda stain. No evidence of residual tumor, skeletal involvement, or tumor cells in bone marrow biopsy.
A: The primary diagnosis is a plasma plasmatic tumor with a history of meningioma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes total tumor resection with no evidence of recurrence or systemic progression.
