The patient will continue to be monitored closely with regular follow-up visits to assess for any recurrence of the disease or progression of symptoms. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient's response to treatment and response to therapy.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a 30 pack-year history of smoking, presenting with symptoms of fatigue, cough, and weight loss. She reports a history of hypercalcemia.
O: Chest CT revealed an 8.6 cm right upper lobe lesion with mediastinal invasion, extensive cervical and mediastal adenopathy, and malignant pericardial effusion. Biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, TTF-1/NAPSIN negative, staged as stage IV cT3N3M1b, with hypercalcymia as a paraneoplastic complication. Initial treatment included palliative PT-DC with carboplatin and gemcitabine, followed by maintenance gemcitibine. After a transient partial response, the patient developed oligo-progressive disease in a celiac lymph node, which was resected with continuation of immunotherapy. A follow-up imaging showed complete response with recurrence of disease.
A: The primary diagnosis is squamous carcinoma of the right lung, stage IV of the lung, with differential diagnoses including other forms of lung cancer. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient's history.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring and supportive care for the disease. The patient will continue to be educated on the signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the disease progression and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on recognizing symptoms of potential complications and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing a burning sensation on the right side of the tongue for about a month. The patient has a 30-year history of chewing betel nuts, averaging around 10 betel nut daily. The pain is associated with a family history of oral cancer, which passed away 15 years ago.
O: Intraoral examination revealed a tender, firm, 2 × 2.5 cm ulcero-proliferative growth at the right lateral border of the right tongue, with normal tongue movements. A 1 × 1 cm tender, solid, ovoid lymph node was noted in the right submandibular region. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) confirmed infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) involving the right medial border of a tongue. Biopsy confirmed infiltrated squamous cells carcinoma, stage III - T2 N1 M0.
A: The primary diagnosis is infiltrating SCC with a secondary stage of stage III-T2-N1-M0. Differential diagnosis initially included proliferative verrucous leukoplakia, which was ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is guarded due to the stage of SCC and the absence of distant metastasis.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options and starting the treatment as soon as possible. The management will include close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and supportive care. The treatment plan will include referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the SCC. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a fever that started on the forearms a few days ago, now spreading to the lower extremities, shoulder, and back. The rash has been present for 4 days. The patient also experiences a dry cough and mild itching on the chest.
O: Physical examination revealed a WBC count of 16.7 × 10^3/µL with an AEC of 1600 cells/�µl. Biopsy of the posterior right arm revealed dermal edema and subepidermal vesicle with fibrin and irregular brown pigmentation. Coccidioidal serology showed weakly reactive ID-IgM and ID-G with a CF antibody titer of less than 1:2. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates on the left lower lobe, suggesting a dry-cheeked rash.
A: The primary diagnosis is a maculopapular rash with respiratory involvement, likely secondary to dry cough. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and itching, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and symptom progression. The management includes regular follow-up appointments to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to a dermatologist for specialized care and a pediatric infectious disease specialist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing a popping sensation followed by heat and pressure at the base of the skull starting at age five, which began when the patient suddenly rotated their head. The sensation occurs approximately five to ten times a year, with a decrease in frequency as the patient ages. The patient also experiences numbness in the back of the tongue and difficulty speaking for approximately 15 seconds. The symptoms have decreased in frequency with age, with increased frequency during competitive fencing and military training. The family history includes no significant past medical, surgical, or developmental issues.
O: Physical and neurologic examination were normal. Cranial nerve exam was normal. MRI of the cervical spine showed slight dysplastic enlargement of the anterior arch of the C1 vertebrae, mild degenerative changes of the atlantoaxial junction, and the spinal canal caliber on the lower end of normal limits. No abnormal bone spurring or abnormalities of the hypoglossal canal were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is a cervical spine injury, likely secondary to a congenital malformation, given the cranial nerve findings and MRI findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cervical spine compression, but these are less likely given the MRI findings and imaging characteristics. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of any significant abnormalities.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's neurological status and neurological status closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment to reassess the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or worsening of the condition. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the spinal cord injury.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old male with a history of Guillain-Barré syndrome, presenting with a fever of 39.5°C, paresthesia in feet, difficulty walking, and a fall from his own height. He reports dyspnea, pneumonia, and persistent muscular pain.
O: Initial laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 14.0 g/dL, creatinine at 0.72 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dl), creatininine levels, and serology tests positive for Zika virus. On June 30th, the patient developed acute respiratory insufficiency type II, necessitating mechanical ventilation with mechanical ventilation. Cerebrospinal fluid showed increased protein (191mg/dL) with normal cell count. Blood cultures for bacteria or fungi were negative. Blood tests for toxoplasmosis, herpes, varicella, and HIV were negative, and serum serological tests were negative for Zika. During the ICU stay, he developed septic shock of undetermined focus, treated with vasoactive amines and intravenous antimicrobials.
A: The primary diagnosis is Guilliain- Barré syndrome with complications including acute respiratory failure and complications from the infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with intravenous immunoglobulin therapy and monitoring of hemoglobin levels. The patient will continue to be monitored for response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports feeling nervous about undergoing prostate surgery. He expresses concern about the procedure and the potential for complications.
O: A CT angiogram revealed a 3.2cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with dissection extending distally involving both common iliac arteries. The patient underwent a minimally invasive procedure for the procedure, using the Endologix AFX2 bifurcated AAA endograft system. The stent-graft was patent with no evidence of endoleak.
A: The primary diagnosis is an infrareneal abdominal Aortic Aneurysmal (AAA), complicated by uncontrolled hypertension. The prognosis is good with appropriate management of hypertension and diabetes management.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the patient's blood pressure and hypertension levels, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and preparing for prostate surgery with regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any signs of complications. The plan includes regular monitoring of blood pressure, hypertension, and diabetes to manage hypertension. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and lifestyle modifications will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing central vision loss in the right eye for approximately 2 weeks. The patient denies any history of previous medical or family history of eye problems.
O: Initial visual acuity was 1.2 OU with no refractive error. Slit-lamp examination showed no abnormalities in both eyes. Funduscopic examination revealed a wedge-shaped dark reddish lesion at the macula in the left eye but no abnormal findings in the other eye. EDI-OCT showed loss or disruption of the interdigitation zone (IZ) at macula, but normal findings in left eye. Fluorescein angiography and indocyanine green angiographic showed initial geographic hypofluorescence corresponding to the lesion. Humphrey threshold 10–2 perimetry showed decreased central sensitivity.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute visual impairment (AMN) in the affected eye, with differential diagnoses including other causes of vision loss and macular abnormalities. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in the lesions and the absence of any specific treatment.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to monitor for any changes in vision. No specific treatment is planned at this time, but the patient is advised to monitor the condition closely and report any changes. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing flatulence and epigastric discomfort over the past few months. The patient denies any history of illness, family history of illnesses, smoking, alcohol use, or medication use.
O: On admission, the patient was afebrile with a blood pressure of 126/84 mmHg, pulse rate of 75-80 beats/minute, and temperature of 36.8 °C. Laboratory tests showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase levels. CT scan revealed a 24 cm mass in the greatest dimension (23.7 cm × 16.5 cm × 11.5cm) originating from the right adrenal gland, compressing the right hepatic lobe and inferior vena cava. Functional adrenal work-up including serum aldosterone, potassium, renin, adrenocorticotrophic hormone levels, dexamethasone suppression test, and 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels were within reference ranges. Fine-needle core biopsy was negative for metastases. Postoperative pathology confirmed ACC.
A: The primary diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC), confirmed by imaging and biopsy results. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of adrenal tumors, but these were ruled out by biopsy and imaging. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of metastatic disease.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or recurrence of the disease. Further adjuvant therapy may be considered if there is no improvement in symptoms or progression. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S:

S: The patient, a 6-month-old female, presented with symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea. The parent expressed concern about her symptoms and suggested starting antibiotic therapy.
O: Initial tests revealed anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Serum vitamin B12 levels were normal, but serum homocysteine was elevated at 53 µmol/L. Igochemical tests showed megaloblastic changes and vacuolization in bone marrow aspiration. Immunological evaluation revealed hypogammaglobulinemia, low levels of antibodies, and normal lymphocyte subsets. Molecular analysis identified a c.1106+1516_1222+1231del mutation, which is not listed in the Human Gene Mutation Database.
A: The primary diagnosis is a genetic deficiency of TC, likely due to a genetic mutation. Differential diagnoses could include sepsis or metabolic disease, but these are less likely given the immunological findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in hematological response and the absence of a speech deficit.
P: The management plan includes treatment with intramuscular Vitamin B12 and oral folic acid to address hematologic issues. The patient will continue to be monitored for response to the treatment and any potential complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education regarding the nature of TC and its implications will be provided to the parents to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 76-year-old male with a history of well-controlled hypertension and coronary artery disease, reports progressive shortness of breath for the past two weeks, worsening. He has been on a 4 L nasal cannula for oxygenation.
O: Vital signs show a blood pressure of 238/146 mm Hg, heart rate of 75 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 80%. Physical examination reveals pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds without murmurs or gallops, marked jugular venous distension, diminished breath sounds at the bases, and mild bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. EKG shows low voltage, chest radiograph shows enlarged cardiac silhouette, bilateral moderate pleural effusions, and echocardiogram indicates a moderate to large pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. Right heart catheterization shows severely elevated right-sided pressures and equalization of right atrial, right ventricular, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressures. Serum tests indicate effusion of 1200 cc of bloody fluid.
A: The primary diagnosis is a moderate-to-large pericardial effusion, likely contributing to the patient's symptoms of shortness and breathlessness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac rhythm changes, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes a labetalol drip to control blood pressure. The patient will continue on a pericardoocentesis regimen to manage the effusion. Continuous monitoring of cardiac function and blood pressure will be necessary, with adjustments to medications as necessary based on the patient’s response to treatment. Further consultations with cardiology and possibly a cardiology specialist may be necessary depending on the progression of the effusions and response to therapy. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the medication regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient, with a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, biatrial anastomosis, bicaval anastomyosis, and pacemaker lead revision, reports a history including transplant vasculopathy, ESRD, ehrlichiosis, cryptococcal pneumonia, and histoplasmosis. The patient has undergone multiple heart transplants and has undergone pacemaker leads revision. In 2013, the patient experienced syncope, subarachnoid hemorrhage, sinus node dysfunction, intermittent sinus bradycardia, and a heart rate of less than 20 beats per minute. Three years later, the pacemaker was placed with a Medtronic ADDRL1 pacemaker and two leads, with the active fixation lead unstable. The pacemaker's undersensing was noted, leading to asynchronous ventricular pacing, and failure to recognize atrial arrhythmias.
O: Initial examination revealed volume overload, which led to pacemaker placement with a pacemaker led by Medtronics ADDRl1. An atrial lead extraction was performed, and the patient was diagnosed with cryptogenic encephalopathy, likely related to subclinical cirrhosis. No change in lead position was detected on chest X-ray.
A: The primary diagnosis is cryptogenic etiocytosis secondary to pacemaking, likely exacerbated by pacemaker implantation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure and cardiac arrhythmia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of cardiac function and cardiac function. The management of cryptogenic infection and cryptogenic symptoms is crucial, with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and manage any potential complications. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to medication regimen is crucial. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the cryptogenic disorder is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of choledochoduodenostomy for a bile duct stone and extensive small intestine excision 32 years ago due to strangulation ileus, reports a residual small intestine of 16 cm post-excision and long-term intravenous hyperalimentation. Recently, the patient has experienced liver dysfunction. The patient has a significant smoking history of 10 cigarettes a day for 45 years and sometimes drinks.
O: Physical examination revealed a scar from the midline incision but no tenderness. Laboratory findings showed elevated AST at 55 IU/L, ALT at 57 IU/l, LDH at 317 IU/dL, γGTP at 445 IU/mL, and ALP at 1067 IU/ml. Liver infection and hepatitis B and C tests were negative. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a papillary mass 40 × 30 mm brighter than the surrounding liver tissue in the left hepatic duct and dilated distal left intrahepatic Bile duct, with dilated liver tissue and lymph nodes. Abstinence enhanced CT showed a mass 40 x 30 mm in the liver and a lymph node of 12 mm. FDG-PET indicated abnormal accumulation in the hepatocytes.
A: The primary diagnosis is liver dysfunction secondary to a biliary obstruction, likely secondary to the biliary dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of liver function and liver function. Treatment options will be considered based on the patient's response to treatment and the findings of liver pathology. The management of liver disease and liver dysfunction will be emphasized, with regular follow-ups to assess the progression or resolution of the liver dysfunction and liver disease. Education on the importance of follow-up and monitoring for any new symptoms or changes in the patient will be provided.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, presents with a chief complaint of an unerupted permanent right maxillary central incisor affecting her self-esteem. She reports being constantly bullied at school due to her unesthetic smile. The patient denies any history of medical illness and has no history of trauma to teeth or jaws.
O: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment with a dental specialist to discuss potential treatment options. No history of dental trauma or trauma is reported. The family is advised to contact the healthcare provider if any further questions or concerns arise.
A: The primary diagnosis is a permanent left maxillary incisors, likely exacerbated by the patient's unesthetic appearance. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of dental malignancies, but these are less likely given the family's history and lack of significant medical history. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the incisores.
P: The treatment plan includes referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management. The plan includes discussing the possibility of further treatment options to improve the patient’s self-confidence and improve self-worth. Education on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old male with a history of stage 1 squamous cell carcinoma, diagnosed 3 years ago. He reports complications from previous surgeries including partial right upper alveolectomy and obturator reconstruction. He experienced a local recurrence two years post-surgery and underwent a definitive upper alvolectomy. He denies any history of radiation or adjuvant therapy.
O: The current reconstructive options include an osteocutaneous radial forearm or fibula flap, depending on the final intraoperative defect size. The patient has not discussed these options with his surgeon but plans to have a meeting with them soon to discuss all the available options and their pros and cons.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage 1 Squamous Cell carcinoma with complications including recurrence of the local recurred recurrence and subsequent surgical intervention. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of recurrence such as malignancy or metastatic disease. The prognosis depends on the success of the reconstruction and the management of the recurrence.
P: The management plan includes discussing the reconstruction options with the patient and discussing the pros and potential cons of each option. The plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment to discuss the options and the potential outcomes. Referral to a radiation specialist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Education on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for recurrence is crucial.

S: The patient reports experiencing occasional pulling pain in the left side, nausea, and a low-grade fever since May. The patient has a history of NSC.
O: Physical examination revealed a cyst in the spleen. Kasoni and ELISA tests for Human Cystic echinococcosis were negative. A percutaneous puncture and MWA of the splenic cyst were performed, with normal blood and urine tests. Ultrasonography and CT scan of the abdominal organs showed a spleen of 20 x 10 cm with clear, even contours and a homogeneous structure, and an upper pole cyst measuring 7.5 x 7.0 x 5 cm with no septa or additional inclusions. No signs of color Doppler mapping were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is NSC, confirmed by imaging and surgical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spleen pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention under intravenous anesthesia with Propofol 150 mg and Phentanylum 0.2 mg. The catheter will be used for the procedure. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of sigmoid colon cancer diagnosed post-sigmoidectomy. He reports multiple metastases in the liver, specifically in S3, S4, S6, and S8. He underwent eight cycles of adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, oxaliplatin, and panitumumab, completing all the cycles. Post-treatment, he experienced side effects but was manageable.
O: Initial abdominal CT showed remarkable shrinkage of liver tumors, with a 44% decrease in tumor sizes. Subsequent chemotherapy with FOLFOX and panitiumumum was administered, leading to a partial response with a reduced tumor size of 10% and a 10% decrease of target lesions. Postoperative findings included a confluent multinodular growth in the hepatic lesion, which was resectable 15 months post-surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic liver cancer with complications including liver metastases and a confluence multinodermal growth. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of liver cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful response to the current chemotherapy regimen and the absence of complications.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow up appointments to monitor for any new or worsening symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately.

S: The patient reports a swelling around the upper left second molar and bone exposure. The patient has a history of excisional biopsy twice previously, which was ruled out as osteoma. The swelling and bone exposures are consistent with the patient's current condition.
O: Clinical examination revealed maxillary bone exposure without pain. CT scan showed a diffuse radiopaque lesion around the alveolar cortical bone surface of the maxilla, spanning from the first molar to the second. Biopsy showed necrotic bone without atypia. The lesion has enlarged during the observation period. T1-weighted fat-suppressed MRI showed heterogeneous contrast-enhanced masses and hypointense areas corresponding to mineralized areas. Histopathological assessment indicated dense atypical spindle cell proliferation and focal cartilage formation with mild atypias. Immunohistochemical staining showed diffuse expression of β-catenin and α-smooth muscle actin in atypic spindle cells.
A: The primary diagnosis is osteoma of the left buccal region, with differential diagnoses including other forms of osteoma or malignancy. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of the lesion's enlargement.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options considering the patient has undergone multiple surgeries including biopsies, debulking surgeries, and immunohistochemistry to assess the extent and nature of the disease. The management will include close monitoring of bone function and response to therapy. Patient education on the nature of osteomyelitis and the importance of regular follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient’s response to treatments and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient reports a chief complaint of bulging in the right eye for the past 8 months, accompanied by tearing up. The patient has a family history of breast cancer, high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes, and no other endocrine issues. The symptoms have been consistent with exophthalmia and epiphora.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests are planned to determine the cause of the symptoms. No other family members with endocrine conditions or other medical issues are reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is exophththalmia with epiphorosis, likely secondary to hormonal imbalances. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular bulging, but these are less likely given the patient's personal medical history and family history.
P: The management plan includes admission to the Endocrinology Department for further evaluation and treatment. A thorough examination and tests will be conducted to determine if the patient has any underlying endocrine or hormonal conditions. The medical team will be involved in the management of the patient’s symptoms and any potential complications. Further consultations with an endocrinologist and a gynecologist will be arranged.

S: The patient is a 23-year-old male from Cameroon presenting with acute-onset, right-sided scrotal pain and swelling. He denies any prior sexual activity, discharge, hematuria, fevers, night sweats, weight loss, or cough. He reports persistent epididymitis, which was treated with ceftriaxone and doxycycline, but symptoms recurred after 6 weeks.
O: Initial urinalysis showed pyuria. Follow-on culture was negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) was negative. Repeat ultrasounds showed persistent epididymis. A 30-day course of ciprofloxacin was administered, which improved symptoms but did not resolve the swelling. Contrast CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed complex right-side scrotals, enlarged prostate, enlarged juxtaesophageal lymph node, and right lung apical nodular scarring. Post-orchiectomy, the epididysis was enlarged (6.0 × 1.7 × 1 cm), caseating necrosis and miliary deposits within the testicle and epididies, and a large scrotary abscess. Histologic sections showed diffuse necrotizing granulomas with giant cell formation in the scrotum, testis, and epidids. Tests for acid-fast bacilli were positive.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute epididymalitis, complicated by the presence of a large, diffuse necrosis in the testicles, and the presence and progression of a scrotous abscess, likely secondary to tuberculosis. Differential diagnoses considered TB were considered but ruled out based on imaging and histologic findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage infection. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for any changes in symptoms. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided. Referral to a nephrologist for specialized care and a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the abscess is recommended.

S: The patient reports severe headaches and visual loss, along with primary amenorrhoea and galactorrhoeas. The patient has a history of recurrent apoplectic suprasellar tumors, which have been managed with cabergoline.
O: MRI findings revealed an apoplectal suprassellar tumor with prolactin levels at 10,919 miU/L. Post-treatment, the patient experienced no improvement in vision. A 6-year follow-up post-treatment showed no recurrence. Histology confirmed pituitary apoplexy with prolactic expression of prolactins in a diffuse pattern, and Ki67 proliferation index was low.
A: The primary diagnosis is an Apoplectic Surgent Surgen Syndrome (ASS) with associated pituitar apoplechitis. The prognosis is good with no recurrences noted.
P: The management plan includes continuation of cabergol and regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and detect any recurrence of symptoms. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-on care is crucial. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of ASS is recommended.

S: The patient reports feeling fatigued for the past 2 months and has unintentionally lost approximately 60 pounds. The patient has been experiencing symptoms of fatigue and weight loss for approximately 2 months.
O: Laboratory tests revealed AIHA, C3 positivity, elevated immunoglobulin (Ig)G, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low haptoglobin, elevated reticulocyte count, elevated RDW-CV (red blood cell distribution width-corpuscular volume), positive direct Coombs test, thrombocytopenia, and proteinuria. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body. Bone marrow biopsy of the left posterior superior iliac spine showed plasma cell myeloma greater than 80% of marrow elements. Flow cytometry showed monoclonal plasma cells with cytoplasmic kappa light chain restriction and characteristics of CD19 neg, CD20 neg, BUN, CD38 bri, CD45 dim to neg, and cKappa mod. Serum protein electrophoresis confirmed monoclanal gammopathy with IgG-K. Quantitative IgG was 7468 with very low IgA and IgM, markedly elevated Kappa free light chain 1879, and elevated β-2-microglobulin 6.99. Cytogenetics were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute myeloid leukemia (ES) with associated complications including myeloproliferative disease (IbP), lymphoma, and bone marrow involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma or bone marrow tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess response to the treatment and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen and follow-ups to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a survivor of laryngeal burns sustained during a house fire, presented with a severe breathy voice and a cough. The patient also reported difficulty breathing and a voice that sounds strange.
O: Initial examination revealed severe breathlessness and a coughing. Laryngoscopic examinations revealed vocal fold movements not as they should be, non-vibrating portion of the vocal folds, and micro-vibration in the mucosa of the entire vocal folds. Digital kymography (DKG) and two-dimensional DKG were performed, and acoustic analysis identified cepstral peak prominence (CPP), low-to-high frequency spectral ratio (L/H spectral ratio), and mean CPP F0. The CPP is a measure of harmony within voice signals, and the L/H spectrum ratio is the mean ratio of signal energy below 4,000 Hz for selected voice frames. auditory perceptual assessment using the GRBAS scale indicated significant dysphonia.
A: The primary diagnosis is larynx damage due to larynal burns, likely exacerbated by the house fire. Differential diagnoses could include post-traumatic stress disorder, given the severity of the symptoms and the absence of mucosal waves.
P: The management plan will focus on addressing the larynarynx and improving voice quality. Psychological counseling will be provided to help cope with post-trauma stress. Referral to a speech therapist for support and psychological counseling will also be arranged. The treatment plan will include supportive care for post-surgical recovery and psychological support to cope with the trauma. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a book binder, reports experiencing sensory disturbance, numbness, and severe neuropathic pain in the index finger, which began 2 weeks ago. The patient has experienced hypoesthesia in the thumb, index, middle, and little fingers.
O: Physical examination revealed a wound scar near the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of the ulnar side of the index, consistent with the injury. Tinel's sign was noted. No radiological findings suggested a fracture. The index finger's range of motion was significantly restricted due to the neuropathy.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe neuropathy, likely exacerbated by the injury, given the location of the wound scar and the severity of the pain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neuropathy such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes performing a sensory nerve conduction study (NCS) to further understand the extent of the injury and identify potential causes of nerve conformation issues. This will involve stimulating the digital nerve and collecting SNAPs from the forearm just above the median nerve using a surface electrode. The NCS will be used to determine the best course of action based on the results of the NCS. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male obese who injured his left knee after jumping from 3 stairs. He reports significant pain and limited range of motion post-fall, limiting his ability to bear weight. He expresses concern about the severity of his injury and the impact on his left leg.
O: Physical examination revealed swelling and bruisedness over the tibial tuberosity and lateral joint line, with no signs of compartment syndrome or neurological or vascular injury. X-ray radiographs and CT scan revealed a Watson-Jones type IIIB avulsion fracture of the tibia apophysis. A CT scan showed a step of the articular surface more than 2 mm extending to the posterior-lateral epiphyseal part of the proximal tibia, also known as the lateral tibia plateau.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right-sided avulsion fractures of the right tibia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee pain and swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and CT findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity and complexity of the injury.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention under general anesthesia to repair the avulsion. The patient will be prepped and draped with an anterolateral approach, with an incision starting from the lateral upper border of the patella to 10 cm down. The deep fascia will be opened anterior to the iliotibial tract to access the fracture. Post-operative care will include follow-up care and rehabilitation to manage recovery and prevent further complications. The surgery will be performed under general care with instructions for postoperative care and recovery. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a postoperative scar near the hairline, described as a long, straight hairless line approximately 20 cm long and 1 cm wide. The patient has a history of a forehead reduction surgery approximately one year ago, which resulted in the creation of the scar.
O: Physical examination revealed the scar as a 20 cm straight, 1 cm long hairless scar. The surgical procedure involved harvesting 700 follicular units (FUs) from the scalp and transplanting them at a density of 35 FUs per square centimeter into the scarred area. A 12-month follow-up visit showed a graft survival rate of approximately 80%. The patient scale score may decrease from 10 to 6, and the observer scale score from 8 to 4.
A: The primary diagnosis is a post-facial linear hairless area, likely due to the absence of a postpartum scar. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hair loss, but these are less likely given the specific nature of the hair transplantation.
P: The management plan includes scheduling a consultation with a hair transplant specialist to assess the patient's scalp and determine the best approach for the hair transplation procedure. The procedure will involve harvesting hair follicles from another scalp, usually the occipital area, and transplantation into the area. Postoperative care will include monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications, and regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports persistent untreated conjunctivitis in the right eye. He has a history of hypertension treated with amlodipine and furosemide, primary open angle glaucoma treated with Timolol 0.5%. He has undergone ectropion surgery on the right lower lid lateral tarsal strip five years ago, bilateral cataract surgery with IOL implantation and YAG-laser capsulotomy, and aponeurotic ptosis in the left eye.
O: Clinical examination shows best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) in the Right Eye at 0.7 logMAR (20/100). Intraocular pressure is 20 mmHg in the upper right eye and 15 mmHG in the lower left eye, with intraocular pressure of 20 mm Hg in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination reveals conjunctival hyperemia and inferior brownish non-granulomatous endothelial precipitates. Corneal fluorescein staining is negative. No pathological findings in the posterior segment.
A: The primary diagnosis is untreated conjunctureivitis with complications including corneal paracentral ulcer and fungal keratitis. Differential diagnoses could include viral etiologies, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and imaging. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the condition and the need for perikeratic injection.
P: The management plan includes modifying the treatment regimen to 2 mg/ml topical voriconazole 1% 4 times daily and moxifloxacin 0.3% 6 times a day. The patient is advised to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist may be considered if the patient does not improve the condition.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, presented with a 5-day history of fever, melena, hematemesis, and haematuria with passage of blood clots. She did not experience abdominal pain or other warning signs of dengue.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be ill-looking, adequately hydrated, with a GCS of 15/15, blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg, pulse rate of 90 beats per minute, and capillary refilling time of less than 2 seconds. Lungs were clear, and abdominal examination showed soft and non-tender abdomen. NS1 and IgM tests were positive. Dengue PCR indicated a serotype of DEN 2. Ultrasound showed no plasma leaking. Liver enzymes were mildly elevated with AST 87 u/L and ALT 56 u/l. Complete blood count showed hemoglobin of 7 g/dl and platelet count of 17 × 10^9/μL.
A: The primary diagnosis is primary denguing fever with bleeding manifestations. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever such as infection or infectious processes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan included transfusion of 1 pint of blood and 4 units of platelets to improve hemoglobin levels. The patient was advised to rest, stay hydrated and take prescribed medications as directed. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor blood counts and liver enzymes, and the patient will be educated on the importance of hydration and medication adherence.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, presents with symptoms of angina pectoris persisting for 9 months.
O: Initial electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment depression in anteroseptal leads and pathological Q waves in inferior wall leads. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricle cavity size with good systolic function and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Left ventricular ejection fraction was 57%. Coronary angiography showed severe stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and a CTO in the right coronary artery (RCA). J-CTO score (3; re-try lesion, blunt stump type, presence of calcification, and occlusion length ≥20 mm) and PROGRESS CTO score (2; proximal cap ambiguity and absence of collaterals). RCA revascularization was complicated by a 3.5 mm × 18 mm biodegradable polymer drug-eluting stent, which was unsuccessful.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe stenotic coronary artery disease (CAD) with complications including CTO and CTO. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of arterial blockage, but these are less likely given the complexity and complexity of the coronary artery system.
P: The management plan includes exploring alternative treatment options, including a retrograde approach to treat the CAD and a septal 1 (S1) collateral channel. The patient will be closely monitored for response to treatment and potential complications. Further consultations with cardiology and possibly a cardiology specialist may be necessary to refine the treatment plan. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of adherence to prescribed medications will be provided.

S: The patient reports difficulty breathing during exercise since age 60, which has been bothersome. The patient has a history of running marathons in their 30s and has been aware of the condition since the 60s.
O: Physical examination revealed a complete left bundle branch block. Echocardiography revealed an enlarged RCA (10 mm) and a vessel with blood flow into the pulmonary artery (PA). Left ventricular ejection fraction was 60%, mild mitral regurgitation noted, and a coronary computed tomography (CT) indicated the LCA arose from the dorsal side of the PA, with dilated coronary arteries and tortuous coronary arteries. Cardiac catheterization showed a pulmonary/systemic blood flow ratio of 1.4, and pulmonary artery pressure (systolic/diastolic/mean) was 39/19/28 mmHg. Adenosine-loading myocardial scintigraphy indicated ischemia in the left anterior descending branch. Median sternotomy and cardiopulmonary bypass were performed, with the patient cooled to 32 °C during surgery. Post-surgery, the patient experienced cardiac arrest with an antegrade injection of cardioplegic solution from the ascending aorta.
A: The primary diagnosis is cardiac cardiac arrest secondary to a cardiopulmonary artery block. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac arrest, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and regular follow-up visits to assess recovery progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on signs of cardiac distress and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to an oncologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac issues is recommended. Further consultations with a cardiologist may be considered if cardiac arrest persists or worsens.

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and running a fever over 38 °C for 2 weeks. The patient has been diagnosed with obstructive pneumonia due to a tracheobronchial tumor.
O: Initial CT scans revealed an infiltrative shadow in the lower left lung field. Chest X-ray and CT imaging identified a solid left main bronchial and carinal tumor with carinal involvement. Bronchoscopy confirmed tumor infiltration into the esophagus and descending aorta, with tumor hemorrhage. Rigid bronchoscopopy confirmed the tumor occlusion of the left main stem bronchus and tumor hemorrhages. Pathological examination showed three typical histologies, with tracheal cartilage rings above the carina, and distal invasion of the tumor. FDG-PET scan showed abnormal enhancement in the tumor with a maximum uptake value.
A: The primary diagnosis is obstructive pneumonitis secondary to tracheotoxic tumor, complicated by trachotoxic lung disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bronchitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and management of the tracheo-adenoid cystic carcinoma. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the tumor's response to treatment and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a middle-aged male, presents with a chief complaint of fatigue, muscle aches, nausea, and a skin rash covering the left eye for the past 5 days. He denies experiencing double vision, pain with eye movements, flashing lights, floaters, or changes in color vision. He has been taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as needed. He also reports a malar rash and violet raised papules on elbows and knees, worsening with exposure to sunlight.
O: Physical examination reveals a right eye of 20/20 and a left eye 20/100. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Extraocular movements are conjugate and full, with no subjective red desaturation. The conjunctiva is white without dilated conjunctival vessels, and the cornea is clear. The anterior chamber shows no evidence of cell or flare bilaterally. Visual acuity tests indicate bilateral retinal vascular engorgement, scattered foci of inner retinal whitening consistent with CWS, and superficial hemorrhages in the peripheral retina. Triton Plus® SS-OCT shows light central macular edema in the right eye and severe central maculopathy in the left.
A: The primary diagnosis is CWS with associated bilateral retinopathy and peripheral macular degeneration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal degeneration, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with ophthalmology and ophthalmology may be necessary depending on the progression of the disease and response to therapy. Education regarding the nature of CWS and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a housewife with a history of 5 years of education and a husband with health issues, reports experiencing musical hallucinations (MH) starting suddenly six months ago during a stressful period. She denies any neurological illnesses, neurodegenerative disorders, or psychopathological conditions. The MH occurs mainly in the afternoon, with no emotional attachment or memories associated with these songs. The patient has been using bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses.
O: Clinical examination and neurological evaluation revealed a daily occurrence of musical hallucinations in different languages, with 3-4 current songs with no special preference. No auditory hallucinations were reported. No abnormalities were noted in the clinical interview or neurological evaluation.
A: The primary diagnosis is musical hallucinations, likely related to the onset of MH, with a differential diagnosis of auditory hallucinations, given the patient's history of hearing impairment and presbyacusis. The presence of auditory and visual hallucinations is noted, but these are less likely given the absence of auditory or visual disturbances.
P: The management plan includes conducting an MRI-PET exam to further investigate the nature of the auditory hallucinations. This will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will involve the use of bilateral mobile prostheses for the purpose of further evaluation. The consultation with an otolaryngologist is necessary for the study to be conducted, and the patient will be provided with written informed consent to proceed with the study. Further investigations may be used in an anonymous form if the patient agrees.

S: The patient reports multiple episodes of vomiting three days ago, accompanied by reduced urine output and shortness of breath for the past couple of days. The patient is conscious, oriented, and afebrile. He is tachypnoeic with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. He also exhibits engorged neck veins and bilateral pedal edema.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be conscious and oriented with a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg, pulse rate of 108/min, and tachycardia with bilateral pleural effusion and ascites. Laboratory tests indicate acute kidney injury (AKI) with a serum creatinine of 1.8, arterial blood gas analysis indicating Type I respiratory failure, sinus tachy cardia, and chest roentgenogram confirming bilateral pleurisy. Diagnostic pleural tap shows transudative picture. Blood culture and urine culture are sterile. Serum pro-calcitonin is normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney impairment (AKA) with complications including bilateral pleuretic effusion, ascites, and acute kidney failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injuries such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included resuscitation with IV fluid bolus, oxygen inhalation, and dual inotropes, followed by intravenous fluid infusion (IV fluid boluconate) and oxygen inhalations, and addition of empirical antibiotics. Treatment included intravenous fluids, oxygenation, dual inotropices (noradrenaline and dopamine), empirical antibiotics, and empirical antibiotics to stabilize the shock. Post-resuscitation, the patient showed improvement in renal function with restoration of adequate urine output within 24 hours. Discharge was scheduled in 3 days with stable vitals. Follow-up in psychiatry is crucial for addressing underlying issues related to the suicide attempt.

S: The patient, with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair with a Dacron Patch over a large ventricular septal defect, reports a 2-month history of fever, weight loss, and left-sided abdominal pain starting one week ago. The patient was previously treated with intravenous ceftriaxone.
O: Physical examination revealed grade IV clubbing without cyanosis, no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis, and a loud pansystolic murmur on the left sternal edge and tenderness on palpation of the left upper abdomen. Initial investigations showed high white blood cell count and elevated C-reactive protein. Chest X-ray showed left mid and right lower lung zone infiltrates. Ultrasound showed an ill-defined splenic lesion without internal vascularity. Blood cultures were negative. Echocardiogram showed vegetation on the VSD patch, dehiscence, large VSD, and moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction. CT abdomen showed multiple liver, splenic, and lung abscesses, an infarcted left kidney, and thrombus at the bifurcation of the aorta secondary to septic embolic phenomenon. Postoperative echocardogram showed mild left ventricular dysfunction and moderately reduced right ventricle function.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe septic pulmonary embolic syndrome secondary to a Dachron Patch repair. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of septic infections or other causes, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of the embolic process.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and regular follow-ups with cardiothoracic surgery to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Further diagnostic tests may be necessary based on the results of the latest tests. Patient education on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms is crucial. Referral to a cardiologist for specialized care and a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the septic process is recommended.

S: The patient reports a history of bilateral headaches persisting for over 10 years, which have progressively increased in frequency over the past year. The patient denies experiencing fever, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness, sensory or movement disorders, visual disturbances, facial palsy, aphasia, incontinence, or convulsions.
O: Vital signs and neurologic examinations were normal. Laboratory tests were unremarkable. MRI revealed a dilated posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle with a well-delineated oval mass measuring 1.3 x 1.2 × 1.0 cm, hypointense on T1-weight and T2-weight images, hyperintense on FLAIR images, with no enhancement following contrast administration. The lesion appeared hypointy on T2 and FLAIR imaging, with hyperintsense spots on T3-weight, and no enhancement post contrast administration, indicating an abnormal mass in the brain.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral headaches, likely secondary to an abnormal brain mass. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headaches, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful neurosurgery.
P: The management plan included surgical intervention with a stereotactic neuronavigator-guided ventriculoscopic procedure, which was successfully performed without further damage to the brain tissue. Postoperative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and detect any new or worsening symptoms. Further consultations with a neurologist and a neurosurgeon are recommended to manage the brain mass and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient reports coughing up blood and has a history of childhood in northern Iran raising sheep. The patient has been hospitalized for respiratory distress and hypoxia since admission.
O: Initial chest CT scan revealed a right lower lobe cyst measuring 9 by 11 cm. A repeat CT scan showed air within the pulmonary cyst with a floating wavy membrane at the air-fluid level, indicative of the camalote. An urgent lobectomy was performed due to the presence of a large ruptured cyst. Histopathology confirmed echinococcal scolices. Preoperative ecchinococcus enzyme-linked immunosorbent IgG antibody assay was negative. Postoperatively, the patient was feeling much better.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured right lower lobotomy with complications including echinocarcinoma, echinocytoma, and a rupture of the pulmonary artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress such as pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes prescribing a 4-week course of albendazole to ensure full recovery and to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms. The plan includes monitoring the patient's response to the medication and managing any potential complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a female with a history of left-sided ductal breast cancer treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, partial mastectomy, axillary lymph node dissection, and radiation therapy, presents with sudden onset of fever, shivers, and suspicion of an infection. She reports a recent episode of erysipelas in her left upper arm, treated with compression stockings, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and hypertension. She has a known systolic murmur but normal echocardiographs in 2011 and 2017.
O: Recent blood cultures showed growth of a bacterium belonging to the S. mitis group, with MIC values of penicillin 0.064 and 0.125 mg/L, vancomycin 0.25 and 0, and gentamicin 2 and 2 mg/l. No local portal of bacterial entry was identified.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent erysiphilic lymphadenopathy (ERPH) in the left arm, likely secondary to lymph node involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lymphadenitis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: Initiate treatment with compression stockingings and compression stocking. Monitor blood cultures closely to detect any new infections or new infections. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and ensure understanding of the treatment process. Consider referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of erphilic lymphosuppression.

S: The patient reports a history of back pain and worsening left lower extremity pain, which started after a fall from standing height a few months ago. The pain has been worsening over the past five months, with no recent fever or difficulty passing urine. The patient denies any history of malignancy or anticoagulant use.
O: Physical examination revealed full power and symmetrical reflexes in both lower extremities, but patchy reduction in sensation in the left lower limb. A left L5 nerve root block was administered for 3 days, but was ineffective. Platelet count and prothrombin time were within normal limits. Lumbar MRI without gadolinium showed a posterior mass at L4/5, isointense with hyperintense areas in the center and hypointense in the periphery, suspected to be a spinal tumor. A second MRI showed a newly isointed mass in the anterior part of the lesion, with a slightly extended hyperintensive area on T2-weighted imaging. No significant enhancement with gadolinia-based contrast was observed.
A: The primary diagnosis is a spinal malignant tumor, likely a spinal lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lower limb pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the spinal malignancies.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Consider additional imaging or treatment options if symptoms persist or worsen. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in the condition. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient is a 21-year-old African American male with a psychiatric history of schizophrenia, presenting with fever and tachycardia. He reports frequent hospitalizations due to nonadherence with his home medications. He denies experiencing pain, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of consciousness, or seizures.
O: Initial labs and urine toxicology were within normal limits. He was started on clozapine 25 mg twice daily and titrated up to 150 mg twice weekly over the next 12 days. On the medical inpatient unit, he was mostly selectively mute, with no signs of pain or vomiting. Physical examination revealed mild dehydration, no skin rash, jugular venous distension, basal crepitation, or pedal edema. Cardiac auscultative findings were largely normal except for a tachypnea, apex beat in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line, heart sounds S1 and S2, with normal heart sounds. Peripheral extremities were warm with a normal capillary refill.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe case of schizophrenia with complications including fever, tachyachycardias, and hypotension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress such as sepsis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient’s condition with adjustments to medication as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to his medication regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on his response to treatment. Further consultations with a neurologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progression of his condition.

S: The patient, with a history of profound intellectual disability, schizophrenia, posttraumatic stress disorder, Parkinson's disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and seizure disorder, presented with feverish, rapid heartbeat, nausea, and vomiting for three days. The patient was brought in from an assisted living facility.
O: On admission, the patient's vital signs were: temperature 102.5F, pulse 123 bpm, respiratory rate 40 bpm with O2 saturation 96% on room air, and blood pressure 154/84 mm/Hg. Imaging included chest X-ray with no evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease and an Electrocardiogram showing sinus tachycardia with possible right atrium enlargement and ventricle hypertrophy. Laboratory tests showed neutrophil 92.8% with absolute neutrophils 9.19 k/cmm, hemoglobin 12.8%, hematocrit 38.0%, atrial blood gas unremarkable. Initial lactic acid was 1.96 mmol/L, later increased to 2.63 mmol/l. Procalcitonin was at 0.32 ng/ml. Metabolic panel showed sodium 149, chloride 114, BUN 37 mg/dL, AST 136 mg/dl, ALT 43, urine ketones 40 mg/L. Urine culture was negative, blood cultures from admission were negative, influenza screen and viral PCR were negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis of unknown origin, likely secondary to catheterization. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress such as infectious or infectious causes. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Initiated treatment with vancomycin, levofloxacin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and haloperidol 2 mg daily. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient and adherence to the prescribed medications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a family history of seizures and tachypnoea, reports a typical development until age 14, when he developed generalized epilepsy. The patient has a history of high blood lactate levels and easy fatigability, which have led to tachycardia. The family history includes a mother with high lactate and a cousin with low pH.
O: Examination revealed elevated serum glucose (12.5 mmol/L) and lactate (9.4 mmol-L), with positive urine tests for glucose and ketones (3+ and 2+ ratings). Arterial blood gas analysis showed elevated lactate at 9.4 mg/L and low pH (7.23). Glycosylated hemoglobin A1 (HbA1c) level was 14.60%. The patient developed severe respiratory acidosis and respiratory failure type II, requiring intubation and artificial ventilation. Neurological examination revealed external ophthalmoplegia, mild limb weakness, and pyramidal signs. Laboratory tests showed elevated plasma lactate, pyruvate (D-3-hydroxybutyrate, 0.35 mmol/l), and glucose levels. Fasting plasma insulin and 30 min and 2 h post-prandial insulin values were 112.54, 298.03, and 73, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy, complicated by severe respiratory and respiratory complications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tachybral tachydomia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of blood glucose levels and electrolytes. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of metabolic disorders.

S: The patient reports severe long-term systemic lupus arteriosus (RSL) with side effects including sleep apnea and light obstructive sleep apneas. The patient has been previously treated with pramipexole and pregabalin, which were discontinued due to side effects.
O: Initial baseline sleep efficiency was low at 67%, with arousals (22/h) and short phases of wakefulness (6/h), with periodic leg movements score of 6/h, and an apnea-hypopnea index of 7.5/h. Follow-up PSG showed significant improvement in sleep efficiency from 67% to 90%, with a PLMS index of 1/h indicating very low sleep efficiency.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe RLS with complications including sleep-related complications including severe restlessness and sleeplessness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of RLS, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and the patient's history.
P: Continue current treatment with BP 50% tablets at four tablets per day (0-0-2-2) without changes in other medications. Monitor sleep architecture closely and adjust treatment as necessary based on clinical response. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance for adherence to it. Consider referral to a sleep specialist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports experiencing blurry vision in the left eye for the past 8 months, diagnosed with uveitis at another clinic. The patient has been receiving local and systemic corticosteroid for the inflammation.
O: Physical examination reveals fine keratic precipitates and an anterior chamber cell grade of 2+ in the right eye. The left eye has a vitreous cell grade 1+, and the left is a grade 2+. Fluorescein angiography shows leakage and hyperfluorescence in the Left Eye. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) is 1.2 in both eyes, and intraocular pressures (IOPs) are 16 mmHg in the same eye and 22 mmHG in the other eye. Non-ocular manifestations like oral ulcers and shoulder arthralgia are noted. No skin or genital lesions are reported. Tests for tuberculosis, tuberculosis, and syphilis were negative. Angiotensin-converting enzyme, antinuclear antibody, matrix metalloproteinase-3, and anti-citrullinated protein antibody levels are within normal limits. Colonoscopy shows no abnormalities.
A: The primary diagnosis is Behçet's disease, likely due to the patient's symptoms of blurry vision and the absence of skin and genital lesions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of eye inflammation and retinal vasculitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue current treatment with 0.1% dexamethasone eye drops four times daily, tropicamide/phenylephrine eye drops once a day, and 5 mg of prednisolone orally. Monitor the patient closely for any new symptoms or changes in condition. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male from Fars province in southern Iran, with a history of failure to thrive, fatigue, muscular dystrophy, generalized muscular atrophy, kyphoscoliosis, and flexion contracture of the knees and elbows. He reports a recent onset of motor symptoms starting at four years old, which worsened over time. He has a family history of similar symptoms, including nasal speech and sleep apnea. He started walking at 11 months, with no delays in motor milestones. The patient has a history with two previous admissions to the pediatric intensive care unit due to pneumonia and respiratory distress.
O: Physical examination reveals cachectic appearance with generalized muscular muscular atromurphy, decreased muscle power in shoulder-girdle muscles, foot extensors, limb muscles, a 4/5 MRC muscle scale rating, pes cavus and contracture, and rigid spine with a chin-sternum distance of 15 cm. Transthoracic echocardiography shows mild pulmonary hypertension and mild tricuspid regurgitation. Pulmonary function tests reveal FEV1 of 35% and FVC of 32%. Serum calcium and phosphorus levels are 8.2 mg/dL, respectively. Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) is elevated at 340 U/L and LDH is elevated to 1200 U/dL. Echocardography shows myopathic changes in deltoid, biceps, tibialis anterior, and rectus femoris muscles.
A: The primary diagnosis is muscular dystrophies, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of respiratory distress and muscle weakness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness and muscle dysfunction. The prognosis depends on the management of the muscular issues and response to treatment.
P: Continue current management of pulmonary hypertension with a BiPAP breathing machine. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-ups to monitor progress and manage any complications. Consider referral to a pediatric neurologist for specialized care and a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports severe redness and discharge in the left eye, which has been bothering him. The patient has been prescribed levofloxacin and fluorometholone instillation, which have been discontinued due to worsening symptoms.
O: Immunochromatography test results were positive for adenovirus, causing the redness, discharge, and blurred vision in the eye. One week after discontinuation, the patient's visual acuity improved to 10/20 in the right eye with mutton-fat KPs and multiple stellate keratitis. The anterior chamber of the eye showed no cells or flare.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute adenitis secondary to levofluozacin, with differential diagnoses including other causes of visual symptoms such as corneal retinopathy and corneas retinitis.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of levoflavoxacins and fluorotholone. The treatment plan includes monitoring the patient’s response to the treatment and discontinuing the instillation. The plan includes regular follow-up visits to assess the effectiveness of the therapy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate medical attention is provided.

S: The patient is a 57-year-old construction worker who tripped and hit his head on a flower pot, losing consciousness for approximately 10 minutes. He reports confusion, weakness on the right side, double vision, and difficulty speaking. He denies any seizure-like activity.
O: On examination, the patient was alert, oriented to time, place, and person, but exhibited dysarthria, ataxia, nystagmus, right-sided weakness, and hyperreflexia with positive Hoffman's bilaterally and up-going plantar response on the left side. Initial examination revealed dysarthriosis, atypia, atystagnmus, and right-side weakness with positive positive Hoffman’s bilaterally. No seizure-related activity was reported. Surgical findings included non-enhancing T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the brainstem and cerebellar peduncles, and periventricular white matter. MRI of the cervical spine showed no acute intracranial findings but showed degenerative changes at the C5-6 level.
A: The primary diagnosis is a cerebral spinal fluid injury (SBP) secondary to a mechanical fall. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral blood pressure, but these are less likely given the MRI findings and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the management of SBP and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's blood pressure with carvedilol 12.5 mg three times a day and labetalol as needed, with a goal of keeping SBP between 140 and 180 mmHg. The patient will be educated on the importance of medication adherence and compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S:

S: The patient is a 25-year-old non-smoker with a history of granulomatous lung disease (CVID), presenting with respiratory issues and feeling like her condition is progressing. She reports feeling short of breath and has been unable to improve her condition.
O: Physical examination and histological examination revealed lymphocytic infiltration of interstitial tissue, confirmed by histologic examination and T and B cells repertoire analysis. The patient's spleen was extended to the iliac crest, measuring 27 cm, and had subileus due to intestinal pressure. Laboratory tests showed progressive LPD with hyperviscosity, paraproteinemia, and high β2M and IgM levels. Respiratory functional study showed reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) of 60%, and low diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (49%). BAL, blood, urine, bone marrow, and sputum cultures were all free of bacteria, mycobacteria, actinobacterial, and fungi. BAL analysis showed an increase in total cell count, predominantly in neutrophils and lymphocytes, but without significant predominance of NKT cells.
A: The primary diagnosis is granuloma lung disease with complications including LIP progression, hypervascularization, and systemic infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory symptoms and systemic infections, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Continue current regimen of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) at 0.3 g/kg every 21 days and glucocorticoids (50 mg/daily) to manage IgG levels. Monitor serum sickness with high IgM-paraproteinemias and opportunistic infections, especially EBV reactivation, and adjust rituximab dose as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage side effects.

S: The patient reports a history of atopic dermatitis since 2 years old, aggravated for the past 4 years. Currently, the patient is on 250mg of cyclosporine, 5mg desloratadine in the morning, and 25mg hydroxyzine at night. The patient also uses moisturizing lotion and clobetasol propionate cream twice daily. Additionally, there is a significant history of allergic rhinitis, hypothyroidism, metabolic syndrome, and depression and insomnia.
O: Current medications include 50mg of levothyroxine sodium daily, 500 mg of metformin hydrochloride daily, and 50 mg of agomelatine daily and 5 mg of buspirone daily. Recent skin exam shows extensive eczema affecting 90% of the skin tissue, intense pruritus, dry skin, and a SCORAD score of 45, indicating severe atopic dermatitis (AD).
A: The primary diagnosis is severe atypical dermatitis with complications including severe eczemism, severe dermatitis (SCORAD), and severe dermatological conditions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dermatitis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes initiating mycophenolate mofetil, 1g every 12 hours, tapering off cyclocyanine, and monitoring for side effects such as weight loss, menstrual changes, and telogen effluvium. A new treatment plan will be discussed with my colleagues, and the patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and regular follow-up appointments. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the disease is recommended.

S: The patient's mother reports that her 8-month-old daughter, born at full term, has been experiencing developmental issues. The patient has a slow pupillary light reflex, hyporeflexia, and hypotonia in all limbs.
O: Cerebral MRI revealed widened ventricles, cisterns, and sulci indicative of delayed myelination. EEG results were normal. Urine organic acid analysis indicated increased excretion of GHB. A compound heterozygous mutation of c.1344-2delA/c.1529C > T in exons 9 and 10 in the patient's daughter was identified as a compound mutation in c. 1344, located in the intron splice site, and p.S510F in the NAD-binding domain.
A: The primary diagnosis is delayed Myelination with associated developmental delays. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delay, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation.
