S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and chronic back pain, presents with new symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has been diagnosed with a 7.2 cm aneurysm in the ascending aorta with a Stanford classification type A dissection.
O: Physical examination revealed a large, undiagnosed aneurage with Stanford classification. The procedure involved axillary cannulation via the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis, nicardipine and esmolol infusions, and an 18-gauge peripheral intravenous line in the right antecubital (AC) fossa. The left radial arterial line (AL), pulse oximeter, and noninvasive blood pressure cuff were placed. Intubation was performed with a right radial AL, left femoral AL, and a 9-French central line. The right radial mean arterial pressure (MAP) was increased to 200 mm Hg, and the left radial/femoral MAP decreased from 60 to 30 mmHg.
A: The primary diagnosis is an aneuried aortic aneuries with Stanford-class Stanford type A. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aneuryysm, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the absence of complications.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust the surgical plan as necessary. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Educate the patient on signs of infection or complications to watch for and ensure compliance with the treatment plan. Ensure compliance with follow up appointments and follow-ups to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as needed.

S: The patient, a 7-year-old male, has been experiencing seizures for the past 3 years. He has been on sodium valproate, clonazepam, and topiramate. The patient has been currently on tDCS treatment at 2 mA.
O: Physical examination revealed no lesions. An ictal video-EEG showed 14 episodes of esophageal dissection (ES), nodding, blinking, deviation of the right corner of the mouth, rapid lifting of the upper limbs, and a spike rhythm. The EEG pattern was typical for ES. The son underwent six blocks of tDCS therapy at two mA, with a seizure frequency of 7.68 ± 5.38 times per day. During the first 19 days of the second follow-up, the seizure frequency was 9.11± 5.49 times daily. The seizure frequency persisted for 6 months.
A: The primary diagnosis is esophagal disposition (ES) secondary to tDCS, evidenced by EEG findings and seizure frequency. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures, but these are less likely given the imaging and EEG findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive response to the current treatment regimen.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's seizure frequency and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and ensure understanding of the treatment process. Schedule regular follow-ups to assess response to treatment and adjust as necessary based on the patient response. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports progressive visual impairment in both eyes. The patient has a history of ophthalmologic examination showing best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of the right eye at 0.3 (-4.50) and left eye at 1.2 (-4).
O: The right eye's BCVA is 0.4 (-4), and the left eye's is 1.5 (+4). Slit-lamp examination shows clear cornea, calm anterior chamber, transparent lens, and normal corneal limbus. The optic discs appear normal on fundus examination, but there are extensive shiny white-yellow deposits in the posterior pole and mid-peripheral retina. An OCT in 2014 showed a central macular thickness of 194 µm in the right and 198 µm on the left, with hyperreflective intraretinal spots and plaque-like deposits at the RPE-Bruch's membrane junction. Intraretinal cystic spaces and outer retinal tubulation were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is BCD, evidenced by the absence of OCT in 2008 and the presence of hyperreflectivity and plaque deposits in both eye. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of BCD and manage any potential complications. Education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a retinal specialist may be considered if there is no improvement in BCD.

S: The patient is an 82-year-old African American female with a history of hypertension and a past surgical history, specifically a laparotomy 20 years ago. She reports nonspecific lower abdominal pain for a long time. She has a past medical history of laparoscopic surgery 20 years prior and has not seen a doctor in 10 years. She denies unintentional weight loss.
O: Physical examination revealed cachectic and dehydrated condition, mild right lower quadrant tenderness, microcytic hypochromic anemia, positive leukocyte esterase, and normal liver function tests. Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly. Abdominal ultrasound revealed mild ascites and a dilated common bile duct to 1 cm. Lab results indicated microcytoxemia and leukocytosis, with elevated CEA at 12.2 ng/ml. Echocardiography showed mitral stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension. Urine culture grew klebsiella.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory failure with complications including dehydration, failure to thrive, and possible gastrointestinal malignancy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in respiratory status and the absence of significant complications.
P: The management plan included admission to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for dehydration and further work-up for gastrointestinal malignment. The patient underwent an EGD and colonoscopy with gastroenterology, which were cancelled due to critical health status. A urine culture was performed, and the patient was transferred to the medical floor for further evaluation and management. Further treatment options will be discussed with the patient and her family.

S: The patient reports experiencing moderately severe headaches for four days, followed by a sudden severe headache. The headache was severe and was all over the head, accompanied by vomiting. The patient denies any history of trauma, fever, seizures, weakness of limbs, or loss of consciousness.
O: On examination, the patient's Glasgow Coma Scale score was 15, placing him at World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies grade I. A plain Computed Tomogram (CT) scan showed subarachnoid hemorrhage in the left sylvian fissure and interhemispheric fissures, a Modified Fisher grade 1 hemorrhage. A CT cerebral angiogram revealed a bilobed anterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 8x7x5 mm, with no evidence of other aneuriesms or vascular malformations. Postoperative complications included right pterional craniotomy and clipping of the aneurymal artery, which were uneventful. A controlled rupture during permanent clipping was noted, leading to temporary clipping.
A: The primary diagnosis is Modified Fisher Grade 1 hemorrhagic stroke (SAH) in the brain, with differential diagnoses including other forms of vascular malignancies. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the hemorrhage and the complexity of the underlying cause.
P: The management plan included antiedema measures, anticonvulsant, analgesic, and Nimodipine, which led to successful surgical intervention. Post-operative management included right-sided oculomotor nerve paralysis, which was managed with sphenoid drilling and clipping. The plan includes monitoring the patient closely for any signs of complications and adjusting antiepileptic therapy as necessary. Further consultations with a neurologist and a neurosurgeon are planned to assess the need for further surgical intervention and manage any potential complications.

S: 
- Pain in the abdomen, pain in the middle of the abdomen. No fever. No vomiting.
- No food. No blood.

O:  

A:  - The patient, a foreigner, presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a history of bowel cancer.
P: - The patient has been using an inhaler for the past three days. No new medication.
  - Denies fever.
 - No new medications. No history of food allergies.

S: The patient, with a history of ASD, developmental delay, and hypotonia, reports a birth history of grade five vesicoureteral reflux, dysplastic kidney on the left, absence seizures at 3 months of age, and subsequent seizures at 9 months. The patient has been on citalopram for depression treatment. There are no specific genetic or specific diagnoses.
O: Physical examination revealed delayed myelination. Brain MRI at two and a half years showed hypoplastic olfactory nerves, a Klippel-Feil anomaly, and incomplete myelin maturation in the inferior frontal lobes and temporal tips. Growth parameters were below the third percentile, hypotonic, and severe constipation, with no specific diagnosis. Clinical CMA, fragile X testing, and metabolic testing were normal. Genetic testing identified a de novo KMT2A frameshift variant c.6169del.
A: The primary diagnosis is Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS) with associated developmental delays and hypotonic symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD) or developmental delays. The prognosis depends on the progression of WSS and the effectiveness of current treatments.
P: Continue current medications and monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Maintain current medications as needed. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on ongoing assessments. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment regimen. Consider referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of ASD.

S: The patient, a young boy, presents with severe neurodevelopmental delays and epilepsy. He has a history of irritability and gastroesophageal reflux starting at three months old, which escalated to severe partial refractory epilepsy and tetraplegic cerebral palsy. The patient has not developed any form of language, eye-to-eye contact, or basic motor and social milestones.
O: Physical examination and imaging studies have been conducted to identify the cause of his condition. Cytogenetic and metabolic panels, including mucopolysaccharidosis, organic acids, amino acids, long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids, and muscle biopsy, are normal. EEG and MRI studies show a static cortico-subcortical atrophic pattern with marked asymmetry. Genetic analysis on the LIS, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PFAH3, FGF8, and PAX2 genes were not altered.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe neurodegenerative disorders, likely exacerbated by a genetic mutation in the EN2 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy and epilepsy, but these are less likely given the genetic findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up visits to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Genetic testing will be conducted to explore other potential causes of neurodevelopment delays and seizures. The family will be educated on the importance of regular monitoring and follow-ups to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, diagnosed with locally advanced rectal carcinoma infiltrating the dental line and lymph node metastases, presents with symptoms of defecation, constipation, and tumor-related anemia. The patient also experienced painful stenosis preventing an endoscopic ultrasound. The oncologist denies any significant preexisting diseases or family history of cancer.
O: Physical examination revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a large cell NEC component, confirmed by strong diffuse staining for synaptophysin and CD56, and chromogranin A testing was negative. Ki67 index was greater than 80%. Histological examination of a biopsy specimen showed poorly differentiated, grade 3 (G3) NEC of large cell type, with multiple metastases in both lobes of the liver. ChromogranIN A testing showed negative Ki67 indices and a Ki67 >80%. CT scan showed ten metastases. TNM stage was cT3cN1cM1.
A: The primary diagnosis is locally advanced Rectal Cancer with metastases to the dental and liver. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of cancer, but these are less likely given the histological findings and biopsy results. The prognosis depends on the response to the treatment and response to therapy.
P: The treatment plan includes starting cisplatin (20 mg/m2 on days 1–5, every 4 weeks) in combination with irinotecan (50 mg-m2/day on days1/8/15, every four weeks) and conventionally fractionated pelvic radiotherapy up to 50.4 Gy (reference point dose, intensity-modulated radiation therapy). The patient will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports one-month fatigue, weakness, poor oral intake, 10 lbs. unintentional weight loss, and periodic confusion. The patient has a history of hypertension, bronchial carcinoid tumor post-lobectomy 15 years prior, occupational asbestos exposure with calcified pleural plaques, and low-risk prostate adenocarcinoma diagnosed 12 years prior. The symptoms started approximately two weeks ago, with right ankle soreness starting two weeks prior. No other symptoms were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed normocytic anemia with hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL, hypercalcemia 14.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.76-1.76 mg/dl), and acute kidney injury with creatinine 1.7 mg/L (normal: <0.5 mg/l). An Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm without abnormal waveforms or intervals. CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed mild splenomegaly to 14 cm and calcified mediastinal lymph nodes, likely related to asbestos exposure.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney damage secondary to occupational asbestos exposures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chronic pain and inflammation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of hypercalcemic episodes.
P: The management plan includes administration of intravenous fluids, furosemide, calcitonin, and pamidronate, along with close monitoring of the patient's condition and response to therapy. Further consultations with nephrology and endocrinology are recommended to address the underlying cause of the acute kidney injuries. Patient education on the signs of worsening symptoms and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing nasal obstruction and hyposmia on the left side for the past 6 months, which was previously completely normal. The patient has tried over-the-counter medications without effective relief. No history of maxillo-facial surgery or trauma. No family history of congenital anomalies.
O: Clinical examination revealed a bump along the floor of the left nasal cavity but normal intraoral dentition. Radiograph of the paranasal sinus and nasal cavity showed a radiopaque focus in the left nostril, with a deviated nasal septum resembling a smaller canine. CT scan of the nasal sinuses confirmed a tooth-like structure in the right nasal cavity, supernumerary tooth, and mild mucosal thickening in bilateral maxillary and sphenoid sinuses. No toothlike structures on the right side were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic intranasal tooth, likely related to the nasal obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal obstruction such as nasal swelling or other nasal anomalies. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and resolution of the tooth.
P: The management plan includes performing an endoscopic removal of the ectopic Intranasalis tooth. The procedure will involve surgical intervention to remove the tooth, which should resolve nasal obstruction, hyposmias, and other nasal symptoms. The treatment plan will involve scheduling a follow-up appointment to monitor the patient's response to the procedure and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and regular follow-ups will be provided.

S: The patient reports a rash on the left cheek that appears immediately upon eating certain foods, which disappears within 30 minutes. The patient has a history of facial and chest trauma, mandibular fracture, and collapsed right lower lobe at age 3. The rash was initially noticed during a recent visit to the paediatric intensive care unit.
O: Physical examination revealed no systemic abnormalities or eczema. However, facial flushing was noted upon eating candy, lasting from the temporal region to the corner of the mouth, which faded within a few minutes. No associated lip or tongue swelling or difficulty in breathing was noted. Skin prick testing was negative for an allergic reaction.
A: The primary diagnosis is Frey's syndrome, characterized by facial nerve involvement and non-allergic pathogenesis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial rash, but these are less likely given the absence of systemic or allergic symptoms.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and avoidance of foods that trigger the rash. No specific treatment is required at this time, but the patient is advised to follow up with their paediatrician for any further concerns or changes in symptoms. Further consultations with a pediatric neurologist and a dermatologist are recommended to manage the condition effectively.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old male, presents with a history of moderate mental retardation, microcephalus, and gait impairment. The parent reports persistent developmental delays and a complex obsessive-compulsive behavior over the past 15 years. The patient also has a slight ataxic gait with little knee flexion.
O: Physical examination revealed microcephaly but other metabolic and infectious tests were normal. Genetic analysis revealed a 182-base deletion in one of the alleles, specifically between 2475 and 2657 bases of the complementary sequence, C7 marker. The genetic anomaly was noted in EN2 markers.
A: The primary diagnosis is a genetic anomaly contributing to the patient's symptoms of microcephalopathy, microdeterminism, and cognitive impairment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays, but these are less likely given the genetic findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and genetic testing to identify the genetic causes of the genetic anomalies. The family is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the nature of the diagnosis, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma stage III in the right mandible, underwent neck dissection and mandibular and side resections. The patient reports feeling okay with the jaw tightness, which should gradually improve post-surgery. No issues with bite on the left side were noted during the surgery.
O: Postoperative care included a VSP simulation and fabrication of surgical guides based on VSP data. The mandible was reconstructed with a fibula free flap (FFF) and fixed in place using miniplates. Panoramic radiographs showed anterior dislocation of the right condyle and failure of the superior miniplate at the connection between the fibula and the ascending ramus, leading to severe displacement of the condylar segment.
A: The primary diagnosis is squamous Cell carcinoma, stage III. The successful reconstruction of the mandible with successful fibula-free flap reconstruction and stabilization of the reconstructed mandible. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the surgery and the potential for further complications.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and postoperative care. The plan includes scheduling a second surgery to replace the broken plates and restore stability to the fibular segment. The surgery will involve replacing the broken miniplates and restoring stability in the connection to the ascending and fibula ascending ramuses. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reported a persistent cough and swollen lymph nodes in the neck in December 2016. The patient underwent a cervical lymph node biopsy, which revealed T-LBL. Post-transplant, the patient experienced abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a rash. Post transplant, symptoms of acute grade three GVHD were managed with broad-spectrum antimicrobials including meropenem and voriconazole.
O: PET-CT revealed multiple lymph node involvements in the cervical neck, mediastinum, bilateral parasternum, and abdomen. Postoperative findings included a CD34+ cell count of 8.33 × 10^9/kg, mononuclear cell count 10.15 × 108/kg post-allo-HSCT, and an MNC count of 10. 15 × 10/kg after transplantation. Post TBI/cyclophosphamide protocol, CD34-cell count increased to 8.34 × 11^6/kg on the 12th day post transplantation, and MNC counts improved to 10.45 × 108.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute grade 3 GVAHD with complications including lymph node involvement and lymphadenopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphadenopathies, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to treatment and manage any complications. Maintain current antiviral therapy and monitor for any signs of recurrence or recurrence of symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and ensure compliance with follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a pediatric infectious disease specialist for further evaluation and management of lymphoma.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old female with a history of acute respiratory failure due to severe aortic stenosis (AS). She has undergone a ventricular septal defect repair at age 10, followed by a mitral valve replacement with a 27 mm Carpentier Edwards Magna Valve. She has end-stage renal disease and requires haemodialysis.
O: Recent transthoracic echocardiography showed a degenerated bicuspid aorticus valve with peak velocity of 5.2 m/s, peak gradient of 108 mmHg, mean gradient of 68 mmHG, and an area of 0.43 cm2. The mitral prosthesis is functioning normally. Invasive coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is a degenerate bicaspid aventic valve with a peak velocity and peak gradient. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of valve failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes cannulating the right femoral artery and introducing a 14 French E-sheath. The valve will cross the valve retrogradely using an Amplatz Left1 diagnostic catheter. The patient will be monitored for valve embolization and will be educated on the procedure and procedure details. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 6-year-old boy, reports a history of limited forearm rotation and elbow flexion starting approximately 2 months ago. He recalls undergoing an open reduction of the radial head and an osteotomy of the ulna, which led to a cast on his arm. The patient has been treated with a LCP combined with a cast to aid in healing.
O: Physical examination revealed a fracture in the left forearm, a consolidated fracture of the left ulna with an associated radial head dislocation, and a neglected Monteggia fracture. The right arm underwent open reduction and osteotomy, followed by a cast. The left arm is currently stable, with no signs of pain or discomfort.
A: The primary diagnosis is a left arm fracture with a neglected malignancy, likely secondary to the fracture. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful healing of the right arm.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's recovery with regular follow-up appointments to assess the extent of the fracture and the effectiveness of the cast. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring proper healing. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or discomfort immediately. Consider consultation with a physical therapist if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old female with no significant past medical history and an Oncology performance status of 0. She reports recent post-menopausal bleeding and a small nodule in the right posterolateral vaginal wall. She has a history of 9 mm invasive melanoma, treated with wide local excision and negative margins, followed by a right periclitoral mass 4 months later.
O: Recent biopsy confirmed a 9 mm melanoma. A positron emission tomography/CT scan showed focal uptake in the mass area with no regional or distant metastases. The excision showed atypical epithelioid cells with melanin synthesis, consistent with malignant melanoma (Breslow depth 9 mm with 3 mitoses/mm2, positive deep margin, and no lymphatic invasion). The patient opted for radiation therapy, considering the high risk of morbidity with additional surgery and chemotherapy.
A: The primary diagnosis is malignant metastatic melanoma of the right vaginal wall, complicated by the patient's history of post-manopausal bleeding. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) to the vulva and vagina for the treatment of melanoma and associated complications. The patient will be closely monitored for response and response to the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 30-year smoker with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, presented with anorexia, shaking chills, diaphoresis, hematuria, productive cough, and a fever up to 103°F. The patient reported feeling weak, had no appetite, and was experiencing terrible chills and sweating, accompanied by blood in the urine. He was diagnosed with high-grade papillary noninvasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, classified as American Joint Committee on Cancer stage TaN0M0. He had a final BCG instillation 17 days prior to admission, with significant gross hematurias, productive coughing, profuse diaphoreis, malaise, and fever of up to 102°F on the day of admission. He has a significant past medical history including type 2 Diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
O: On examination, the patient appeared fatigued and acutely ill. Vital signs included a temperature of 103° F, respiratory rate of 24, blood pressure of 160/80, pulse 84, and pulse oximetry 97% on 2 L nasal canula. Lab results showed a white blood cell count of 3.6 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 14.4 g/dL, platelet count of 98 ×10^9, and urinalysis of 92 U/L. Urinalysis was moderate with moderate blood, 3–10 RBC/hpf, and 0–5 WBC/HPf.
A: The primary diagnosis is high-risk papillary Noninvasive Urotherial Cancer of the Lung, with complications including anemia, fever, and abdominal crackles. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and BCG therapy, with adjustments to the regimen as necessary based on clinical response and lab results. The management of the infection and the patient will focus on symptom management and symptom management. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 57-year-old female with a history of breast cancer diagnosed at 48 years old, reports a long-standing history of invasive ductal carcinoma, histology grade 2, positive for estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, and HER2. Her Ki67 is 10%, and 27 out of 28 lymph nodes are positive for lymphoma. She underwent chemotherapy with paclitaxel and doxifluridine, hormonal therapy with tamoxifen, and radiation therapy with trastuzumab. She also had a bone metastasis at 57 years of age, treated with fulvestrant and trastzumab emtansine, followed by zoledronate and denosumab due to renal failure. She has experienced temporary right hip pain but persistent left hip pain. She had a left displaced femoral subtrochanteric fracture at 63 years old.
O: Physical examination revealed no signs of metastasis. Radiography showed cortical bone sclerosis in the fracture area. Bone scintigraphy indicated atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) in both proximal femurs. No metastatic lesions were detected.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast cancer with complications including atypic femoral fracture (AFF) and bone metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancer, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of metastases effectively.
P: The management plan will focus on treating the AFF and monitoring for metastatic disease. The patient will continue on bone-modifying agents for a total of 8 years. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management will be necessary.

S: The patient reports dull aching new-onset low back pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a history of severe aortic stenosis, bioprosthetic aortics placement 4 years ago, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypertension.
O: Physical examination revealed positive tenderness over the lower lumbar spine with a fever of 38.7°C, heart rate of 96/min, blood pressure of 130/90 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. A new holosystolic murmur was noted at the mitral area. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 4.33 × 10^3/µL, hemoglobin/hematocrit of 6.8 g/dL/20.6%, and thrombocytopenic with a platelet count of 100 × 10 µµµl. Renal and liver function tests were normal. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein were elevated at 107 mm/h and 205 mg/L, respectively. MRI of the spine revealed a lubar (L4-L5) epidural abscess and vertebral osteomyelitis, and discitis. Biopsy of L4- L5 was positive for C hominis. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed small vegetation on the Mitral valve with mild regurgitation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a lupus arteriovenous myeloma with complications including a linoctopic myelitis (LIA) and a bacteremia (C hominis). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of back pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and biopsy results.
P: Initiate intravenous ceftriaxone 2 g once daily for 6 weeks to manage the infection. After reassessment, the patient will be discharged to continue the treatment course. Close monitoring of the patient's condition will be necessary to ensure no recurrence of the infection or complications. Family education regarding the nature of the illness and the importance of follow-up care will be provided.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old Hispanic female presenting with stage II B (T4aN0M0) melanoma of the clitoris, presenting with a chief complaint of a pigmented vulvar lesion over the past month, which has been growing and turning dark. She has a history of hypothyroidism, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastritis, total hysterectomy, and left breast lumpectomy.
O: Physical examination revealed a pigmentation lesion with a thickness of 8.0 mm, invading the reticular dermis, with no ulceration, lymphovascular or perineural invasion, and no microsatellites. A re-excision on February 5, 2015, negative for melanoma. A staging positron emission tomography (PET) scan was negative for metastasis, and lymphoscintigraphy was performed on the left inguinal sentinel lymph node. Immunohistochemical stains for Malan-A and S-100 were identified. A follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor the patient's condition closely.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIB melanoma, with a differential diagnosis including metastatic melanoma given the lesion's size and immunohistochemistry. The patient's history of multiple surgeries and multiple malignancies is consistent with her current condition.
P: The management plan includes observation or a clinical trial of high-dose interferon for one year, with the patient advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess response to the treatment and manage any potential complications. Education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care is provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest and back pain following a fall from a ladder. The pain is localized to the shoulder.
O: Upon arrival at the hospital, vital signs were stable with a blood pressure of 160/87 mmHg, heart rate of 109 bpm, and GCS score of E4V5M6. An enhanced CT scan revealed an aortic dissection with an intramural hematoma, with no extravasation or pseudoaneurysm observed. The patient underwent conservative therapy including blood pressure control with a target systolic pressure below 140 mmHG, bed rest for 14 days, and close observation using enhanced and plain CT on hospital days 1, 3, 5, 9, and 14. TEVAR was performed on hospital day 16. Postoperative CT showed a decrease in the thickness of the intraluminal hematoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is aortical dissection, likely secondary to a traumatic brain injury (TBI) given the patient's history of previous surgical interventions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain such as cardiac arrhythmias or vascular malignancy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the successful end-stage treatment.
P: The management plan includes conservative therapy with blood pressure management and close monitoring of the patient. Treatment included conservative therapy for blood pressure and close follow-up CT scans to assess the effectiveness of the treatment. Follow-up imaging studies will be conducted to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient reports progressive dyspnea and chest pain persisting for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a history of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radical cystectomy.
O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Physical findings included irregular irregular heart rhythm, distention of jugular veins, and Kussmaul's sign, with pulsus paradoxus not observed. Bibasilar crackles were noted on lung auscultation. Laboratory tests showed a creatinine level of 1.42 (baseline 1.08), INR of 3.6 (normal range: 0.5-1.0), complete blood counts and electrolytes normal, and atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate and electrical alternans. Chest radiograph showed enlargement of the cardiac silhouette. Bedside transthoracic echocardiogram showed a large pericardial effusion with diastolic compression of the right ventricle, and mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic uropal carcinoma with complications including cardiac tamponade and mild right ventricular dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes a reversal of INR to <1.5 and surgical intervention of an emergent subxiphoid pericardiial window to remove 700 ml of turbid, dark, bloody pericardoial fluid. The plan includes regular monitoring of the patient's condition and symptomatology. The treatment plan will include regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a non-smoker with a history of De Quervain's tenosynovitis of the left hand, presents with right-sided chest pain following acupuncture and cupping at a traditional medicine practitioner, accompanied by intermittent numbness and tingling of both hands. The patient denies fever, cough, runny nose, or sore throat.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile with a blood pressure of 99/63 mmHg, heart rate of 96 bpm, respiratory rate of 22 per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Vital signs were within normal limits. Chest radiograph revealed a right-side pneumothorax with an apical-cupola distance of 3.6 cm.
A: The primary diagnosis is right-sax pneumothoreax, likely exacerbated by air in the space between the lung and chest wall, causing the lung to collapse partially. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and difficulty breathing. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes placing the patient on non-rebreather mask with a FiO2, monitoring vital signs, and adjusting the mask as necessary. The treatment plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications such as respiratory distress or chest pain. Patient education on the signs of respiratory distress and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient, a two-year-old male, presented to the pediatric emergency department for possible foreign body ingestion. The mother reported that the child was found with 10 button batteries but was only able to find one battery. No symptoms were reported.
O: Physical examination was within normal limits. Radiographs showed six foreign bodies within the child's stomach and one distally. The child was not aware of the foreign bodies until the radiographs were taken.
A: The primary diagnosis is a possible ingestion of foreign bodies by the child, likely due to the presence of batteries. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the radiographic findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the child and the removal of the batteries. The patient will be educated on the procedure and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of reporting new symptoms and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided.

S: The patient, a 62-year-old with a history of malignant melanoma in the nasal cavity, reports feeling tired, nauseous, and sweating. The patient has a medical history of hypothyroidism secondary to Hashimoto's disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with insulin injections.
O: On admission, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.0°C, tachycardic, agitated, and acutely anxious, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 14/15 and blood pressure of 70/50 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a diffuse goiter without exophthalmoses, jugular venous distension, and peripheral edema. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, and skin was warm and wet. An electrocardiogram indicated marked tachy-cardia with atrial fibrillation. Laboratory tests showed TSH at 31.7 pg/ml, FT3 at 31 pg/mL, FT4 at 3.43 ng/dl, and thyroglobulin at 3 mg/dl.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe thyrotoxicosis and poor blood glucose control. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypotoxicosis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the management of thyrotoxicity and blood glucose levels.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of thyrocytes and glucose levels, regular follow-ups to assess the effectiveness of the treatment, and adjustment of medications as necessary based on clinical response and laboratory results. Further consultations with a hematologist and a cardiologist may be necessary depending on the progression of symptoms and response to treatment. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient, a 28-year-old male, presents with generalized erythroderma with mild infiltration and whitish fine scales on his body. He reports a history of dermatological treatments including phototherapy and oral acitretin, which were ineffective. He has a family history of psoriasis and has been under regular dermatological care for 28 years. He denies any family members with PRP.
O: Physical examination reveals generalized ewear with mild infiltrations and whitishes on the body. Clinical and histological findings indicate an atypical PRP phenotype, characterized by a chronic course of symptoms in early childhood and no sustained clearance. Genetic testing shows three heterozygous missense variants (c.1641G/C p.Arg547Ser in exon 14, c.2044C/T p. Arg682Trp in exons 17, and c.2458C/ T p.Ar820Trp at exon 20). The splice site variant in homozygous form c.676-6G/A is expected to be pathogenic, whereas the other three variants are benign.
A: The primary diagnosis is PRP type V, likely exacerbated by the presence of CARD14 gene variants contributing to the patient's symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of dermatitis, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to targeted therapies and the management of PRP-related symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the progression of the PRP with regular dermatology visits. Maintain current treatment regimen of phototherapy, oral acitonretin at 25 mg/day, and methotrexate at 60 mg daily. Regular follow-ups with dermatology and dermatology are recommended to monitor the progression and response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in the condition. Consider referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient, with a history of multiple myeloma, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension, presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, orthopnea, and a single episode of syncope over the past two days. The patient denies any symptoms of fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 120/70 mmHg, respiration rate of 28 breaths per minute, and peripheral capillary oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiac exam showed bilateral inspiratory crackle. Laboratory findings showed normal white blood cell count, normal hemoglobin, and normal electrolytes. Pro-brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) was 1425 pg/mL, significantly higher than the reference range of 1–100 pg/dL. Chest radiography indicated pulmonary edema in the lower lung field with Kerley-B lines, and EKG showed a right bundle branch block with low voltage in limb leads. Echocardiogram showed increased left ventricular wall thickness, hyperdynamic function with an ejection fraction of 75%, paradoxical motion of the interventricular septum with LVOT obstruction due to systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, and moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. Genetic testing for HOCM mutations was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is multiple myelocele with complications including pulmonary edemia, right bundle limb block, and right bundle branches block. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac symptoms such as pulmonary embolism or other cardiac complications. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying cardiac issues.
P: The management plan will include referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management. The plan will involve regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on recognizing symptoms of cardiac distress and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided. Referral to an oncologist for specialized care and possibly a cardiology specialist for ongoing management of cardiac issues is recommended.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and dizzy for the past week or so and has lost more than 20 lbs. over the past year. The patient has a history of anemia.
O: Physical examination revealed reddish annular spots on the right lower extremities. Blood pressure was recorded at 169/72 mmHg, pulse 102 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute, temperature 98.3 F, and pulse ox 100% on room air. Laboratory tests showed serum anion gap at 21.5, delta/delta ratio at 0.74, and urine osmolar gap (UOG) at 95.43 mOsm/kg. Bone marrow biopsy indicated markedly hypercellular bone marrow with 70% B-lymphoblast, positive for TdT, PAX5, CD79a, and CD10. Peripheral blood smear showed only a few target cells. CT scan of the abdomen showed enlargement of the kidneys bilaterally.
A: The primary diagnosis is distal renal tachycardia (RTA), complicated by B-ALL. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal involvement, but these are less likely given the specific findings and imaging. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of RTA.
P: The management plan includes managing metabolic acidosis with fluid replacement and sodium bicarbonate, with monitoring for lactic acidosis and monitoring for potential causes of liver damage. Treatment options will be discussed during the hospital stay, with emphasis on monitoring for liver damage and renal involvement. The treatment plan will focus on managing RTA and monitoring liver function. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 78-year-old African-American male with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), hyperuricemia with chronic gouty arthropathy, and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3. He reports a chief complaint of shortness of breath and fatigue for one day. He has been on ibrutinib 420 mg daily and allopurinol 300 mg daily.
O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 101.6 degrees Fahrenheit but otherwise asymptomatic. Blood and urine cultures were obtained, and oral levofloxacin was started. Lab results showed a fever of 102.8°F, an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air, conjunctival pallor, and scleral icterus. CT angiogram of the chest showed a left lower lobe infiltrate. Laboratory findings included drop-in hemoglobin (4.9 mg/dL), indirect hyperbilirubinemia (7.2 mg/dl), low haptoglobin (<10 mg/L), and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (1611 IU/L).
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic lymphocarcinoma with complications including chronic kidney diseases and chronic liver disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's symptoms and laboratory results to determine the best course of treatment. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular follow-ups to monitor his condition and adjust as necessary. Referral to an oncologist and nephrologist is recommended for further evaluation and management. Education on recognizing symptoms of fatigue and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided.

S: The patient, a 4-year-old male, presents with severe speech delay, motor delay, and hypotonia. He has a history of agenesis of the splenium of the corpus callosum. At 3 years of age, his OFC was 49 cm (-1 SD) and his height was 98 cm (0 SD). He exhibits hypertelorism, prominent nasal tip, bulbous nose, small mouth, and both retro- and micrognathia.
O: The son's OFC at 3 years showed a height of 98 cm. At age 3, his facial features were hypertelored, with features including a prominent nasal and bulbous nasal tip and a small mouth. He also has retro-and micrognathsia. The son has a missense variant in the ZBTB18 gene, predicted to be deleterious with a SIFT score of 0 and a Polyphen score of0.991, affecting a highly conserved amino acid residue in the zNF domain. Out of 15 patients, 9 showed corpus callosal abnormalities.
A: The primary diagnosis is a pathogenic variant in ZBT B18, specifically the missense, with a differential diagnosis including other genetic disorders. The prognosis depends on the progression of the disease and the management of congenital anomalies.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with neurology, speech therapy, and physical therapy to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular followups to monitor growth, development, neurological function, and any congenital abnormalities. Education on the nature of his condition and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, admitted with a gunshot injury on the upper left side of the chest, reports being in shock and hypoxemic upon arrival at the other hospital. The patient was treated with resuscitation and a chest tube. He also experienced a brachial plexus injury and impaired sensation in the right upper left limb.
O: Upon admission, the patient's Glasgow coma scale score was 14, indicating a non-expanding and non-pulsatile chest hematoma. A computed tomography angiogram identified a distinct 5 x 5-mm pseudo-aneurysm in the third part of the axillary artery proximal to the posterior origin of the circumflex humeral artery, with a well-defined regional hematomas adjacent to the artery. Diagnostic angiography confirmed the presence of a pseudo-anurysmic in the left brachyial artery. A 6 x 50 mm VIABAHN®-covered stent was placed over the injury site, and a 6x100-mm non-compliable balloon was inflated through the stent to seal the arterial segment.
A: The primary diagnosis is a gunshot wound to the chest with complications including a pseudo anurysmia and patent blood flow. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain and bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes discharge three days post-procedure, followed by follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and blood flow, and the patient is advised to adhere strictly to follow all prescribed medications and schedule follow-ups. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a male with a history of spinal cord tumor surgically removed 4 years ago, developed spastic paraplegia and bed-bound post-surgery. He also developed a chronic pressure sore at the labia majora, treated with multiple debridements. The patient also experienced vaginal spotting three days prior to the anaphylaxis episode. He has a history with fruit allergies since age 50, including bananas, longans, and jackfruit, which caused pruritus of the lips, urticarial rashes, and angioedema.
O: Physical examination revealed vaginal spotting. Pelvic examination was performed using CHX for vaginal preparation and NRL gloves with lubricating gel. Post-procedural examination, the patient developed generalized hives, swollen eyelids, and hypotensive syncope. Intravenous fluid and intramuscular epinephrine were administered without biphasic reactions. The symptoms improved without biphaic reaction.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe anaphyphritis of the vagina, likely exacerbated by the use of NRL gloves and CHX. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal pruritis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes avoiding NRL gloves or CHX in future procedures and examinations to prevent potential cross-reactive allergic reactions. Close monitoring of the patient and potential complications will be necessary, including potential allergic reactions to other fruits. Education on the importance of avoiding latex in future medical procedures and ensuring patient education on the signs of potential allergic reaction. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the anemia is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male who was referred for further evaluation following a physical examination at a military training center for compulsory Greek military service. He reports no symptoms or problems during the examination. He has no history of trauma or surgeries in the past.
O: Physical examination revealed a solitary right kidney, with no scars on the trunk or external genitalia. Physical examination showed no scars or masses. Digital rectal examination was not performed due to the patient's preference. Abdominopelvic CT and MRI of the pelvis showed the absence of the left kidney and a large lobulated multicystic lesion in the left seminal vesicle without enhancement. MRI showed a 7.2 cm × 6.1 cm lobulated lesion and an extended ectopic ureter extending up to the L3 vertebral body with a length of approximately 16 cm.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large cystic tumor in the anatomic region of the right seminal Vesicle, with associated complications including a large fibrous lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cystic lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging characteristics.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the lesion, urethra, and urethral structures. The patient will be educated on the signs of potential complications and advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient reports a recent itchy eruption on the upper to mid-back and along the "V" of the neck, which has been present for a few weeks. The patient has been on a strict diet for the past month.
O: Examination of the affected areas reveals a 3-week history of itchy eruptions on the lower to midback, along the V, and on the neck. No changes in lifestyle or habits were reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is an unusual itchy rash, likely related to recent diet changes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin reactions, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes gradually reintroducing foods that have been eliminated, monitoring skin reactions. The treatment plan includes using an over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream to alleviate the itching and scheduling a follow-up appointment in two weeks to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The plan includes monitoring the skin's response to the reintroduction of foods and monitoring for any worsening of the itching. The management team will continue to advise the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in their diet.

S: The patient reports a month-long history of diarrhea and a cough, characterized by watery, productive cough with yellowish mucus, shortness of breath, and weight loss. The patient denies any history of hemoptysis or abdominal pain. No recent medical contact or use of drugs.
O: Physical examination shows the patient to be conscious, oriented, and alert. No pallor or cyanosis is noted. Grade 3 lower limb edema and underweight are noted. Cardiovascular examination is unremarkable, with decreased air entry on the left side with inspiratory crackles. Blood tests show a WBC count of 14.2 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 7.1 g/dl, platelets at 660 × 10/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/L), albumin at 18 g/dL (normal: 0-1/2), ESR at 89 mm/h, CRP at 74 mg/L. Chest x-ray reveals a cavity on the right side with pleural effusion. CT scan reveals left upper lobe air space consolidation with secretion in the left upper main bronchus, a cavity lesion measuring 3 × 4 × 3 cm, and bilateral pleural discharge. Abdominal CT shows a large left inferior subpleural cavity-like abscess with a diameter of 11 × 10 × 12 cm and upper pole splenic infarction. BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage) culture and sensitivity are negative, but biopsy was positive for mucormycosis. Upper GI endoscopy reveals spleen invading the fundus of the stomach.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic bronchitis with associated spleen invasion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis depends on the response to surgical management and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical management of the lung tissue, including a left thoracotomy and left upper lobectomy to remove the affected lung tissue. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and a gastroenterologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the surgical intervention. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, with a history of epilepsy, reports a 10-day history of seizures, including a Generalized Tonic-Clonic (GTC) seizure at work 10 days ago, followed by another seizure at home 10 days later. The patient experienced dyspnea and hypoxic respiratory failure, necessitating intubation for hypoxia.
O: Upon admission, the patient was dyspneic, hypoxic, and had to be intubated due to hypoxic inhalation. A chest radiograph showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates and pink frothy sputum in the endotracheal tube, suspected aspiration pneumonitis. A CT scan showed no acute intracranial abnormality. Continuous EEG indicated diffuse background slowing and occasional bifrontal spike and wave discharges. A bedside nasopharyngolaryngoscopy showed no upper airway bleeding. Repeat chest radiographs showed rapid resolution of bilateral infiltration and PaO2:FiO2 ratio. Blood, urine, and respiratory syncytial virus polymerase chain reaction tests were negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is frontal lobe epilepsy, likely secondary to the recent seizure and subsequent pulmonary embolism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy such as pulmonary emboli or other pulmonary syndromes, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's epilepsy with regular follow-ups with neurology and neurology to assess the progression or resolution of the seizures. Further treatment options may include surgical intervention for aspiration pneumons or surgical intervention if the patient is unable to breathe. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presenting with sudden, severe left flank pain, which began while watching TV at home. He denies any recent trauma or use of anticoagulation medications.
O: Vital signs include a temperature of 37.5°C, pulse 107 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, blood pressure 104/62 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals severe tenderness in the left flank. Laboratory tests show elevated creatinine at 1.6, hemoglobin at 9.7, and lactate at 4.5. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a large acute retroperitoneal hematoma extending into the left suprarenal fossa and left hemi pelvis displacing the left renal parenchyma. Hemoglobin levels drop to 8.4, and transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells. Arteriogram shows multiple bilateral renal artery aneurysms and active extravasation from the L2 segmental artery trunk.
A: The primary diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), evidenced by imaging and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute flank pain and renal involvement, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes embolization of the area, administration of prednisone 60 mg daily, and embolizing the area. The patient will be started on prednisolone 60mg daily to secure bleeding. Further consultations with rheumatology and hematology are planned to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling and pain in the left ankle for about a year, which has improved with anti-TB drugs. The patient has a history of pulmonary TB and intracranial TB, which were treated with antihistamines.
O: Physical examination revealed hyperplasia of synovial tissue, pale areas, regional congestion, scattered fibrous protein, and necrotic tissue. Arthroscopy confirmed the presence of ankle scarring tissue and improved motor function of the ankle. Post-procedure, the patient's AOFAS score improved to 93 points.
A: The primary diagnosis is ankle TB, evidenced by the patient undergoing arthroscopic debridement to remove the ankle tissue and improve motor function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ankle pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes performing arthrothroscopies to remove and improve the ankle's motor function, with the patient advised to monitor the ankle and report any further pain or swelling. Further follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and follow-ups will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic hepatitis B, reports progressive dysphagia that has been occurring for a few weeks, mainly with solid foods. The patient has experienced holocranial headaches, falls with dizziness, nausea, and photophobia for the past 3 to 6 weeks.
O: Initial tests included a barium swallow test, abdominal ultrasound, and esophagogastroduodenoscopy. Biopsies revealed a nodule in the distal esophagus and a large, friable, and ulcerated mass along the gastric cardia. Pathology confirmed adenocarcinoma, intestinal type, with neoplastic glands infiltrating the muscularis mucosae. The nodule biopsy showed high-grade dysplasia, and antral biopsies showed reactive mucosiae. positron emission tomography and computed tomography scans confirmed the gastral mass and two fluorodeoxyglucose avid lymph nodes. MRI of the head showed three peripherally enhancing lesions with surrounding edema in the right cerebral hemisphere, with the largest lesion in the temporoparietal lobes causing mass effect with midline shift.
A: The primary diagnosis is adenocytosis with complications including gastric mass, lymph node involvement, and metastatic disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms such as malignancy or metastatic diseases. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the metastases.
P: The management plan includes gamma knife radiosurgery for the resection cavity and remaining metastases, with close monitoring of the patient's condition and response to therapy. Treatment will include chemotherapy with paclitaxel, capecitabine, and pegfilgrastim kit, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis, treatment expectations, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 47-year-old male with a history of severe thoracic trauma from a forklift accident 14 hours ago, presenting with hemoptysis and serious signs of respiratory distress. He reports no specific past medical history.
O: Upon arrival at the local hospital, the patient's pulse oxygen was around 80%. Physical examination revealed subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and chest, no breathing in the left lung, and moist rales in the right lung. CT scan showed left-side pneumothorax, right-side pneumonia, bilateral traumatic wet lung, multiple rib fractures, and bronchoscopy indicated a left main bronchial rupture. The patient's vital signs and lab results were not provided.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe thoric trauma with complications including left-sided pneumonia, pneumonia, and respiratory distress, likely exacerbated by the accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory symptoms such as pulmonary embolism or pneumonia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included bilateral closed thoracacic drainage, fluid infusion, and immobilization of the chest wall. Post-accident, the vital signs deteriorated, and the patient was transferred to the emergency department for further evaluation and management. Postoperative management included bilateral closure thoracics, fluid infusions, and chest wall immobilization. Blood gas analysis revealed respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis, exacerbating both conditions. Chest x-rays were taken before pneumonectomy and after the withdrawal of ECMO. The treatment plan included initiating ECMO without delay, which was completed without complications.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of symptomatic varicose veins on the left leg, presenting with pain and swelling around the ankle. He reports dyslipidemia and arterial hypertension. He is currently on simvastatin and lisinopril. He denies any prior venous thromboembolic events or neoplasia.
O: Physical examination revealed varicoses in the knee and lower leg mediodorsally, with perimalleolar edema on the right side. No varicosarcoma or local signs of inflammation were noted in the groin. A duplex ultrasound examination revealed an insufficient left GSV with a long-lasting reflux, longer than 2 seconds from the SFJ down to the ankle, and a 10x10x8 mm isoechogenic mass with hyperechogenic component in an eccentric dilated segment of the GSV adherent to the terminal valve and to the vein wall. No color Doppler signals were detected within the mass.
A: The primary diagnosis is focal thrombosis of the left femoral artery (GSV) with associated varicosity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vascular obstruction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes initiating thrombroembolic prophylaxis with Rivaroxaban 10mg once daily to prevent complications. An accelerated EVLA of the GSF will be performed in 7 days, with the patient's consent to proceed with the intervention. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a female with a history of hypothyroidism, epilepsy, and learning difficulties, presents with skin tags on her nipples for quite a long time. She denies any family history of NFI.
O: Clinical examination reveals bilateral, pedunculated, polypoid, and fleshy lesions on both nipple-areolar complexes. The right nipple lesion measures 60x55x35mm, and the left one measures 25x25x25mm. Microscopic findings include dermal proliferations of bland spindle-shaped cells with elongated wavy dark nuclei, and smooth muscle fibers of the nipple are in close proximity to mammary ducts. Immunohistochemistry supports neural differentiation of spindle cells with immunopositivity for S100 and neurofilament, negative for a panel of cytokeratins including AE1/3 and p63.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent skin tag lesions on the nipples, characterized by dermal proliferation of spindles and spindle cell proliferation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin tag proliferation, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with the healthcare provider to monitor the lesion's response to the neurofibroma. The patient is advised to monitor for any changes or concerns and to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Education on the importance of regular monitoring and follow-up appointments is crucial. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of skin tags is recommended.

S: The patient reports severe headaches, trouble speaking, weird twitching, and weaker all over. The patient has a history of fever last week and painful ulcers in the mouth. Additionally, the patient's 3-year-old son tested positive for EV-71.
O: Neurological examination revealed motor aphasia, right facial paralysis, tetraparesis, and hyperreflexia. Brain MRI showed left frontal cortical thickening in FLAIR images, hyperintense in diffusion weighted images (DWI), with leptomeningeal enhancement. Spinal cord MRI showed cervical and lumbosacral lesions. CSF test indicated pleocytosis, but enterovirus PCR was negative. Stool sample detected enterovir RNA.
A: The primary diagnosis is motor aplastic anemia with associated spinal cord lesions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the rapid deterioration and the absence of complications.
P: Initiated plasmapheresis (PEX) therapy 72 hours post-initial neurological symptoms. Post-therapy, PEX therapy was performed every other day, with no complications observed. The plan includes monitoring the patient closely for any new symptoms or complications. The management plan includes regular follow-ups to assess recovery and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient, previously treated with curative laparoscopic ileocecal resection for cecum cancer, reports a history of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma without K-RAS mutation, T3 N1, stage IIIB. The patient underwent CRS (CC-0) and HIPEC after 5 months of adjuvant chemotherapy, achieving a PCI score of 5/39. Post-operative complications included peritoneal metastases and bilateral ovarian metastases, which were managed with CRS and HIPec.
O: Postoperative findings included liver metastasis to segment 6, which was managed with systemic chemotherapy with FOLFOX and bevacizumab. Subsequent liver resection showed significant reduction in size, with no other metastasis or dissemination detected. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient underwent a posterior sectionectomy of the liver.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately-differentiated tubular abdominal adenoma with a secondary diagnosis of liver metastases. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with no recurrence in five months post- hepatectomy.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's health post-surgery to ensure any recurrence of the disease. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the cancer and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a hepatologist for specialized care and a gastroenterologist for ongoing management of liver disease is recommended.

S: The patient, a male with a history of Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed at age 16, reports recent neck pain. He denies any history of previous cancer treatment and is currently in remission. He has no significant past surgical history and no family history of breast or thyroid cancer. He smokes but quit after about 10 years. He reports no significant medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed a subcutaneous mass over the mid-clavicle, a breast mass, and multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. The largest nodule measured 1.5 × 1.6 × 2.0 cm. Ultrasound measurements showed the breast mass at 2.6 x 4.0 × 4.9 cm. A CT scan of the neck revealed a large breast mass in the right upper-outer quadrant, with a size of 2.8 × 4,0 × 5.6 cm, and a large nodule over the clavicle. The mass was not found in the breast and thyroid clinics.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign breast mass with associated thyroid nodules and nodules. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of thyroid cancer, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the thyroid mass.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's thyroid function and thyroid function. A surgical oncologist will discuss the case and determine the best course of action. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up visits and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the patient’s recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the cancer and its implications will be provided.

S: The patient reports a pruritic rash on the trunk and both upper and lower extremities, which has been particularly uncomfortable. The patient has tried various treatments including topical halobetasol, topical tacrolimus, oral antihistamines, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil, which did not alleviate the symptoms.
O: Biopsies revealed mild spongiosis with an underlying superficial and deep perivascular infiltrate. Initial treatments with various treatments, including topical Halobetazole, oral anthistamines and prednisones, and Mycophenol mofeta, did not significantly improve the patient's condition. Follow-up biopsies showed mild improvement in the rash and pruritus, with minimal residual post-inflammatory hyperpigmented macules.
A: The primary diagnosis is pruritis, likely secondary to the initial treatment with dupilumab, which was ineffective. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of prurititis, but biopsy results and biopsy findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful response to the current treatment.
P: Continue the current regimen of dupilatumab with regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any concerns immediately.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old female, presented with symptoms of severe abdominal colic, vomiting, constipation, and fatigue. She was prescribed a nasal spray liquid twice daily for 10 days, which she was prescribed. The patient developed severe symptoms of fatigue and abdominal colitis.
O: Vital signs were not provided. Laboratory tests showed elevated venous blood lead (BLL) at 91 μg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 ng/dL), creatine kinase at 747 U/L (normal: <0.5 ng/L), creatine isoenzyme MB at 14.8 ng/mL, AST at 119 U/l, and ALT at 390 U/dL. Radiography of the abdomen revealed shadows of stool and gas, increased density, and radiopaque particles. The white blood cell count dropped to 2.11× 109/L after 2 days of treatment.
A: The primary diagnosis is rhinitis secondary to nasal spray use, likely exacerbated by lead exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms such as gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the elevated BLL and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes administering folium sennae as a cathartic cath for chelation therapy, which was successful in achieving a BLL of 36 μg/L at the end of 5 days. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of follow-up care and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms is crucial.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old immigrant male presenting with multiple masses in bilateral parotid glands, with the left side being larger than the right. He has a history of neurocysticercosis, which he attributes to eating uncooked pork in Mexico. He underwent a craniotomy to remove a brain mass. He was vaccinated against tuberculosis, and his work-up for systemic tuberculosis was negative.
O: Physical examination revealed bilateral parotsid masses. CT scan of the neck with i.v. contrast revealed a dominant, ring-enhancing, hypodense lesion in the left superficial parotoid gland, measuring 3.0 × 2.9 cm. Pathological analysis confirmed a large yellowish fluid-filled cyst. Microcopathology indicated a squamous epithelium-lined cyst with lymphoepithelial complexes, also known as brown islands. Serological studies confirmed HIV infection.
A: The primary diagnosis is a squamosal cyst, likely a lymphosomectomy, given the presence of a lymphocompromised lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other cysticercotic lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular check-ups and lifestyle modifications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for regular follow-ups. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to manage the condition effectively. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of pulmonary sarcoidosis, hypertension, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and obesity, reports a sudden onset of difficulty seeing out of the right eye and difficulty remembering names and events.
