O: Recent MRI confirmed liver metastases. Past medical history includes angiomolipomatosis of the kidneys, uterin leioma, and obstructive sleeping apnea. She also has Achilles tenditis and arthritis treated with bone grafts. Current medications include estradol-norenthindone and trazosodone, with a recent PET-CT scan showing new pulmonary metastases, and ipilimumab 3 mg/kg. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and flexible sigmoidoscopy revealed normal esophageal, gastric, and duodenal mucosa without ulceration or significant mucosal injury. Gastric biopsies indicated lymphocytic inflammation surrounding pigmented cells.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic liver cancer with complications including epigastric pain and gastric reflux, unresponsive to high-dose proton pump inhibitors like pantoprazole 40 mg twice daily and Carafate. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups. Maintain current medications and adjust as necessary based on the biopsy results. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the metastatic lung cancer. Consider consultation with a pulmonologist for specialized care and possibly a gastroendocrinologist for gastrointestinal management. Ensure patient understands the treatment regimen and follow-up schedule.

S: The patient, a 67-year-old with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and an enlarged spleen, presents for evaluation of refractory anemia. The patient has a long-standing history of anemia managed with various therapeutic agents, including adalimumab, methotrexate, abatacept, infliximab, azathioprine, rituximab and prednisone. At age 68, the patient became transfusion dependent and underwent a splenectomy at 67. The anemia progressed, leading to a diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome at 68, which was managed with transfusions and adjusted-dose lenalidomide. The current patient is on erythropoietin and has a hemoglobin level of 13 g/dL, which has decreased to 13.
O: Physical examination revealed minimal morphologic dysplasia with a diploid karyotype. BM core biopsy and aspiration showed hypercellular marrow with trilineage dysplastic, moderate reticulin fibrosis, and 2% blasts. Flow cytometry indicated changes consistent with MDS, including decreased side scatter in granulocytes, absence of hematogones, and aberrant myeloid blasts with an expression pattern of increased CD13 and CD34, and decreased CD38. Dendritic cells with a CD123bright, CD4+, HLA-DR+, CD56− immunophenotype were 0.2% of all analyzed cells. Cytogenetic studies showed a normal diploidal karyotyping.
A: The primary diagnosis is refractive anemia with complications including myelosplastic syndromes (MDS) and myelofibrosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocardial infarction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of MDS.
P: The management plan will involve a multidisciplinary team including oncology, hematology, and infectious disease specialists to discuss the diagnosis and treatment options. The management will involve close monitoring of the patient's anemia and MDS status, and regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the response and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 76-year-old Asian male with a 55-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, referred for right intermittent claudication for 3 years. He reports a history of diabetic retinopathy and has been treated with insulin for the past three years.
O: Physical examination revealed a right femoral bruit and diminished right popliteal pulse, suggestive of a left femoral lesion. The right ABI measured by a volume plethysmograph was 1.28, within normal limits of 1.00–1.40, and elevated to 1.55 (>1.10). Angiography showed a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, with no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Fluoroscopic images and computed tomography showed severe calcification of infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle and bilateral infrapopopliteals.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe calcified lesion of the left femur at the base of the superficial femur, likely exacerbated by the presence of PAD. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the right extremity, but these are less likely given the angiographic findings.
P: The management plan includes a supervised exercise training program for 6 months, with the patient to continue 2 hours a day walking. The exercise program will be completed for six months, and the patient will continue to spend 2 hours daily walking. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and encouraged to report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, a male, presented with nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea for five days. He reported eating meatloaf from a local store three days prior to the onset of symptoms. He has a history of consuming meatloaves prior to symptoms.
O: Vital signs are stable. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin at 12 g/dl (normal range: 13-17 g/dL), platelet count at 47 x 10^3/mL (normal: 161-160 x 10/mL), sodium at 119 mmol/L (normal ranges: 4.4-11.2 mmol/l), potassium at 4.5 mmol/dL (normal <1.0 mg/dl), creatinine at 6.7 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen at 99 mg/L. Urinalysis revealed mildly increased schistocytes, normochromic normocytic erythrocytes, and marked thrombocytopenia. Hemolytic workup showed elevated reticulocyte count at 3.08%, lactic acid dehydrogenase at 480 IU/L, normal bilirubin levels, haptoglobin at 163 mg/mL, and free hemoglobin up to 115 mg.
A: The primary diagnosis is a urinary tract infection caused by Enterococcus faecalis, with differential diagnoses including other causes of acute kidney injury such as thrombinosis or thrombus infection. The patient's history of viral gastroenteritis and recent hospitalization suggest a possible atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome.
P: Initiate treatment with ampicillin for the urinary tract infections and consider additional antimicrobials if symptoms persist or worsen. Monitor hemoglobin levels closely and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of infection and the importance of follow-up with the primary care physician. Consider referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of TMA. Consider consultation with a cardiologist for further assessment and management.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old female presenting with a chief complaint of fever, altered consciousness, and hypotension for a few days. She reports feeling really out of it and has a low blood pressure. She has a history of dermatomyositis, which has been present for the last year. She denies any contact with sick people or travel.
O: Physical examination revealed a heliotrope rash on the face. Laboratory findings included hemoglobin 8.5 g/dl, hematocrit 0.28, red blood cells 3.30x1012/L, and platelet count 40,000/ul. LDH 814 IU/L (normal range: 8-11 IU/l), total bilirubin 2.2mg/dl (normal: 2-4 mg/dl), prothrombin time (PT) 16 sec, and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 38 sec. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) was 42 mg/dL, and creatinine was 3.5mg/dL. Spinal tap, urinalysis, and blood cultures were negative. ANA and anti-Jo tests were positive.
A: The primary diagnosis is dermatomyosis (TTP) of the patient's skin, evidenced by the presence of fever and altered state of consciousness, renal failure, anemia, and thrombolysis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of dermatopathies, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results.
P: The management plan includes initiating plasmapheresis to manage dermatomyositionis. The patient will continue to be monitored for response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as needed. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to manage the condition effectively. Patient education regarding the nature of her condition and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reported a sudden onset of severe back pain, described as sudden and intense. The pain was initially suspected to be aortic dissection, which was ruled out by a chest and abdominal computed tomography with contrast enhancement. The patient denies any current medications and is a smoker. The dog has been bitten and scratched by a corgi dog.
O: On examination, the patient's vital signs were within normal limits with a temperature of 37.5 °C, blood pressure 127/48 mmHg, heart rate 84 bpm, and oxygen saturation 95% in ambient air without accelerated respiration. Physical examination showed no spinal knocking pain, neurological abnormalities, or other specific findings. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 13,360 cells/mm3, platelet count 17.0 × 104/μL, serum creatinine 0.66 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein 18.5 mg/dl. Enhanced CT and plane MRI of the spine was not diagnostic, but Gram-negative bacilli was detected in blood cultures.
A: The primary diagnosis is spinal epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis/discitis. Differential diagnoses initially included spinal spinal injury and vertebral fractures, which were ruled out based on negative cultures and imaging. The presence of P. multocida in the blood suggests a possible drug-resistant condition.
P: Continue intravenous meropenem 1 g every 8 hours as a provisional diagnosis. Monitor the response to the treatment and adjust the regimen as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of avoiding further dog bites or scratches to prevent complications. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reported high blood pressure and small red spots on the skin, diagnosed as petechiae. The patient also experienced an acute pregnancy-onset TTP episode in November 2012 during which she experienced low platelet count, anemia, and hemolytic anemia. She experienced severe intrauterine growth restriction during her pregnancy, necessitating termination of the pregnancy. She has been in remission post-discharge of plasma exchange and has been diagnosed with ADAMTS13 in both her plasma and molecular levels.
O: Physical examination and laboratory analysis revealed a thrombocytopenia of 5 x 10^9 platelets/L, hemolysis with a hemoglobin level of 7.0 g/dL, schistocytes in 7-10 out of every 1,000 red blood cells, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels at 454 U/L. The direct Coombs test was negative. MRI of the brain showed old ischemic lesions in both cerebral hemispheres, likely from an ischeptic event 7 months prior. The pregnancy was terminated due to severe intrautero-growth restriction.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute pregnancy with TTP, evidenced by the patient's symptoms of low platelets and anemia and the absence of blood clotting disorders. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blood loss and hemoglobinuria, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Continue monitoring the patient and her condition closely. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of ADAMT13 and the effectiveness of the treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for regular monitoring of her condition. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, referred to the clinic in December 2017 for acute liver failure of unknown origin, reports no pre-existing medical conditions and no exposure to drugs, promiscuity, or autoimmune disorders. The patient initially presented with indolent jaundice.
O: Physical examination revealed distinct jaundices and hepatic encephalopathy grade I. Laboratory tests revealed massively elevated transaminases with an ALT level of 4645 U/l and AST level of 4956 U/L, both significantly elevated. Cholestatic liver enzymes were elevated at 216 U/ls and gamma-glutamyl-transferase (γ-GT) at 91 U/ml. Liver synthesis parameters were significantly impaired, with total bilirubin 14.8 mg/dl, INR 2.39, and factor V activity less than 35%. Laboratory tests for autoimmune hepatitis, viral hepatitis (A-E), Wilson's disease, and hemochromatosis were negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is cryptogenic acute liver disease, with differential diagnoses including autoimmune hepatitis and viral hepatitis. The absence of serological evidence for these conditions complicates the clinical picture.
P: The management plan includes administration of vitamin K, ursodeoxycholic acid, and lactulose, with close monitoring of liver function and liver function. Treatment adjustments will be made as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment and response to treatment. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on clinical response and laboratory results. Further consultations with hepatology and hepatology may be necessary depending on the progression of the disease.

S: The patient is a 56-year-old mother of three presenting with multiple neck lumps for 4 months, general vague abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and lower back pain. She denies significant medical, family, or psychosocial history.
O: Clinical examination revealed multiple enlarged cervical lymph nodes, a 2x2 cm firm lump on the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, enlarged right inguinal lymph nodes. Abdominal, rectal, and breast examinations were normal. Neurological examination of the lower limbs was normal. Ultrasound of the abdomen and neck showed no abnormalities. CT scan of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed multiple nodules in the thyroid gland, low-density nodules, and a mixed density mass lesion in the lower L2 vertebra, suggestive of bone metastases. Biopsies from the uterine cervix and endometrial curettage indicated moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with local extension into the endometrium. An excision biopsy of one of the lymph nodes indicated metastatic deposits of moderately differentiated carcinoma. Ultrasonography of the cervical and lymph nodes showed metastatic lesions suggestive of malignant deposits.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated cervical carcinoma, with differential diagnoses including malignant malignancy and metastatic disease. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the patient's adherence to the treatment plan.
P: The management plan will include surgical intervention to address the cervical cancer, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or combination of these. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment as necessary. Patient education on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments will be provided.

S: The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse and presumed cirrhosis, presenting with a chief complaint of weakness and drooping right side of his face.
O: Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of low atypical atypically low (BP <0.5 mmHg) and a body temperature of lower than normal. Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam were administered. Diagnostic paracentesis showed 9,787 nucleated cells per microliter with abundant intra- and extra-cellular bacteria. Point-of-care ultrasound showed air bubbles and debris bubbling through ascites and intraperitoneal A-lines, indicative of pneumoperitoneum. A portable abdominal radiograph was suspicious for free air. Post-operative findings included a ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia in the distal ileum and cecum, with no frank necrosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is pneumoperthyosis, likely secondary to alcohol use and cirrhotic cirrhopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal swelling and infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the infection and the complexity of the patient's condition.
P: The management plan included intubation and continuous norepinephrine infusion to stabilize the condition. The patient was started on intravenous van comycin, piperaceillin-tarabactam, and intravenous fluids. Postoperative care included monitoring for signs of infection or complications, and surgical intervention was necessary to address the ruptured ulcer. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are planned to assess the extent of infection and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: The patient reports a painless swelling on the right side of the neck, just below the jaw, for the past two weeks, without fever or other symptoms. The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes but is regularly treated.
O: Physical examination revealed a right submandibular swelling measuring 6 x 5 cm, non-tender, mobile, and firm in consistency, with bimanual palpation. Intraorally, pus was noted at the Wharton's duct orifice, but no sialolith was observed. Preoperative blood investigations including complete blood count, serum urea and electrolytes, and serum uric acid tests were normal. CT scan of the right sub mandibular gland and duct showed opacity in the right and left submandular glands. Histopathology confirmed severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute on-choral sialadism with complications including severe acute postoperative scleroderma and multiple calculitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neck swelling such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathology findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the left sub mandible under general anesthesia, followed by removal of the gland and any stones present in the duct. Postoperative recovery will be closely monitored with regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient's response to treatment and recovery.

S: The patient, a bedridden individual, reports experiencing generalized pain for a while, with no evidence of burning or discomfort from the heating pad. The patient has been using an electrical heating pad for about 12 months, which has led to intractable pain. The pain has not been alleviated by the use of the pad.
O: Physical examination revealed reticulated, ill-defined, reddish-brown patches on the back, which were likely due to chronic heat exposure from the pad, which was not noted. The skin lesions were noted to be temporary but resolved after discontinuing the pad and avoiding heat sources.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic heat-induced skin lesions, likely secondary to chronic heating pad use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin color changes, but these are less likely given the patient's history and symptoms.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of the heating pads and avoiding all heat sources on the patient. A follow-up visit is scheduled in a few months to monitor the skin lesions and ensure no further damage to the skin. Education on the importance of avoiding heat source exposure is provided to the patient to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and stroke, presents with a two-month history of muscle weakness and remote exposure to statins.
O: Physical examination reveals 2/5 strength on the left side and 4/5 on the right. Laboratory tests reveal a high CK level at 28,885 U/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 U/dL), suggestive of necrotizing myositis. MRI shows extensive proximal muscle edema and biopsy of the vastus medialis shows necrotization features without inflammation. Hydroxy-Methyl-Glutaryl Coenzyme A (HMG CoA) antibodies are strongly positive. One month after presentation, motor weakness improved, CK levels dropped to 5,546 u/L. Two months post-treatment, CK level remained elevated at 3,178 U/l. TAC 4 mg/day was added, and PDN 40 mg daily was tapered. Eight months after TAC initiation, the patient improved markedly, and labs normalized. One year post-TAC, CK dropped to 117 U/°C, and LDH level was 251 U/mL.
A: The primary diagnosis is necrotized Myositis, likely secondary to statin exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of motor weakness and muscle weakness. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in CK levels and the recent reduction in PDN dose.
P: The management plan includes continuation of tacrolimus and MMF, with close monitoring of CK levels. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a hematologist may be considered if new symptoms arise or if there is a recurrence of symptoms.

S: The patient reports intermittent mucoid-runny diarrhea 3-4 times daily, accompanied by visceral pain around the belly button. The pain resolves after diarrhea. The patient has a history of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage due to a peptic ulcer 10 years ago but no surgeries or drug use.
O: Physical examination revealed a fever of 36 °C, pulse of 82/min, and arterial blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg. Abdominal distention, increased bowel sounds, and ileocecal tenderness were noted. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 14,000/uL, C-reactive protein of 185 mg/L, erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 60 mm/h, and negative celiac markers. Stool microscopy showed leukocytes, no parasitic organisms, and no microorganisms detected. Gastroscopy and colonoscopy showed purulent fluid evacuation around the appendix orifice, ulcerated and granular appearance around the caecum base, and colitis. Abnormal stool culture was negative. Abstraction ultrasonography (USG) indicated inflammation of intestinal loops, omental inflammatory thickening, and a 7x5x4 cm fluid collection in the pericaecal area. CT scan indicated a hyperdense area of 12x16 mm in the anterior mesenteric fat tissue at the ileoccecal valve level.
A: The primary diagnosis is plastron appendicitis, evidenced by the presence of ulceration and granulopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal discomfort, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes hydrating and administration of empiric cefixime 1x100 mg and metronidazole 3x500 mg, with ongoing hydration and monitoring. The treatment plan includes continued antibiotic therapy and hydration, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the management plan as needed. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis and the importance of adherence to treatment will be provided.

S: The patient is a 46-year-old woman with a history of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma treated with radiation therapy and currently on temozolomide. She reports recent cough and palpitations.
O: On admission, vital signs include blood pressure at 115/83 mm Hg, heart rate at 117 beats/min, body temperature at 36.5°C, SpO2 at 96% with an O2 2 L/min cannula. A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII with negative T in V1–3. Ultrasound cardiogram reveals distended right ventricle, D-shape (+), moderate tricuspid valve regurgitation, and moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension with a maximum pressure gradient of 59 mm HG. Chest X-ray indicates distended pulmonary arteries and interstitial lung infiltrate. Emergency CT scan shows no thrombus in the major pulmonary arteries but shows nodular opacities with a tree-in-bud pattern. Abdominal CT shows a slightly distended gastric wall with lymphadenopathies. Laboratory findings include decreased platelets (71 × 10^3/μL), activated partial thromboplastin time of 30.7 seconds, prothrombin time-international normalized ratio of 1.19, fibrinogen level 100 mg/dL, and increased D-dimer 20.08 μg/mL.
A: The primary diagnosis is temozoleomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. Differential diagnoses include pulmonary embolism, which was ruled out by imaging and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Initiate steroid pulse therapy with methylprednisolone 1 g/d to treat the interstitial pneumonitis. Administer recombinant Thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion to manage hypercoagulable state. Monitor vital signs closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns during her stay.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with a coma and shock. He reported no prior hospital visits or medication use.
O: Upon admission, the patient was found to be in a coma with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15 (E1V1M1), blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, pulse 130 bpm, and temperature 37.3°C. Laboratory tests showed neutropenia with a neutrophils count of 640/µL, elevated C-reactive protein at 12.73 mg/dL, blood glucose 237 mg/dl, and hemoglobin A1c 12.1%. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed diffuse gas collection in the urinary bladder wall, indicative of an infection caused by gas-forming bacteria.
A: The primary diagnosis is Escherichia coli infection of the urinary tract, evidenced by the presence of gas-formulating bacteria in the urine. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of infectious or infectious infections, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Initiated treatment with meropenem hydrate and vasopressor, followed by a broad-spectrum antibiotic (meropenem) hydrate, vasopressors, and catheterization. The patient was placed on a respirator and underwent further management. The family was informed of the patient's death and was encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient, a tobacco smoker with a history of NSCLC (T1bN3M0 stage IIIB) diagnosed a year ago, reports progressively worsening abdominal pain and constipation. The patient has been in remission post-radiation and immunotherapy with pembrolizumab.
O: On admission, the patient exhibited progressively worsening symptoms including abdominal pain, constipation, and elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (4.2 ng/dL). A CT scan revealed severe colonic stool burden and a soft tissue left upper lobe lung mass, with a single large soft tissue mass with mucosal invasion in the rectosigmoid colon. An urgent diagnostic laparoscopy was performed, converting the procedure to open exploratory laparotomy due to numerous bowel-to-bowel and abdominal wall adhesions. Postoperative biopsies showed high-grade NSCLCs and metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin. Hematoxylin and eosin staining showed extensive necrosis, focal mucosal involvement, and negativity for regional lymph node carcinoma. Colonic glandular cells surrounded by atypical cells were detected in the colonic stroma. Immunohistochemical stains for CK7, TTF-1, Napsin-A, and epithelial specific antigen/EpCAM were also identified.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic NSCLCC with metastasis to the colon. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the metastatic disease.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups with the oncologist to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects. Further treatment options may be considered based on the results of these tests. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old male Jack Russell Terrier, presented with sudden weakness and reluctance to move from his basket. The owner reports that the dog lives mostly indoors and is vaccinated against distemper, parvovirosis, leptospirosis, Rubarth disease, parainfluenza, and rabies. The dog has a history of traveling abroad but does not have recent exposure to ticks.
O: Physical examination and biochemistry were unremarkable. Serological examinations for Toxoplasma gondii and Borrelia species were negative. Serology for toxoplasmosis and Lyme serology were positive with a titer of 1:1024. The patient's dog was treated with doxycycline, which was administered orally twice a day for 30 days.
A: The primary diagnosis is Lyme disease, confirmed by the positive serology and positive serological tests for Tuxoplasma, Borrelias, and other infectious bacteria. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tick-borne illnesses, but these are less likely given the negative serology.
P: The management plan includes prescribing 5 mg/kg of doxychlorine, to be administered twice daily. The treatment plan includes monitoring the dog's response to the treatment and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the antibiotic and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of monitoring symptoms and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a 5-day history of frequent vomiting, moderate to severe headache, giddiness, weakness on the right side of the body, and altered sensorium. He reported one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures before the onset of symptoms. He denies any past medical history of major illness or drug treatments, and no addictions.
O: Vital signs showed the patient to be afebrile with a pulse of 86/minute and a blood pressure of 126/74 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed drowsy, poorly responding to verbal commands, hypertonia, grade III power in the right upper limb and lower limb, mildly exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and positive Babinski sign on the left side. Chest, abdomen, and cardiovascular system were unremarkable. Blood tests showed macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin at 11.4 g/dl and MCV at 110 fl, macrocytes and macro-ovalocytes with hypersegmented neutrophils in peripheral blood film, and low serum cobalamin levels at 68 pg/ml. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies were negative. No gastric atrophy was found on stomach biopsy.
A: The primary diagnosis is a neurological disorder, likely exacerbated by low cobalamine levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of neurological impairment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of neurological status and symptomatology. Further diagnostic tests such as MRI and CT scan will be conducted to identify the cause of the neurological symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports noticing a firm palpable mass close to the supernumerary nipple on the right side over the past few months. The patient denies any other symptoms.
O: Physical examination revealed a palpable mass near the supernatary nipple. Mammogram and ultrasound showed normal breast tissue but a hypoechoic, well-defined area measuring 10 mm in diameter. Ultrasound-guided needle core biopsy with a 16G needle showed elongated epithelial islands with a small centrally located lumen and focally identifiable cuticles, surrounded by dense fibrous stroma. Microscopic examination of the tumor showed a firm, grey-white tumor with focal cysts, solid trabecular and glandular imitating formations, and an eosinophilic cytoplasm.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign benign breast tumor (SyT) with uncertain malignant potential. Differential diagnosis initially included other benign breast tumors, but biopsy confirmed SyT. The prognosis is guarded due to the presence of foreign body giant cells.
P: The management plan included surgical resection of the benign tumor with a 5 mm rim of normal tissue. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. Education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old divorced Caucasian male with a 20-year history of cocaine use, presenting with severe headache and lower extremity numbness. He reports no prior psychiatric history or hospitalizations. He has experienced depressive and anxiety symptoms since the stroke, but has remained optimistic about his recovery. He denies vegetative depressive symptoms or suicidal thoughts. He was diagnosed with an adjustment disorder post-surgery, which was managed with stabilization in the medical floor and a two-week stay at a rehabilitation program.
O: Physical examination revealed two small foci of increased signal intensity in the subcortical white matter of the left frontal lobe, and bilateral foci infarct on the right side of the pons. MRI findings indicated two small Foci of Increased Signal intensity within the subcarotid white matter and bilateral Foci in the right frontal lobe. No vegetative or suicidal ideation was reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is an adjustment disorders, likely exacerbated by cocaine use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of depression and anxiety, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation and history. The prognosis depends on the management of the adjustment disorder and the progression of symptoms.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient and his family, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening depression and the importance of adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment as needed. Patient education regarding the nature of the disorder and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a psychiatrist for further evaluation and management of his adjustment disorder is recommended.

S: The patient reports daily vertigo, worsening with sudden head movements, nausea, vomiting, and difficulties sustaining balance in confined spaces. The patient has a history of meningitis diagnosed at age 2, with no family history of vertigo or epilepsy. The symptoms have since disappeared, but the patient has noticed decreased vision in lateral visual fields for fast-approaching objects.
O: Neurologic and audiometric examination revealed perceptive high tone loss in the right ear, but no evidence of a cause. MRI results were normal. Neurological examination confirmed benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) with new bilateral horizontal nystagmus and a tandem gait below normal for age. Dix-Hallpike test was positive with a predilection to the right. An audiometric evaluation indicated persistent perceptive low tone loss. Follow-up MRI with thin slices through the cerebellum and cerebellopontine angle and series after contrast administration showed no pathology.
A: The primary diagnosis is benign parochial positional vertiginous vertigo with associated perceptive loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vertiginal symptoms, but MRI findings support BPPV. The prognosis depends on the response to home exercises and the management of the vertigo.
P: The management plan includes continuation of home exercises to alleviate symptoms and supportive care for vertigo and hearing loss. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of medication adherence and symptom management will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of BPPVs is recommended.

S: The patient, recently returned from a trip to Lagos, Nigeria, reports a few episodes of syncope, which started six days post-travel. The patient experienced nausea and diarrhea, followed by fevers and sweats multiple times a day. The episode occurred three days post return, and the patient experienced two episodes of synope. The symptoms were described as headache, neck stiffness, sore throat, and respiratory symptoms. No other symptoms were reported during the visit.
O: Physical examination reveals a temperature of 100.8°, pulse 117 beats per minute, blood pressure 127/78 mmHg, respirations 18 per minute and unlabored, and O2 saturation 98% on room air. No significant past medical history or current medications are noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is syncope secondary to malaria, with differential diagnoses including other causes of synapse, such as other infectious or infectious diseases, given the patient's history of malaria and recent vaccinations. The differential diagnosis could include other infectious etiologies, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes further diagnostic tests to confirm the cause of the syncope and to determine the extent of the infection. Treatment will be based on the results of these tests, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on further evaluation and clinical response. Referral to an infectious disease specialist may be considered if the symptoms persist or worsen. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the prescribed medications and follow-up schedules is crucial.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling in the suprapubic area and difficulty in passing urine for the last 4 months. The patient denies fever, vomiting, hematuria, or bleeding per rectum.
O: Physical examination revealed a smooth, firm, slightly tender, nonmobile lump approximately 5 cm above the pubic symphysis, with no palpable lower limit. Digital rectal examination showed a smooth spherical mass outside the rectal wall, but normal rectal mucosa. Blood tests showed a hemoglobin of 12.4 g/dl, total leucocyte count of 8900/mm3, platelet count of 2.54 lakh/mm, blood urea 33 mg/dl (normal range: 0.5-11.2 mg/dL), serum bilirubin 0.75 mg/d (normal: 0-1.2 g/dL for men), S.G.O.T. 16 U/L (normal), SGTP 36 U/l (normal): alkaline phosphatase 88 u/L. Urine culture was sterile. Chest X-ray and ECG were normal. Ultrasound revealed a cystic mass in the pelvis suggestive of a hydatid cyst with bilateral hydroureteronephrosis. CT scan indicated a well-defined capsulated heterogeneously heterogeneous cyst compressing the urinary bladder and rectosigmoid, reaching till the pelvic sidewalls, with moderate hydronephritis on the right side and mild hydrones on the left.
A: The primary diagnosis is a hydrotherapy cyst, likely secondary to a hydration-related cyst. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management of the hydatids. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of the hydronyphrosis, which may require surgical intervention. Patient education regarding the nature of the cyst and its potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports constipation and difficulty defecating for several days. The patient has been diagnosed with cT3N1M0 stage IIIa rectal cancer.
O: Colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor 60 mm from the anal verge, a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. An enhanced computed tomography (CT) showed a 6.3-cm bulky middle to lower rectal tumor and multiple enlarged regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. Emergency CT scan and colonoscopy showed a clinical partial response (cPR) to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NAT) with irinotecan and S-1, with smooth stenosis and fibrous tissue growth. A self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS) was placed across the obstruction as a bridge to surgery (BTS). Post-surgical follow-up showed a successful laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy.
A: The primary diagnosis is cT 3N1 M0 stage IIa rectilinear cancer with complications including obstructive bowel obstruction (CUT) and obstruction of the colon. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with Niti-S Colonic Stent placement to address the obstruction and close monitoring of the patient's bowel function. Post-operative care will include regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Further surgical interventions may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of progressive dysphagia and recent dysphonia and dyspnea, reports increasing difficulty swallowing, hoarse voice, and recent onset of shortness of breath. The patient also mentions difficulty swallowing and recent symptoms of difficulty breathing.
O: Clinical examination revealed a large mass in the oropharynx measuring 80 x 55 mm, measuring firm, tender, without fluctuation, cervical lymph nodes, and pain in the right lower limb. A rescue tracheotomy was performed. MRI revealed a voluminous process infiltrating the posterior tongue, heterogeneous on T1 and T2 tissue signal, and infiltrated the uvula and tonsils. Biopsy of the tongue showed tumoral proliferation with distinct plasmacytic differentiation. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity of CD138 and monoclonal expression of Lambda chains. Whole-body MRI showed a lesional process in the lower metaphysis of the right femur, with polylobed contours and an intermediate signal in T1 with a central zone in hypersignal, measuring 61 x 47 x 47 mm. Laboratory tests showed normocytic anemia, accelerated sedimentation rate, and normal calcemia and renal function. Serum electrophoresis confirmed nephelometric free light chains dosage. Beta2 microglobulin was slightly elevated.
A: The primary diagnosis is a complex congenital malignancy involving the tongue and right femurs. Differential diagnoses could include other malignancies or malignant processes, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the malignant process.
P: The management plan will include surgical intervention to address the malformation, possibly chemotherapy, depending on the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and treatment response. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a pulmonologist for specialized care and a neurologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The owner reports a 3-day-old male Boxer puppy who has been very active and continuously suckling, without gaining weight. He also notes nasal discharge after sucking.
O: Physical examination revealed a midline defect in the hard palate and a caudally divergent defect in a soft palate, classified as a cleft palate. No asymmetrical facial growth was observed. No other congenital diseases were detected. The owner notes that the puppy exhibited good general condition but showed occasional sneezing.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe cleft lip of the Boxer, characterized by a moderately wide, moderately wide palate and absence of asymmetric facial growth. Differential diagnoses could include congenital or congenital defects, but these are less likely given the severity of the condition.
P: The management plan includes attempting to raise the puppy at the Clinic for Obstetrics, Gynecology and Andrology of Large and Small Animals with Ambulatory Service of the Justus-Liebig University in Germany. The puppy will be educated on signs of infection and encouraged to consume milk to gain weight. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the puppy's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, referred in September 2018, reported pain, redness, and hyperemia in the right eye following cigarette ash exposure. The patient underwent corneal scraping and tests, which were negative. Subsequent treatment included levofloxacin eye drops, cefminox sodium, and voriconazole, which did not significantly improve the patient's condition.
O: During hospitalization, a grayish-white ulcer was observed in the central of the bitamporal cornea, measuring 4 × 6 mm, with inflammatory infiltrates with feathered margins and hypopyon with a depth of 2 mm. The cornea had dense central stromal opacity surrounded by a reticular pattern of subepithelial and superficial stromals. Post-surgery, exudation was noted in the anterior chamber, and the mycelium was identified as P. insidiosum, with three protein peaks identified as 2094.01, 4834.62, and 2094-01.
A: The primary diagnosis is a fungal infection of the right cornea secondary to cigarette ash, complicated by the presence of mycelial growth on the PDA plate. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of corneitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the mycellular status and treatment of the infection. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended.

S: The patient, who was brought to the emergency department due to a drowning incident at sea, reports feeling weak and disoriented. He was hemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 100/55 mmHg, heart rate of 135 bpm, and breaths per minute, and was afebrile with a temperature of 36.7 C. Laboratory investigations revealed hematocrit at 23% and hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, with hemodynamic instability. He underwent fluid resuscitation and transfusion, which stabilized his condition.
O: Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamic, with Hct at 19% and Hgb at 6.4 g/dl. Abdominal ultrasonography showed free intra-abdominal fluid. Chest X-ray was negative for tympanic abdomen or pneumoperitoneum. An exploratory laparotomy identified the bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach, which was successfully ligated. The patient was discharged on the 12th postoperative day.
A: The primary diagnosis was a traumatic event involving a drowning at sea with complications including hemodynamic stability, hemodynamic stabilization, and bleeding. Differential diagnoses could have included other causes of acute abdominal bleeding, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included fluid resuscitative and transfusions, followed by surgical intervention to remove the bleeding vessels. Postoperative care included monitoring for signs of infection or complications, and supportive care including hydration and hydration. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate medical attention was provided.

S: The patient, a high-functioning autism worker, presented with symptoms of lethargy and extreme exhaustion, including a fall from the restroom floor, mild flu-like symptoms, a low-grade fever, and multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting over the past 3 days. The patient denies any history of suicide attempts or ideation.
O: Upon examination, the patient's vital signs were temperature 98.2°F, blood pressure 140/71 mm Hg, heart rate 136 bpm, respiratory rate 38/min, and oxygen saturation 96% on ambient air. Physical examination revealed dry mucous membranes, cold skin, decreased turgor, and deep and labored breathing, with chest clear to auscultation. Gastrointestinal and cardiovascular examinations were unremarkable.
A: The primary diagnosis is syncope, likely exacerbated by recent falls from the bathroom floor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of syncope such as respiratory distress syndrome, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the management of syncopation and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and lab values, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on symptom progression and response. Further consultations with a neurologist and possibly a pulmonologist are recommended to manage syncope and manage any potential complications. Patient education regarding the importance of hydration and rest will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old nulliparous woman presenting with right lower abdominal pain. She reports the pain is particularly painful in the lower right side.
O: Vital signs and biochemistry were within normal limits. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a non-echogenic cyst in the right flank. CT scan with intravenous and oral contrast confirmed a right lower abdomen cystic formation with a diameter of 38 by 33 mm and a density of 24 Hounsfield units. Gynecological examination showed a normal cervix in speculo, a mobile uterus with normal adnexa, and an intrauterine device in the uterine cavity, a normal left ovary, and a normal right adnex. An explorative laparoscopy revealed a normal appendix without mucocele. Exploration of the internal genitals revealed a unicornuate uterus and normal left fallopian tube and ovary with infrahepatic positioning.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right upper abdominal cyst, likely secondary to enteric duplication cyst and mesenterial cyst. Differential diagnoses considered included other causes of abdominal pain such as enteric duplications or mesenteric cysts, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes referral to a gynecologist for further evaluation and management of the right upper abdomen. The patient will be educated on the nature of the diagnosis and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the management plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a smoker with a history of hypertension and neurodermatitis, presents with a chief complaint of feeling down, difficulty sleeping, lack of energy, and a recent episode of left-thoracic chest pain lasting about 2 hours. The patient also reports hyperventilation, symmetric leg tingling, and heaviness, but these episodes were not related to the patient's breathing. The symptoms were not associated with any past episodes of dyspnea or consciousness disturbances.
O: Physical examination and an ECG were unremarkable. Troponin T level was significantly elevated at 243 ng/ml (normal <14 ng/mL). ECG showed sinus rhythm, heart rate 84/min, normal cardiac axis, and normal transition between R and S waves. Emergency cardiac catheterization showed severely reduced left ventricular function with typical apical ballooning. N-terminal (NT)-pro-brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels were elevated at 307.0 pg/ml.
A: The primary diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, likely triggered by stress. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and chest pain. The prognosis depends on the management of the underlying condition and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and management of any new or worsening symptoms. A multidisciplinary team meeting will be scheduled to discuss potential treatment options, including potential adjustments in medications or lifestyle modifications. The management team will be involved in managing stress and addressing mental health concerns. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient presents with a chief complaint of hematemesis persisting for 7 days. The patient has a history of laparoscopic cholecystectomy, ischemic brain stroke, and is currently paraplegic due to a lumbar herniated disc. No family history of GI disorders was reported.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be cachectic with a blood pressure of 90/40 mmHg, heart rate of 110 beats/min, respiratory rate of 22/min and oral temperature of 36.8. No icterus in sclera, lymphadenopathy, abdominal tenderness, or palpable mass were noted. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a linear clean base ulcer in the lower third of the esophagus, Mallory Weiss syndrome, likely caused by repeated vomiting, and a submucosal lesion in the bulb area of the duodenum. Endoscopic ultrasonography identified an anechoic lesion measuring 45x55 mm adjacent to the Duodenal wall. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed multiple cortical cysts in both kidneys.
A: The primary diagnosis is MalloryWeiss syndrome, complicated by recurrent vomiting and anechoia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematic symptoms such as gastrointestinal bleeding or other gastrointestinal disorders, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to conservative treatment and the extent of the lesion.
P: Initiate conservative treatment with crystalloid fluids and intravenous pantoprazole. Monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and ensuring compliance with follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the underlying condition.

S: The patient reports intractable pruritus, scaling, dry skin, and generalized eczematous lesions resistant to atopic dermatitis therapy. The patient also experiences red patches all over the body, which have been present for quite a while.
O: Physical examination revealed dry, erythematous scaly patches on the abdomen, face, and extremities, but no typical atopic skin lesions. Height and weight were normal. Biochemical tests, serum folate, iron, vitamin B12, and zinc levels were within normal limits. Urine amino acid analysis, immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM), and lymphocyte subset counts (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD14, CD19, CD56) were normal, and antibody tests were negative. Thyroid hormone levels and thyroid autoantibodies were within the normal reference range.
A: The primary diagnosis is intravascular dermatitis with complications including dry, pruritic, and dermatitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dermatitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the dermatitis and potential complications from the current treatment regimen. Further consultations with an oncologist may be necessary to refine the treatment plan and determine the best approach. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to an allergist may be considered if there is no improvement in the condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing left-sided mastodynia following an excisional biopsy of a fibroadenoma in the left breast. The patient has a history of previous surgical interventions including a biopsy in the right breast.
O: MRI findings revealed a 7 mm enhancing stellate lesion at 9 o'clock in the same breast, homogeneously low signal on T1-weighted images and rapid early enhancement with plateau kinetics on dynamic contrast imaging, with no diffusion restriction. Mammography and breast ultrasound showed a focal asymmetric density with spiculated margins in the superolateral quadrant, no microcalcifications or suspicious lesions elsewhere. A second-look ultrasound identified a small oval hypoechoic mass measuring 4 mm with partially obscured borders. Core needle biopsy identified an infiltrative stromal process with interlacing bundles of fibroblast and myofibroblast, suggestive of a desmoid tumor. Histological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of fibromatosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is fibromatinosis of the left mastodyne, confirmed by histological analysis and biopsy results. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the histological findings and imaging characteristics.
P: The management plan includes a wide excision of the tumor to remove the fibroid. Post-operative care will include monitoring for recurrence and managing any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of follow-up care will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the management plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 26-year-old primigravida woman who presented with a severe postpartum haemorrhage and a blood loss of 2 L. She experienced severe dyspnea post-transfusion, leading to an emergency caesarean section due to complications. She reported feeling severely dyspnoeic post the transfusion.
O: Initial chest X-rays showed congestion. Echocardiography showed severe left ventricular dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of 15%, moderate wall motility in the basal septal region, and no signs of ischaemia or coagulopathy. Follow-up echocardography showed normal left ventral function with normal dimensions within a few days.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute heart failure due to takotsubo cardiomyopathy, evidenced by the echoscopic findings and echographic findings. Differential diagnoses initially included amniotic fluid embolism, which was ruled out by echochromatosis (PPCM). The prognosis is good with the successful recovery of left ventricle function and normalization of ventricular dimensions.
P: The management plan included intubation and transfer to the ICU for further management. The patient was extubated and treated with conventional heart failure medication. Post-treatment, she underwent a follow-up with a psychologist to manage her trauma and improve her health. She is scheduled for a repeat ultrasound in one year to reassess her condition. Further consultations with a cardiologist may be necessary to monitor her condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a slow-growing, ulcerated skin mass on the front, inner part of the left lower leg for approximately 2 years, which is tender and moves around a bit. The mass is approximately 5 by 6 centimeters in size, with skin surface ulceration, purulent drainage, and foul smell. The patient initially consulted traditional healers but did not see improvement.
O: Vital signs and lab results are within normal limits. Biopsy of the lesion at Butaro Cancer Centre of Excellence in Rwanda showed incisional infiltration of the dermis and subcutis, infiltrated by intermediate to large-sized immature cells with irregular nuclei, dispersed chromatin, distinct small nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm, with frequent mitotic figures. Immunostains were positive for CD45, terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (mostly), PAX5, negative for CD3, CD20, myeloperoxidase, and lysozyme. Additional studies at Brigham and Women’s Hospital showed positive CD2, CD33, CD4 (weak), CD56, CD123, and TCL1. Immunophenotype was inconclusive.
A: The primary diagnosis is an incisionous lesion of the lower leg, likely secondary to a wound superinfection, with differential diagnoses including other causes of skin mass infection. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of the infection.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications. Further diagnostic tests such as an immunophenotype or a biopsy will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and guide further treatment. Patient education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the skin mass is recommended.

S: The patient is a 4-year-old girl who was born at 33 weeks of gestation with anastomotic stricture (EA) and a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). She reports a history of multiple surgeries including anastomy, tracheostomy, and gastric interposition. She experienced dysphagia with solid food one year post-surgery.
O: Initial examination under general anesthesia revealed an esophagus with a large tracheoeophageally-induced fistula. Bronchoscopic and esophagoscopic examination revealed a tracheosophagealis fistula at the level of the upper esophageus, likely iatrogenic post stent placement, causing erosion of adjacent tracheooesophagal walls. Endoscopy identified a large, iatrogensic tracheoplasty with a cuffed trachostomy tube, leading to tracheopric interposition. Post-operative findings included a mucosal bridge at the gastroesophagus level, divided under endoscopic vision using a 6 mm flexible endoscope and a 5 mm miniature stapler, with no intra- or postoperative complications reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is a trachosophagus fistula with associated esophagesis, likely induced by stent placements. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esopharyngeal anastasis, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's progress and ensure no further complications arise. Maintain current medications and monitor for any signs of complications. Educate the patient on signs of potential complications and ensure she understands when to seek immediate medical attention. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess her condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, admitted for surgical treatment of a mediastinal tumor detected on a chest roentgenogram, reports no specific symptoms.
O: Chest roentggenogram revealed a mediASTinal tumor in the right thoracic outlet adjacent to the right subclavian vein and right brachiocephalic artery. A preoperative diagnosis of benign neurinoma with malignancy was unavailable.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign neurinal tumor with a possible malignant nature. Differential diagnoses could include other benign tumors or malignancies. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes starting with VATS, followed by dissection of the caudal side using VATS. The patient will be placed in a left semi-lateral decubitus position, with three access ports at the 5th intercostal space on the middle axillary line, 3rd intercostals on the 3rd axillary lines, and 5th in the anterior axillary. The procedure will involve dissection using VATs, with the cranial side being dissectioned using TMA. The intraoperative diagnosis will be a benign tumor compatible with a neurogenic tumor, with a chance of transient Horner syndrome post-surgery. Postoperative care will include monitoring recovery postoperatively and ensuring no functional restriction of the right upper extremity. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old obese male with a BMI of 42 kg/m², with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and arthritis. He reports a surgical history of open appendectomy, incisional hernia treated with intraperitoneal mesh, right colic erosion, and fistula requiring right colectomy. He has a significant past medical history including multiple median and transverse abdominal scar incisions and recurrence of an enormous incisions in the right iliac fossa.
O: Preoperative upper fibroscopy showed 2 cm of BE without dysplasia. Postoperative complications included a gastric leak requiring surgical reoperation and drainage by a Kehr tube. Post-SG, the patient experienced complications including cutaneous dehiscence and a supraumbilical hernia repaired using preaponeurotic subcutaneous polypropylene mesh. Upper digestive tract opacification showed a lacunar image on the lower esophagus. An upper endoscopic ultrasound identified a supra-cardial pediculate hypoechoic lesion 2 cm in diameter without peritumoral lymph nodes. Biopsy confirmed well-differentiated intra-epithelial adenocarcinoma with negative HER2 expression.
A: The primary diagnosis is a well-developed intra-Epithelioid adenoma of the lower gastrointestinal tract (BE) with complications including a supraoperative hernia and a postoperative pseudo-polyp neoformation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric erosion and dyslipids, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and imaging findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the adenomas and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports worsening abdominal pain and distention over the past 4 days. The patient denies any past medical or surgical history.
O: Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals generalized abdominal tenderness and guarding of the abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal an abnormally elevated white blood cell count of 24,900/mm3. Abdominal x-ray shows multiple air fluid levels. CT scan reveals a small amount of free fluid in the abdomen and dilated small bowel loops with ischemia. Laparoscopy reveals severe ischemic distal ileal segment.  ileocececectomy with a side to side primary anastomosis using a 75 GIA stapler.
A: The primary diagnosis is a small intestinal obstruction, likely secondary to a severe ischemic process. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain or distention, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Postoperative management included a laparotomy to remove 20 cm of herniated and twisted distal intestine. Postoperative care included monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and the patient was advised to follow up with the hospital on the 8th postoperative day for further instructions and recovery planning.

S: The patient, a 35-year-old female, reports worsening abdominal pain since completing an extreme conditioning competition two days ago. She has a history of extreme conditioning programs for the past five years and has a weight of 60.5 kg and a height of 1.55 m. She denies any history of diseases.
O: Initial tests revealed serum CK at 43,322 U/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 U/dL). She was advised to take bed rest and drink plenty of water. Subsequent tests showed elevated CK at 77,590 U/l, with normal kidney function and elevated liver enzymes.
A: The primary diagnosis is rhabdomyolysis secondary to extreme conditioning. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and muscle swelling, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation with aggressive IV resuscitation. The patient will be discharged on the fourth day of hospitalization but advised to avoid intense exercise. Follow-up examinations will be scheduled to monitor serum CK levels and adjust treatment as necessary. Education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance for reporting any worsening symptoms or concerns will be provided.

S: The patient, a 2-month-old female, presented with a lump on her left thigh, which has been growing progressively since birth. The patient's parent reports that the lump was first identified on prenatal ultrasound at 30 weeks of gestation as a pre-femoral soft tissue mass of 20/7 mm, which was delivered via cesarean section due to fetal distress.
O: Clinical examination revealed a 25/10 mm nodule on the antero-internal side of the left thigh that was firm, mobile, and within the deep layers. The overlying skin was normal. No other lesions were noted. X-ray and ultrasound showed a 30/13 mm nonhomogeneous mass with a nonspecific vascular involvement. MRI indicated a mass of 19.33/15.19/34 mm with nonspecial vascular involvement, with a low signal intensity in T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on fat-saturated images. Intravascular contrast was administered.
A: The primary diagnosis is a schwannoma of the saphenous nerve, likely a lesion on the left inner thigh. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of soft tissue lesions, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the schwanoma with an italic S-shaped incision from the crural arch distally extended for approximately 6 cm. Post-operative care will focus on recovery and monitoring of the lesion's response to surgery and recovery. Education on signs of infection and signs of potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and obesity, presents with a chief complaint of hip pain following a recent fall. The patient denies any dislocation or fracture.
O: Physical examination revealed proximal muscle weakness greater in the lower extremities, negative for skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, joints inflammation, and pedal edema. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no ST-T changes. Laboratory tests showed elevated CPK (9767), CKMB (101.50), aldolase (60), and LFT derangement (AST-302 and ALT404). Laboratory findings included ANA, anti-Jo antibody, and antimitochondrial antibody. Physical exam showed significant impairment in walking and rising from a chair without support. Laboratory results showed persisting elevated muscle enzyme (CPK, CKMB, and aldolinase) levels. Muscle biopsy confirmed necrotizing myopathy.
A: The primary diagnosis is statin-induced necrosisizing autoimmune myopathy, confirmed by muscle biopsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness such as autoimmune myositis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of atorvastatin and close follow-up in the medical clinic. Initiation of Prednisone therapy at 1 mg/kg per day and taper over three months to improve muscle strength and mobility, along with normalization of muscle enzymes and liver enzymes. The treatment plan will include continued monitoring of muscle function and muscle enzymes, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old multigravid female presenting for a routine antenatal transabdominal ultrasound at 16 weeks gestation. She reports no family history of twins. She has a history of Anti-D post-delivery and a single viable healthy male baby. She denies any history of abortion or miscarriage.
O: Physical examination reveals a height of 165 cm, weight of 63 kg, normal weight of 165 kg, and no history of anaemia or hypertensive status. A colour Doppler study shows two aortic arches emerging from the single functional heart. The patient's abdomen appears slightly large for the date of pregnancy. A Dopple study shows a single functional cardiac heart with two aorts.
A: The primary diagnosis is dicephalic thoraco-omphalopagus conjoined twins, with a differential diagnosis including other causes of pregnancy such as congenital heart defects. The prognosis is guarded due to the malformation and the potential for complications post delivery.
P: The management plan includes termination of the pregnancy, with the patient and her husband advised to schedule an appointment for the termination procedure. She is advised to monitor the condition closely and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further evaluation and investigation of the malformations will be necessary, and the patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 78-year-old Japanese woman, gravida 10, para 2, with a 10-year history of uterine prolapse. She reports bleeding from an ulcerated lesion on the surface of her prolapsed uterus for the past month.
O: Physical examination revealed severe uterine and posterior vaginal prolapse, manually irreducible, classified as stage IV. An ulceration of about 3 cm in diameter and a deep-seated induration were noted on the completely prolapsed surface. Biopsy confirmed keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. MRI showed a 1.6 cm mass in the uterine cervix, with no endometrial cavity invasion. Fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography/CT showed no metastases to lymph nodes or other organs.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage I vaginal cancer with a secondary tumor in the uterus. Differential diagnosis initially included uterine cancer, which was ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is guarded due to the tumor's advanced age and the presence of arrhythmia.
P: The treatment plan includes radiation therapy (RT) alone, with the option of external beam radiation therapy for radiation dermatitis of the genitalia. The patient will be closely monitored for side effects of radiation therapy and is advised to follow up regularly with her team to ensure effective treatment and safe management. Further consultations with oncology and gynecology may be necessary depending on the patient's response to radiation therapy.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old woman with a history of intermittent fever for more than a month, weight loss of 18 kilograms over the past half year, and a dry cough. She reports no recent travel.
O: Physical examination at admission showed a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 101 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min and blood pressure of 142/54 mmHg. Pulmonary examination showed accessory muscles use and bilaterally diffuse rales. Abdominal examination showed a palpable spleen contour without muscle guarding or rebounding pain. Laboratory tests showed a total leukocyte count of 19,900 cells per μL, platelet count of 133,000 per μl, alkaline phosphate at 481 U/L, serum total bilirubin at 3.2 mg/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 311 U/l. Serum transaminases, internal normalized ratio (INR), and aPTT were within normal limits. Chest X-ray showed multiple tiny nodules over bilateral lung fields, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy over the omentum and mediastinum, suggestive of disseminated tuberculosis. CT scan indicated multiple nodules and lymphadomies. Oxyhemoglobin saturation was 83% in room air.
A: The primary diagnosis is disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis with miliary tuberculosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory symptoms such as pneumonia or other infectious processes. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of tuberculosis.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, regular follow-ups with infectious disease specialists, and supportive care. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to a rheumatologist for specialized care and a hematologist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports an electrical burn from a power line, resulting in 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries. The injury to the left knee was treated with three skin grafting procedures and a spatial external fixator (SEF) placed 24 days post-accident, which was kept on for 8.5 weeks. The SEF was locked in full extension. No significant complications were recorded during the treatment.
O: Post-treatment, the patient underwent two additional skin graftings and a bony prominence resection. No PT/OT notes or follow-up were recorded. No complications were noted during treatment, and the patient was advised to schedule an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess the current condition and formulate a comprehensive recovery plan.
A: The primary diagnosis is an open joint injury with complications including an electrical burns and a structural injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee injuries such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the absence of PT/O notes and follow-ups. The prognosis depends on the management of the structural injury and recovery from the SEF.
P: The management plan includes scheduling an appointment for physical therapy and occupational therapy to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns during the recovery process. Further consultations with physical therapists and occupational therapists are recommended to ensure optimal recovery and function.

S: The patient, a 15-year-old male, presents with fatigue for the past 10 days, shortness of breath, cough, sore throat, and a low-grade fever. He reports a history of a similar episode 15 years ago, treated with root canal therapy.
