O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 96 bpm, body temperature of 36.7 °C, hemoglobin level of 36 g/L, mean corpuscular volume of 78.9 fL, and red blood cell count of 1.42 × 10¹¹/L. The patient's reticulocyte count was 2.52%. Urinalysis indicated urobilinogen positive with 4+, and urine red blood cells at 3 cells/μL. Blood chemistry tests showed a lactic dehydrogenase level of 594 U/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 × 10^¹²/L), serum total bilirubin 27.3 μmol/L and indirect bilirubsin 20.45 μmol. Serum autoantibodies showed ANA 188.35 IU/ml, anti-double-stranded DNA antibody 186.42 IU/L with an AnuA 27.01 IU/mL, antiSSA antibody positive, anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL) IgG and IgM positive, antiβ2-glycoprotein-I antibodies positive, and Coombs test 4+.
A: The primary diagnosis is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), complicated by autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of autoimmune hemoglobinuria, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: Initiate treatment with dexamethasone at 10 mg daily to manage SLE. Monitor hemoglobin levels and renal function closely. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects.

S: The patient is an 85-year-old woman with a history of pseudoexfoliative glaucoma, presenting with decreased vision in her right eye for approximately 4 months. She reports that her vision is currently 20/60 in the right eye. Recently, she has experienced a central scotoma in the same eye.
O: Initial OCT showed a macular hole (MH) in the left eye, which was successfully closed after a month. Post-OCT, the best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) improved to 20/50. A second OCT confirmed the closure of the MH, revealing intraretinal cystic spaces. The patient's current BCVA is 20/125 in her left eye. No immediate surgical intervention is planned at this time.
A: The primary diagnosis is macular macular septum (MH), with complications including a spontaneous closure of MH and intraretinous cystic space. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or progression of the macular issue. The management of the vision issues will be based on the patient’s response to the new OCT findings and the need for surgical intervention. Education on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan will be provided to the patient and her family to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of vision issues is recommended.

S: Patient 3 reports experiencing hoarseness and difficulty swallowing for a few weeks.
O: CT scan revealed a 3.8 cm left thyroid tumor with superior mediastinal and tracheal involvements, currently at stage pT4bN0M0. Post-surgery, post-surgical chemotherapy will be administered with docetaxel at 120 mg/m2 and cisplatin at 30 mg/mm2. Postoperative radiation therapy will be 70 Gy per fraction, followed by intensity modulated radiotherapy at 70 Gy at 2.5 Gy/min.
A: The primary diagnosis is a left thyroid cancer with a history of metastasis to the trachea. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the successful surgical resection of the tumor.
P: The management plan includes post-operative care with postoperative care including post-procedure care and monitoring for any recurrence or metastasis. The patient is advised to continue regular check-ups to monitor for any signs of recurrence. The treatment plan will be adjusted as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment and ongoing care.

S: The patient, a 37-week gestation female, presented for delivery at the 37th week of gestation. She reports a history of two children and three abortions, with one previous cesarean section. She expresses a preference for conservative surgical management for massive bleeding.
O: Preoperative blood tests showed hemoglobin at 10.8 g/dL, prothrombin time (PT) of 10.5 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 29 seconds, international normalized ratio of 2.3, and platelet count of 385x109/L. Transabdominal sonography and magnetic resonance imaging showed total placenta previa and myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder at the anterior wall of the uterus. Post-cesareaning, the patient experienced a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss at the posterior wall of her uterus. Pelvic packing was applied for 20 minutes, and 1.0 polyglactine sutures were placed. Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter was placed in the uterus for suturing. Postoperative complications included intraoperative hemorrhage, which was managed with erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 unites postoperatively) and 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe intraoperative bleeding secondary to a ruptured uterine and hypogastric artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to the surgical intervention and the management of the hemorrhage.
P: The management plan included surgical intervention with pelvic packing, suture of the bleeding sites, and placement of a Seng staken- Blakemore balloon. The patient was educated on the signs of hemorrhage and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Education on signs of bleeding and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: The patient, a long-term smoker with a history of stage IIIa non-small cell lung cancer in the upper lobe of the right lung, reports progressive deterioration of renal function post initial immunotherapy with nivolumab. The patient has a long history of smoking 20 cigarettes per day and no other comorbidities.
O: Physical examination revealed a normal body temperature of 36.7°C, blood pressure of 135/70 mmHg, and pulse rate of 80 bpm. Previous treatments included radiotherapy, chemotherapy, paclitaxel, carboplatin, and immunotherapy. PET/CT scan showed malignant extension to tracheobronchial and subcarinal lymph nodes. The first infusion of nivolinumab was administered approximately 105 days after initial exposure, with serum creatinine of 176.8 μmol/L and an eGFR of 35.2 ml/min/1.73m2. Subsequent treatments included additional cycles of nivaolumaban, which were administered, and the patient's eG FR declined to 14.8 ml/μmol/μl.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIIA non-smoker's disease with complications including renal function impairment and acute renal impairment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the renal function deterioration.
P: Continue monitoring renal function and adjust treatment as necessary. Maintain current immunotherapy regimen as needed. Consider additional chemotherapy or radiation therapy based on the patient and oncologist's response to the current regimen. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or progression of the disease. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management if renal function deteriorates.

S: The patient, with a history of acromegaly and a transsphenoidal pituitary resection three weeks ago, presents with severe, intermittent, throbbing headache and clear nasal discharge since the removal of a nasal splint. The headache worsens with standing or cough, but acetaminophen is effective.
O: Physical examination and neurological examination were normal. CT scan of the head revealed multiple air loculi in the basal cisterns, lateral, third and fourth ventricles, and numerous air-filled spaces in the brain, with no mass effect or midline shift observed. A repeat CT scan showed mild increased diffuse pons in the parafalcine region, anterior horn of the left ventricle, posterior fossa, and left middle fossa.
A: The primary diagnosis is a diffuse pulmonary occlusion (PNC) with intracranial air loculae in the anterior horn and posterior fossas, causing a mass effect on the pons. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal discharge, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes rest in bed in the Fowler position at 30° and avoiding Valsalva maneuvers like analgesia, coughing, and sneezing. The patient will be monitored closely for any signs of worsening symptoms or changes in the PNC. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, currently undergoing chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), reports a terrible reaction to pentamidine treatment, leading to severe abdominal pain, emesis, diarrhea, lightheadedness, and fainting. The patient initially developed a nonocclusive thrombus involving arteries, including the celiac trunk, proximal hepatic, and splenic arteries. Post-treatment, the patient experienced severe abdominal and emesis pain, diarrhea (twice), and lightness (twelve minutes). The patient also developed a nonspecific rash without mucosal involvement, which was initially attributed to trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Abdominal X-ray showed non-obstructive gas patterns with small bowel wall thickening, followed by a platelet transfusion for thrombocytopenia. MR enterography showed a non-occlusive, patchy transmural ischemic colitis. Postoperative pathology confirmed patchy ischeptic colitis without local thrombal involvement.
O: Initial treatment included intramuscular epinephrine and intramural epinellase, which led to a positive response. Subsequent treatment included partial colectomy with patchy transverse colon to mid distal colon pathology, which showed patchy transmission of transmural colitis with no evidence of local thromabosis or emboli. A paired two-tailed Wilcoxon test on pre- and post-anaphylactic platelet levels showed an overall P value of <0.0001, indicating significant platelet changes.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute Myeloid Leukemia with complications including a nonocalctomy and patchy disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischeic colitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to the desensitization protocol and the management of symptoms.
P: Continue current regimen of intravenous pentamiline and monitor platelet function closely. Maintain regular monitoring of platelet counts and response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports a visual change in the left eye, described as blurry and distorted. The patient has been diagnosed with choroidal melanoma, confirmed by histopathology.
O: Initial imaging in January 2016 showed hepatic lesions in the liver. In August 2016, the largest lesion was identified, measuring 7.1 × 5.8 cm (M1b). LDH was 641 U/L and ALP was 111 U/l. Liver biopsy confirmed metastatic uveal melanoma (MUM). Repeat imaging in November 2016 showed a marked decrease in the size and number of metastatic liver lesions.
A: The primary diagnosis is choroid melanoma with complications including hepatic and liver metastases. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of melanoma. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the disease and the complexity of the patient's condition.
P: The management plan includes continued surveillance with nivolumab (1 mg/kg) and ipilimumab (3 mg/ kg) every 2 weeks, with TACE treatments every 4 weeks. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor disease progression and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient reports a chronic right-sided headache, foul discharge from the nose, and a nose that feels stuffed. The patient has a history of maxillary osteomyelitis treated with multiple interventions and a complex mediofacial resection in 2009, resulting in a subtotal defect of the hard plate, maxillary sinus, and nasal septum. Additionally, the patient has depression and type two diabetes mellitus managed with peroral therapy.
O: Recent nasal endoscopy and CT scan revealed a huge pathologic cavity in the nasal cavity, with minor communication with the right orbit. Biopsy results showed severe but unspecific changes in the epithelium, including zones of reserve cell hyperplasia, epithelial erosions, ulcers, squamous cell metaplasia with acanthosis, and squamous cells metaplas. Subsequent treatments included complete replacement of glandular epithelia and submucosal squamous tissue nests, with no signs of cellular atypia. Interstitium was severely affected by granulation tissue, fibrosis, and chronic inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes and plasma cells, but giant cells were absent.
A: The primary diagnosis is empty nose syndrome (ENS) based on clinical and endoscopic findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal mucosa changes, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's symptoms and adherence to follow-up appointments. The treatment plan will include adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the clinical findings and biopsy findings. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists will be necessary to manage the condition effectively. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis and potential side effects of the treatment will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old male with a history of 48% TBSA third-degree injuries, reports an electrical burn following contact with a power line at age 16. He underwent six skin grafting procedures prior to the placement of the SEF 53 days post-discharge. He has undergone two additional surgeries post-SEF placement, including ulnar nerve transposition, heterotopic ossification removal, and contracture release with arthrofibrosis excision. He reports a 13-month follow-up post-surgery showing a final ROM of 20°–90° in the extension and flexion arc, supination of 25°, pronation 85°, and motor strength of 4-/5.
O: The initial PT/OT notes showed a final range of motion (ROM) of 20-90°, supinating and pronation not tested, and a 4/5 motor strength. Prior to the elbow contracture, the ROM was 0°–30°, with supination 25° and pronations 85°. Prior post-elbow contracture releases, the patient's ROM was reduced to 0°-30° in extension, and supination was 25°. The patient experienced heterotopia ossify, cubital tunnel syndrome, and elbow stiffness.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe right elbow injury with complications including orthotopic and neuromuscular involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint pain and stiffness, but these are less likely given the history and current findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in joint strength and the absence of further surgical interventions.
P: Continue physical therapy and follow-ups regularly to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the need for immediate reporting of any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms. Consider referral to a pain management specialist if symptoms worsen or new symptoms arise.

S: The patient reports experiencing nocturia and bothersome symptoms. The patient has been diagnosed with castration-resistant prostate cancer (cT3aN1M1b).
O: Initial blood test showed elevated PSA levels at 76.2 ng/mL. Digital rectal examination revealed induration in the prostate. Pelvic MRI showed extensive high signal of the prostate in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI). Fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography/CT confirmed multiple spine and pelvic bone and para-aortic and pelvic lymph node metastases. Post-treatment, the patient's PSA level increased to 2.33 ng/L. CT, bone scan, and WB-MRI showed multiple osteoblastic lesions in the spine and pelvis, and shrunken para-axillary lymph nodes. Histopathological examinations of both the prostate and vertebra showed 10 of 12 cores of viable prostate cancer cells. CT-guided needle biopsy from the osteoblast lesion of the second lumbar vertebra confirmed the presence of viable cancer cells in the bone and vertebral lesions.
A: The primary diagnosis is castration resistant prostate cancer, confirmed by PET and MRI findings. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to androgen deprivation therapy and the management of the disease.
P: Initiate androgen therapy with degarelix and an anti-androgen agent called bicalutamide. Monitor PSA status closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments to monitor disease progression and treatment efficacy.

S: The patient, a 70-year-old male, reports experiencing dizziness and difficulty with memory and thinking since turning 70. He also mentions difficulty in moving his hands and has noticed slower movements lately.
O: Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score was 23, indicating mild cognitive impairment. Neurological examination revealed mild bradykinesia in movements. Brain CT scan revealed calcified areas in various regions of the brain, including the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, pulvinar thalami, dentate nucleus, and subcortical and periventricular regions.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild cognitive impairments, likely exacerbated by calcified brain regions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cognitive impairment, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes regular check-ups and monitoring of the patient's condition closely. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms or concerns. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient’s response to treatment and lifestyle changes.

S: The patient reports a dull, aching generalized abdominal pain for eight months, worsening after meals, nausea, and reduced appetite. The pain worsens with bowel movements, with softer stool but no melena or hematochezia. The patient has a history of hypertension and has undergone four surgeries within the last 10 years, including laparoscopic cholecystectomy, laparoscopectomy, umbilical hernia repair, and tubal ligation. No significant weight loss was reported. Family history includes breast cancer and prostate cancer.
O: Physical examination is unremarkable. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a nonobstructing, nonbleeding cratered ulcer in the posterior wall of the gastric body. Biopsies indicated moderate-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. PET scan showed increased uptake in two regions in the medial gastric fundus and a second region near the cecum, with abnormal circumferential thickening and pericolonic inflammatory changes. Colonoscopy showed a fungating, partially obstructing, nonsbleeding, circumflexing mass in the Cecum. Blood tests showed anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.3 and a CEA level of 0.819 preoperatively.
A: The primary diagnosis is synchronous gastric and colon cancer, with differential diagnoses including malignancy and metastatic disease. The prognosis is good given the resectability of the tumor and the absence of metastatic spread.
P: The management plan includes surgical resection of the colorectal cancer. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's bowel movements and bowel function, with follow-up appointments scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a male, presented to the emergency department after accidentally taking two celphos tablets approximately 7 hours ago. He reported shortness of breath and passing cola-colored urine. He has a history of hemolytic anemia and was unaware of any other drugs causing the symptoms.
O: Vital signs include blood pressure 76/54 mm Hg, pulse 114/minute, respiratory rate 24/minute. SaO2 is 86% in ambient air. Oxygen at 4-5 L/minute was administered. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 15/15, with no focal neurological signs. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis. Hemoglobin levels fall from the initial baseline, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated hemoglobin at 11 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows normal hemosiderin.
A: The primary diagnosis is hemolysis, likely exacerbated by celphosal ingestion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes administration of central venous pressure guided intravenous fluids, ionotropes, and magnesium sulfate injections. The patient will be admitted to the ICU for further management. Continuous monitoring of hemoglobin levels and biochemistry will be necessary, with the patient advised to avoid taking any drugs that may worsen the hemolytosis. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor hemogram results and hemodynamic status. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient, with no past medical history, presented with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, weight loss, and painless jaundice. The pain began suddenly and was severe, accompanied by significant weight loss and yellowing of the skin and eyes.
O: Emergency management included stabilization in the emergency room. Physical examination revealed scleral icterus. Laboratory tests showed liver enzymes dysfunction: alanine transaminase at 144 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase at 122 U/l, alkaline phosphatase at 331 IU/L. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia was noted at 5.4 mg/dl. Immunoglobulins assay showed an increase in IgG total to 15.1 g/dl, and IgG subclass analysis showed an increased IgG-4 level to 155 mg/dL. Tumor marker screen for cancer antigen 19-9 was normal. Imaging showed lymph node enlargement close to the celiac plexus origin and minimal calcification of the pancreatic head. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) showed distal stricture in the common bile duct, relieved with stenting. ERCP brushing was suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangeitis (PSC). Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) was unremarkable.
A: The primary diagnosis is autoimmune pancreatitis, initially diagnosed as autoimmune pancreatic disease. Differential diagnoses initially included hypothyroidism and Hashimoto's, which were ruled out by negative imaging and tumor marker screen. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive response to steroid therapy.
P: The management plan includes continuation of thyroxine therapy for autoimmune pancreatis. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. The patient will be educated on the signs of recurrence and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology may be necessary to address the underlying cause of pancreatitis.

S: The patient, who underwent a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy to treat a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, reports a history of pancreatic fluid leak from the tail of the pancreas and an abdominal drain. The drain was removed, and subsequent imaging confirmed a well-demarcated, hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection adjacent to the tail. The patient experienced a neurological event before the stent was removed.
O: Initial postoperative imaging showed an increase in the size of the pancreatic duct stent with internal barbs. An endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and placement of a 15 mm x 10 mm LAMS under endosonographic guidance from the stomach drained large amounts of pus. A CT scan of the abdomen a month later showed a decrease in the volume of the LUQ rim-enhancing fluid collection.
A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatic neoplasm with complications including pancreatic mucosa leak and renal dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatitis, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the absence of complications.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up scans to assess the effectiveness of the current treatment and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the renal dysfunction and renal function. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing low blood pressure, chest pain, and difficulty breathing for the past three days.
O: Doppler sonography revealed acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT), characterized by blood clots in the deep veins of the body, usually in the legs. Echocardiography showed severe right ventricular dysfunction and enlargement. The patient's systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) was 70 mmHg, which was significantly reduced.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute deep venous thromboembolism (DVT) with complications including severe right lung dysfunction and pulmonary artery obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of DVT, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of reteplase to break down blood clotting and improve heart function. Follow-up appointments are scheduled in a few weeks to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Recommend lifestyle modifications and medications to prevent future DVT episodes. The management team will recommend lifestyle changes to prevent DVT.

S: The patient, with a history of poorly controlled diabetes, presented to the emergency room with vomiting blood and disorientation. The patient reported experiencing nausea and epigastralgia for the past 2 days.
O: Physical examination revealed a general status of shock, with no response to rehydration. Laboratory findings included blood glucose level of 470 mg/dL, arterial blood gas pH 7.2, PCO2 25.2 mmHg, HCO3 9.9 mEq/L, and PO2 169 mmHG with an anion gap of 24.3 mEQ/L. Positive urinary ketones and glucose were noted. Intubation and emergency endoscopy revealed black pigmentation in the entire esophageal mucosa. CT scan showed circumferential edematous thickening of the esophagus with slight pleural effusion, but no perforation or free air in the mediastinum.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute esophagocytic encephalopathy (AEN) with complications including esophagesis and pleural perforations. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophagic encephalopathies, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Initiated treatment with antibiotics, glycemic control, proton pump inhibitors, and plasmapheresis. Post-operative care included extubation on day 5, followed by chest X-ray showing accumulation of pleural fluid. Emergency thoracoscopy was performed, revealing significant pleural and perforated esophas. The procedure involved resection of the transmural necrotic thoracic esophago and placement of drainage tubes at the posterior mediastinal and diaphragm. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's diabetes status and adherence to diabetes management.

S: The patient, a 6-year-old non-pregnant huacaya alpaca mare, presented with respiratory symptoms for approximately 6 weeks, with forced breathing but no fever. She has also lost weight. The patient reports no improvement in symptoms.
O: Clinical examination revealed the patient to be alert and nervous, with a body mass of 53 kg (normal 55-90 kg) and a body condition score of 1 out of 5. Rectal temperature was 38.3 °C, within normal range of 37.5–38.9 °C. Heart rate was 72 beats per minute, within the reference range of 60-80 bpm. Respiratory rate was 60 bpm (normal 10–30 bpm). Laboratory tests showed a neutrophilia of 9.37 × 10^9/l, slightly above the reference interval of 3.4–9.1 × 10 µL, and low potassium levels at 3.64 mmol/l (normal 4–5.2 mmol/L). Blood chemistry showed low potassium, low magnesium, and magnesium levels.
A: The primary diagnosis is respiratory symptoms and weight loss, likely exacerbated by the patient's recent weight loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory symptoms such as metabolic disturbances or metabolic disturbances, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the alpacaya mare's respiratory status and weight management. Further diagnostic tests such as complete blood cell count and blood chemistry panel will be conducted to determine the cause of the respiratory symptoms. The owner will be educated on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a 39-year-old male with a history of acroparesthesia, heat intolerance, severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal abnormalities, and bronchial asthma, presents with progressive dyspnea, reduced physical activity, periodic cardiac arrhythmia, palpitations, dyspsia, tinnitus, hearing impairments, and angiokeratoma in the umbilical region. He also reports episodes of Tinnitus and hearing impairment.
O: Physical examination revealed a normal glomerulus filtration rate and normal kidney ultrasound. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm, short PR interval, and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy with secondary repolarization abnormalities. Echocardiography showed asymmetric myocardial hypertrophaly in the LV apex and in the lateral wall without LV outflow tract obstruction. Two-dimensional strain analysis showed reduced global longitudinal strain (GLS−14%), especially reduced in the posterolateral wall (peak systolic strain−8%), and normal diastolic function of the LV. Cardiac MRI showed asymmetrical myocardia with no fibrotic alterations. Brain MRI showed white matter hyperintensities.
A: The primary diagnosis is Fabry disease, evidenced by the patient's clinical suspicion and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocarditis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the progression of the disease and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of cardiac function and renal function. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow up with healthcare providers as needed. Further diagnostic workup will be conducted to assess the progression or resolution of the condition. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old female presenting with right wrist pain and swelling following a fall. She reports a history of a distal fracture of the right radius, treated with splinting and subsequent return to the local hospital. She describes blister formation along the splint application area as heat and stuffiness.
O: Physical examination revealed blister formation on the right forearm. Plain X-ray examination revealed a distally displaced distal bone fragment (AO classification: type A2). Plain Xray examination of the forearm revealed a dorsal displacement of the distal bones fragment. The patient underwent minimally invasive locking plate osteosynthesis using the Henry approach. No skin lesion was found at the incision site.
A: The primary diagnosis is a distral fracture of a right radius with dorsal displacement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blister formation such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the surgical outcome and the absence of skin lesions.
P: The management plan includes minimally-invasive locking plates for the surgery site. Postoperative care will include immobilization in a bulky dressing without an arm splint until tissue swelling has decreased. All muscles, vessels, and nerves of the anterior compartment will be retracted ulnarly. The pronator quadratus will be incised transversely at its distal portion and dissected off the periosteum using a periocentral elevator preserving its ulnar and radial insertions. Postoperatively, the wrist will be immobilized postoperatively without an elbow splint. The procedure will involve careful monitoring of tissue swelling and nerve function.

S: The patient, with a history of arthritis and a right total hip arthroplasty performed 9 years ago, reports complications including choledocholithiasis treated with intravenous antibiotics and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stone pulverization and placement of two plastic 10F × 12 cm biliary stents. The patient experienced septic shock, fevers, chills, lethargy, altered mental status, and E. coli-positive blood and urine cultures. Recently, the patient experienced right hip pain and inability to move.
O: Recent CT scans showed two partly calcified soft tissue masses and a fine needle biopsy of the right hip and psoas locules, with 100 mL of pus aspirated. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a 3 cm hepatic abscess. A recent MRI of the hip showed a large air- and fluid-filled collection.
A: The primary diagnosis is a hepatic infection, likely secondary to an iliopsoas abscess and periprosthetic infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hip pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the hepatic infections.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications. The management team will focus on managing the infection and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a housewife with a history of TOT surgery 2 years ago, presents with urinary incontinence issues, characterized by cough, walking, and dysuria during sexual intercourse. She reports using duloxetine 80 mg daily for 3 months and has not taken any other medications. She denies alcohol consumption or tobacco smoking. She has a past medical history of two vaginal births and one cesarean delivery.
O: On examination, the patient's temperature was 36.6 °C, pulse 82 beats/minute, and blood pressure 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination revealed no abdominal tenderness or anatomic anomalies. No murmurs or arrhythmia were detected during auscultation of the heart. Respiratory frequency was 14/minute. Neurological examination showed normal muscle strength and tone, with normal ulnar, patellar, and Achilles reflexes. Urine analysis showed microscopic hematuria. Laboratory tests showed a total white blood cell count of 6.9 × 10^3/mm3, hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL, alanine aminotransferase 38 u/l, aspartate aminOTransferases 35 u/L, C-reactive protein 1.1 mg/l and creatinine 0.6 mg/dl. Serological tests were negative for hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg), anti-hepatitis C virus (HCV), and anti-HIV. Uruvate culture was sterile.
A: The primary diagnosis is SUI, likely secondary to TOT, given the history of previous surgical interventions and current symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infection (UTI) and urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Continue Kegel exercises and duloxyetine for now. Schedule a follow-up appointment to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of SUI. Consider consultation with a hematologist for ongoing management of UTI and possibly a nephrologist for potential long-term management.

S: The patient, with a history of severe peripheral vascular disease, right hip disarticulation, and paraplegia, reports a stage IV pressure ulcer on the left greater trochanter leading to osteomyelitis. The patient underwent a Girdlestone procedure, which led to an invasive infection in the hip and acetabulum, leading to the wound draining and dehiscing.
O: Initial examination revealed a grossly necrotic femoral head with a large open wound over the greater trochter. Cultures from the Girdleestone procedure grew Staphylococcus epidermidis. Post-operative care included a Cleanse Choice NPWTi-d, delayed primary closure over closed suction drains, and placement of a Prevena negative pressure device over the incision. The incision healed completely, but persistent low volume drainage was noted at five months postoperatively.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe infection of the greater extremity, likely secondary to a Staphococcus Epidermidi infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of infection and infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the wound and infection with ceftriaxone and vancomycin. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and absence of recurrence of the infection. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection or infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing seizures and is concerned about them. The patient has a history of glioma diagnosed in May 2010, treated with chemotherapy with TMZ, which led to anorexia, insomnia, and depression. Recently, the patient experienced another seizure requiring hospitalization.
O: MRI findings in 2010 showed intra-axial expansive and infiltrative lesions in the anterior half of the right temporal lobe, extending from the pole to the Sylvian fissure superiorly and to the right parahippocampal gyrus posteriorly and medially. Pathologic diagnosis was astrocytoma grade II. Subsequent treatments included TMZ at a dose of 2,000 mg, cycles every 28 days from 2011 to 2013, with no tumor regrowth. In 2015, MRI findings revealed discrete extension of signal alteration areas in the subinsular regions. The tumor size increased to 100 mg/day in March 2015, leading to a surgical re-approach.
A: The primary diagnosis is gliocarcinoma with complications including recurrent seizures, anorexic disease (PSD), and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up MRI scans to assess tumor size and response to treatment. Maintain current chemotherapy regimen and monitor for any recurrence of seizures. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan. Consider referral to a neuro-oncology specialist for further evaluation and management of the recurrent seizures.

S: The patient reports experiencing left-sided testicular pain for about a month, a dry cough, fever, weakness and tiredness, and decreased appetite over the past four days. The patient has a history of insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, stage 3 chronic renal disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be febrile and tachycardic, with left testicular edema and pain on epididymal palpation. Laboratory tests showed neutrophilic leukocytosis with 24.2 x103/uL WBC and 87% neutrophils. Chest X-ray showed thickening of the bronchial walls but no parenchymal abnormalities. Urinalysis showed an increase in white blood cells and Gram-negative bacteria. Testicular ultrasound revealed an abscess in the tail of the left epididysis. Initial treatment included oral doxycycline therapy, which was discontinued on the fourth day due to worsening respiratory symptoms and inadequate metabolic control. CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed multiple bilateral nodular lesions and left pleural effusion. Blood and urine cultures were positive for K. pneumoniae sensitive to penicillin, quinolone, and carbapenem. Chest CT confirmed multiple nodules with halo sign and reversed halo signs.
A: The primary diagnosis is SpE secondary to epididymitis, based on the imaging and clinical evolution. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of acute respiratory symptoms, but these were ruled out based on imaging and lab results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the response to the current antibiotic course and the improvement in respiratory symptoms.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of doxychloroquine and initiation of intravenous ciprofloxacin. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists will be necessary to manage the underlying conditions. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing pelvic and abdominal pain following a serious car accident. The patient denies any issues with voiding.
O: Clinical examination revealed pelvic instability and blood loss from the urethra. An urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a small liver laceration and an unstable pelvic fracture, with normal kidneys and empty bladder. External fixation was performed, but the bladder was not visible on ultrasound. A suprapubic catheter was attempted, but it was unsuccessful. A follow-up abdominopelvic CT scan with an excretory phase showed a nearly empty and upwards displaced bladder with contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity. Post-trauma, the patient experienced progressive clinical deterioration with signs and symptoms suggestive of sepsis.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to a traumatic car accident, evidenced by the patient's symptoms of hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, abdominal pain, and severe electrolyte imbalance. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain and renal impairment.
P: The management plan included immediate hemofiltration, followed by a laparotomy, which drained copious amounts of urine, and drainage of the bladder dome. Postoperative care included close monitoring and supportive care, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient’s condition and potential complications, including potential septic infection or complications related to the trauma. Education on the importance of hydration and hydration was provided to the patient and family.

S: The patient, an eight-year-old female, presented with massive ascites over the past two months, leading to fatigue, abdominal distention, and weight loss of 10-15 pounds. She has no significant medical history and has been on anti-tuberculosis medications.
O: Physical examination at a tertiary care hospital showed normal vitals, but the abdomen was distended with no signs of peritonitis or perforation. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin 14.6 g/dL, low red cell indices, low platelet count 641,000/microliter, hypochromia, anisocytosis, microcytosis with few reactive lymphocytes, and increased platelets. C-reactive protein was 24.27 mg/L. Liver function tests and coagulation profile were normal. ascitic tap results were positive for red blood cells with a total lymphocyte count of 122/cumm, protein 2.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/L), and Serum-ascites albumin gradient of less than 1.1 gdL. Cytology showed mature lymphocytes and reactive mesothelial cells, but no atypical cells. Chest X-ray and Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA by PCR were negative. CT scan of the abdomen showed gross ascites with omental thickening and nodularity.
A: The primary diagnosis is ascites secondary to suspected abdominal tuberculosis, complicated by the patient's symptoms and ascites. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ascites such as infectious or infectious processes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes continuation of supportive care and supportive care. The patient is advised to continue monitoring her symptoms and report any significant changes or worsening of symptoms immediately. Further diagnostic tests may be necessary to determine the exact cause of the ascites and determine the extent of infection. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and importance of follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient, a male on renal dialysis for the past 2 years, presents with general malaise and septic shock-like symptoms. He reports feeling weak and unwell. He has a history of end-stage hepatic failure (Child-Pugh stage C) treated with anorexia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia. He denies any type of cancer, chemotherapy, corticosteroid therapy, autoimmune diseases, or alcohol consumption. He was unaware of his blood pressure being unmeasurable prior to admission.
O: On admission, the patient was afebrile, severely anemic, and icteric with liver dysfunction and hemorrhagic tendency. Laboratory tests showed high serum C-reactive protein, increased direct bilirubin, extremely high hyaluronic acid, and type IV collagen levels, and reduced total protein and albumin levels. Laboratory findings included reduced hemolytic complement (CH50) and C3 levels, with normal C4 levels. Abdominal CT revealed pleural effusion and small ascites. Cell counts were 272/μL, with a negative culture. Blood culture revealed Cryptococcus.
A: The primary diagnosis is decompensated liver dysfunction with complications including severe anemia, anemia (HBCV), and hemorrhage. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney failure and hemolysis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive care, and supportive care. The patient will continue on dialysis with appropriate anticoagulation therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of liver dysfunction, infection, and other symptoms. Education on recognizing signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided. Referral to a hepatologist for specialized care and a hematologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient, diagnosed with refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML), was admitted for treatment. The patient reports feeling worried about the treatment plan.
O: Current hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dl, and platelet count is 20,000 per microliter. Urinalysis is normal. Recent labs show fever and neutrophil count. Hemoglobin levels are stable. Recent CT scan of the paranasal sinuses revealed sinusitis with hyperdense opacification. Surgical intervention included sinus endoscopy and functional endoscopic sinus surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is refractive alveolar leukemia (EML), complicated by catheter-related infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes administration of meropenem and teicoplanin as antibiotics. Antibiotic lock therapy will be initiated, along with systemic antibiotics. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and imaging studies are necessary to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on the patient's response to treatment and any new symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment efficacy and manage side effects. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: 
- Patient reports persistent abdominal pain, constant, light-colored discharge, and occasional vaginal bleeding. No history of previous periods.

O:

S: SZ.F reports a 4 cm lump in the neck that has been bothering him. The lump started to grow and became painful recently.
O: Recent blood tests were normal. Fine needle aspiration cytology indicated lymphoproliferative disorder. Neck CT scans revealed a 33x25 mm hypodense, homogenous mass in a neck region, with other smaller lymph nodes in the surrounding area. Open surgical biopsy identified necrotic tissue with a fibrotic capsule and Vimentin-positive connective tissue components and vessels. Silver impregnation indicated residual reticular sinusoidal structure. Immunohistochemistry indicated histiocytes and residual lymphoid cells. Ki-67 reaction showed a 10% proliferation index of CD-20 positive lymphocytes.
A: The primary diagnosis is subtotal lymph node infarction, a non-cancerous condition. The patient's condition is currently under control with no signs of malignancy.
P: The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor and was treated with a routine CT scan showing a 17 mm cystic mass in the incision area. The final histologic diagnosis was a lymph node infusion without signs of cancer. The prognosis is good, with no evidence of recurrence or metastasis.

S: The patient reports difficulty breathing and chest discomfort. He has a history of severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, enlarged heart chambers, right moderate ventricular dysfunction, and severe tricuspid regurgitation post-surgery. He also has a past medical history of cerebral infection and Kaposi's Sarcoma.
O: Recent test results indicate Ebstein's anomaly, severe right heart atrial, right ventricle dilatations, enlarged cardiac chambers, and right moderate Ventricular dysfunction. The patient also experiences low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS), which necessitates ECMO support.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe heart failure with complications including severe atrial atrial dysfunction and severe right ventral dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will focus on managing the heart condition and ensuring HIV immunodeficiency is well-controlled with appropriate medications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and adherence to prescribed medications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, diagnosed with severe HEMA in early childhood, reports a history of factor VIII activity less than 0.001%, and a brother who also suffered from severe hematuria (HEMA). The patient was diagnosed with F8 mutation in the late 1980s and early 1990s, which led to the development of a smaller and less frequent mutation in F8. The patient has been cured for HIV-1 and hepatitis C, but has been diagnosed with HIV LTNP.
O: Genetic testing for F8 mutations was not performed due to the distant past of the diagnosis. Blood transfusions were administered, and the patient was treated with factor VIII inhibitors. A blood sample in EDTA tubes and isolated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) over ficoll gradient was depleted. Whole exome sequencing (WES) was performed employing Kapa H.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe HMA with a differential diagnosis of F8, likely due to genetic predispositions. The absence of factor X inhibitors suggests a smaller mutation in a specific mutation, potentially contributing to the patient's HIV LTN phenotype.
P: The management plan includes reviewing the results of the WES and further genetic testing to determine the causative mutation. Further follow-up will be necessary based on the results and any further diagnostic findings. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a female with a history of metastatic breast cancer treated with mastectomy and systemic chemotherapy, reports no recent abdominal pain or fever. She has been on lapatinib, capecitabine, zoledronic acid, and steroids for cerebral oedema.
O: Recent CT scan revealed moderate pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, with intramural gas along the caecum and ascending colon. No other abnormalities were noted. The patient has been taking lapatinab, capecabine and zoledron acid for cerebral edema. The oncologist has decided to discontinue steroids due to concerns about the presence of gas in the tissue.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic metastatic cancer with complications including pneumatitis and intramuranic gas. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and fever, but these are less likely given the absence of other concerning findings.
P: The management plan includes conservative clinical and radiological surveillance to monitor the patient's condition and detect any new symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-up imaging will be conducted to monitor for any recurrence or progression of the disease. Patient education on the importance of reporting new symptoms and ensuring compliance with the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient, a 37-week pregnant female, presented for obstetric ultrasonography at 37 weeks gestation. She reported no issues during her pregnancy, and no abnormalities were noted during the examination at 22 weeks.
O: During the ultrasonographic examination, the patient was lying down, and the baby appeared to be developing well. No abnormalities were found during the ultrasonic examination at the time.
A: The primary diagnosis is a foetal malformation, likely due to the patient's pregnancy and the ultrasound findings. The prognosis is good with no signs of abnormalities noted during ultrasonology.
P: The management plan includes continued regular check-ups and monitoring for the remainder of the pregnancy. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in the pregnancy immediately. The plan includes scheduling a next appointment to reassess the baby's development and ensure no further complications arise. The family is encouraged to reach out with any concerns or changes during the pregnancy to ensure continued health and support.

S: The patient presented with a moderately severe frontal headache, which has been bothering him for the past 9 months.
O: Initial Brain MRI showed multiple discrete regions of abnormal signal and mild swelling involving white matter and overlying cortex. Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) showed numerous cortical lobar microbleeds throughout both cerebral hemispheres. A repeat MRI showed resolution of many parenchymal abnormalities but new peripheral microbles. Amyloid-PET using 18F-florbetapir showed moderate widespread amyloid deposition. CSF analysis showed reduced amyloids-beta 1–42 and high-normal total tau. Neuropsychological testing suggested mild compromise in frontal functioning only. Follow-up MRI showed almost complete resolution of the parenchyma and persisting lobar macrobleeds.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild frontal compromise, evidenced by imaging findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headache such as transient brain injury, but these are less likely given the imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of 5 days of intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily) followed by an oral taper from prednisololone 60 mg over 8 weeks. The patient will continue to be monitored with stable brain imaging to assess for any new symptoms or changes in condition. Further follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of synthetic cannabinoid use for approximately five years, presents with a chief complaint of strange symptoms including peeing blood and nosebleeds. The patient also mentions a red eye.
O: Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals a right conjunctival hemorrhage in the eye, active epistaxis in the left nostril, and blood-tinged urine. Laboratory results indicate a prothrombin time greater than 106 seconds, partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 79.5 seconds, and INR of not determinable.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute chemical-induced coagulopathy, likely exacerbated by synthetic cannabinoids. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coagulation, but these are less likely given the lab results and clinical presentation.
P: The treatment plan includes administration of intravenous vitamin K1 50 mg and two doses of oral vitamin K 1 50 mg over the next two days, with instructions to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and to report any new symptoms or concerns. Further treatment will be initiated with intravenous Vitamin K1 100 mg and oral Vitamin K 1 100 mg until PT normalizes. The plan includes monitoring and management of blood loss in the context of an acute chemical induced coagulusopathy. Education on the importance of avoiding synthetic cannabinoids and the potential risks associated with them will be provided.

S: The patient, a 53-month-old female, reports progressive bilateral breast enlargement and accelerated growth since she was 9 months old. She denies vaginal bleeding or development of pubic or axillary hair.
O: Physical examination reveals a well-looking girl with normal blood pressure, weight of 17 kg, height of 108 cm, mid-parental height 175 cm, predicted adult height 167 cm using the JM Tanner formula. Tanner staging is A1, P1, and B3, with a reddish mucoid vagina but no clitoromegaly, acne, hirsutism, or palpable abdominal mass. Laboratory tests reveal a basal luteinizing hormone level of 3.1 mIU/L (normal range: 5-15 pg/ml) and elevated estradiol E2 at 29,000 pg/mL (normal: 2.3 ng/mL), dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate at 90 ng/L, and early morning cortisol level of 16 ng/dL (normal 7-28 ng/ml). Abdominal ultrasound reveals a right-sided hypoechoic suprarenal mass with ovarian volume of 1.8 cm3, uterine volume of 3 cm3 and endometrial thickness of 0.2 cm3. An abdominal CT scan shows a 25 × 22 mm well-defined rounded focal lesion at the level of the right adrenal gland with homogeneous attenuation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a hypoechopositis with associated ovarian and uterine enlargement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperplasia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the hypoarthritis.
P: The management plan includes referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for further evaluation and management. The patient will be monitored closely for any signs of recurrence or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education regarding the nature of the condition and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a gynecologist for specialized care is recommended.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male presenting with a chief complaint of progressive dysphagia for the past 8 months, characterized by difficulty swallowing and a foreign body lodged in the throat. He denies pain during swallowing or voice changes.
O: Physical examination revealed no obvious pathology. An indirect laryngoscopy showed a protrusion in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall, unremarkable endolarynx exam, and normal vocal cord mobility. Neurological examination was normal. CT scan of the cervical spine showed extensive flowing anterior osteophytes from C5 to D1, with a level of compression at C5-C6. The level of compression on swallow studies was C5.
A: The primary diagnosis is progressive dysphangia, likely secondary to a foreign object in the neck, given the patient's age and the presence of osteophyte levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagias, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes discharge with a prescription for anti-inflammatory drugs and dietary recommendations for dietary changes. The patient will be monitored for any worsening of symptoms and advised to return for follow-up if symptoms worsen or if he changes his mind about surgery. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a dietitian are recommended to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

S: The patient reports a chief complaint of left eye redness and swelling for more than a month, accompanied by mild blurred vision, double vision, and occasional headaches. The patient has a history of a head injury, basilar skull fractures, subarachnoid haemorrhage, and epidural haematoma treated with conservative treatment at a local hospital. Symptoms began 4 months post-accident, with blurred vision and swelling in the left eye. The left eye exhibits eyelid swelling, exophthalmos, chemosis, and corkscrew hyperaemia.
O: Physical examination revealed visual acuity and intraocular pressure in the right eye, with values of 6/5 and 17 mmHg, respectively. The right eye exhibits slight hyperaemic, eyelid and exophalmos swelling, and mild ptosis, with no limitation on eye movement. The cornea exhibits abduction and elevation, normal movement on adduction and depression, and shallow left anterior chamber. No abnormalities in the eye's internal structures or imaging findings were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is left eye inflammation, likely secondary to a traumatic head injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual symptoms such as retinal detachment or retinal swelling, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the eye inflammation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on clinical response and laboratory results. Further consultations with ophthalmology and ophthalmology may be necessary depending on the progression of the condition and response to therapy. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a specialist in retinal and corneal diseases for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient is a 20-year-old male with no known co-morbid conditions, presenting with a three-week history of low-grade fever and weakness in one of his limbs, worsening over time. He reports feeling out of consciousness for the last five days. He has no recent contact with pets.
O: Physical examination reveals a thin and lean young man with a Glasgow coma scale of 13/15 (E4, M5, V4). Neurological examination reveals increased tone in the right lower limb, normal limb bulk, decreased power in the upper and lower limbs, and decreased power at 5/5 in the left limbs. Laboratory findings include complete blood count, urea, creatinine, electrolytes, liver function tests, calcium, magnesium, and albumin levels. Lumbar puncture shows protein 46mg/dl (normal range 20-40 mg/dl), glucose 72mg/dL (60% of plasma glucose), 6 red blood cells (normal 0-4/cumm), and 5 white blood cells. MRI of the brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the white and grey matter, surrounded by vasogenic edema. AFB smear and MTB DNA test are negative. C3 and C4 levels are within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is a brain tumor with associated symptoms of fever, weakness, and altered consciousness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's neurological status and response to treatment. The patient will be educated on the importance of regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the neurological symptoms is recommended. Education on the nature of the tumor and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports 2 generalized tonic-clonic seizures within 1 month. The patient has a history of choroid plexus papilloma treated with posterior fossa resection and a cadaveric dural patch in 1980. There is no family history of brain hemorrhage or cognitive impairment.
O: Clinical examination revealed longstanding right arm mild pyramidal weakness and ataxia, and a slightly unsteady gait. Brain MRI showed patchy T2 hyperintensities bilaterally, 5 punctate foci of restricted diffusion at the gray–white matter interface, intermittent left anterior centrotemporal theta/delta activity, enhanced by drowsiness and hyperventilation, and occasional sharp slow waves. Follow-up brain MRI showed multifocal abnormal cortical signal and swelling on T2-weighted sequences, with associated leptomeningeal enhancement and recent subarachnoid hemorrhage. Lumbar puncture showed 680 red blood cells and elevated protein levels at 0.99 g/l.
A: The primary diagnosis is primary central nervous system vasculitis, likely secondary to the patient's recent seizures and associated neurological deficits. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures and neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Initiated treatment with levetiracetam for seizures and a 24-hour electrocardiogram. Initiated intravenous methylprednisolone 500 mg daily for 5 days, followed by oral prednisololone (50 mg). The patient underwent a brain biopsy, which revealed leptomereningeal and cortical CAA with scattered leptomeeningeal hemosiderin deposits and widespread diffuse parenchymal Aβ deposits. Ongoing monitoring and supportive care will be necessary to manage the condition effectively.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old white female, gravida 3, para 0, presenting with dizziness, impaired vision, facial edema, and increasing edema in her lower legs since yesterday. She reports a history of gestational hypertension and is currently on alpha-methyl-dopa 250 mg 1-2-1 medication. She has been on magnesium 40 mg 1/1-1 and progesterone 100 mg 2-0-2 since the onset of this pregnancy. She also reports a blood pressure of approximately 175/105 mmHg.
O: Physical examination revealed a tumor at the posterior wall of the uterus, likely a fibroma. Ultrasound revealed two viable embryos, with no pathologies identified. The patient underwent genetic counselling and testing for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), lupus erythematosus, and thrombophilia, which were ruled out. An ultrasound of the genital organs indicated a tumor. A hysteroscopy showed an arcuate uterus but no need to interfere surgically. Follow-up ultrasounds showed two embryos.
A: The primary diagnosis is a fibromatoma, likely related to the patient's history of multiple inseminations and assisted reproductive technologies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pregnancy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded given the patient and her history of maternal and fetal health.
P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the patient’s pregnancy and fetal development. The management of hypertension and diabetes is essential, with adjustments to medication as necessary based on the patient-somatic status and ongoing fetal health assessments. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the management plan and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and monitoring for potential complications is crucial.

S: The patient, a former smoker with a history of urothelial bladder cancer, presents with chest pain localized to the middle of the chest, described as pressure, worsening with active exertion. No sweating or palpitations were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 147/85 mmHg and a heart rate of 79 beats/minute. An exercise stress test showed inferior wall ischemic changes. An elective angiogram revealed a sinus rhythm with a right bundle branch block, but no ST segment or T wave changes indicative of ischemia. Lab tests including troponin, lipid profiles, and fasting blood glucose were within normal limits. Coronary angiograms through the right femoral artery showed an anomalous origin of the left circumflex artery and the right coronary artery from a shared ostium, with 80% stenosis in the middle and distal segments and 70% in the proximal segment. The left coronary ostia was found to originate from the right anterior descending artery, with no significant stenosis. A cardiac multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) was performed to further study the anatomy of the coronary arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is a coronary artery anomaly, likely related to the patient's history of bladder cancer and previous smoking. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain such as ischemias or vascular malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included aborting the procedure to perform the MDCT to further investigate the coronary artery anatomy. The patient will be closely monitored for any signs of infection or complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation. She reports a two-week history of acute on chronic left hip pain, severe, sharp, and constant, radiating to the left thigh. She cannot walk due to the pain.
O: Physical examination revealed a 3-cm decubitus ulcer in the left lower extremity. Laboratory tests showed elevated potassium at 7.2, creatinine at 13.34 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen at 103, white blood cell count at 51,200/mcl, platelet count at 585, lactic acid at 7,2, erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 97, and C-reactive protein at 23. Electrocardiogram indicated generalized hyperacute T waves. A non-tunneled central line catheter was placed for urgent hemodialysis, but the patient became hypotensive and tachycardic, not responsive to aggressive intravenous fluids resuscitation. Vasopressors were initiated, and vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam were administered. Blood cultures showed Gram-positive rods. A left hip arthroscopy was performed, but no synovial fluid was yield.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to urinary tract infection with suspected blood culture contamination. Differential diagnoses could include other sources of infection, but these are less likely given the negative urine culture and negative blood cultures. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying infection.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on ongoing lab results and lab results. Maintain current medications and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports experiencing anxiety and depressive symptoms, which began after excessive acetaminophen use in 2012. The patient has a history of an ischemic stroke two years prior to the onset of anxiety and depression. The stroke left the patient with incomplete Broca's aphasia and dysprosody, which have progressively worsened over time.
O: Physical examination revealed no family or personal history of psychiatric diseases before language impairments. A cerebral MRI showed diffuse white matter high-signal hyper-intensity in the left posteroinferior portion of the frontal lobe, anterior to the motor cortex.
A: The primary diagnosis is speech impairment, likely related to the stroke and the patient's history of a stroke. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of speech impairment or cognitive impairment, but these are less likely given the MRI findings.
P: The management plan will include speech therapy, medication, and counseling to address both speech impairment and anxiety. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of rheumatic heart disease and an episode of IE three years ago, presents with a chief complaint of low-grade intermittent fever and progressive shortness of breath for the past two months. The patient has a non-smoker and no intravenous drug use.
O: Physical examination revealed a low grade fever of 99 °F, tachycardia with 110 beats per minute, hypotension at 90/60 mm Hg, mild pallor, and bilateral pitting ankle edema. Chest auscultation revealed displaced apex beat and pan-systolic murmur radiating to the axilla, bilateral basal crepitation, massive cardiomegaly with interstitial edema, and mild pleural effusion. 2D-Echocardiography showed a dilated left ventricle, severe aortic and mitral regurgitation, and reduced ejection fraction to 30%. Trans-esophageal echocardography showed deformed calcified mitral valve and a large 14×17 mm vegetation on the aortical valve, with grade 3 mitral and aortics regurgitating. Blood tests showed mild anaemia and normal biochemical profile.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe cardiomyopathy with complications including severe cardiopulmonary involvement and severe cardiac involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiomatosis such as pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Initiated empirical antimicrobial treatment with Ceftriaxone 2 g IV once daily, Gentamicin 60 mg IV 8 hourly, and Vancomycin 120 mg 8 hourly. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment regimen as needed. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient reports a diagnosis of a left frontal tumor with minimal contrast enhancement. The patient underwent en bloc resection of the tumor but noted loss of white matter tissue on the medial/inferior side of the brain.
O: MRI findings include minimal enhancement. Histopathological examination of the left frontal brain revealed an IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma with a Ki67 proliferation rate of 25%. PET scan identified 15 ROIs in the hot spot (ROI1), five with medium uptake (ROi2), and one with lower MET uptake in the tumor periphery. No significant correlation between MET uptake and tumor perfusion.
A: The primary diagnosis is a WHO grade III tumor with a WHO-grade III Ki67 proliferative rate. Differential diagnoses could include other types of brain tumors, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment and potential for further treatment. The management will include regular follow-up appointments to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The treatment plan will include close monitoring and supportive care for the patient and family, with emphasis on adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen.

S: The patient reports a 12-month history of cognitive decline, characterized by loss of weight, nausea, gait disturbance, and tremor. The patient has a history of dull holocephalic headache that persisted for 3 months, diagnosed as tension-type headache and a depressive disorder. Previous treatments included duloxetine, which did not improve the patient's symptoms.
O: Initial examination at a neurologist showed no focal neurological signs. Neurological examination in February 2012 showed bilateral white matter lesions and an old lacunar lesion at the left striatum. MRI in May 2012 showed a severe decline of attention, memory, and executive functions, with a weight loss of 20 kg over the past year. Recent diagnostic work-up at the SMZ-Ost-Donauspital revealed a weight of 47 kg, with significant changes in gait and muscle tone. No paresis or pyramidal signs were observed, but tendon reflexes were brisk.
A: The primary diagnosis is subcortical dementia, likely exacerbated by vascular encephalopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cognitive impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient’s neurological status and adjustment of treatment as necessary. Referral to a neurology specialist for further evaluation and management of vascular enchilada is recommended.
