Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, who underwent an open REYGB six years ago, presents with crampy abdominal pain over the past few days, intermittent vomiting and obstipation. The patient denies fever or changes in bowel habits.
O: Physical examination revealed abdominal tenderness. Abdominal CT scan indicated dilatation of the biliopancreatic limb of the REYEGB, intussusception of the small bowel through the jejunojejunostomy, and a dilatated bile duct in the biliary tract. An exploratory laparoscopy was performed to reduce the intususception and check the viability of the bowel loops. No bowel resection was necessary.
A: The primary diagnosis is a dilated biliopygia (REYGB) with an intusception in the small intestine. The successful surgical intervention was achieved, and the patient is expected to return to normal bowel function in about two days.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's bowel function and monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications related to the surgery. Post-operative care will include monitoring for recurrence of symptoms and ensuring no further complications arise. Further consultations with gastroenterology and possibly a gastroenterologist may be necessary depending on the response to the surgical intervention.

S: The patient, with a history of morbid obesity and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion and intermittent substernal chest pain for the past two months. The patient has a significant weight loss post-surgery, with an 18-point drop in BMI from 100 pounds to 24 pounds. No history of tobacco abuse, excessive alcohol consumption, or drug use was reported.
O: Physical examination revealed resting bradycardia with a heart rate of 55 BPM and blood pressure at 89/54 mmHg. BMI was 24. Electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST wave changes. High sensitivity troponin I was within normal limits (<0.017). EKG exercise stress test was performed using Bruce protocol. At rest, the heart rate was 68, during stage I of exercise 81, and during stage III of exercise at 10.4 metabolic equivalents (METs) increased to 133 beats per minute. No significant rise in heart rate until stage IV of exercise.
A: The primary diagnosis is post-surgical dyspneal dyspnias, likely secondary to weight loss from bariatric surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and dyspnesia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of cardiac function and symptomatology. Regular follow-ups with the primary care physician are recommended to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications will be provided to prevent recurrence. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac symptoms is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and benign prostatic hypertrophy, presents with a four-day history of testicular swelling and pain. The patient reports persistent back pain.
O: Physical examination revealed an abscess on the inner gluteal fold of the perineal region, spontaneously draining serosanguinous output. The left scrotum appears erythematous and indurated, with no signs of cellulitis. Mild tenderness to palpation of the scrotal area, with crepitus in the thighs or scrotus, and no blood-tinged drainage from the wound. A CT scan of the spine revealed a recent L1 vertebral compression fracture with sclerosis, lumbar spine compression fractures at T12, L3, and L4, and multilevel degenerative changes in the lumbarean spine.
A: The primary diagnosis is Fournier's gangrene, evidenced by the patient's history of ureterolithiasis and nephrolithiasis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scrotary swelling and tenderness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will include referral to urology and general surgery for further evaluation and management of Fourniers gangrene. Referral to a urologist for further management of the gangrene is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, transient ischemic attack, and osteoarthritis, presents with a chief complaint of a fall due to syncope. He reports taking aspirin 81 mg once daily, losartan 25 mg daily, and multivitamins.
O: Physical examination revealed no focal neurological deficits, additional heart sounds, or murmurs. EKG showed a 2-mm ST elevation in the lateral leads I and aVL and a reciprocal 1-mm depression in the inferior leads II, III, and aVF. Initial troponin T level was 0.81 ng/dL, significantly higher than the reference range of less than 0.03 ng/L. Left ventriculogram showed an ejection fraction of 30% with poor anteroapical and distal inferior wall hypokinesis. Cardiac angiography showed non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Left Ventriculography showed an EF of 30%, poor anteryx, and distral inferior wall hyperokinesia suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Lipid panel showed total cholesterol 140 mg/dL (normal range: 140-140 mg/L), LDL 60 mg/dl (normal: 60-70 mg/l), and HDL 73 mg/mL (normal ranges: 0.1-6.7 mg/ml). Transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed apical ballooning and akinesis, typical of Takotubo Cardiomyopath.
A: The primary diagnosis is Takotsobo cardiacopathy, evidenced by elevated troponins, creatine kinase, and liver enzymes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the patient's history of smoking and hypertension.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of cardiac function and liver function. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician to discuss further treatment options and adjust the medication regimen as necessary. Regular follow-ups with the cardiology team are recommended to monitor the progression of the disease and manage risk factors. The plan includes regular monitoring of the patient and liver functions, adjusting the treatment plan as necessary, and regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as needed. Education on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications is crucial.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest pain and hoarseness recently. The patient has a history of a traffic accident 3 months ago, resulting in fractures in the femur, radius, ribs, and sternum, which were treated with internal fixation.
O: Physical examination was normal. A CT scan revealed a ruptured aortic arch with a pseudoaneurysm measuring 20 mm x 48 mm x 30 mm in the upper mediastinum. The pseudoaneursm was compressed by the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. A thoracic and abdominal CT angiography on the 7th postoperative day showed no leak or reconstruction of blood vessels.
A: The primary diagnosis is a rupture of the aorta with a significant compression of the left primary artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain or hoarness, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan included a hybrid operation involving debranching and thoracical endovascular aortics repair (TEVAR) using artificial vessels and a covered stent. The procedure was successfully performed, and the patient is advised to monitor recovery and report any new symptoms or concerns. Further follow-up care will be necessary to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with cT3N2M0 disease, reports a history of stage IIIA luminal-HER2 type breast cancer treated with preoperative chemotherapy, epirubicin plus cyclophosphamide, and weekly PTX. Post-mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection, the patient achieved a Grade 1b therapeutic effect. The patient underwent trastuzumab and LHRH-a with tamoxifen, but did not undergo post-mastmastectomy radiotherapy. The prognosis is guarded due to the absence of pathological CR.
O: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast cancer with complications including lung and internal mammary lymph node metastases. The progression of disease post-surgery and adjuvant endocrine therapy has shown a complete radiological response and non-pathological values for CA15-3 and NCC-ST-439. The last follow-up was in August 2018, indicating the patient has survived for 10 months post-termination of anti-her2 therapy.
A: The clinical presentation and imaging findings support the primary diagnosis of metastatic cancer, with differential diagnoses including other forms of breast cancer and metastatic disease, given the patient's history of multiple surgeries and the absence or absence of radiotherapy post-surgical intervention. The absence of CR and the presence of metastases post-treatment are concerning for the prognosis.
P: Continue regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or progression of cancer. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and regular monitoring for any new symptoms or concerns. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule a follow up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms persist.

S: The patient, a newborn, was admitted for ineffective breastfeeding and failure to thrive. He was born at term from spontaneous delivery, small for gestational age, with a delayed intrauterine growth restriction detected during the last month. The parent reports that the newborn's external genitalia and skin pigmentation are normal.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests revealed severe hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia, metabolic acidosis, increased lactate, and urinary sodium loss. Endocrinological tests showed low plasmatic aldosterone levels, dramatically increased renin, elevated adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and normal plasmatric cortisol levels. Neonatal screening for 17-OH-progesterone was within normal limits. Cerebral ultrasounds and cerebral MRI were normal. ECG and chest X-rays were normal, and abdominal MRI showed normal size of the adrenal glands.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe neonatal imbalance with electrolytes imbalance, likely exacerbated by the lack of electrolytes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neonatal abnormalities, but these are less likely given the clinical and hormonal findings.
P: The management plan includes continued electrolyte replacement, Fludrocortisone (50 μg/die) and salt integration therapy, with regular blood tests to monitor electrolyte levels. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor growth and development. Further consultations with a pediatric endocrinologist may be necessary to manage electrolyte imbalances and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of gastric cancer surgery, presents for a gastroscopy due to eating obstruction. He reports experiencing nausea and vomiting, severe pain in the chest and lower back, and neck compression. He describes the procedure as painful and uncomfortable.
O: Recent esophagus CT scan shows normal esophageal CT. Laboratory analysis revealed serum RBC 4.7cell/L; Hgb 138 g/L (normal range: 0.8-1.2% for men and 0.1-1% for women). Post-procedure, the patient experienced subcutaneous emphysema in the thoracolumbar segment and face and neck, with crepitus. Emergency CT scan revealed extensive subcutaneously emphyphysem in the neck, large amounts of left pleural effusion, and no pneumothorax. Postoperative findings included a long strip rupture in the esophagia, treated with blood stasis and a hemostatic clip, followed by a large Boston's clip. Esophagal angiography showed no contrast agent leakage or exacerbation of emphysysema.
A: The primary diagnosis is spontaneous esophagic rupture of the esosophagus, complicated by severe postoperative complications including severe post-operative complications and complications from surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophagesis, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes fasting and anti-infection treatment. Postoperatively, the plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and adherence to follow-up appointments. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology may be necessary to manage the patient and his condition.

S: The patient, a homeless individual, presented with upper extremity swelling and pain in the left arm. He was discharged after treatment for cellulitis but left before further tests could confirm his diagnosis. He denies any significant past medical or surgical history.
O: Physical examination revealed swelling, redness, tenderness, and a normal heart rate. Laboratory findings showed a WBC of 256 with 87.5% atypical lymphocytes, hemoglobin of 13.4 g/dl, and platelet count of 166 x 109/L, with a potassium level of 5.4 meq/L. A peripheral blood smear showed smudge cells and enlarged lymph nodes. Flow cytometry confirmed CLL with monoclonal B cells. Over the course of the hospital stay, potassium levels were asymptomatic at 8 meq-L, and electrocardiogram showed no changes.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), complicated by the patient's history of untreated cellulitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lymphadenopathy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient and his condition. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to medical advice and adhere to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to treatment and follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 9-year-old female, presents with bilateral glaucoma, treated with Sholl solution and anti-acidosis capsules three times daily, and eye drops containing a β-blocker and carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. She has a history of oligohydramnios during pregnancy, and was prematurely born with intrauterine growth retardation. There is no family history of inherited diseases, cataract, or pRTA. The patient's weight and height are below the 3rd percentile, and she has demonstrated intellectual disability. Neurological signs are unremarkable. The family history includes a history with oligohydramsnios and intrauterines growth retardations.
O: Recent laboratory tests show sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 3.1 mmol/l, chloride 110 mmol/dL, blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL and creatinine 0.9 mg/L. Blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.22, HCO3− 11 mmol/mL, and PCO2 29 mmHg. Urinalysis shows normal urinary excretion of amino acids and a urinary β2-microglobulin level of 110 μg/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 μg/dL). Thyroid hormones, IGF-I, IGFBP3 levels, renal ultrasound, and brain MR imaging confirm parenchymal stone in the right kidney. No intracranial calcification was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is parenchyal stone syndrome (pRTA) with associated symptoms of micrognathia, fish-mouth, epicanthal folds, ptosis, low-set ears, a short neck with a low hairline, a broad shield-like chest, and wide-spaced nipples. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of parenching, but these are less likely given the patient's short stature and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and her condition. Regular follow-ups with the infectious disease team are necessary to assess the progression of the condition and manage any potential complications. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided. Referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for specialized care and a geneticist for genetic counseling are recommended. Education regarding the nature of the disease and its implications will be reinforced to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports progressive dyspnea with mild exertion, edema in the lower extremities, paresthesia, and pain. The patient has a history of viral perimyocarditis treated four months ago and new onset heart failure with reduced ventricular ejection fraction.
O: Vital signs show the patient to be afebrile, tachycardiac with a heart rate in the 110s BPM, tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 20s Br/min, and normotensive with a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Laboratory findings include neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis with a WBC count of 19 x 10^3 mcL, elevated brain natriuretic peptide at 2506 pg/mL, troponin-I at 0.48 ng/mL and D-dimer at 6.6 μg/mL. Echocardiogram shows severe global hypokinesis, moderate-to-severe systolic dysfunction, paradoxical septal motion, and multiple biventricular pedunculated mobile echodensities. A CT study for pulmonary embolism revealed right lobar pulmonary emboli and bilateral small pleural effusions.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute coronary syndrome with complications including right lobnar pulmonary embollus and bilateral pleural edema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute coronary artery disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes urgent embolectomy and thrombectomies to remove blood clots and restore blood flow. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's heart function and blood flow, with appropriate treatment for heart failure. The treatment plan will include continued monitoring of cardiac function and hemodynamic status. The management of the heart failure will be based on the patient’s response to the treatment and the management of underlying conditions. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing vision loss in both eyes for the last 5 days, accompanied by severe headache on the right side and jaw pain.
O: Neuro-Ophthalmological examination revealed alertness and oriented visual acuities, with no light perception in both eye pupils. Slit lamp examination revealed punctate cataract. Funduscopic examination revealed diffused swollen of the optic disc with pallid "chalky white" appearance, atrophy around the optic discs, and tenderness in bilateral superficial temporal arteries. Laboratory tests showed slightly decreased RBC and Hb levels, normal platelet count, and elevated CRP levels. Color duplex ultrasonography (CDUS) indicated decreased posterior ciliary artery, central retinal artery, and ophthalmic artery in both areas. The CDUS showed inflammation of the vessel wall as a hypo-echoic concentric ring, referred to as the "halo sign." orbital fat-suppression T1-weighted MRI with contrast showed enhancement of optic nerve sheath in the left eye but no inflammatory or mass occupation lesions. MRA results were unremarkable. Right temporal artery biopsy revealed occlusion of the luminal.
A: The primary diagnosis is inflammation and occlusions in the temporal arteries, with differential diagnoses including other causes of visual impairment such as optic nerve injury or optic nerve involvement. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular monitoring for any new symptoms or changes in vision. Referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent induction chemotherapy (IC) on day 0. He experienced bone marrow suppression and fever on day 10, followed by bone marrow septic shock. He reports a recurrent fever and hemiplegia from day 10 to day 25, followed initially by neutropenia and hemiconvulsions on the right limb. He also experienced a sudden onset of hemorrhagic fever and sudden hemiphemia on day 25.
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 100.70 pg/mL. CT scans of the brain showed a hyperdense lesion with surrounding edema and small hypodense areas in the left and right parietal lobes. MRI of the lung showed multiple hyperdenses on day 18. Febrile neutropensia with cerebral symptoms after chemotherapy was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is a fungal infection, likely secondary to chemotherapy, given the positive β-D-glucan test on day 22. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage and brain lesions. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the fungal infections.
P: Continue current treatment with voriconazole and imipenem as antifungal and antibacterial agents. Monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are essential to manage and monitor for any recurrence or complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports sudden onset left upper limb dyspraxia and confusion. The patient has a history of hemochromatosis and a distant history of meningococcal meningitis.
O: Initial MRI revealed a large right parietal lesion. CT and PET scans identified left upper and lower lobe lung lesions, a solitary liver lesion, and a base of skull lesion in the brain. Follow-up MRI brain showed intracranial recurrence but confirmed stable extracranial disease. A redo craniotomy was performed, complicated by cerebral abscess and ventriculitis. A burr hole and drainage confirmed corynebacterium acnes, leading to intravenous Cephalothin treatment. ECG showed sinus tachycardia, left axis deviation, and right bundle branch block. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a new circumferential pericardial effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiac MRI confirmed ICI-induced Pericarditis with associated pericardiial effusions.
A: The primary diagnosis is BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma with complications including intracral recurrence and pericarticular effusion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pericarcoma such as myocarditis or myocardial infarction. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the diagnosis and the need for close monitoring.
P: The management plan includes continuation of intravenous (IV) Cephelothin for 12 weeks, discontinuation of immunotherapy, and regular monitoring of cardiac status. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with a cardiologist are recommended to manage the patient's condition and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of well-controlled hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage III, and a right solitary kidney from a left-sided nephrectomy for atrophic kidney from ureteropelvic junction obstruction. He reports worsening shortness of breath over the past week, which he describes as feeling bloated. He denies experiencing fever, night sweats, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, or similar symptoms. He is currently on atenolol, allopurinol, atorvastatin, and over-the-counter antacids and laxatives.
O: Vital signs and oxygen saturation on room air were normal. Physical examination revealed decreased tactile fremitus and dullness upon percussion with reduced breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray showed a large right-sided pleural effusion. Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis removed 1.5 liters of turbid orange fluid. A CT scan at presentation showed right-side hydroureteronephrosis extending down to the urogeno-vesicular junction and an irregular bladder wall thickening.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent right-siphonal pleurisy, likely secondary to a primary bladder tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pleural discharge, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the potential for complications.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the pleural fluid cytology and consultation with a primary care physician to formulate a comprehensive treatment plan. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up appointments to monitor his condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Education regarding the nature of the condition and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a gardening worker, reported being bitten by a snake approximately five hours ago. He was unaware of any medication or alcohol use until the incident.
O: Physical examination revealed mild swelling and pain at the bite site, and epigastric pain. The patient was fully conscious, alert, and oriented. Laboratory findings showed mild swelling, tenderness on the right foot with two fang marks below the right lateral malleolus, heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg on a supine position, mild postural dizziness, and increased thirst. WBCT20 was <20 min, and INR was 1.05.
A: The primary diagnosis is a Merrem's hump-nosed viper bite, likely secondary to a previous bite by a pit viper. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute pain and swelling, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Initiated treatment with oral fluids intake of 0.6 L and intravenous infusion of 0% saline at 100 ml/hour, with a total of 3 L over 24 hours. Tetanus toxoid and oral cloxacillin 500 mg every 6 hours were administered, respectively. A generalized tonic-clonic seizure occurred 23 hours after the bite, lasting 30 minutes. The management plan includes monitoring the patient closely and providing appropriate antivenom as the only available antivenomer is not effective against hump-Nosed pit vipers. The family was informed about the seizure and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old ambulatory male with a history of hypertension, sarcoidosis, complete atrioventricular block status post-pacemaker implantation, chronic kidney disease due to FSGS, and right facial nerve paralysis. He reports sporadic gait and numbness in the right face. He has a history with sarcoids diagnosed 14 years ago, treated with immunosuppressive therapy. He also experienced palpitations and complete cardiac block (FSGS) diagnosed one year ago.
O: Recent labs show a serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL, proteinuria of 0.4 g/day, and no Hematuria. Renal biopsy revealed sclerotic glomeruli and residual glomerulosclerosis with segmental sclerosing lesions. The patient's proteinuria was mild, and he was treated with a pacemaker implant. Recent CT with iodinated contrast and CT angiography showed no ischemic lesions or occlusion of major cerebral arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is primary atriovaentricular blocks (FSGs) with complications including transient ischemia (TIA) suspected. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac symptoms, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient’s symptoms and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The management will include regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment as needed. Patient education regarding the nature of his condition and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the TIA is recommended.

S: The patient, a 4-year-old female, presented with a fever and swelling in her right leg for a while. She has a history of Takayasu arteritis diagnosed at age two, treated with prednisolone and tocilizumab, and has been resistant to standard therapy.
O: Physical examination and imaging studies revealed a fever, swelling, and necrosis of the right leg. Laboratory tests including CT, echocardiography, and skin biopsy were inconclusive. The patient's C-reactive protein (CRP) levels initially decreased from 8.7 mg/dL to 1.6 mg/dl, and elevated again on day 23 to 9.0 mg/mL. Blood IgG levels were lower than the standard value. Immunoglobulin was administered at 2.5 g on various days. Plasma IFX concentrations were measured using LC-MS/MS with nano-surface and molecular-orientation limited proteolysis.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute myeloid leukemia (IML) with complications including fever, necrotic leg, and chronic inflammation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute fever, but these are less likely given the clinical history and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes adjusting the dosages and intervals of IFX administration based on the patient's trough IFX levels. The treatment plan will continue with IFX biweekly at 8 mg/kg per administration, with a goal of gradually increasing plasma IFX to around 2 mg per administration within 40 days. The plan will be adjusted based on response to the new treatment regimen and the patient’s response to treatment. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and kidney disease, presented for renal replacement therapy. He was previously diagnosed with a radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula in the left upper extremity.
O: During the surgical creation of the fistula, a large cystic formation enmeshed in the radial artery was observed, with strong local pulse. Surgical intervention involved slight adhesions between the vessel and cyst, allowing the cyst to be dissected free of the artery without rupture or major leakage of cyst content. Histopathological analysis confirmed a cystic lesion of the arterial wall. Follow-up echo-Doppler 1 year post-procedure showed no signs of artery degeneration.
A: The primary diagnosis is a radiocephaly fistula for hemodialysis. The successful surgical intervention and successful surgical resection of the cystic segment and preservation of the radial arteries were noted. Differential diagnoses could have included other causes of cystic disease, but these were ruled out by imaging and histopathological findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and the function of the prosthetic fistula. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the fistulae and function. The patient is advised to report any changes or concerns to the medical team immediately.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old woman who reports a 1-cm dark red nodule in her right breast for a month before her hospital visit. She has a history of breast cancer treated four years ago with BCS and axillary lymph node dissection, endocrine therapy, and radiation therapy.
O: Physical examination revealed a 27 × 13 mm mass in the outer lower lesion of the right breast. The surrounding skin was markedly thickened. Mapping biopsies from the nodule showed no tumor invasion at 5 cm and 10 cm from the edge. Tumor invasion was noted at 5, 5, 10 cm, and at 10 cm. Postoperative chemotherapy included total mastectomy with extensive skin resection (30 × 22 cm) and a wide skin graft from the abdominal skin. The patient has experienced no recurrence for six years and three months.
A: The primary diagnosis is angiosarcoma of the breast, confirmed by imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is good with no recurrences. The absence of tumor invasion suggests a successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes continued postoperative chemotherapy with weekly paclitaxel at 80 mg/m2 for six cycles. Follow-up care includes regular monitoring of the patient's condition and monitoring for any recurrence. Education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care is crucial. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the disease is recommended.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old male, presented with asymptomatic proteinuria discovered during a urinary screening test in Japan at age 3. He reports frequent urination and polydipsia with a urine output of 3L in a day. He has a history of nephrotic syndrome without systemic edema at age 8, and has a family history of renal or neurological disorders.
O: The urine protein to creatinine ratio (UPCR) was 1.0-1.5 g/gCr, with normal echogenicity in both kidneys. Ultrasonography showed normal echinogenicity. Serum creatininine was 0.97 mg/dL, with an eGFR of 46.8 mL/min/1.73m2. Urine specific gravity was elevated at 1.008, and urinary beta 2-microglobulin increased to 9,269 µg/L (normal <150 μg/L). Kidney biopsy revealed 13 (52%) of 25 glomeruli with segmental or global sclerosis, and two glomerular lesions with swollen, vacuolated, proliferative epithelial cells and karyorrhexis. No glomerulonephritis or neurological symptoms were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is familial nephropathy syndrome (FSGS) with associated renal and neurological deficits. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of proteinuria, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and clinical presentation.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's renal function and renal function closely. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of FSGS. Educate the patient on the importance of regular follow-up appointments to monitor renal function. Consider consultation with an endocrinologist for renal function assessment and a hematologist for nephrology.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old male, presented with a 5-day history of cough and febrile illness. He was diagnosed with left-sided pneumonia at a regional hospital and started on intravenous antibiotics, including Ampicillin. The parent reports worsening respiratory distress despite treatment.
O: Initial hospitalization included acute respiratory failure, endotracheal intubation, and invasive ventilation. Chest X-ray revealed effusion and pneumothorax on the left side, necessitating two chest drains. Chest CT confirmed severe necrotizing pneumonia of the left lung with destruction of lung parenchyma and formation of a large abscess cavity in the lower lobe, and consolidation of the right lung. High peak inspiratory pressure (PIP = 40 cm H2O), high positive end-expiratory pressure (<10 cm H 2O), and FIO2 100% were achieved. Chest computer tomography (CT) showed severe necrosis of the lung, destruction of pulmonary parenchymal structures, and a large lung abscess.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute respiratory distress secondary to Streptococcus pneumonia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress such as pneumonia or pneumonia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV-ECMO) on day 19 of mechanical ventilation, with initial ECMO settings of a blood flow of 2 L/min and an RPM of 3000. The patient will continue to be monitored closely for any signs of worsening respiratory symptoms or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 10-year-old right-handed boy, reports a history of sudden onset seizures starting at age 7, followed by a seizure lasting 4-5 minutes. The first episode occurred 10 days after starting oxcarbazepine. The second episode occurred at age 8, with symptoms including panic, shouting, rapid heartbeat, headache, left eye pain, abdominal pain, and nausea. The patient has experienced a decrease in seizure frequency from once a month to up to 4 times a day, with no history of perinatal hypoxia, febrile convulsions, brain injury, or family history of epilepsy.
O: Physical examination shows stable vital signs and neurological examination. Neurological examination shows normal neurological findings. Blood routine, biochemical tests, infection immunoassay, blood coagulation tests, and urinalysis are normal. Electrocardiogram and chest radiography are also normal. Video observation and neurologic interview are conducted.
A: The primary diagnosis is seizure-related ictal fear, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of seizures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes adjusting the medication regimen to manage seizures and icta. The plan will include adjusting the dosage of oxcarbamazepine as needed to manage the fear. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the effectiveness of the medication and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of medication adherence and the potential side effects of medication adjustments will be provided. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of seizures and seizures is recommended.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, who presented with abdominal pain in the lower part of the abdomen at 32+2 weeks of gestation. She reports no distinct symptoms of fetal fibrosis (FFTS) during her pregnancy. She was treated with phloroglucinol for tocolysis and dexamethasone for lung maturation. She experienced continuous abdominal distension on the fourth day of the fifth day of fetal heartbeats, which ceased at 4:30 am. The deceased fetuses were delivered by caesarean section, weighted 1700, 2100, and 1800 grams.
O: Ultrasound examination revealed two fetuses with a weight estimated for 33 weeks and 32 weeks, respectively, with a non-stress test indicating slight abnormality. Fetal heartbeating stopped at four am, and fetal movement ceased. External examination revealed thin and pale fetuses, heavy and red fetus B, and congestion and hemorrhage of the organs. Microscopic examination of placental villi indicated differences in placental blood flow.
A: The primary diagnosis is MC triplet gestation with complications including arterio-arterial anastomosis (AAA) and AVA. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fetal distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment with the obstetrician to discuss further concerns and to monitor recovery. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-ups to monitor her recovery. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: Patient 54, a 12-year-old male with a history of cutaneous bleeding and mild reduction in platelet count, reports feeling okay but still experiencing bleeding issues. He has a stop-loss variant in the GATA1 gene, c.1240T>C, p.*414Arg+41, causing loss of the wild type stop codon and extension of the protein by 41 amino acids. He experiences easy bruising but does not bruise easily.
O: Recent platelet counts range from 86 to 94 × 10^9/L. A rare X-linked blood group called Lu(a-b-) phenotype results in a marked decrease in the expression of Lutheran glycoprotein on the erythrocyte cell surface. Serological analysis using flow cytometry has not identified Lutheran on the surface. Giant occasional macrothrombocytes are not present.
A: Primary diagnosis is a causative variant of the RUNX1 gene causing FPD/AML in three patients from a single pedigree. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bleeding and hematological abnormalities. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and monitoring of the patient's condition.
P: Continue regular monitoring of patient's platelet levels and symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of avoiding situations where he might be at risk of injury or bleeding. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of his condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition promptly.

S: The patient is a 56-year-old married, retired Caucasian male with a 6-year history of Parkinson's Disease (PD). He reports a history of right-handed tremor diagnosed seven years ago, treated with carbidopa-levodopa and Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) in the left hemisphere three years ago. Recently, he attempted suicide by carbon monoxide poisoning.
O: Vital signs show an oxygen saturation of 94%, carboxyhemoglobin level of 49.3, and arterial blood gas study shows a carboxymoglobin of 493. The patient's symptoms include apathy and poor communication skills in social settings, and uncharacteristic hypersexuality, anger, and impulsivity.
A: The primary diagnosis is Parkinson's disease, complicated by a history and symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of Parkinsonian symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and the patient's history.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of neurological and mental status, with adjustments to medication and DBS settings as necessary. The family will be educated on the importance of reporting any changes in symptoms or behavior. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and family's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Education on recognizing signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, referred to the Child Neuropsychiatry Unit in April 2018, reports a history of mucohemorragic diarrhea, tenesmus, and abdominal pain since age 12, accompanied by frequent bathroom use. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms since childhood, which have been hard on their lives. The symptoms have led to the development of grossly disorganized behavior, conceptual disorganization, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusion, suspiciousness, hostility, social and emotional withdrawal, and somatic concerns.
O: Initial treatment included mesalazine, prednisone, metronidazole, azathioprine, infliximab, and adalimumab. Subsequent treatments included thalidomide, which was discontinued. Post-treatment, the patient developed delusional hallucinations, delusions, suspicious behaviors, and social withdrawal. EEG showed slow waves with isolated spikes in the right temporal and parietal regions.
A: The primary diagnosis is Ulcerative Colitis, with differential diagnoses including other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological symptoms. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the need for ongoing monitoring.
P: The management plan will include continued monitoring of symptoms and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as needed. Education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended.

S: The patient is a 39-year-old gravida one para zero woman presenting with progressive, severe abdominal pain for the past 10 days, accompanied by moderate vaginal bleeding for a few months and intermittent nausea and vomiting. She reports a history of intrauterine pregnancy with an estimated gestational age of nine weeks and zero days.
O: On examination, the patient was tachycardic with a heart rate of 131 bpm and normotensive at 116/84 mmHg. Physical examination revealed tenderness to palpation of the abdomen with rebound and guarding. Lab results indicated moderate anemia with hemoglobin at 9.2 grams per deciliter, leukocytosis at 13,200 WBC, and mild elevations of alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminOTransferases at 76 units per liter (u/L) and 53 u/L, respectively. A limited POCUS identified a fetus measuring 16 weeks one day by biparietal diameter with a rate of 163 bpm. Oligohydramnios was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured left tubal ectopic pregnancy, complicated by a rupture of the left tuba and subsequent left-sided salpingo-oophorectomy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included a follow-up with the obstetrician to monitor recovery and manage any further symptoms. The patient was advised to seek immediate medical attention if she experiences any further pain, bleeding, or other concerning symptoms. Further consultations with obstetrics and a gynecologist were recommended to manage her condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, with a history of Barrett's esophagus and high-grade dysplasia, reports difficulty swallowing and occasional chest pain.
O: An EGD and biopsy were performed to rule out invasive carcinoma. Endoscopic evaluation revealed a large hiatal hernia and an approximate 3 cm segment of the esophageal canal. A focal area of ulceration was removed via EMR. Microscopic evaluation of the specimen revealed focal high grade dysplastic adjacent to squamous epithelium, cavernous and ectatic venous channels, and abnormal cell growth in the middle portion of the tissue, irregularities in blood vessels, and minor salivary glands with cystification in the ducts. Radiofrequency ablation was performed to control the abnormal growth and alleviate symptoms.
A: The primary diagnosis is Barrett's Esophagus with complications including high-Grade dysplasm, high-risk for malignancy, and malignant growth. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophagitis such as malignant tumors or malignant malignancies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful treatment and absence of complications.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to monitor for any progression or complications. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing memory loss, gait disorder, and urinary incontinence. The patient denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, or bad personal habits.
O: Neurological examination revealed the patient to be conscious and able to respond to questions. MMSE score was 16. Strength in extremities showed normal strength with exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. Babinski's signs on both sides were positive. Cerebrospinal fluid pressure was below 120 mmH2O, and biochemical analysis was normal. Brain imaging showed ventricular dilation with an Evan index greater than 0.3, periventricular and deep white matter changes. Barthel index of ADL and FAQ scores were 20 and 26, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe dementia with complications including slight gait disturbance, urinary incinence, and severe dementia. Differential diagnoses could include INPH and LA, but these are less likely given the absence of effective interventions for CAA. The prognosis is guarded due to the lack of response to treatment and lack of improvement in symptoms.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and supportive care. The family will be provided with support and counseling to manage the patient and family. Education on recognizing symptoms of dementia and the importance of medication compliance will be emphasized. Referral to a neurologist for specialized care and a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of CAA will be arranged.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain and discomfort, with associated swelling. The patient has a history of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), characterized by pleurisy, arthritis, and proteinuria. Symptoms include pleuritis, joint pain, and swelling.
O: Initial tests showed positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm, and complement consumption. Subsequent tests showed purulent pleural fluid and elevated adenosine deaminase levels. A blood culture positive for coagulase-negative staphylococci was also positive for Pp65 antigenemia. Recent labs showed a decrease in fever but occasional peaks. A transesophageal echocardiogram revealed mitral valve perforation in the heart.
A: The primary diagnosis is SLE with complications including bacterial endocarditis, infection of the heart's inner lining, and infection with a positive Pp45 antigenemia test. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of inflammation and inflammation, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results.
P: The management plan includes referral to a cardiac surgeon for further evaluation and management of SLE. The plan includes continued antibiotic therapy, blood transfusions, and oral corticosteroids to manage symptoms. The management of the infection with ganciclovir will be adjusted based on the patient's response to the new antibiotic therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of gastroesophageal reflux and deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism, presented with a sudden onset of a severe headache prior to Nissen fundoplication surgery. The patient was initially diagnosed with a right-sided caudate intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) with ventricular extension but without hydrocephalus. Initial findings included a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 7t, elevated ICH score at 2, and worsening neurological function with intraventricular hemorrhage.
O: On examination, the patient was admitted to the ICU for further monitoring and treatment. A repeat CT head six hours post EVD placement showed a collapsed ventricle due to CSF drainage, perihematoma edema, and midline shift. A 5 cm curvilinear right frontal incision and 4 cm craniotomy were performed, identifying the posterior aspect of the right frontal superior sulcus with stereotactic trans-sulcal introduction of a 75 mm sheath and obturator. An exoscope magnification showed the inferior depth of the hematoma evacuated with gentle irrigation and suction, and a straight rigid endoscope was used for further examination and evaluation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a collapsed right ventricular hematologic hematology with complications including perihemoma and midlining shift. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute neurological deficits such as cerebral hemorrhage or other vascular malformations. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the need for intensive care.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring in the ICUs with close follow-up imaging and assessments to assess recovery and manage any potential complications. Further surgical interventions may be considered based on the patient’s recovery progress and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a neurologist for specialized care and a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of his hematological condition is planned.

S: The patient, a male in his late 30s with a history of SLE, presents with new proteinuria and concerns about his condition. He reports a history with positive anti-nuclear antibodies, anti-Smith antibodies (1:160), anti-double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (anti-dsDNA) antibodies (> 1:640), antiRNP antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, immunoglobulin M (IgM) anti-cardiolipin antibodies, hypocomplementemia (C3 < 40, normal: 90 - 165 mg/dl; C4 < 8 < 10 mg/dL), rheumatoid factor 50 IU/mL (negative: < 13.9), elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), arthritis, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
O: Recent urine protein/creatinine ratio is 1,059 mg/g, with normal creatinine levels at 0.6 mg/d. Antibodies of perinuclear (p)-ANCA, cytoplasmic (c)- ANCA, and atypical p-ANCA were negative. Renal biopsy indicated focal necrotizing/extracapillary proliferative glomerulonephritis. Serologies indicated low C3 at 77 mg/l and positive anti–dsDNA antibodies. Serology indicated class II lupous nephritis with deposits staining for IgG, IgM, and kappa, with negative staining from immunogloglobulins A, C3, C1q, and lambda.
A: The primary diagnosis is pauci-immune focal necrosisizing/Extracapular proliferative Glomerular Nephritis, with a differential diagnosis of class II Lupus. The patient's symptoms and clinical presentation suggest a complex and potentially inflammatory process.
P: The management plan includes adjusting the treatment regimen based on the patient's response to rituximab, mycophenolate mofetil (3g daily), and prednisone. Regular monitoring of proteinuria, creatininine, and creatinines is essential. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment and the treatment schedule will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing transient episodes of amnesia and independent short-duration loss of awareness with oral automatism, which have been worsening. The patient has a history of early-stage Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and temporal lobe epilepsy.
O: Brain MRI at a local hospital revealed a cavernous malformation (CM) in the right amygdala. A seven-day scalp video-EEG showed no interictal epileptiform discharges, impaired awareness seizures, or oral automatisms. Neuropsychological examinations revealed a preoperative MMSE score of 25/30, Hasegawa's dementia scale-revised (HDS-R) 22/30 and Weschler memory scale-III score of 79, visual memory at 68, and total memory at 72. Trained trail making test (TMT-A) took 1 min 27 s, and TMT-B took 3 min 37 s.
A: The primary diagnosis is early stage Alzheimer's disease (AD), with associated cognitive decline. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of amnesic episodes, but these are less likely given the clinical history and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes selective removal of the CM in the amygdala, with close monitoring of the patient's progress and recovery. The CM will be monitored closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the removal and manage the AD and temporal lobes. Further treatment options may include additional cognitive therapy, possibly involving cognitive therapy or a combination of cognitive therapy.

S: The patient, diagnosed with acute pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) 5 years ago, reports respiratory distress during exertion and a dry cough without treatment. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress and dry cough for the past 5 years.
O: Physical examination revealed bilateral fine crackles in the lungs. CT scan revealed a high level of pertussis toxin (PT) antibodies at 147 EU/mL in blood samples, indicating an infection. The PT level decreased to 52 EU/L 30 days post-admission.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory effusion (AE-IPF), complicated by poor blood oxygen concentration and new ground-glass opacity findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes initiating long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) to manage respiratory distress. Post-treatment, the patient will be discharged to a home for close monitoring and supportive care. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance for adherence to follow-up care will be provided.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-standing ischemic cardiomyopathy with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction (EF 40% and grade I diastolic dysfunction), chronic kidney disease stage III B, and hypertension. He presents with acute onset non-radiating exertional chest pressure, orthopnea, and shortness of breath, which began eight months ago. He reports no improvement post-treatment.
O: Physical examination reveals 2+ bilateral pitting pedal edema and diffuse crackles on lung auscultation. N-terminal-pro hormone B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) levels are significantly elevated (>4000 pg/mL), indicating a low suspicion of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). Chest x-ray shows pulmonary edema. Chest X-ray indicates prominent cardiomegaly. ECG reveals new T-wave changes in the inferior leads concerning possible ischemia. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) indicates further reduction in LV systolic function with EF at 30-35%, with an akinetic apex.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute exacerbation of heart failure, complicated by worsening cardiac symptoms and a history. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac symptoms such as cardiothoracic thrombocytopenia (CTHA) or cardiogenic thromboembolic thrombus (CCHP). The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the cardiac symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac status and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess the progression of the condition and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms promptly. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac issues.

S: The patient reports experiencing shaking head movements for approximately one month, which began shortly after starting hydroxychloroquine for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis in December 2012. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, cardioembolic cerebrovascular accident, two transient ischemic attacks, Sjögren’s syndrome, pseudogout, calcium pyrophosphate disease, osteoarthritis, pacemaker placement, left-sided multinodular goiter, osteoporosis, chronic hypertension, heart failure with preserved ejection function, recurrent bilateral lower extremity deep vein thromboses, iron deficiency anemia, anxiety disorder, major depressive disorder, and dyslipidemia. The medication regimen includes atorvastatin, carvedilol, cyclosporine, docusate, ergocalciferol, ferrous sulfate, folic acid, furosemide, losartan, melatonin, methotrexate, omeprazole, polyethylene glycol, prednisone, hydroxycholone, and warfarin.
O: Vital signs include blood pressure 135/72 mmHg, temperature 97.7 Fahrenheit (38.6 Celsius), and body mass index 41.05 kg/m2. Neurological examination shows intact cranial nerves, sensation to pinprick, vibration, and joint position, with reflexes 2+ at all tendons, and strength 5/5 in all extremities. Dysmetria with finger-to-nose testing is noted. Heart palpation shows a holosystolic murmur in the aortic region. Pulmonary, abdominal, and integumentary exams are unremarkable.
A: The primary diagnosis is hydroxy-chloroquin-induced shaking of the head movements, likely related to rheumatic arthritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of shaking head movement, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes discussing the possibility of alternative treatment options with the patient, considering alternative therapies if symptoms persist or worsen. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the shaking head symptoms is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the symptoms and the importance of follow-up appointments is crucial. Referrals to a rheology specialist and a heath specialist are recommended to address the underlying cause.

S: The patient, a 79-year-old male with a history of melanoma on the left cheek, presented with melanoma ulcerated and non-ulcerated, with a BT of 2.4 mm. He reported a positive SNB leading to a left neck dissection, which led to paracardiac nodes, adrenal, lung, and multiple large subcutaneous metastatic deposits. The patient was started on IMM-101 as a named-patient program, which stabilized his disease. He experienced a complete response to pembrolizumab treatment after 6 weeks, showing a PR of more than 50% as per RECIST1.1 criteria.
O: Physical examination revealed a positive right-sided snout (SNB) with no other positive nodes. A restaging CT scan showed a PR over 50% and a complete CR after 18 months. A follow-up CT scan post-procedure showed a CR of over 50%.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic melanoma of the right cheek, with differential diagnoses including other forms of cancer or metastatic disease. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the response to the treatment and the patient's age.
P: Continue the current regimen of pembolizumib for 18 months, with close monitoring of disease progression and response to ongoing treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen and ensure regular follow-ups to monitor for any new symptoms or side effects. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, common variable immunodeficiency, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis, diagnosed in 2013. She reports worsening of joint symptoms and synovitis. She was previously treated with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, prednisone, and methotrexate due to hair loss and inadequate disease control. Recently, she was started on abatacept 10 mg/kg intravenous infusion with concurrent therapy of leflunomide, hydrochloroquines, and prednisones.
O: Initial treatment included myophenolate and hydroxycholinesterase, which improved. Subsequent treatment with methotrax and leflutomide was discontinued due to worsening of cutaneous lesions. Follow-up visits showed improvement with abatacespt, which was discontinued after four months.
A: The primary diagnosis is seropositis with complications including cutaneous vasculitis and synocarcinoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint pain and joint symptoms. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in symptoms and the absence of recurrence.
P: Continue current medications and monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Regular follow-ups are essential to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and encourage regular follow-up appointments to monitor her condition and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, previously treated with oseltamivir for 5 days, reports worsening symptoms including fatigue, low activity, and breathing difficulty. The patient denies any history of recurrent bacterial infections or growth failure.
O: Physical examination at admission revealed respiratory distress and consciousness disturbance (Glasgow Coma Scale, E4V3M4). Vital signs included a body temperature of 38.0°C, blood pressure of 126/77 mmHg, heart rate of 155 beats/min, respiratory rate of 60 breaths/min and oxygen saturation of 90% at room air. Laboratory findings included WBC 20,000/μL with 95.1% neutrophils, hemoglobin 14.0 g/dL, platelet count 22.7 × 104/μl, C-reactive protein 20.54 mg/dl, procalcitonin 45.23 ng/mL, LDH 512 U/L, ferritin 261 ng/ml, sIL-2R 6,176 U/mL. IL-1β was 1.3 pg/mL; IL-6 233 pg/dL; IL10 67 mg/mL and TNF-α 2.6 pg/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is influenza A infection, likely exacerbated by the patient's respiratory distress. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, such as pneumonia or other infectious processes. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient’s condition and adjustment of treatment as necessary. The management of the respiratory distress will involve adjusting the treatment plan as necessary, focusing on symptom management and symptom management. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as needed. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) in December 2020, reports a history of hypercellular marrow with 32% myeloid blasts and aberrations in the RUNX1 gene. The patient recalls feeling tired and weak, with increased sickness and fatigue.
O: Initial treatment included venetoclax and azacitidine, which led to complete remission (CR) and consolidation therapy, followed by chidamide, venetoprolazole, and azaccitidine. The treatment was followed by two courses of VA, with progressive disease with 67% blasts in the bone marrow, managed with chidamamide and venetophosphamide. After one course of treatment, the patient achieved complete remission.
A: The primary diagnosis is Acute myelodysplastic leukemia with associated bone marrow abnormalities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bone marrow disease, but these are less likely given the clinical history and treatment history. The prognosis is generally favorable with no significant side effects or side effects noted during the whole treatment process.
P: Continue current regimen of chidophosphazole and azocitidine with close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment. Monitor for any new or worsening symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health status immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess treatment efficacy and manage any potential side effects.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal pain, fever, and dark-colored urine for several months. The patient was previously admitted three months ago with similar symptoms. The initial CBC results showed pancytopenia (8.8 × 10^9/L), hemoglobin (110 g/dL), and platelet count (155 × 10/L). Urinalysis revealed too many red blood cells in urine. Abdominal CT showed thickening of the wall of the small bowel, cecum, and ascending colon. Initial differential diagnoses included acute glomerulonephritis, inflammatory bowel disease with anemia of chronic disease, intestinal lymphoma, vasculitis, and leukemia, and infectious colitis and IgA nephropathy.
O: Initial CBC showed a white blood cell count of 8.8 x 10^6/L, hemoglobin 110 g/dl, and platelets 155 × 10x 10^4/L. Urinary CT revealed Clostridium difficile in the stool. Cystoscopy was performed, and the patient was treated with metronidazole and discharged. Laboratory results showed a WBC count of 3.9 × 10L.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute glomulonephantritis with an associated inflammatory bowel disorder, including infectious coli, IgA, and inflammatory bowel diseases. Differential diagnoses considered included infectious colisomyelitis and inflammatory colitis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence of symptoms or complications. Education on signs of infection or infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the management plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, oromandibular dystonia treated with Botox, and a recent diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), presents with a numb area of the left chin, approximately the size of a fingertip. The patient reports significant difficulty swallowing solids for three weeks, but not liquids. Three weeks post-upper endoscopy, the patient experienced right jaw pain and swelling following a work bench incident. CT scan revealed a right mandibular angle fracture and coronoid fracture. A second upper endoscopied confirmed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus. A PET/CT confirmed a large, hypermetabolic distal mass, with hypermetabolism involving the regional lymph nodes, lungs, spine, and right mandible.
O: Initial upper endoscopic results showed LA Class D esophagitis with ulceration in the distale and inflamed glandular mucosa with high-grade dysplasia. CT scans and biopsies confirmed a right retromolar angle fracture. Biopsy confirmed moderately differentiated esophageally differentiated adensocarcinal adenoma of distal and regional esophagesis. PET and CT scans identified a hypermetallic distal adenocytoma with multiple metastatic lesions.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic esophatic adenomas of the esopharyngeal mass. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of esophagic malignancies, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and biopsy findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and treatment response. Treatment options will be discussed in detail with the patient and his family, with emphasis on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the diagnosis, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma in the left mandible, reports undergoing neck dissection and resections. Post-surgery, the patient has experienced gradual relief of trismus and pain around the TMJ, with no issues with bite. The patient has not experienced any issues with the bite during mastication.
O: Postoperative follow-up appointments and radiographs indicate an anterior dislocation of the left condyle and narrower left posterior interocclusal space. No issues with biting were noted post-surgeries. The miniplates at the connection between the fibula and the mandible have failed, with widening of the inferior border. A panoramic radiograph taken 3 years and 1 month post-surgical shows anterior displacement of the right mandibular incisor to the ascending ramus, and a displacement between the anterior part of fibula segment and mandible.
A: The primary diagnosis is squamous carcinoma of the mandibula, with complications including an inappropriate height of the ramus from the gonial angle area to the condyle portion. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful repair of the miniplates and the absence of any complications postoperatively.
P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow--up appointment to discuss reinforcement and additional fixation options to address the complications. Patient education regarding the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and the importance for compliance with follow-ups is crucial. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the TMK is recommended.

S: The patient reports worsening chronic lower back pain for the past three weeks, accompanied by chills for two days. The patient has a history of leukopenia treated with 6-mercaptopurine, which led to the cessation of treatment. No fever was noted during the visit.
O: Physical examination revealed no fever. Blood cultures were taken, and a Gram-positive coccus, Granulicatella adiacens, was detected in the blood culture. Physical examination showed a blood pressure of 130/93 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and auricular temperature of 37.5°C. A holosystolic heart murmur was noted in the apical region, but no spinal percussion tenderness or focal neurological deficits were noted. Hemoglobin was elevated at 11.0 g/dL (normal range 14-18 g/dl). White blood cell count was within normal limits, but erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein were elevated at 46 mm/h and 45 mg/L, respectively. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms indicated mitral valve insufficiency, but Dukes criteria were not met.
A: The primary diagnosis is a suspected case of chronic lower-back pain with associated complications including a Grampositive coccus, Granulateicatella Adiacens. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lower back and lower-body pain, but these are less likely given the absence of fever and absence of other systemic symptoms.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of gentamicin and initiation of penicillin 12 * 106 U/24 h intravenously for suspected endocarditis. The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. The management includes discontinuing gentamicillin and adjusting penicilline dose as needed. The treatment plan will continue to be closely monitored, with adjustments to the treatment regimen as necessary based on the progression of symptoms and response to treatment. The family will be educated on the importance of reporting new symptoms or worsening of symptoms.

S: The patient, with a history of avascular necrosis in the left hip, panniculitis, and diffuse systemic sclerosis and pulmonary fibrosis, has been on methotrexate 15 mg/week and prednisolone 5 mg b.i.d since 2014. Cyclophosphamide 50 mg was added in January 2015, which was reduced to once daily in July 2016. The patient reports gross hematuria and dysuria without fever, suprapubic or flank pain, or loss of appetite.
O: Clinical examination revealed diffuse skin thickening from underlying disease. Urinalysis showed more than 100 red blood cells and leukocytes/μL, but urine culture was negative for organisms. Kidney function was within normal limits. Ultrasonography of the kidney, ureter, and bladder system showed normal kidneys and turbid urine in the urinary bladder. Cystoscopy showed a white-yellowish plaque in the bladder. Hematoxylin and eosin stain with a magnification of 400x showed sheets of large macrophages with granular eosinsophilic cytoplasm and mixed inflammatory cells infiltration. Stain of von Kossa at 400x magnification showed Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.
A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse systemic systemic sclerosis with complications including hematurias and dysurpnea. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal impairment, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes permanently discontinuing cyclophosphate treatment and discontinuation of ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 2 weeks to manage the infection. The prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole, prednisole, and methotroxate will be continued. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient, diagnosed with a heterozygous de novo T385M missense mutation in the STAT1 gene, reports recurrent oral Candida infections since age 8 months. The patient has tried multiple drug treatments including fluconazole, nystatin, ketoconazole and miconazole but only provided partial improvements for a short period. Recently, the patient has experienced severe oral candidiasis.
O: Current treatment includes polyvalent IgG mouthwash for 12 days, which has been ineffective. Previous treatments for severe oral Candidiasis were ineffective.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent Candida infection, likely exacerbated by the mutation. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of Candida-related infections, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis depends on the effectiveness of the current treatment and adherence to the prescribed regimen.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of symptoms and symptomatology. The treatment plan should include regular follow-ups to assess the efficacy of the treatment and adjust as necessary based on symptomatological and clinical response. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the effectiveness and manage any new symptoms. Education on the importance of adherence to treatment and the potential for complications should be provided to the patient.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, presented with progressive shortness of breath for 3 days. The patient denied experiencing fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloody stool, or tenesmus recently.
O: Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 131/79 mm Hg, pulse rate of 80 bpm, respiratory rate of 28/min, and body temperature of 36.0°C. Physical examination revealed coarse breathing sounds with bilateral crackles upon chest auscultation. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 10,600/μL with 79% neutrophils, hemoglobin at 9.7 g/dL, and platelet count at 464,000/μl. Biochemistry showed elevated C-reactive protein (79.7 mg/L), mildly impaired renal function with blood urea nitrogen at 21.2 mg/dL and creatinine at 1.23 mg/dl, and normal alanine aminotransferase at 13 U/L. Electrocardiography showed normal sinus rhythm. Echocardiography showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 77%. Chest radiography indicated increased infiltration with patchy consolidations in both lungs and lower lobe predominance. Oxygen was administered via a nasal cannula.
A: The primary diagnosis is community-acquired pneumonia, complicated by acute interstitial pneumonia and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia. Differential diagnoses initially included cryptogenic organize pneumonia, acute intrastitial pneumonia, and metastasis. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the need for close monitoring and adjustment of treatment.
P: The management plan includes continued antibiotic therapy, close monitoring of vital signs, and regular follow-ups with the healthcare team to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The plan includes regular monitoring of respiratory function and response to treatment adjustments. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to manage the patient’s condition effectively.
