Patient education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago, reports a long-standing use of glimepiride and metformin due to cognitive decline. Recently, the patient ran out of medicine before a scheduled appointment.
O: Physical examination reveals a body weight of 41.7 kg with a BMI of 20.1 kg/m2, liver function with an AST of 24 IU/mL, and renal function with a creatinine of 0.68 mg/dL. No diabetic complications are reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is a chronic diabetic mellitus with complications including cognitive decline and a recent discontinuation of teneligliptin, a dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. The patient's blood sugar levels have significantly decreased over the past 6 months, with an increase in hemoglobin A1c to 10.2% within 6 months.
P: The management plan includes discontinuing the use of exenatide-LAR once weekly to manage the risk of hypoglycemia. The plan includes discussing alternatives to the current regimen, including discontinuing exenatinide-lAR and increasing the dose to 2 weeks and 1 month. Further consultations with a hematologist and a dietitian may be necessary to optimize the management of diabetes.

S: The patient reports feeling down and anxious for the past 3 years, and reports worsening memory loss. The patient has a history of panic disorder treated with panic disorder.
O: Neurologic examination revealed mild cerebellar ataxia. CT scan revealed marked calcification in various areas of the brain, including the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, pulvinar thalami, and dentate nucleis. No evidence of brain calcification was found in the CT scans.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild cerebrospinal fluid (CGB) ataxias, likely related to the patient's father's dementia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebropinal fluid, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and family for any changes in mental health or cognitive function. Regular follow-ups will be necessary to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended.

S: The patient reports a history of right limb weakness persisting for one year, with no other symptoms. The patient has been feeling generally okay.
O: Neurological examination revealed a noncalcified homogeneously enhancing mass with peripheral signal hyperintensity around the ventricles, edema, and multiple damaged parts. Serum LDH level was elevated at 375 U/L, CSF protein concentration was high at 625 mg/L. IELSG score was 4, placing the patient in the high-risk group.
A: The primary diagnosis is a brain growth in the right limb, with involvement of deep structures of the brain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb weakness, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The treatment plan includes HD-MTX at 3.5 g/m2, chemotherapy with cytarabine, and consolidative whole-brain radiotherapy at 40 Gy. Post-therapy, the patient should achieve a partial response (PR) and the mass in the brain will have shrunk significantly. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of end-stage renal failure secondary to hypertension and primary antiphospholipid syndrome, underwent an allograft transplant due to end-day renal failure. The patient reports symptoms of reduced urine output, progressive abdominal distension, pain, and fever three weeks post-surgery.
O: Initial treatment with warfarin was optimized, leading to a renal hematoma diagnosed as 13 cm × 7 cm. Ultrasonography revealed a homogenous fluid collection posterior to the allogart, extending up to the right subhepatic area and down into the pelvis, displacing the bladder to the left. Postoperative findings included a renal hematoma, which was later identified as a large perigraft collection. Subsequent imaging showed a large urinoma, suspected to be anastomotic, and a passive external drain was placed. Surgical exploration and definitive reconstruction revealed an allodraft vascular pedicle in the inferolateral aspect of the graft and a completely sloughed off allografted ureter.
A: The primary diagnosis is a renal hemorrhage secondary to primary antifungal syndrome, likely secondary to a secondary infection from a previous kidney transplant. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal hemorrhages or complications from previous kidney transplants.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adherence to prescribed medications. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are essential to manage any new symptoms or changes in urine output. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a urologist may be necessary if new symptoms arise. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of right total hip arthroplasty 18 years ago due to rapidly destructive coxopathy and revision arthropeplasty 9 years ago for the loosening of the femoral stem. She has been taking alendronate for more than five years. She reports no pain in her right leg post-surgery.
O: Radiographs revealed localized thickening in the lateral femoral cortical bone and a complete transverse fracture with internal spikes. A third bone fragment identified as a Vancouver type B1 periprosthetic fracture was also identified. Radiographic findings indicated a thinning of the cortical bone, transverse lucency on the outside, and transverse alignment on the inside. Post-operative radiographs showed no displacement or loosening.
A: The primary diagnosis is a Vancouver Type B1 Periprothetic fracture, likely due to the incomplete fracture. Differential diagnoses could include other types of periprocessal fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging and radiographic findings.
P: The management plan includes performing an open reduction and internal fixation using a locking plate with cable grip, discontinuing alendroneate use, and prescribing weekly subcutaneous injections of 56.5 μg teriparatide along with LIPUS. The patient will continue to walk non-weight-bearing exercises during the healing process. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 65-year-old female with no significant medical history, presenting for surgical reconstructive therapy. She reports rapid onset swelling on the left cheek and periorbital space, along with a slight asymmetry in the face and drooping of the left eyelid.
O: During the procedure, the patient experienced a rapid onset of swelling on her left cheek as well as in the periorbiital space. Intra- and extra-oral inspection and palpation revealed no swelling or crepitus in the mandibular region, but air was entrapped into the upper and middle loose spaces of the face.
A: The primary diagnosis is a peri-implantitis lesion around the mandible left distal implant. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial asymmetry and ptosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of infection and the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments. Consider consultation with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the lesion. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, the youngest sibling of two patients, presented with anxiety and stomach issues. The patient has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and gastritis, and family history of cleft lip.
O: Genetic screening revealed a specific mutation in the CDH1 gene, which was identified in the siblings. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no abnormalities. EGD biopsy was performed to confirm the presence of the mutation. Post-surgery, the patient underwent a prophylactic total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy and j-tube placement.
A: The primary diagnosis is a high risk of gastric cancer, likely secondary to CDH-related genetic mutations. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of gastritis or gastric tumors, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes a follow-up with the clinic to monitor recovery and ensure no complications arise. The procedure will involve surgical removal of the stomach and connecting the esophagus to the small intestine, followed by elective cholecystectomy to remove the gallbladder. Postoperative recovery will be managed with adequate abdominal pain and nutrition, and the patient will be discharged on post-operative day 7 to ensure adequate health. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma in 2015, reports nocturia and back pain. He underwent a radical prostatectomy and lymph node dissection two months post-diagnosis. He is familiar with CLL/SLL but has not heard of it before.
O: Immunohistochemical studies revealed positive CD20, CD5 (dim), CD23, and BCL2, negative for CD3, CD10, and cyclin D1. The interfollicular areas of the lymph nodes were composed of T-lymphocytes expressing CD3 (bright), CD43, and bCL2. The follicular pattern is known as CLL-SLL. Complete blood count showed a WBC count of 12.5 × 10^9/L. Flow cytometry immunophenotypic analysis revealed 26% of blood cells with the following immunophenotypes: CD20 (+), CD5 (+),CD19 (+), BD22 (+), BCL23 (partial +), CD79b (+), and CD200 (+). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) screen showed del(11q) and del(13q, respectively, with hypermutation of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH). The patient's peripheral blood WBC doubling time was estimated at 6 months.
A: The primary diagnosis is Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL-sLL), complicated by a complex karyotype and a complex tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the immunophenotype and tumor markers. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further treatment options may be considered based on the progression of the disease and the response of the tumor to treatment. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the progression or progression of disease and manage any complications.

S: The patient, referred for surgical treatment of two hepatic tumors, reports a history of hepatitis B and C viral infection diagnosed at age 30, interferon therapy at age 33, and hemodialysis at age 49. The patient has a significant medical history, including a blood transfusion at age 6 for a traumatic left femoral fracture and a recent CT scan showing two hepatocellular tumors.
O: Physical examination revealed soft, flat abdomen without ascites, and absence of liver and spleen palpable in the subcostal area. Laboratory findings included platelet and white blood cell counts of 4.0 × 104/μL and 2000/ μL, hemoglobin, albumin, total bilirubin, and creatinine levels of 12.0 g/dL, 3.8 g/dl, and 0.4 mg/dL. Serum alpha-fetoprotein was elevated at 126.0 ng/mL, and protein levels were within normal limits at 18.0 mAU/mL. Pre-contrast CT scans revealed two hypoattenuating hepatic lesions, each measuring less than 1.0 cm in diameter, located in segments 3 (S3) and 7 (S7). Prothrombin time (percent) was 66.5%, and Child–Pugh grade was A. Indocyanine green retention rate at 15 minutes was 4.9%.
A: The primary diagnosis is hepatic tumor formation, likely secondary to hepatitis B, C, and HIV, with differential diagnoses including other causes of liver tumors. The prognosis depends on the response to surgical treatment and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical treatment for the hepatic cancer, with surgical intervention planned based on the imaging results and clinical presentation. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any arising complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain and asymmetric penile swelling following an injury approximately an hour ago. The patient experienced a 'snap' in the left side of the penis, followed by severe pain, discoloration, and deformation. No blood was observed in urine.
O: Physical examination revealed a grossly deformed penis with swelling and deviation to the right. Dipstick urinalysis showed no microscopic hematuria. An axial CT scan confirmed a unilateral 0.8cm x 1.4cm tear in the right lateral tunica albuginea with an adjacent hematoma, causing the penile shaft to deviate to the left.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured penis with associated hematomas. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of penile deformity, but these are less likely given the CT findings. The prognosis depends on the surgical intervention and recovery from the hematomatoma.
P: The management plan includes surgical exploration of the ruptured tunica with surgical intervention. Post-operative care will involve surgical exploration, evacuation of the hema, and repair of the rupture. The surgery will be performed with absorbable sutures, and the patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 3 months to monitor healing and prevent plaque formation. The procedure will be managed with appropriate surgical intervention, with follow-ups to ensure healing and to prevent further complications.

S: The patient reports swelling and redness in the right eye, which began during a 10-day trip to South Africa, where the patient experienced conjunctivitis symptoms starting two days after visiting False Bay. The patient has a blank past medical history and has been healthy overall. The symptoms started during a recent medical visit to the eye clinic in South Africa.
O: Initial treatment included oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days and topical dexamethasone/tobramycin eye drops, which did not improve the symptoms. Subsequent treatment with topical dexamsethasophen/tobarbital eye drops was ineffective.
A: The primary diagnosis is persistent conjunctivalitis, likely exacerbated by the patient's recent medical trip and recent flare-ups of conjunctiva symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of eye swelling and inflammation, but these are less likely given the history and symptomatology.
P: The management plan includes continuation of topical azithromcin and topical Dexamethazophen/Tobarbokinen eye drops. A different oral medication may be prescribed to clear up the infection. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: Proband D, a patient with a history of recurrent jaundice for 8 years and splenomegaly for more than 6 years, presents with a chief complaint of cutaneous and icteric sclera and palpable spleen 60 mm below the costal margin. Proband W has undergone cholecystectomy, splenectomy, and is currently experiencing cholelithiasis.
O: Physical examination revealed cutaneous, icterical, and spleen spleen. Laboratory tests showed serum total bilirubin 73.1 μmol/l (normal range: 0.8-1.2 μmol) and direct biliruberin 7.3 μmol. Abdominal ultrasonography indicated choleliithiasis and splenic hemoglobinuria. Serum hepatitis B virus surface antigen test was positive, and liver biopsy showed no cirrhosis.
A: Primary diagnosis is recurrent jelithiasis complicated by choleluithiasis, splenicemia, and cholelytic splenomatosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenic hemorrhage and spenic hematuria, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Plan to discuss the treatment options with specialists to determine the best approach for the patient and family. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of cholebrocystitis is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition and the importance of follow-up care will be provided. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of posterior, stage IIB NSCLC in the left upper lobe, currently undergoing neoadjuvant carboplatin, pemetrexed, and radiotherapy. She reports severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia.
O: Physical examination and MRI studies showed no evidence of direct tumor invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. The patient has consented to a posterior approach, image-guided T2 and T3 osteotomy followed by transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor.
A: The primary diagnosis is a posterior, Stage IIB neurosurgery with associated neuropathic pain and numbness. Differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out based on MRI and imaging studies.
P: The management plan includes posterior approach with image-directed T2, T3 and tran sthoracacic resection. The surgical plan includes an initial incision in the operating room, exposing spinal processes, lamina, transverse processes, and 5 cm of ribs from the left costovertebral junction on the side of the tumor. Post-operative care instructions will be provided to ensure a smooth recovery. Follow-up care instructions post-operation will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications.

S: The patient, a female with no personal history of thyroid disease, presented for a thyroid ultrasound examination and routine laboratory tests. She reported a sister diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma.
O: Ultrasound examination and laboratory tests revealed a BMI of 33 kg/m2 and normal lab results. Bidimensional ultrasonography (DUS 2) with high frequency probes (13 - 15 MHz) identified a highly suspicious micro-focus in the left thyroid lobe, with a radial shape, markedly hypoechoic echostructure, and irregular margins measuring 0.3 cm. ADF test indicated clear flow through newly formed tortuous vessels at the periphery of the specific micro-Focus. FNAC procedure was performed under ultrasound guidance. Histological examination of the lesion showed a proliferation of well-differentiated epithelial cells, surrounded by blood vessels with irregular borders, and infiltrating the thyroid parenchyma. Final TNM 8th eds. staging was pT1, pN0.
A: The primary diagnosis is a papillary tumor of the thyroid, classified as TIR5 according to the Italian Consensus and category VI according to The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology. The prognosis is favorable following successful Total Extracapsular Thyroidectomy (TT) procedure.
P: The management plan includes a Total Extraceapsular Throatectomy (TTT) to remove the tumor. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and lymph node function. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient presented to the ER with colic pain in the lower left abdomen, with no fever or hematuria reported. The patient has a history of bilateral hysteroscopic fallopian tube embolization in 2009, followed by a small amount of clear vaginal discharge starting 3-5 days before the period and ending on the last day of the period. No further treatment was sought until the patient experienced sudden abdominal pain.
O: Initial emergency CT scan revealed a thick-walled cystic mass approximately 2.1 x 1.5 cm in size in the left adnexa, dilated adjacent to the left ureter, and severe hydronephrosis on the left kidney with a very thin cortex. A subsequent gynecologic ultrasound and hysteroscopy were normal. CT retrograde uterogram showed extravasation of contrast media into the left proximal ureters and pelvis, confirming a ureterno-fallopian fistula. A left nephrectomy was performed, and the patient was successfully removed without vaginal discharge.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe cystic cyst in the right kidney, likely secondary to a previous hysteroscopic procedure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and surgical history. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of vaginal discharge post-surgery.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's recovery and address any concerns related to the cyst. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the prognosis and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the prescribed treatment regimen and ensuring compliance with the treatment plan. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with SLE three years ago, reports a history of skin lesions, alopecia, and positive ANA positive for anti-Sm, anti-dsDNA, and complement consumption. The patient also experienced lupus nephritis three months ago, characterized by nephrotic range proteinuria, dysmorphic hematuria, positive direct Coombs test, and recurrent episodes of fever, mental disorientation, and hallucinations.
O: Recent diagnostic tests including CMV infection and pp65 antigenemia levels were negative. CMV screening was positive but low pp65. No specific treatment was given for CMV. The current patient reports feeling much better with the recent improvement in symptoms.
A: The primary diagnosis is luposus nepaticus (SLE) with complications including nephropathy, nephrocytosis (NPP), and CMV infections. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lupitis, but these are less likely given the negative CMV test.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms closely with regular follow-ups. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of CMV and NPP. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 48-year-old male presenting with intraventricular hemorrhage, presenting with severe headaches, dizziness, vomiting, and feeling weak and disoriented. He underwent a combined STA-MCA bypass and EDAS surgery. He reports feeling better overall, with less frequent headaches and dizziness.
O: The follow-up DSA showed the direct bypass was almost occluded, with revascularization at Matsushima level 3. The CTP showed improved perfusion at the temporal region, indicating increased blood flow to the area. The patient's symptoms have improved, and he has been advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle to support recovery.
A: The primary diagnosis is intraventral hemorrhage secondary to a combined STA bypass and subsequent EDAS surgical intervention. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute headaches and vomiting, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's vital signs and blood flow levels. The management of symptoms and recovery will be based on adherence to the post-surgery care instructions and regular follow-ups to monitor for any changes in symptoms or concerns. Regular monitoring of blood flow and blood pressure will be essential to manage any potential complications. The Patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately.

S: The patient is a 48-year-old female presenting with recurrent abdominal pain in the back for the last eight months and recurrent jaundice in the last three months. She was diagnosed with hepatitis at a district hospital.
O: Physical examination revealed slight jaundiness at the sclera and skin, with normal abdominal limits. Laboratory tests showed elevated blood sugar levels, normal serum amylase, renal function tests, and Liver Function Tests (LFT's). Chest X-Ray and ECG were normal. Plain radiogram showed opacities and areas of dilatation in the biliary tract and pancreatic duct. MRCP indicated a radiolucent stone in the distal of the common bile duct and the duct of the pancreas.
A: The primary diagnosis is obstructive jaundica with chronic pancreatitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will include surgical removal of the stone, which may involve medication, lifestyle changes, or surgery. The patient will be closely monitored for any signs of infection or complications. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and manage any arising complications.

S: The patient reports intermittent fever, joint pain, and a persistent achy joints. The patient has a history of B-lymphoblastic lymphoma (BLL) with hypodiploid gene rearrangement.
O: Clinical findings include CRP at 12.91 mg/dL, ferritin at 246 ng/mL, and elevated soluble IL-2 receptor (sIL2R) at 1389 U/mL. WBC count is normal at 6,880/μL, with 2% lymphoblasts and moderate thrombocytopenia. Transaminase levels are normal at 1315 U/L, LDH is elevated (1315 U-L), and blood coagulation test is slightly abnormal. Bone marrow aspiration reveals 56.2% of nucleated cells with immature nuclei, high N/C ratio, and positive staining for PAS. Flow cytometry shows positivities for CD19, CD20, CD22, c-CD79, CD38, CD99, and HLA-DR, with weak positivity for CD10. Low-hypodiploids are found in 36 or 37 chromosomes.
A: The primary diagnosis is BLL with hypodermic involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to chemotherapy and response to therapy.
P: The treatment plan includes multidrug chemotherapy followed by high-dose chemotherapy with allo-HSCT. The chemotherapy will consist of steroid, Vincristine, anthracyclines, and L-asparagenase. Post-treatment, the patient will be transferred to our hospital for allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. The treatment will involve steroid, antibiotics, and l-asperagenase, with close monitoring of clinical remission post-treatment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient is an 8.2-year-old male with a history of partial secondary generalized epilepsy with atypical absences, moderate mental retardation with language delay. He reports difficulty focusing, difficulty staying still, and difficulty learning and understanding things. He also experiences episodes of sudden loss of consciousness or sudden disappearance of consciousness.
O: Physical examination and neurological exams were normal. EEG revealed abnormal discharges of slow waves and spikes, bi-temporally localized waves, and irregular electrical activities in the brain. MRI showed cortico-subcortical atrophy and corpus callosum hypoplasia. High definition karyotype and metabolic panel were normal, and a genetic study identified a 116-base deletion in the genomic sequence of the EN2 gene and abnormalities in transcription of the gene.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild mental retardancy with language delays. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the genetic findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of valproic acid to manage seizures and hyperkinetic behavior. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient should report any new symptoms or worsening of the condition immediately. Education regarding the nature of his condition and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a lifelong non-smoker with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, asthma, and dementia, presented with a painful right foot fifth digit wound, initially diagnosed as a diabetic foot ulcer. The lesion improved with local wound care but did not heal completely. The patient also noted a granulomatous mass on the medial aspect of the right fifth digit, which was sloughed off in the sock the week prior to the biopsy, leaving only a small partial-thickness ulcer, which improved with regular follow-ups. The wound has developed into two painful papules.
O: Physical examination revealed palpable pedal pulses with triphasic flow to the bilateral dorsalis pedis artery and posterior tibialis artery, right hallux toe pressure of 126 mmHg and left hallux toes pressure of 184 mmhg, with diminished protective sensation, 2 out of 4 sites bilaterally, and a 10-g 5.07 Semmes-Weinstein monofilament. No family history of skin lesions or cancer was reported. The last recorded hemoglobin A1c was 6.1%.
A: The primary diagnosis is a painful, diabetic foot fifth- digit wound with complications including a granular mass and a granulated granuloma mass. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of diabetic foot wounds, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the granulomas and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the wound with regular wound care and wound care, with regular check-ups at the wound center to assess the progression or resolution of the lesion and the extent of its complications. Further consultations with a wound specialist and a dermatologist may be necessary to manage the ulcer and prevent further complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a wound care specialist may be considered if the patient's condition does not improve.

S: The patient reports experiencing nausea, vomiting, and pain in the chest and stomach for the past few weeks, which began after an atrial fibrillation catheter ablation. The pain alleviates when sitting down. The patient has a history of an inflammatory syndrome with CRP levels increasing from 57 mg/L to 441 mg/dL in 48 hours.
O: Recent imaging includes chest CT, gastroscopy, and CTA. Chest CT shows a massive hydropneumopericardium with white arrows pointing to it. Gastroscopy shows a transparietal ulcer with purulent content on the anterior face of the esophagus, approximately 30 centimeters below the dental arches, and identified the ulcer just in front of the posterior wall of the left atrial appendage.
A: The primary diagnosis is Oesophageal-pericardial fistula secondary to atrial Fibrillation Catheter Ablation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes surgical pericardials and esophagial stenting to cover the ulcers. The treatment plan will involve surgical drainage of the gastric ulcer, esophageals stenting, and a minimally invasive approach to manage the condition. Patient education on the signs of infection and the importance of follow-up care will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of cardiac disease and liver cirrhosis, presented for close examination due to decreased renal function. The patient has a family history of renal insufficiency with a chief diagnosis of maxillary sinusitis three years ago. Previous treatments with valsartan were ineffective, leading to a recent increase in serum creatinine to 1.94 mg/dL and urine protein to 2.0 g/gCr.
O: On admission, the patient's blood pressure was 110/60 mmHg, pulse rate was 84/min, and body temperature was 36.2°C. Recent urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, 2+ occult blood, and no glycosuria. Urinary sediment showed no granular or red blood cell casts. Proteinuria was 1.31 g/cr. Blood examination revealed renal insufficient with a creatininine level of 1.95 mg/dl and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 21.0 mL/min/1.73 m2. No evidence of Fanconi syndrome was noted. Immunological data showed normal complement levels but mild elevation of immunoglobulin G with decreased IgA and IgM levels. Anti-nuclear antibodies were detected.
A: The primary diagnosis is renal insiciency, likely secondary to chronic kidney disease, given the elevated creatinines and renal dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Continue monitoring renal function and renal function closely. Maintain current regimen of valsarta and monitor for any signs of worsening renal function or complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of renal impairment. Consider consultation with a kidney specialist if renal dysfunction persists or worsens.

S: The patient reports a history of keloid scars on both shoulders from a Bacillus Calmette–Guérin vaccination, which have been present for three months. The scar on the right shoulder has been present since 3 months ago, with a protruding lesion at the center of the scar, which has become swollen and now painful. The lesion has already ruptured and spread to surrounding keloids.
O: Physical examination reveals a 9 × 7 cm keloidal scar with a ruptured lesion measuring 2 × 1.5 cm. Histopathological examination of the kelsoid scar shows a large laminated keratin-filled cyst in the dermis surrounded by a dense collagenous kelous scar wall, suggestive of an epidermoid cyst (EC). Histopathologically, the cyst wall is stratified squamous epithelium with a granular layer, consistent with an EC. The adjacent dermis contains characteristic broad, eosinophilic, and homogeneous kelsoidal collagen bundles.
A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrence of an EC with complications including infection and wound dehiscence. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of keratinous scarring, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the keratinized lesion and repair of the wound using subdermal 3-0 PDS and interrupted 5-0 Ethilone sutures. Postoperative care will include surgical excisions, Steri-Strip skin closures for 1 month, and Mepiform for 5 months to prevent recurrence. The patient will be monitored for recurrence and postoperative recovery, with follow-up appointments scheduled to assess recovery and ensure no recurrence or overgrowth.

S: The patient, with a history of esophageal dysmotility, GERD, lymphocytic colitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), essential hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia, neuropathy, and depression, presents with substernal pleuritic chest pain and lightheadedness that began a couple of hours after outpatient upper and lower endoscopy. The patient denies any known allergies. Family history includes a myocardial infarction, a cerebrovascular accident, and a family history of heart disease and stroke.
O: On examination, the patient was taking oxybutynin, omeprazole, amlodipine, bupropion, escitalopram, topiramate, tramadol, and fenofibric acid for urinary symptoms and chronic diarrhea. The last three endoscopies were performed for epigastric abdominal pain, periumbilical abdominal pain and diarrhea. Biopsies were taken from the esophagus, stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon.
A: The primary diagnosis is esophagitis secondary to chronic diarrhea, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of smoking and alcohol use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms such as chronic diarrhea or other gastrointestinal disorders. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the underlying conditions.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and the patient for any recurrence of symptoms or complications related to the current condition. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and possibly a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the underlying causes of the symptoms and prevent further complications. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and adherence to prescribed therapies will be provided. Referral to a gastroesophageologist for further evaluation and management of chronic diarrhea is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient’s condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports recurrent acute pyelonephritis for the past 4 years, with no symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, muscular cramps, carpopedal spasms, generalized seizures. The patient does not take regular medication. Family history includes a sibling who passed away from renal failure at age 25.
O: Physical examination reveals a height of 160 cm, weight of 55 kg, and BMI of 21.48 kg/m2. Laboratory tests show impaired renal function with SCr of 250 μmol/L, EPI-eGFR of 20.1 ml/min/1.73m2, hypocalcemia with calcium at 1.42 mmol/l, and normal serum parathyroid hormone levels at 65.59 pg/ml, 25OH-Vitamin D levels at 26 ng/ml. Serum magnesium is slightly low at 0.60 mmol/L and 24-hour urinary calcium is 3.9 mmol/µL. Urine acidification function is normal at pH < 5.3, and serum bicarbonate is nearly normal at HCO3− 22 mmol/dL. Renal ultrasound imaging shows bilateral nephrocalcinosis and parenchymal renal calculi. Ophthalmologic examination is normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute pyalonephrosis with associated renal impairment, likely secondary to renal tubular acidosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal impairment such as nephrotoxicity or renal failure. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of renal dysfunction.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of renal function and monitoring of calcium, magnesium, and renal function closely. Treatment options will be adjusted based on the patient's response to the treatment and the need for regular follow-ups. The management will focus on managing the renal impairment and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms. Education on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and regular followups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing epigastric pain and throat discomfort. The patient has a history of reflux esophagitis, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, urticaria, and insomnia. Recently, the patient has been using a flurbiprofen poultice for chronic lumbar pain.
O: Physical examination revealed no abnormalities in the abdomen. Laboratory findings showed elevated total cholesterol at 254 mg/dL, triglyceride at 130 mg/dl, haemoglobin A1c at 7.7%, and immunoglobulin E at 598 IU/mL. Hemoglobin A2c was normal. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed multiple white spots in the gastric fornix, body, and antrum. Endoscopic findings included atrophic gastritis and oesophageal hernia. Biopsied specimen from the white spots showed cystic dilation in the dilated duct, approximately 600 μm in diameter, with parietal cell protrusions and dilated glands forming microcysts. Positive H. pylori IgG antibody was positive.
A: The primary diagnosis is reflux gastroenteritis with associated gastric pain, throat discomfort, and gastric involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric discomfort, but these are less likely given the positive IgG antibodies and the patient's history.
P: The management plan will include discussing a treatment plan to address the reflux infection and manage other chronic conditions, including cholesterol and diabetes. Adjustments in medications may be considered based on the patient response to the treatment and side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the medication regimen and adherence to treatment will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, atrial fibrillation, cerebrovascular disease, polymyalgia rheumatica, and osteoporosis. He reports a recent hematoma on his right thigh following a minor trauma.
O: Clinical examination revealed splenomegaly at inspiration. Hemoglobin was elevated at 10.3 g/dL (normal range 13.4–17.0 g/dl). Platelet count was greater than 2000 × 10^9/L, white blood cell count was 23 × 109/L. LDH was 366 U/L higher than normal. Peripheral blood smear showed leukoerythroblastic features including nucleated erythrocytes, promyelocytes, and myelocytes. BM biopsy confirmed focal bundles of reticulin fibers and proliferation of megakaryocytes with classic atypia. Mutation analysis for JAK2V617F mutation was negative. RT-qPCR detected most common BCR-ABL1 fusions.
A: The primary diagnosis is primary myelofibrosis (PMF), characterized by megakarocytic proliferation and reticulopathy, with associated anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other myeloid malignancies, but these are less likely given the genetic profile and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will include a multidisciplinary approach including chemotherapy, immunosuppressive therapy, and possibly a combination of targeted therapies. The patient will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of his condition will be provided.

S: The patient reports severe headaches and nausea over the past months. The headaches have been particularly severe and have made it difficult to go about daily activities. The patient denies any history of alcohol, tobacco, or drug use. No family history of similar cases.
O: CT and MRI scan revealed an ill-defined tumor measuring 39 × 37 × 29 mm in the anterior-posterior, transverse, and cranial-caudal dimensions, slightly hypointense on CT with poor contrast enhancement, hyperintensity on MRI, and hypointensity on T2-weighted imaging. No obstructive hydrocephalus was observed in the right cerebellar hemisphere. Neurological examinations showed no sensorimotor deficits, cranial nerve deficits, abnormal reflex responses, or unstableness. Blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and laboratory findings were within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is a malignant tumor of the brain, with differential diagnoses including malignant malignancy and malignant brain tumor. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical removal of the tumor and recovery from the malignant process.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention under general anesthesia with somatosensory and muscle-evoked potentials. A right-sided suboccipital craniotomy will be performed to remove the tumor. Postoperative care will involve monitoring recovery and ensuring postoperative outcomes are positive. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing numbness and tingling sensation in the legs, which is becoming difficult to walk. The patient has a history of a laparoscopic gastric sleeve procedure performed in January 2017 due to morbidly obese status. No other symptoms such as pain, memory impairment, or dizziness were reported.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient is pale, in pain, dehydrated, conscious, oriented, and alert, with hemodynamically stable and afebrile. Motor functions show normal tone but slightly decreased power, absent reflexes, decreased sensation up to the knees, and decreased upper limb reflexes. Laboratory tests and nutritional assessments indicate normal blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels. Vitamin B12 and selenium levels are normal, but vitamin D and B1 levels are low. Copper levels normal but potassium is decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis indicates hypoalbuminemia.
A: The primary diagnosis is nutritional deficiencies, likely exacerbated by vitamin D deficiency and imbalances. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb weakness and limb weakness, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes prescribing supplements for vitamin D, B1, and potassium. A lumbar puncture will be performed to monitor potassium levels and monitor for any further deterioration or worsening of symptoms. Patient education on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health status is crucial. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a thirty-two-year-old male, presents with symptoms of weakness, numbness, and difficulty swallowing. He has a family history of stroke. He denies any other symptoms.
O: He has been on aspirin, seventy-five mg once a day, and has a history of mini-strokes. He is currently on Aspirin, which he started after his father's operation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a stroke, with complications including short-term weakness and numbness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stroke such as other causes, but these are less likely given the patient's age and history.
P: Referral to a mini-stroke clinic or a TIA clinic is planned. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in symptoms immediately. He will be educated on the importance of medication adherence and when to seek immediate medical attention. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male presenting with dizziness since yesterday, without loss of consciousness, weakness in extremities, or seizures. He reports non-bloody, nonbilious, and projectile vomiting. He has a history of dizziness experienced one and a half months ago after falling off his bicycle, which resolved after a while. The patient has a nonconsanguineous marriage and a premature cardiovascular death at age 35.
O: Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable, with neurological evaluation normal. Neurological evaluation was unremarkable, with no signs of weakness, positive Babinski sign, or sensory involvement. An ear, nose, and throat consultation ruled out local causes of vertigo. Ophthalmology evaluation showed no papilloedema on indirect ophthalmoscopy. Anthropometric review showed increased arm length more than the height. MRI indicated bilateral cerebellar non-hemorrhagic infarcts, with respiratory distress, pooling of secretions, hoarseness of voice, and deviation of the uvula to the right side with an absent gag reflex.
A: The primary diagnosis is cerebellary non-hematical infarction, complicated by neurological symptoms and neurological symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral palsy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of neurological status, supportive care, and supportive care in the pediatric intensive care unit, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on clinical response and laboratory results. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a high grade fever with a maximum axillary temperature of 39.8 °C, vomiting, and inability to eat for 4 days, along with irritability. The patient was previously treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for 24 hours without improvement.
O: On admission, the patient's general condition was described as irritable but overall good. Vital signs included a body weight of 11 kg, heart rate of 101 beats/min, body temperature 38 °C with room air 98%, and blood pressure 90/50 mmHg. Cardiorespiratory and abdominal examinations were normal. No signs of meningitis were observed. Laboratory tests showed elevated WBC counts of 14,090/mmc with 75.7% neutrophils, C-reactive protein (CRP) concentration of 5.76 mg/dl, and normal Electrolytes, renal function, and coagulation tests. Lumbar puncture revealed clear CSF with neutrophilic predominance and glucose and protein concentrations of 38 and 44 mg/dL, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is a bacterial infection, likely secondary to an antibiotic-induced fever and vomiting. Differential diagnoses could include other infectious etiologies, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to the antibiotic and response to treatment.
P: The management plan included discontinuation of oral antibiotic ceftriaxone (100 mg/kg/day) and initiation of intravenous antiviral therapy with acyclovir (30 mg/mg/day in 3 doses). The patient will continue with the current regimen of ceftrilaxone and continue with intravenous antibiotics. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, poorly controlled diabetes, and nephrolithiasis, presented with a chief complaint of right-sided abdominal pain, fevers, nausea, vomiting, and trouble peeing. The patient also reported a UTI diagnosed three days ago.
O: CBC and serum chemistry panel tests showed leukocytosis of 13,740/μL and creatinine of 1.06 mg/dL. Urinalysis was positive for ketones, proteinuria, urobilin, nitrite, leukocyte esterase, 146 RBC per HPF, over 182 WBC per HF, and many bacteria. Urine culture was positive. CT scan revealed an 8 mm right obstructive proximal ureteral stone and bilateral nonobstructive stones. Ureterals were placed with ceftriaxone and piperacillin-tazobactam. Postoperative findings included an 8 cm right obstructible uretery stone in an interpolar calyx, which was removed with laser lithotripsy.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right obstructing uretheral stone, likely caused by Escherichia coli infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and absence of a stent.
P: The management plan includes ceftriaaxone, piperacsillin-tarabactam, and placement of a right uretersal stent with a rigid cystoscope and flexible grasper. Postoperatively, the patient underwent an uncomplicated URS-LL, followed by a URS with a flexible urethal access sheath and a flexible Urethal Stent. The procedure was performed with a successful extraction of the stone, and the patient was discharged after 43 minutes. The plan includes regular follow-ups with the primary care physician to monitor the patient's condition and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, with a history of a left ankle fracture treated with open reduction and internal fixation in 1990, reports chronic pain for a long time. The patient underwent a total ankle replacement in November 2016, followed by a wound treated with amoxicillin and clavulanic acid. The wound was treated with a Palacos® cement spacer mixed with vancomycin and tobramycin, and a split-thickness skin graft, which was negative for superficial wound cultures. Post-surgery, the wound closed around March 2017, and the patient underwent deep wound debridement, closure with flap advancement, and allograft superficial peroneal nerve reconstruction. No recent travel or hospital exposures were reported.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests revealed no evidence of Candida auris infection in the patient's wound. The surgical findings included fibrinous tissue with the appearance of biofilm, but cultures were plated on Blood, Chocolate, and MacConkey agar plates. Cultures grew Candidaria auris in moderate amounts after 2 days on Blood and Macconkey plates.
A: The primary diagnosis is Candida Auris infection, likely secondary to previous surgical interventions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chronic pain and infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the wound and wound care. The management of the infection will include regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the current treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with an infectious disease specialist may be necessary to manage the infection and prevent further complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, referred for abdominal pain following a bowel resection 10 years ago for bowel stenosis due to obstruction, reports experiencing abdominal pain. The patient has a history of bowel resections 10 years prior.
O: Abdominal auscultation revealed a bruit. Laboratory tests and a computed tomography scan showed ectasia in the superior mesenteric vein secondary to an arteriovenous fistula (AVF). Angiography revealed a large fistula between the superior and aneurysmal vessels, an aneurism, and bulging, weakened area. Coil embolization was performed using a 7-F guiding catheter and a 5-mm balloon catheter, with balloon inflation. The final angiography showed successful embolizing with no visualization of the fistula or the anifice.
A: The primary diagnosis is an arterial fistula secondary to a vascular fistula. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful embalming and absence of complications.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adherence to follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the embolized procedure and ensure no further complications arise. Further treatment options may be considered based on the final results and the need for further follow-ups. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old male with a known case of schizophrenia, currently on clozapine. He reports painful erythema and tense skin blisters on his upper limbs after exposure to sunlight for a few hours. The blisters formed into larger, fluid-filled bullae, forming serous bullae. He denies using sun protection during vacation and reports miliaria rubra on his axillae and back.
O: Physical examination revealed erytherma and blisters in the upper limbs. The patient's skin was dry, with small, red bumps or irritated skin on the axillary and back, likely due to heat exposure. No sunburns were reported before starting the medication.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe skin conditions related to clozape and excessive sun exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history of sun exposure and current symptoms.
P: The management plan includes pain killers and supportive treatment for the skin issues. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 2 weeks to assess recovery and manage any further skin issues or concerns. The treatment plan will include pain killers to manage symptoms and supportive care to prevent further skin damage. Education on the importance of sun protection and avoiding excessive sun exposures will be provided to the patient and family.

S: The patient reports experiencing general fatigue, loss of appetite, and jaundice. The patient also notes yellowish skin and eyes.
O: Laboratory tests revealed an elevated total bilirubin level at 7.7 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dl). Endoscopic retrograde biliary drainage (ERBD) decreased total bilubin to 1.9 mg/L (normal: 0-1 mg/l). Endoscopy revealed a 10-mm tumor in the Vater's papilla, which was surgically removed. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) showed invasion of the pancreatic parenchyma. Contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a hypovascular mass at Vater’s papilla. CEA and CA19-9 levels were not elevated. Subsequent surgical intervention revealed a soft and non-fibrotic pancreas, soft and no fibrotic pancreatic fistula.
A: The primary diagnosis is a papillary adenocarcinoma of the Papilla, likely due to the tumor's invasion into pancreatic tissue. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pancreatic tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of distant metastasis.
P: The management plan includes a subtotal stomach-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (SSPPD) with D2 lymph node dissection. Postoperative management includes persistent drainage with appropriate drainage, and the patient was discharged on the 30th postoperative day. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's health and manage any complications. The family will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular monitoring for any new symptoms or complications.

S: Patient reports sharp epigastric pain radiating to the back, accompanied by nausea and diarrhea. The patient has a history of cholecystectomy in 2010, depression, and IBS-D. No family history of pancreatitis. Currently on eluxadoline, bupropion, and oral contraceptive pills.
O: Vital signs: BP 123/78 mm Hg, heart rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 18/minute, oxygen saturation 100% on room air. Physical examination shows no jaundice or pallor. No organomegaly noted on CT scan of the abdomen.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to eluxidoline, given the patient's history of IBS and recent symptoms of epigastic pain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatic pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue symptomatic management with analgesics, anti-emetics, and a diet plan to support diet as tolerated. Monitor liver function and liver function closely. Educate patient on signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate medical attention. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor liver function, liver function tests, and overall health.

S: The patient is a right-handed male with a history of heroin addiction, currently in a post-anoxic coma for 15 days. He reports significant inertia, lack of drive, complete loss of self-activation, and no spontaneous complaints about his state of health. He experienced a sudden circulatory collapse of unknown duration due to a heroin overdose, resulting in a coma lasting 15 days and significant behavioral changes. The patient denies any significant depressive symptoms or compulsive behaviors.
O: Neurological examination revealed a major impairment in speech, aprosodic, hypophonic, and characterized by accelerated articulation, almost unintelligible, and bilateral hyperreflexia. Neurological evaluation indicated low anxiety, marked flattened affect, and mild compulsive counting and checking. A forelimb dystonic syndrome was noted in the left arm one year after the onset of symptoms.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe neurological disorder characterized by hypophonia, hyponatremia, and rapid speech impairment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and neurological findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's neurological status, regular follow-up appointments, and potential adjustment of treatment based on symptom progression or new symptoms. The management will focus on addressing the underlying neurological disorder and symptomatology. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the neurological deficits is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic kidney disease of unknown etiology for 6 years, presented with sudden neurological impairment while walking down the street. The patient reported feeling stuporous and did not respond well to external stimuli.
O: Upon admission, vital signs and capillary glucose levels were within normal limits. Initial glucose levels increased to 20 mg/dl after a 50 ml infusion of 50% dextrose. Post-infusion, the patient experienced a new episode of symptomatic hypoglycemia. Blood samples showed abnormal results, including a new infusion rate of 10.416 ml/hr. A computed axial tomography with double contrast showed no abnormal findings.
A: The primary diagnosis is insulinoma, likely secondary to chronic kidney diseases. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemic episodes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the lack of response to current treatments.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the diabetic patient's glucose levels and glucose levels, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on clinical response and laboratory results. Further consultations with an endocrinologist and a hematologist are recommended to address the underlying cause of the symptoms. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the potential side effects of insulinoma will be provided. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the current treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, in his late seventies, reports feeling unwell and unsure of what is going on. He has a history of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the left liver lobe.
O: Physical examination revealed a lump in the abdomen and CT scan revealed an isovascular nodule in the liver lobe, mildly elevated CRP at 0.39 mg/dL, and decreased hemoglobin at 8.9 g/dL. No signs of HBV or HCV were noted. Surgical removal of the hepatic nodule was performed, revealing an unencapsulated, ill-defined, expansive nodule with atypical epithelial cells arranged in solid nests, trabeculae, and fused tubule-like structures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for CK7, CK8/CK18, and CK19/CD56, but negative for Hepatocyte.
A: The primary diagnosis is primary cholangiolocellular cell carcinoma intermediate type (CHC-INT). The tumor was surgically removed, with no signs of recurrence noted.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups every few months for the first year to monitor recovery and ensure no recurrence. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or symptoms arise. Further consultations with oncology and hepatology may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma in the left main bronchus, reports feeling nervous about the whole situation. The patient has experienced difficulty breathing and occasional chest pain.
O: Bronchoscopy confirmed the extent of the tumor. Two imaging techniques, LCI and WLI, were used to assess the tumor's submucosal vascularity and margin on the bronchial mucosa. The bronchoscopies showed a much clearer view of the carcinoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is adenoidal cyst carcinoma (ACC) in the bronchius, with differential diagnoses including other forms of lung cancer. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and the patient's response to the treatment.
P: The management plan includes a left pneumonectomy to remove the affected lung. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of recovery and adjustment to breathing with one lung. The surgery is scheduled for tomorrow morning, with the patient advised to report any additional questions or concerns during the procedure. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and a pulmonary specialist will be arranged to manage the tumor and ensure optimal surgical outcomes.

S: The patient, a farmworker, reports experiencing vesicular lesions on the right forearm, which have been treated with topical steroid therapy and parenteral ceftriaxone, but have deteriorated. The patient has a history of working on a horse farm near an anthrax outbreak.
O: On examination at the Spallanzani Institute, bilateral oedema of the upper extremity up to the shoulders, ulcerated and necrotising skin lesions covered by black eschars was noted. Initial treatment with topical steroids was initially effective, but the patient developed complications including ulceration, necrotizing skin lesions, and exposure to the blood of a dead cow.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral vesicle lesions in the right arm, likely related to the patient's work history. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions and infection, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical history.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of antibiotic therapy and initiation of intravenous meropenem (1 g every 3 h), daptomycin (350 mg every 24 h), and clindamycin (600 mg every 6 h). The patient will continue on intravenous ciprofloxacin (400 mg twice/day) for two weeks, followed by oral ciproprofloxinacin for an additional 7 days. Continuous monitoring of blood cultures and PCR for B. anthracis DNA from margin eschar fragments will be necessary. The treatment plan includes continuation of antibiotic treatment and monitoring for any new symptoms or complications.

S: The patient, a child, presented with a referral for further management of pulp necrosis in the lower right second premolar (tooth 45), secondary to the fractured tubercle of dens evaginatus. The patient reports no new pain after treatment at a general dental clinic two weeks ago. The pain was initially treated with symptomatic irreversible pulpitis and root canal therapy, which led to the removal of calcium hydroxide.
O: Physical examination revealed mild gingivitis with a basic periodontal examination (BPE) score of 1 in all sextants. Oral hygiene was maintained with a plaque score of 30%, indicating room for improvement. An occlusal glass ionomer dressing of the access cavity was made, and cold and electric pulp sensibility tests showed positive responses for all fully erupted premolars. Periapical radiographs showed an immature root with a convergent open apex and small periapsical radiolucency. The pulp space of tooth 45 is of an even width from the coronal to the apical portion.
A: The primary diagnosis is pulp fibrosis in tooth 45, secondary to fractures evaginatitis and symptomatic apical periodontitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tooth loss such as dental malformations or other dental malignancies. The prognosis depends on the management of tooth necrosis and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes isolating tooth 45 with a rubber dam after infiltration of local anaesthetic solution containing 2% lidocaine, to manage symptoms and prevent further complications. Post-treatment, the patient is advised to maintain regular oral hygiene and report any new symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-ups with the Pediatric Dental Clinic are recommended to monitor progress and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient is a 6.5-year-old girl presenting with painless thickening in her PIP joints for the past two months. She denies any history of fever, trauma, or rash. She was born with a weight of 3700 g. She has a history of normocytic anemia and has a past medical history of pneumonia before turning 3, normocysis anemia, and normocytosis.
O: Physical examination reveals symmetric thickening of the DIPs and PIPs in both hands without joint effusion, tenderness, or stress pain. The joints have normal range of motion, no signs of tenosynovitis, synovitis or enthesitis, and no muscle wasting. Height 110 cm (10th percentile), weight 19 kg (~30th percentile). Radiographs of the hands, feet, and pelvis show short distal phalanges with bilateral swelling of soft tissue around the joints. The spine radiograph shows shortening of intervertebral spaces D 4–5-6 and D 10–11-12. Eosinophilia levels are slightly elevated at 2.2 K/microL (normal < 0.7 K/μL; 24.2%), and CRP and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are normal. Biochemistry, CPK, complement levels, Rheumatic factor (RF), and serum lipid profile are within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is painless skin lesions in the PIP joint, likely due to the presence of a congenital condition. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions and joint swelling, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with follow-up appointments in a few weeks to assess any changes or progression of symptoms. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with rheumatology may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen. Education on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and follow-ups will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of angina, coronary artery disease (CAD), transient ischemic attack (TIA), hyperlipidemia, and gastric bypass, presents with chest pain. The patient has no history of anesthesia-related issues.
O: Physical examination revealed chest pain and a variant in the RYR1 gene, associated with Malignant Hyperthermia (MH). Genetic screening identified a variant of the RY1 gene with 48 pathogenic mutations. The perfusionist was instructed to treat the patient as an MH positive and not to add volatile anesthetics to the circuit during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). A bispectral index (BIS) monitor was applied throughout the surgery to monitor the depth of anesthesia.
A: The primary diagnosis is Malignant hyperthermia, likely secondary to the RRY1 gene variant. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the patient's clinical presentation and the absence of MH complications.
P: The management plan includes pre-operative preparations with a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker (rocuronium) and maintaining a balanced anesthetic with fentanyl, midazolam, and infusion of propofol. Preoperative preparations will include pre-procedure preparations with CO2 absorbent, charcoal filters, and removal of vaporizers. Post-operative care will include monitoring for coagulopathy and postoperative recovery. The management of coagulation and post-operative recovery will be closely monitored, with follow-up appointments to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports sudden severe right shoulder and flank pain, accompanied by numbness in the right hand. The patient has a history of hypertension managed with medication.
O: Initial symptoms of hemoptysis, hypoxemia, severe forced breathing, and tachypnea were noted by the patient. Intubation was performed, and the patient was intubated and transferred to the emergency department. Physical examination revealed a coarse crackle with right lateral dominance, suctioning a small volume of blood through the tracheal tube. Blood pressure was 132/87 mmHg, pulse 109 beats per minute, and body temperature 36.7 °C. Chest CT showed infiltration in the upper lobe, spreading to the right middle and lower lobe, and left hilar area. Arterial blood gas analysis showed a pH of 7.174 with a partial pressure of carbon dioxide 62.4 mmHG, oxygen 94.3 mmhg, and base deficit of -7.4. Laboratory tests including blood cell count, coagulation, and biochemistry were normal except for slight elevation in serum creatinine.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory failure secondary to hypertension, evidenced by the presence of infiltration and infiltration in peripheral blood. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory failure, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued sedation and mechanical ventilation with spontaneous breathing at 14 breaths per minute. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and lab values is necessary. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and possibly a cardiologist may be necessary depending on the progression of the condition and response to treatment. Patient education regarding the importance of medication compliance and adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided.

S: The patient, a 46-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) diagnosed 3 years ago, reports feeling tired due to sleep deprivation. He has refused consent for awake fiberoptic intubation under sedation.
O: Physical examination revealed a short neck with a circumference of 51 cm, limited extension due to thick fat, and a Mallampatti score of Ш. The patient's vital signs before anesthesia induction showed Bp 142/79 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, SpO2 96%, and RR 22 bpm. BIS was 51. Initial direct laryngoscopy with a video larengoscope and fiberoptics was performed, with Midazolam 3 mg and sufentanil 10 μg intravenously. Post-surgical adjustments included 100 mg of intravenous propofol and 100 mg in a TCI at 3μg/mL.
A: The primary diagnosis is postoperative complications from postoperative sleep deprivation, likely exacerbated by the patient's nervousness and refusal to consent for anesthesia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sleep deprivation and hypoxia, but these are less likely given the history and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes tracheal intubations with anesthesia induction, followed by fiberoptical intubulation and laryngeal mask airway airway (LMA). The patient will be monitored for signs of complications such as hypoxemia or hypothermia. Postoperative care will include close monitoring of vital signs and oxygen saturation. A WEI Nasal Jet Tube (WNJ) will be placed from Well Lead Medical Equipment Ltd., Guangzhou, to ensure optimal recovery and comfort during surgery. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease stage IV, presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and urine for the past 2 weeks. The patient reported a recent loss of appetite but no significant weight changes.
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 133/60 mmHg, heart rate of 75 bpm, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, temperature of 97.7°F, and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air. Laboratory findings included hemoglobin 11 g/dl, white blood cell count of 3,800 cell/mm3, platelet count of 214,000/mm2, ALT 326, AST 321 IU/L, Total bilirubin 3.1 mg/dl with direct biliruberin 1.8 mg/dL, ALP 1,219 IU/dL with lipase 250 IU/mL. Renal function tests were baseline at 1.72 mg/l, within the range of 1.7–1.9 mg/d for the patient. Recent upper and lower endoscopy showed no significant abnormalities except for mild antral gastropathy. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed stable pelvic adenopathy with the largest lymph node measuring 4 cm.
A: The primary diagnosis is elevated liver enzymes, likely due to elevated biliruble levels, with differential diagnoses including chronic venous stasis and acute myeloid leukemia. The presence of a stable lymph node and elevated ALT and ALP suggests a possible underlying cause.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's liver enzymes with appropriate follow-up and management of renal function and other health conditions. Further diagnostic workup will be necessary to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Patient education on the importance of regular follow-ups and adherence to prescribed medications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a significant receding of gums on one of his teeth, which does not look very good.
O: Clinical examination revealed a deep Miller Class III gum recession on the buccal aspect of tooth #2, exposed root apex exposed entirely, and degree 3 Muhlemann mobility associated with tooth extrusion. probing examination revealed pockets of 6 mm on the mesial and palatal mesial aspect and 5 mm on distal aspect. Radiographs indicated advanced vertical bone loss on mesial, distal, and mesial aspects of the tooth, with an apical lesion and mild root resorption. Thermal pulp tests indicated necrotic pulp, and occlusion was checked.
A: The primary diagnosis is a periodontal-endodontic lesion in tooth #1. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gum recession, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The treatment plan includes mechanical therapy, scaling and root planing, and administration of antimicrobial drugs, amoxicillin 500 mg and metronidazole 250 mg, to be administered 3 times a day during 7 days. An endodontical treatment will be performed, followed by a corrective phase of the treatment. The patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old male Miniature Pinscher dog, presented with a history of generalized nodules and a ventral umbilical hernia.
