The nodules were initially disseminated, which worsened over a period of 2 months, with a gradual increase in size. The dog received oral prednisolone and antibiotics for 2 weeks before the referral.
O: Physical examination showed no enlargement of the peripheral lymph nodes. Dermatologic examination revealed generalized ulcerative nodules, erosion, erythema, and hyperpigmentation in the dorsum, ventrum, neck, and perianal region. Six mm punch skin biopsies of nodular lesions were performed. Impression cytology showed numerous neutrophils and phagocytized cocci bacteria, and fine needle aspiration biopsy identified a cluster of intermediate to large lymphocytes with multinuclear cells. Histopathological findings indicated proliferation of round cells and mitotic figures in the epidermis and dermis. Immunohistochemical staining was CD3 positive, confirming T cell origin.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic leukocytosis (CETL) with differential diagnoses including other causes of lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive response to retinoic acid and IFN-α treatment.
P: The treatment plan includes continuation of retinoics and IFNs for 2 months to manage the disease. The patient will be closely monitored for response to the treatment and adjustments to the management plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment, manage any side effects, and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient, a female, delivered via cesarean via echocardiogram. She presented with normal appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration at delivery, and an APGAR score of 5 minutes. A few days ago, she experienced a presyncopal episode, shortness of breath, and grunting. The patient's oxygen saturation was 24% in room air.
O: During the emergency room visit, the patient was resuscitated with a mask and balloon, stabilized with resuscitation, and a second echocoardiogram showed cyclic complete obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract. Cardiac and cerebral MRI revealed a mobile and large mass in the right Ventricle, measuring 13 mm × 9 mm, attached to the baso septum and moving to the pulmonary trunk during systole. Pulmonary artery flow measurements indicated pulmonary insufficiency. A patent foramen oval (PFO) and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) were also observed, with global kinetics homogeneous compared to a slight dilation in the left ventricle.
A: The primary diagnosis is a tumor of the ventriculonephritis, likely secondary to the tumor's effects on heart function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ventricular dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the tumor and its effects on cardiac function. The management of the patient's respiratory symptoms and potential interventions will be discussed in a multidisciplinary team meeting to discuss potential treatment options. Education on the importance of medication adherence and monitoring for potential complications will be provided. Referral to a pediatric cardiologist for specialized care and a cardiology specialist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor response and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of migraine headaches, reports feeling off-balance for the past four months following a three-and-a-half week cruise, characterized by constant motion throughout the day and even while lying down. The symptoms have subsided, but the vertigo persists. The patient has not experienced vertigo since three years ago, which resolved after positional exercises.
O: Physical and neurological examination revealed normal MRI, video-nystagmography, oculomotor testing, positional testing, and audiogram results. The presence of Mal de Débarquement syndrome was noted, but these tests were not specific.
A: The primary diagnosis is Mal De Débrog syndrome, a chronic neurological disorder characterized by persistent motion, headache, nausea, vomiting, tinnitus, and falls. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of migraine or other neurological disorders. The prognosis is generally favorable given the absence of other neurological symptoms.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the patient's neurological status closely and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment as needed. Education on the nature of the condition and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a newborn female, was born with fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly. The mother reports no history of prenatal complications.
O: The baby's birth weight was 2660 g, birth length was 48 cm, and head circumference was 34 cm. Physical examination revealed shortening and anterolateral bowing of the left lower limb at the distal third of the tibia, curved and shorter than normal. The toes were also oligosyndacty. Hip ultrasound showed no congenital hip dysplasia. Radiographic examination confirmed hypoplastic hypoplasm of the fibula, absence of two rays on the left foot and one ray on the right, and normal anterolecular bowing and shortening of the right tibia. Both femora were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is fibular Hypoplasia with associated congenital anomalies including fibular fibula hypoplasia, fibula anteral bowing, anterollateral bow, and shortened tibia femora. Differential diagnoses could include other congenital conditions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with pediatric specialists to monitor the baby's progress and address any potential complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a pediatric orthopedic specialist may be necessary if there is no improvement in the patient's condition or new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old woman with a 16-year history of ulcerative colitis, treated with mesalazine and infliximab. She reports no specific symptoms. She underwent a laparoscopic proctocolectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy with TaTME.
O: Initial colonoscopy revealed absence of the haustra between the transverse colon and rectum, suggesting rectal cancer. Histopathological examination of multiple random biopsies indicated dysplasia with p53 overexpression in the rectum. Post-operative management included a lapary proctolectomy, D2, and intra-surgical mobilization of the colon and D3. Transanal surgery involved two surgical teams, five abdominal ports, and laparoscopy-guided dissection of blood vessels. The rectum was mobilized in the TME plane, and the left and right neurovascular bundles were incised. The patient underwent a circumferential mucosectomy with preservation of the anal sphincter muscle, and a purse-string suture was used to close the rectal lumen.
A: The primary diagnosis is rectal colitis with complications including colon cancer, lymphadenopathy, and metastasis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of colitis such as malignancy or metastatic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's recovery and detect any unusual symptoms. The plan includes scheduling regular colonoscopies to monitor for any recurrence or recurrence of the colitis. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a pulmonologist may be considered if there is no improvement in the colic condition. Patient education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient reports intermittent abdominal pain for the past 10 days. The pain is located in the lower right abdomen, close to the inguinal region.
O: Clinical examination revealed tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Blood tests showed no signs of inflammation. Ultrasound examination revealed a direct ingueinal hernia protruding anteromedially and inferiorly to the inferior epigastric vessels, with a small tubular structure compatible with the appendix. A complementary CT scan of the abdomen confirmed Amyand's hernia.
A: The primary diagnosis is Amyand’s hernia with signs of infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as perforation or abscess, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to a specialist for further evaluation and possible surgical intervention. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if worsening symptoms occur. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a female, presented with a painful mass in the right groin that has been growing for the past 2 days. She denied experiencing nausea, emesis, diarrhea, or constipation.
O: Vital signs were normal. Physical examination revealed a bulging tender mass in her right groin consistent with a femoral hernia. Laboratory tests showed an elevated WBC count of 13,500/μL and a CRP of 34 mg/L. CT of the abdomen-pelvis revealed an inflamed appendix within the femoral sac and a small fluid collection in the femorally canal area.
A: The primary diagnosis is a De Garengeot's hernia, confirmed by imaging and lab results. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with cefuroxime 1500 mg and metronidazole 500 mg, followed by a small incision under general anesthesia under Lockwood's infrainguinal approach. Postoperative care will include close monitoring of the wound and wound healing. The patient will be discharged 7 days post-operation to ensure healing and complete wound closure. Follow-up will include follow-up for postoperative care and monitoring for any signs of complications.

S: The patient is a 39-year-old Caucasian male with a history of ESRD, presenting for an evaluation and exchange of his malfunctioning internal jugular hemodialysis catheter. He reports recent issues with his catheter, including SVC stricture issues, and has undergone four previous SVC venoplasties.
O: Physical examination and examination revealed high-grade SVC stenosis near the cavoatrial junction and multiple collateral veins filling in the vicinity of the heart. Venograms showed two vascular structures that followed the contour of the right heart border and the base of the chest, with refluxed contrast within the azygos vein. Coronary arteriographic evaluation showed no fistulous communication between the SVC and the coronary arterial system. A repeat venogram showed a small cardiac vein with direct communication with the superior vena cava and early filling of the coronary sinus.
A: The primary diagnosis is arteriovenous fistula in the right coronary artery, likely secondary to the small coronary vein. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vascular stenosis such as arterioversus, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's cardiac function and vascular integrity. The patient will be educated on the signs of potential complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the management plan and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, admitted to our institution in 2016, reported recurrent attacks of high intraocular pressure (IOP) and intraocular tear (AU) in the left eye for 4 months. The patient has a history of Posner-Schlossman syndrome, recurred 20 years ago, and has experienced vision issues.
O: On admission in September 2016, the patient's best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/25 with deep anterior chamber, fine pupillary light reflex, and a few anterior chamber inflammations. Examinations showed significant thinned retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) at superior and nasal side, visual field defects in inferior temple quadrant, and cornea edema with bullous keratopathy, fine white keratic precipitates, deep anterior chambers, 2+ flare counts in aqueous, and patched iris atrophy. The left eye showed cornea and bullous edema, KPs, deep posterior chamber, 2- flare counts, and patch iris. Serum IgG was positive for CMV, and CMV-DNA was positive with 1800 copies/ml.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent high intraoperoperoperatively (IOC) with associated eye pressure and visual field defect. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intraocular pain and visual symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient and IOP closely. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor IOP, inflammation, and visual fields. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to prescribed dosages. Consider referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of the eye condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling in the neck. The patient denies any other symptoms.
O: Initial blood tests revealed a leukocyte count of 49.1 X 10^9/L (normal range: 4.5-11.2 X 10/L), with 90% of lymphocytes. Immunophenotyping tests were positive for CD20, CD5, and CD23 surface antigens. A subsequent treatment with cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, vincristine, and prednisone was ineffective, leading to a relapse of CLL.
A: The primary diagnosis is CLL (Rai IV), a type of cancer affecting the blood and bone marrow. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of bone marrow cancer, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued chemotherapy with a focus on managing CLL and managing its complications. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on the response to the current therapy. Regular follow-ups with the hematologist are recommended to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a dislocated intraocular lumbar puncture (IOL) in the left eye due to noninfectious chronic uveitis and persistent cystoid macular edema. The patient underwent a vitrectomy in August 2010, followed by a sclerally-fixated IOL exchange using a knotless zigzag-shaped intrascleral suture. Post-surgery, the patient's best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) improved from 20/100 to 20/200.
O: Post-Vitrectomy, the left ophthalmologic region showed diffuse corneal edema and counting fingers. An anterior segment examination showed diffuse IOL and a stable scleral IOL. A Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK) procedure was performed two and nine days after the DMEK procedure, with rebubbling procedures performed due to a partially detached graft. The left eye has not fully recovered from the procedure.
A: The primary diagnosis is a dislocation IOL in the right eye, likely secondary to chronic uvitis and macular disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The plan includes continued monitoring of the left Ophthalmic region to assess the extent of the IOL's spread and any potential complications. Patient education on the importance of adhering to the prescribed treatment regimen and regular monitoring of vision is crucial. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the ophthalmic condition is recommended.

S: The patient reports a 2-month history of spiking fever of 39–40 °C, dry cough, night sweats, and fatigue. The patient has no history of arthralgia, rash, weight loss, or family history of other causes.
O: Physical examination revealed scattered rales on the right lung, splenomegaly, and enlarged lymph nodes in the right cervical region. Laboratory tests showed peripheral pancytopenia with white blood cells at 2.28*109/L, HGB at 87 g/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/dL), HGB 87 g-L (average range: 4-11 g/l), and PLT 71*10^9/L. Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 192 U/L), AST 139 U/l, LDH 554 U/dL) and hyperferritinaemia (Fer 4090 ng/ml). NK cell activity was reduced. Haemophagocytosis was noted in bone marrow aspirate. Serological investigations for common pathogens and autoimmune diseases were negative. Chest CT scan revealed bilateral nodules and right pleural effusion. Ultrasound-guided puncture on the left cervical lymph nodes identified M. intracellulare.
A: The primary diagnosis is M. extraculare infection, indicated by the presence of multiple inflammatory markers and elevated liver enzymes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and fatigue, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and potential complications from the infection. Treatment options will be discussed, including potential surgical intervention if symptoms persist or worsen. Patient education regarding the nature of the infection, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports a worsening headache for the past 3 days, characterized by constant pressure on the back of the head. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, decreased consciousness, visual disturbances, slurred speech, or body weaknesses. The pain is often associated with high blood pressure, and the patient has a history of hypertension treated with antihypertensive drugs.
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg (normal range: 150-160 mmHG), tenderness and inflammation at the occiput region, and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) of 6-7, with no signs of tenderness or inflammation. The rest of the physical examinations were within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is a persistent headache with associated blood pressure associated with hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headache and blood pressure. The prognosis depends on the management of hypertension and adherence to prescribed medications.
P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the patient's blood pressure and other vital signs, with adjustments to medication as necessary based on symptomatology and lab results. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the progression of the headache and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to medication and regular follow-ups is crucial.

S: Mrs. Patient 2 presents for a follow-up regarding her treatment for WM and the IgMkappa paraprotein. She denies any new symptoms or changes in health recently.
O: Recent test results include capillary zone electrophoresis, gel electrophoreis, capillary zones electrophoretic, and urine immunofixation. Biochemistry and hematology post-treatment confirm an IgMKappa paraprotech with IgG heavy chain and kappa light chain. Serum-free light chain ratio is elevated. Total IgG levels were increased at 35.1 g/L at diagnosis of γ-HCD with suppressed IgA and an IgG paraprotein of 10.7 g/dL. IgG1 subtype was elevated, and other IgG subtypes were decreased or at lower reference ranges. Bone marrow results show lymphoma cells CD5−, CD20+, and partially CD79a+, CD10+, CD23+, CD56+, and CD138+. Bone marrow histology identifies lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/WM.
A: Primary diagnosis of WM with IgM-heavy chain. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of lymphoma, but these were ruled out based on histology and bone marrow results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive response to ibrutinib and the absence of IgM/kappa.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for reporting new symptoms. Consider referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of WM.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension, presented with chronic abdominal and right inguinal pain, which has been present for a while. He denies any history of surgery or trauma.
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 135/95 mm Hg, heart rate of 62 bpm, and body temperature of 36.8°C. No signs of rigidity, rebound, or pulsatile mass were noted in the abdomen. Laboratory findings included leukocyte count of 7300/mm3, normal range 4600-10200/mm2, c-reactive protein of 2.7 mg/dL, and potassium of 3.8 mmol/dL (normal range 3.5-5.1 mmol/L). Imaging tests showed a calcified mass measuring 60x52 mm in size between the right internal iliac artery and urinary bladder. A Tru-cut biopsy was undiagnostic.
A: The primary diagnosis is a pelvic hydatid cyst, likely benign or malignant. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the pelvic hydatinid cystic. The patient will be started on a liquid diet, and Albendazole 200 mg/day will be prescribed as part of the treatment plan. Post-operative care will include monitoring vital signs and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old male, presents with a large black hairy skin patch on his face since birth, covering the left periorbital area, forehead, cheek, and nose. There is no family history of similar lesions or skin cancer. The patient denies any neurological symptoms or taking any medications.
O: Physical examination reveals a 13 cm pigmented patch extending to nearly half of his face. No increase in size or color of the lesion since birth. No pain, itching, or discharge reported. No other similar lesions on the body. No congenital anomalies reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large, pigmented, skin patch covering the entire left side of the face, covering nearly half the face. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of skin cancer, but these are less likely given the size and nature of the skin patch.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up appointments to assess the response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the nature of skin lesions and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a pediatric dermatologist for specialized care and a pediatric orthopedic surgeon for specialized consultations is recommended. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as needed.

S: The patient, referred for rectal SMT detected during a checkup at another hospital, reports no symptoms. The patient was unaware of the discovery until the patient underwent a trans-sacral resection of the tumor.
O: Digital examination of the anus and rectum revealed a 20-mm elastic hard tumor on the right and ventral sides of the anal canal, 2 to 3 cm proximal to the anal verge. Laboratory tests showed no elevation of carcinoembryonic antigen or cancer antigen 19-9. Colonoscopy confirmed a 19-mm SMT. Abdominal CT scan and MRI showed a mucinous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia, and surgical margins were negative. Follow-up CT and MRI scans showed a new cystic lesion near the site of the removed cystic tumor. Pathological examination post-trans-sphincter-preserving ISR showed tumor cells at the anal gland under the mucosa, producing mucin and fibrosis. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive for cytokeratin 7 (CK7).
A: The primary diagnosis is a mucinal adenocarcinoma of the lower rectum with a possible remnant tumor at the local site. Differential diagnosis initially included benign cysts, which were ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up visits to assess for any recurrence or complications. Further diagnostic tests such as biopsy or biopsy will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and rule out recurrence. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of potential recurrence is recommended.

S: The patient, a 40-year smoker with a history of prostate resection for hypertrophy, left total knee replacement, and decompression for spinal stenosis, presents with a 10-day history of dry cough, dyspnoea, and fatigue. The patient has a history with HIV, well controlled with combination anti-retroviral therapy, and has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. He also has minimal alcohol intake and no illicit substance use.
O: Physical examination revealed a respiratory rate of 18 per minute with saturations of 93% on 2 L of nasal prong oxygen, heart rate of 75 bpm, sinus rhythm, and blood pressure of 104/60 mmHg. Physical examination showed reduced air entry with bibasal crackles. Laboratory tests showed a hemoglobin of 115 g/L, neutrophils 8.19 × 10^9/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 × 10/L), lymphocytes 0.49 × 10 µL (average range: 1.5–2.1 µL), eosinophils 0.17 × 10·9/l (normal ranges: 0-1/L) and platelets 390 × 10−9/LL. Chest film showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates, predominantly in the lower zones. Urinalysis showed more than 500 erythrocytes, 10 leucocytes, and no bacteria.
A: The primary diagnosis is pneumonia, likely secondary to HIV infection, given the patient's history of multiple surgical interventions and current medications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory failure and kidney dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Initiated treatment with ceftriaxone, azithromycin, oxygen, and intravenous fluids, followed by continuation of IV fluids. Continued monitoring of hemoglobin levels and renal function is necessary. The plan includes adjusting the treatment regimen as necessary based on the patient’s response to treatment and any new symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old male, presented with a 5-day history of respiratory distress and retching. The parent reported that the child was struggling to breathe and had a history of bowel loops in the left lower hemithorax.
O: Upon admission, the patient exhibited severe dyspnea, temperature 39.5°C, and tachycardia of 200/min. An immediate endotracheal intubation was performed. A thoracic CT scan confirmed a left-sided enterothorax with mediastinal shift. A left-side chest tube was inserted, and a right-sided Chest tube was used to drain the fluid. Diagnostic laparoscopy revealed a Bochdalek hernia with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach. Bile-stained fluid was found in the thorax and abdomen. A gastric perforation at the lesser curvature was successfully closed. A retrovesical abscess was drained 30 days post-surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a left pneumothoracic hernia secondary to a gastric puncture. Differential diagnosis initially included a diaphragmatic rupture, which was ruled out based on imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is good with ongoing monitoring and supportive care.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up visits to assess recovery and detect any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a five-week history of right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. He reported a fall five weeks ago, which led to the onset of progressively worsening right chest pain. He has no prior medical or social history, renal disease, or renal disease.
O: On examination, the patient was tachycardic with a pulse rate of 104 beats/minute, blood pressure of 121/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Cardiac examination was unremarkable with no additional sounds and murmurs. Lungs were clear to auscultation with no rales or rhonchi. Abdominal examination was soft and non-tender, with no signs of organomegaly or peripheral edema. Chest X-ray indicated a pleural lesion in the right hemothorax. CT scan showed an expansile lytic lesion and multiple lytic deposits. Skeletal survey indicated multiple lesions on the skull, pelvic bone, and proximal right femur.
A: The primary diagnosis is normocytic anemia with associated lytic lesions and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain and chest discomfort, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests and consult with a specialist to determine the exact cause and develop a treatment plan. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes immediately. Further consultations with an infectious disease specialist are necessary to refine the treatment plan and guide further management.

S: The patient, with a history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, hypertension, irritable bowel syndrome, and anxiety disorder, reports a long history of dry skin and abnormal menstrual periods, menorrhagia with irregular menses, and increasing polymenorrhea. Recently, the patient has experienced chronic diarrhea alternating with constipation, and recently gained 20 lbs. The patient also mentions a recent onset of galactorrhea and breast enlargement and tenderness.
O: Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) is >150 mIU/mL (normal 0.5-5.5), free thyroxine (FT4) is 0.4 ng/dL (lowest 0.61-1.82), prolactin is 29.5 ng/mL (<normal 3.34-26.72), and an MRI of the pituitary gland revealed an enlarged pituitar gland measuring 14x12 mm, abutting the optic chiasm. No symptoms of transient blurry vision, apraxia, aphasia, chest tightness, or increased anxiety were reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is pituitarian hyperthyroidism with associated hormonal imbalances and pituitaries. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperthyroxine deficiency, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Continue current medications including amphetamine, nebivolol, clonazepam, citalopram, hydrochlorothiazide, polyethylene glycol, levocetirizine, and amphetamine. Initiate lifestyle modifications to manage weight and overall health. Schedule additional diagnostic tests and consultations with specialists to refine the diagnosis and treatment plan. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of end-stage liver disease who underwent an orthotopic liver transplant in March 2018, leading to improvement in hepatic encephalopathy and synthetic function. He reports feeling better since the transplant, but has been on an outpatient regimen of dialysis every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. He underwent a renal transplant in August 2018. He has been receiving hemodialysis through a tunneled central venous catheter. He was previously bacteremic with ESBL Klebesiella oxytoca and treated with Citrobacter, Stenotrophomonas ESBL, and ESBL. He experienced a profound change in mentation and personality post-treatment.
O: Initial treatment included ertapenem for a catheter infection, which was later discontinued due to suspected hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's tacrolimus level was elevated at 5.3 ng/mL, which is within normal limits and at goal for his liver transplant. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust treatment as necessary.
A: The primary diagnosis is hepatic and synthetic liver disease with complications including hepatorenality and hepatorenals. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and response to treatment. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the management of the hepatic issues and the absence of significant complications.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of ertapeenem and monitoring for any new or worsening symptoms. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any potential complications. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for regular follow-up visits is crucial. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of hepatic dysfunction is recommended. Further consultations with a hepatology specialist may be necessary depending on the progression of the liver disease and the response to therapy.

S: The patient, who underwent strabismus surgery for concomitant exotropia, reports feeling okay but has noticed something unusual in the left eye. The patient has a history of a subconjunctival cyst in the right eye, which was surgically removed.
O: Physical examination revealed thin purulent fluid and necrotic soft tissue, with a surgical design of 5 mm posterior insertion. The medial rectus was firmly attached to the sclera surface, with the initial muscle suture intact but loose. A bacterial culture was positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection, and a drug sensitivity test was administered. Postoperative follow-up showed complete recovery of the conjunctival incision, and right binocular alignment was restored.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic suppurative inflammation of the left subconjugunctival area, likely secondary to the surgical intervention. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular inflammation, but these are less likely given the positive bacterial culture and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of vancomycin (0.25 g, q8h) via intravenous drip and local antibiotic and corticosteroid eye drops from Tobradex, with close monitoring of the patient's condition postoperatively. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing myalgia, arthralgia, and a frontal headache over a 12-hour period. The patient denies experiencing photophobia, phonophobia, skin rash, fits, cough, or urinary symptoms. There is no history of smoking or alcohol, drug abuse, or high-risk sexual behavior. The chief complaint is mild intermittent bronchial asthma.
O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 101.3 °F and drowsy with a Glasgow coma scale of 11/15. Neurological examination was normal. Fundoscopic examination showed a pulse rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg with no postural hypotension, and respiratory rate 14/min. Laboratory tests showed white blood cells at 6 × 10^9/L, neutrophils at 59%, hemoglobin at 14.3 g/dL, platelet count at 74 × 10/L. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 13 mm in the first hour, elevated C-reactive protein at 63 mg/l, and mild impaired renal function. Liver enzymes were elevated with alanine aminotransferase at 303 U/l and AST at 482 U/L; total bilirubin at 10.6 µmol/L was within normal limits. Urine analysis and coagulation profile were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is cerebral oedema, likely secondary to chronic bronchitis, given the elevated liver enzymes and elevated liver function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or progression of symptoms. Further treatment options may be considered based on the progression of oedemia and response to treatment. Patient education on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns is crucial. Referral to a rheumatologist for specialized care and a hematologist for ongoing management of chronic bronchiitis is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing a bit of crowded teeth and concerns about cavities. The patient has a history of Class I canine occlusion on both sides, increased overjet, and moderate crowding in the anterior segments in both the upper jaw and lower jaw. The lower-left first molar appears tipped forward in the space of the second deciduous molar.
O: Clinical examination revealed severe caries affecting the second and third decidsuous molars in the upper and lower jaws, and an ectopic eruption of the first permanent molars. Radiographic examination showed a submerged second decidaire (8.5) on the right side, with a high risk of caries. A minimally invasive approach was used for the space regaining procedure.
A: The primary diagnosis is a submerged molar with associated caries and high risk for caries, necessitating the extraction of the submerged second. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dental cavities, but these are less likely given the imaging and radiologic findings.
P: The management plan includes the extraction and space regaining procedure using a minimally-imvasive approach. The procedure will involve fitting a band with a double buccal tube on the permanent molar and using a .014-inch round NiTi wire to bond the wire perpendicular to the main tooth axis during the procedure. Post-procedure, the patient will receive detailed instructions for preparation and aftercare. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a male, presented with sudden onset of weakness and dizziness. He reported being obtunded with a Glasgow Coma Score of 3 and a blood sugar level of 33 mg/dL. He was intubated and administered D50 through an EZ-IO® device.
O: Upon arrival, the patient was hypoglycemic and unresponsive. Initial attempts at intravenous access were unsuccessful, and dextrose was administered at a concentration of 50% to raise blood sugar levels. A POCUS was performed to evaluate the functionality of the IO needle, revealing an absence of flow in the IO space during normal saline injection. The patient was resuscitated and stabilized with a second 45 mm IO needle placed in the right humerus. Examination revealed firm compartments and decreased peripheral pulses, raising concerns for compartment syndrome. A deep posterior compartment pressure measured 85 mmHg. Radiograph indicated a puncture of both the anterior and posterior cortex of the tibia, extending 2 mm beyond the posterior cortex.
A: The primary diagnosis is compartment syndrome, likely secondary to the intracranial IO needle puncture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute hypoglycemia such as infection or infection. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan included resuscitation with a four-compartment fasciotomy performed by orthopedic surgery, which was successful. The plan includes follow-up with the orthopedics surgeon for further evaluation and management of the compartment syndrome and the need for further management. Further consultations with an oncologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progress of the surgery and the patient's response to treatment.

S: The patient, with a 7-year history of Basedow's disease, presents with a high fever for the past 9 days, palpitations, and a dry cough. The patient denies experiencing sore throat, cervical pain, dyspnea, or stomachache. Additionally, the patient has lost 20 kg over the past 6 months and has chronic mild diarrhea. No recent travel or travel or sick contacts were reported.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be anxious and febrile with a temperature of 39.1 °C, blood pressure 129/77 mmHg, pulse 131 bpm, respiratory rate 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. The thyroid gland is soft, diffusely enlarged, non-tender, with no skin redness or warmth. Cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia, hyperactive bowel sounds, and normal abdomen. Neurological examination is normal. Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with WBC 11,360 WBC /μL, neutrophils 78.6%, hyperthyroidism with TSH < 0.021 μIU/mL, F-T3 > 30.00 pg/mL and F-4 > 8.88 ng/mL. CRP level is 5.07 mg/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is Basedow’s disease, likely exacerbated by the cessation of thiamazole. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and palpitation, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the disease.
P: The management plan includes restarting thiamrazole and regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The management of Basedowe's disease will be adjusted based on the patient”s response and response to therapy. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists may be necessary to manage the patient and improve overall health.

S: The patient, a 50-year-old with a history of transient liver injury and cervical and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, presents with a periodic fever and skin rash persisting for 7-10 days, occurring every 14-20 days for the past 2 months. The patient also reports a productive cough for several days, which has resolved. No family history of periodic fever or autoimmune diseases is reported.
O: Physical examination revealed a pruritic skin rash with urticaria on the arms and legs, erythema and swelling of fingers, and a pink rash on the back and a salmon-pink rash on one arm. Skin biopsy was nonspecific. The rash was treated with antipyretics and anti-allergy drugs but not with immunosuppressive therapy. Blood cell counts are normal, but AST 79 IU/L, ALT 51 IU, LDH 471 IU/l, ALP 152 IU/dL, γ-GTP 24 IU/mL, CRP 2.86 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/L), CRP 3.86 g/dL (<normal range), ferritin 4731 ng/mL (normal <0.5 ng/L). Screenings for hepatitis B and C are pending.
A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent skin rash, likely related to a food allergy, given the patient's history of multiple food allergies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin rash and fever, but these are less likely given the absence of specific symptoms. The differential diagnosis could include autoimmune or inflammatory conditions given the history of food allergies and the patient’s history of autoimmune conditions.
P: Continue monitoring the patient closely with immunotherapy and anticoagulation therapy. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of the skin rash. Educate the patient on the nature of the condition and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Consider consultation with a rhesumatologist if symptoms persist or worsen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, a male with a history of epilepsy, presented to the emergency room in a confused condition and reduced awareness following a pub fight. He denied any psychiatric history or known medical conditions. He was previously on antiepileptic drugs for epilepsy but discontinued them a while ago.
O: Physical examination, neurological examination, brain CAT, and cerebrospinal fluid findings were unremarkable. Blood analysis showed slight leukocytosis. EEG showed general slowing without traces of epilepsy. Urine toxicology test showed a decrease in leukaemia, CK to 521 U/L, and a slight increase in CRP to 16.2 mg/L. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and the patient's Valproic acid blood levels were 54 mg/dL.
A: The primary diagnosis is an epileptic seizure, likely secondary to medication discontinuation due to the patient’s history of medication discontinuities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epileptic seizures, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the seizure.
P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the patient and seizure activity. The patient is advised to continue with current medications and monitor for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Education on seizure management and the importance of medication adherence will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports persistent left epigastric dull pain, chills, and febrile symptoms. The pain started without a clear cause and has been present for a while. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which has led to intermittent abdominal pain.
O: Physical examination revealed no distended abdomen, normoactive bowel sounds, rebound tenderness, tenderness in the left upper quadrant, and no palpable mass. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 17.37 × 10^9 cells/L, neutrophils 93.9%, lymphocytes 3.1%, monocytes3.0%, eosinophils 0.00%, and basophils0.00%. Liver function tests, alpha-fetoprotein, carcinoembryonic antigen, and carbohydrate antigen 19–9 were normal. C-reactive protein was 56.6 mg/L. Upper abdominal contrast-enhanced CT showed diffuse hepatic disease, spleen abscess with inflammatory exudate, and spleen calcification. Chest radiograph and CT scan showed chronic inflammation of the inferior lobe of the left lung, a small amount of fluid, and thickening of the gastric fundus. Histological examination of biopsies indicated spleen enlargement, fibrosis, and necrosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic left upper abdominal pain, likely secondary to chronic hepatitis or tuberculosis, given the patient's history of Type 2 diabetes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain such as inflammatory bowel disease or other inflammatory bowel diseases, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings.
P: The management plan includes continuation of anti-infection therapy and regular follow-ups with gastroenterology and hepatology to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and possibly a hepatologist are recommended to manage type 2 Diabetes. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications is crucial. Referral to a hepatology specialist for further evaluation and management of chronic liver disease is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the progression of symptoms and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal distention and pain for the past 5 hours, accompanied by vomiting twice. The patient has a history of acute pancreatitis (AP) treated with lipid-lowering drugs in May this year, which led to the cessation of the medication.
O: Initial tests revealed a Ranson score of 4, Balthazar CT grade of D, APACHE II score of 17, and SOFA score of 9. Upper abdominal CT, liver, kidney, and heart function, and electrolyte levels were reviewed. Ranson scores were 4, APAHE II grade of 17 (normal range: 4-17), and SO FA score of 8 (normal ranges: 0-5).
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute pancreaticitis (SAP) with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (heart, liver and kidney). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The treatment plan includes positive expansion, gastrointestinal decompression, and nutritional support. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) will be initiated on the second day, followed by intraperitoneal puncture and drainage on days 2, 4, 8, and 15. Eight root drainage tubes will be placed on the 11th day. Jejunal nutrition will be administered for 16 days post-admission. Post-treatment, the patient's renal function will be restored, and the APAChe II and SOFI scores will increase to 3 on day 18. Temperature will return to normal around day 19. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a female, presented with a cervical nodule and a lump in her neck. She reported no neurological symptoms. She has a history of dermatological surgery in the right cervical area, which required admission to intensive care.
O: Color Doppler ultrasonography revealed a large nodule posterior to the left carotid bifurcation and a ligature of the right common carotaid artery from a previous surgical procedure. Arteriography identified a hypervascularized glomus tumor with a maximum diameter of 5 cm, located in the ascending pharyngeal artery and occlusion of the left ophthalmic artery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a glomerus tumor, with associated complications including a contralateral carottid occlusions and a saccular aneurysm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cervical nodules and vascular lesions. The prognosis depends on the successful resection of the tumor.
P: The management plan includes surgical resection with preoperative embolization. The procedure involves superselective catheterization of the artery feeding the tumor, using the pressure cooker technique, femoral artery puncture, and a 1.3-F Marathon® microcatheter. A 1.5-F Apollo® catheter will be used to inject Onyx® until arterial reflux is identified on fluoroscopy. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a 3-year history of pain on the left side of the face, described as burning and pricking, intermittent, and spreading to the left temporal and orbital region. The pain has worsened over the past 3 years, with frequent anxiety and agitation. The patient has been prescribed various medications, including analgesics, antibiotics, steroids, and antidepressants, but no relief has been found.
O: Physical examination revealed a sharp, localized pain in the hamular region due to an elongated hamular process with a knife-edge bony projection. MRI of the brain, OPG, and cephalograms ruled out vascular decompression, central pontine dysfunction, skull base, and metastatic tumor. Oral examination showed deep dentinal caries with respect to 18 and pulp stones with respectto 16 on the right side. Blood tests indicated no changes in color or texture.
A: The primary diagnosis is a hamular pain secondary to a hamolar process, likely exacerbated by the patient's dental history and recent dental procedures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pain such as cranial arteritis or autoimmune disorders, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Initiate local anesthetic (1 ml of 2% lidocaine) to alleviate the pain. Plan to perform blood tests and discuss the results with the patient and potential surgical intervention if necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring compliance with follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a history of repaired hypospadias and anal atresia, presents with chronic prostatitis-like complaints persisting for three months.
O: MRI of the pelvis revealed a large thick-walled cystic lesion in the midline between the prostate and the deformed sacrum, communicating with the prostatic urethra at the level of the verumontanum via a thin neck. MRI findings confirmed a giant utricle cyst with chronic superinfection. Urethroscopy confirmed the connection between the lesion and the verumsontanus. Post-surgery, the patient developed a pelvic abscess and perforation of the bladder wall. A control cystography showed closure of the defect one month later.
A: The primary diagnosis is a giant urethral cyst, likely caused by chronic supercontinence. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of prostatosis and urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan included surgical marsupialization of the cyst to address the cystic infection and closure of a bladder defect. The patient underwent a robot-assisted surgical marsuppialization procedure, which was successful. Follow-up care will include monitoring for complications such as infection recurrence or complications related to the bladder defect, and regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, previously treated for Helicobacter pylori gastritis, reports experiencing indigestion, heartburn, and bloating for the past six months.
O: An upper GI endoscopy revealed a duodenal bulb polyp. Biopsy of the polyp revealed a clonal population of malignant B-cells with a CD5+, CD10-, CD20+, CD23- immunophenotype, and over-expression of cyclin D1. PET and CT scans identified an enlarged inguinal lymph node and a nonenlarged left external iliac lymph node. Bone marrow biopsy was normal. Repeat upper endoscopies with endoscopic ultrasound and colonoscopy in November 2014 showed an increase in the size of the duodenumal bulb lesion and abnormal mucosa in the ileocecal valve. Repeat tests in December 2018 showed a normal appearance of the ilocarcoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is MCL, with differential diagnoses including other forms of malignancy and malignant lymphadenopathy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of recurrence of the disease.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. The patient will continue on rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CVP) and regular surveillance with repeat PET/CT scans every three months. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient.

S: The patient, with a history of epilepsy and asthma, presented with recurrent seizures and a referral to another hospital for higher care. The patient reported two or three episodes of generalized tonic clonic seizure-like activity, lasting approximately 5-10 minutes, and became apneic and cyanotic upon arrival.
O: Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient was in a postictal phase, with an episode of a generalized tononic seizure lasting approximately five minutes. He was sedated and intubated for airway protection. A Brain CT was unremarkable. Vital signs showed elevated blood pressure at 170/90 mmHg and a heart rate in the 120s. Lab results showed mild leukocytosis and normal renal function with serum creatinine at 1.3 mg/dL. Urine drug screen was negative. On transfer to ICU admission, serum creatine kinase (CK) was mildly elevated at 297 U/L. On day 2, labs showed worsening acute kidney injury (AKI) with serum creatine at 4.9 g/dL, bicarbonate at 18 mEq/L, and CK at 663 U/l. Urgent urine microscopy showed consistent urine output at 40-60 ml/hr.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent seizures, likely exacerbated by the patient's epilepsy and recent seizure activity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure activity, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes continued antiseizure therapy with IV Midazolam, Levetiracetam, and Lacosamide, with adjustments to the treatment as necessary based on further lab results and clinical presentation. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient and his family, with regular follow-ups to assess seizure response and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on seizure management and the importance of adherence to the medication regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of hypothyroidism and benign prostatic hyperplasia, presents with a four-month history of dry mouth, generalized weakness, decreased oral intake, and a 30-pound weight loss in four months. The patient has a family history of Crohn's disease and lupus.
O: Physical examination revealed dry oropharyngeal mucosa. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum calcium at 12.71 mg/dL (normal range: 8.4-10.7 mg/dl), ionized calcium at 1.9 mmoL/L (normal: 1.10-1.30 mg/L), and elevated creatinine at 3.81 g/dL. Parathyroid hormone levels were decreased at 6.5 pg/mL (normal ranges: 15-65 pg/dL), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 55 mm/hr. Laboratory workup showed undetectable parathyroid hormones (PTHrp), mildly decreased 25-hydroxyvitamin D at 18.1 ng/ml, and elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamins at 72 pg/ml.
A: The primary diagnosis is hypercalcemia secondary to hypothyrosyroidism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperchemia such as chronic kidney disease or other autoimmune disorders. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of hypercalcemic symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring calcium levels and other lab results closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment with the rheumatologist as soon as possible for further evaluation and treatment recommendations. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a dietitian for nutritional support and a physical therapist for nutritional counseling.

S: The patient, with a history of persistent atrial fibrillation and arterial hypertension, reports no palpitations or irregular heartbeat. The patient also has a thalassemic trait and is currently asymptomatic for cardiological symptoms.
O: Current medications include Flecainide 100 mg twice daily and Dabigatran (CHA2DS2-VASC score 2). Echocardiography showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. An echocardogram indicated an AF recurrence. Echotardiography indicated a left and right atrial index volume of 48 mL/mm2 and an ejection rate of 47% on an electrocardiogram.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent atrial Fibrillation, likely secondary to thalassic trait. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of arrhythmia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes AF ablation through PVI, using a multi-electrode mapping (MEM) catheter Pentaray™. The procedure will involve mapping the right and left atrium to define the inferior and superior vena cava, the His location, and the coronary sinus (A). A decapolar catheter will be inserted in the right atrium under 3D EAM guidance, with the FO looking for fragmented and low-voltage signals. Post-procedure, the patient will be educated on the procedure and advised to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease, presents with a four-day history of chest pain radiating to the jaw and along the left arm. The patient also reports shortness of breath.
O: Initial EKG showed old Q waves in the inferior leads and new ST depression in leads I, AVL, V5, and V6. Troponin levels peaked at 15.8. Chest radiograph showed pulmonary edema. Emergency cardiac catheterization revealed 100% occlusion in the right coronary, left main coronary, and proximal portion of the circumflex artery, with diffuse disease of the grafted vessels to circumflex. Emergency echocardiography showed partial disruption of the medial papillary muscle with a severely flail posterior MV leaflet and severe MR. ECMO pump placement was performed by cardiothoracic surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a 100% coronary artery occlusions with diffuse vascular disease, including the right common femoral artery and right femoral vein. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coronary artery dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition.
P: The management plan includes a transcatheter procedure to address the arterial occlusive and MR. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of cardiac function and hemodynamic compromise. The procedure will involve a transseptal puncture using ultrasound guidance and intraoperative transesophageal echocoardiography. Postoperative follow-up will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and the patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes.

S: Patient 7 reports experiencing weakness on the left side for approximately 45 minutes. He denies any known underlying diseases.
O: Initial NIHSS score was 18, indicating significant neurological deficits. Multimodal CT (MTT) revealed a perfusion delay in the whole right MCA territory. Oxygen saturation in the brain was 48.35% and cerebral rSO2 was 64.87%, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is left hemiparesis, likely due to the perfusion delays in the left MCA. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Initiate Endovascular Therapy (EVT) to restore proper blood flow to the brain and alleviate symptoms. Monitor patient's condition closely and provide necessary support. Educate patient on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and ensure understanding of the treatment process.

S: The patient reports a 30-day history of fever, headaches, paresthesia, and pain in the right arm, accompanied by red spots on the skin. The skin lesions worsened and spread to the lower limbs and trunk within 10 days. The patient has been on NSAID for the initial symptoms.
O: On the 15th day post-skin disease onset, the patient developed thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction with an INR of 1.45 and Prothrombin Time of 56%, edema in hands and feet, and hemorrhagic bullous lesions on skin. Intensive care included meropenem and vancomycin for 6 days, followed by intravenous administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (Human), 5% (Flebogamma® 5% DIF) at 400 mg/kg/day for 5 days. Post-treatment, platelet levels increased from 43,000 to 201,000, total leukocyte count improved, and significant reduction in edema, necrosis, and erythema. Ten days post-globulin administration, aphasia evolved.
A: The primary diagnosis is transient acute ischemic stroke (CHIKV), confirmed by laboratory findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's symptoms and adherence to the treatment plan. The management of CHIKV should include regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns to the healthcare team is crucial.

S: The patient, a sheep farmer, reported drowning in cold river water. He was not a good swimmer and could not stay above water. The incident occurred at a depth of 2 metres, with the patient unconscious, not breathing, and blue lips and nails. The patient's skin was very cold.
O: Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient was conscious, disoriented, anxious, and pale. Initial CPR was performed, and chest compression was performed. Upon admission, the body temperature was hypothermic at 35.1°C, and shivering was noted. Vital signs included heart, blood pressure, temperature, and pulse oximetry. Auscultation of the lungs revealed weakened breathing sounds, early inspirium cracklings, low tone whistling, and arrhythmic cardiac action with tachycardia up to 120 beats per minute and blood pressure at 100/55.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute hypothermia secondary to a fall from a river, likely exacerbated by the patient's poor swimming ability. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute hyponatremia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the cardiac function and response to treatment. A nasogastric tube and urinary catheter have been placed to aid in recovery. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with a cardiologist and possibly a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progression of the condition. Patient education on signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, admitted to Kasturba Hospital with acute gastroenteritis, reports experiencing loose stools, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fever for one day. The patient has a history of oral candidiasis, upper respiratory tract infections, and leucopenia. The stools have been watery but have not been noticed by the patient.
O: On examination, the patient's stools were watery, but there was no evidence of mucus or blood in the stools. He has a past medical history of Oral candidiasis (previously treated with cyclophosphamide 700 mg every 2 weeks), upper respiratory infections (lower respiratory tract infection), and leukopenia (lower urinary tract infection).
A: The primary diagnosis is lupus nephritis class IV with complications including loose stool, fever, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms, but these are less likely given the current symptoms and history.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient and the treatment plan. The fifth pulse of cyclophophospham is scheduled to be administered as scheduled. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on patient's response to the fifth pulse and the need for additional treatment. The healthcare team will continue to support the patient with hydration and hydration, and the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a female with a history of endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, tubal surgery, intrauterine device use, and a previous ectopic pregnancy, presents with an 8-week delay of menstruation and increasing pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, accompanied by intense reflex sensitivity in the left shoulder. She denies any history of ectopic pregnancies.
O: Physical examination revealed no signs of intrauterinine pregnancy, normal bilateral adnexa, or free fluid in the abdomen. CT scan of abdomen and pelvis revealed a 90-mm-long mixed hypodense mass on the upper surface of the right liver lobe. Diagnostic abdominocentesis revealed uncoagulable blood. Laparoscopy revealed a significant hemoperitoneum with approximately 1500 ml of blood, uterus and ovaries normal, and no bleeding from the pelvic organs. A 50 mm corpus luteum cyst was noted around the perihepatic area and spleen.
A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic pregnant in the liver, with complications including a ruptured abdominal pregnancy and hemorrhagic shock. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and weakness, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful resection of the mass.
P: The management plan included transfer to a tertiary referral center for further management. Post-operative care included laparoscopic surgery and placement of a bipolar electrocoagulation device to manage bleeding. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of complications and is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports discomfort in the right groin area, with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and a 6-year history of an enlarging right inguinal hernia.
O: Physical examination revealed a cystic mass on the superior right testicle and a firm, solid, mobile testicular mass. The mass was fully mobile within the subcutaneous space and minimally tender, with no external ring connections. A CT scan revealed a partially visualized, heterogenous, enhancing right ingueinal mass without associated peripheral nerve sheath tumor or sarcoma of the spermatic cord. Pathology confirmed the mass was inside the external cord but outside of the internal sperma fascia, eroded through the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle, and was easily separated from the spermmatic cord, weighing 67.5 grams and measuring 7 x 5.5 x 2.5 cm. Microscopic examination showed a heterogeneous pattern-less architecture with alternating hypocellular and hypercellular areas, interstitial hyalinization, and intermixed ropy collagen bands. The vascular compartment showed a continuum of changes, ranging from thick-walled vessels with proliferation of myocytes to vessels with intimal thickening.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign ingue mass with associated vascular changes and associated vascular abnormalities. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of vascular malignancies or malignancy, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the tumor and treatment efficacy. The patient will be educated on the signs of potential complications and encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and possibly a pulmonologist may be considered if the tumor does not recur. Education on recognizing signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a computer scientist, presents with a seven-day history of myalgia, retro-orbital headaches, fatigue, recurrent fever, and nausea. He reports increasing difficulty in walking due to myalgia in the calf region and an episode of gum bleeding after cleaning teeth. He denies any recent travel or contact with animals. He has a minor knee injury and a skin abrasion two weeks ago, which occurred while bathing in the river Isar near Munich. He does not consume alcohol, nicotine, or drugs, and has no relevant medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed a body temperature of 36.8 °C, pulse 90 bpm, blood pressure 114/75 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 bpm. Lung and heart auscultation were unremarkable, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. Skin and scleral inspection revealed jaundice, slight gum bleeding, and tenderness in the thighs and calves upon pressure. Abdominal ultrasound showed hepatosplenomegaly with no signs of intra- or extrahepatic cholestasis. WBC count was 9.9 G/L with 87% neutrophils and 3.5% lymphocytes. Hemoglobin was 13.3 g/dl. Serum sodium was 123 mmol/l, and potassium was within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute myalgia with complications including gum bleeding and jaundic symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of jaundiness such as infection or infectious processes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or progression of symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately. Further diagnostic tests may be required to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes. Education on the importance of reporting new symptoms and promptly reporting them is crucial.

S: The patient reports a progressive decrease in vision in the left eye over the past six months, accompanied by excessive perspiration and sweating. The patient has a history of pituitary gigantism diagnosed at age 16, secondary to a GH-functional prosthetic (PA). The patient underwent microsurgical trans sphenoidal surgery for resection of a PA in 1990 and adjuvant radiotherapy in 2011.
O: Ophthalmologic examination revealed left ptosis, exophthalmos, and upward/inward limitation on left eye movements. Goldmann's test perimeter showed ipsilateral amaurosis and right hemianopia. Random serum GH level was 0.071 ng/ml (normal 0.003–0.97 ng/mL). During the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), GH-nadir was 0 (0.13 ng/l). Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) was 84.3 ng/ ml (normal 64–210 ng/L). Brain MRI revealed a large policystic selar lesion with extensive osteophytic reaction and invasion of the ipsilaterally orbital apex associated with fibrous dysplasia. T2-weighted imaging revealed a hypointense and enhancing selar mass lesion, with Calcium intensity.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large selar malignant lesion in the brain, likely causing the vision problems and other symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vision loss and ocular symptoms, but these are less likely given the MRI findings and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the selar and ophthalmic conditions. The management will include close monitoring of the patient's ocular condition, regular follow-ups with ophthalmology, and possibly a retinal specialist to assess the lesion's response to treatment. Patient education regarding the nature of the lesional and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a specialist for specialized care and management is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and HOCM, presented with sudden onset of sharp, non-radiating, left-sided flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient expressed concern about the symptoms and the need for further diagnostic tests.
O: Vital signs were unremarkable. Physical examination revealed a Grade III/VI systolic murmur at the apex with no radiation, marked tenderness on superficial palpation of the left inferior costal margin, no rebound tenderness, no costovertebral angle tenderness or abdominal or flank erythema. Lab workup showed leukocytosis at 13,000 and acute kidney injury with creatinine at 1.3 mg/dl from a baseline of 0.7 mg/dL. Urinalysis was positive for hematuria, but urine toxicology was negative for illicit substances. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed bilateral segmental hypoperfusion with the left side more affected than the right. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of infarction, ischemia, or atrial fibrillation. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed hyperdynamic left ventricle systsolic function, moderately dilated left atrium at 54 mm, mild thickening of the anterior and posterior mitral valve leaflets, and a peak subvalvular gradient of 20 mmHg with no obvious masses or vegetation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral renal infarct, likely secondary to a hypercoagulable state, autoimmune etiology, sickle cell disease, patent foramen ovale, and arrhythmias. Differential diagnoses include infection, hypercemia, or other causes of renal dysfunction. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Initiated heparin drip for the renal infascularization. Ongoing monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications will be necessary. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of renal function is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis, treatment options, and importance of follow-up care will be provided.

S: The patient reports an abnormal curve in the spine since birth, uneven growth, and a birthmark on the back and swelling on the left tonsil. The patient has a history of hemangioma on the face and back since birth and facial hemangitis at age 4, with a recent diagnosis of Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome (KTS) due to abnormal asymmetric growth and venous varicosities in both lower extremities three years ago. There is no family history of KTS.
O: Physical examination revealed hemihypertrophy of the left face, trunk, and lower limb, a port-wine stain on both lower limbs, and an intact left leg. Neurological examination showed claudication. Laboratory findings included increased D-Dimer level at 2.02 mg/L, decreased hemoglobin at 105 g/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dL), decreased 1,25(OH)2D3 at 6.58 pg/mL (normal: <0.5 pg/L), and decreased Fe at 34.7μg/dL (normal <35-40 μg/mL).
A: The primary diagnosis is Klippelman-Trentaunay syndrome, complicated by kyphoscoliosis and associated hemangia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of kyphaliosis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan will include medication, physical therapy, and possibly surgery for kyphy. Laboratory tests will be closely monitored to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The management will include physical therapy and possibly surgical intervention to address kyppel-trenaunAY syndrome. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the management plan as needed.

S: The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure, presenting with dysuria, severe urinary frequency, nocturia, suprapubic pain, fever, and increasing lethargy. He reports no previous abdominal surgeries.
O: Initial urinalysis revealed a urinary tract infection with positive nitrites, proteinuria, and leukocyturia, but urine culture was negative. Blood tests showed neutrophilia and mild acute renal impairment. Urine culture and urine culture were negative, and blood tests showed no bacteria cultivated from urine. Ultrasound examination of the urinary tract showed a heterogenous mass anterior to the urinary bladder measuring 8.5 × 4.9 × 6.1cm. CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis showed a large, thick-walled mass measuring 8cm superior to the bladder, communicating with the bladder and in contact with the small bowel, with enlarged lymph node groups in both groins, lateral vesical groups bilaterally, and the left para-aortic region up to the left renal hilum.
