Cystoscopy was performed to localize the fistula and its relation to the ureteric orifices.
A: The primary diagnosis is a heterogeneous urinary tract mass, likely secondary to a urinary bladder infection, with differential diagnoses including other causes of urinary tract infections such as neoplasms or renal dysfunction. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition and the need for surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes continuation of intravenous Co-Amoxiclav therapy and close monitoring of renal function. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, with no known past medical history, presents with sudden right hip pain and progressive difficulty in walking for the past three weeks. The pain is severe and worsens with rest, worsening with rest. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma (MM) and metastatic prostate cancer.
O: Physical examination revealed multiple lytic lesions. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 9 g/dl, creatinine at 2.8 mg/dl (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dL), calcium at 13.5 mg/di (normal: 0-1 mg/d), albumin at 2-7 g/di, total serum protein at 9.6 g/dL (normal <0.5), globulin at 7.1 g/d (normal >0.3 g/l), free PSA at 6.9ng/mL (normal 0.6-1 ng/mL), and total PSA 78.0 ng/dL. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and hematuria. MRI of the spine and bone scan showed diffuse metastatic disease. Urology confirmed multiple myelo-myeloma with metastasis.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic metastatic cancer of the right hip, evidenced by the presence of lytic lesion and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hip pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes a bilateral orchiectomy to prevent spinal cord compression. Treatment includes intravenous fluid hydration and zoledronic acid to manage hypercalcemia. Continuous monitoring of creatininine levels is essential, with adjustments to treatment as necessary. The treatment plan will include regular follow-ups with primary care physician and specialists to manage the patient's condition. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments is crucial.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old transgender woman presenting with severe pain in the right forearm, redness, and blistering. She reports a solar branding tattoo on her right forearm approximately 2 weeks ago, worsening the blistering three days later. She has sought medical care for a superficial infection of her right arm full thickness burn, which was diagnosed as a superficial wound. She expresses concern about the treatment and the lack of improvement despite taking oral clindamycin for a week.
O: Physical examination reveals painful blisters and redness on the left forearm, with mild pain when flexing the hand. No signs of sepsis or sepsitis are noted. Vital signs and white blood cell count are within normal limits. The patient has a full range of motion but mild pain in flexing her hand.
A: The primary diagnosis is a superficial right forearm full-sided burn with complications including blistering, blisters, and cellulitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blistering and blisters. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the infection.
P: The management plan includes initiating intravenous antibiotics and possible operative interventions, including bedside debridement in the Burn Unit. Post-operative care will include a tangential excision of the wound and a split-thickness skin autograft placement on the right arm. The treatment plan will involve intravenous antibiotic therapy, bedside treatment, and surgical intervention. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and manage any complications related to the wound.

S: The patient, a male with a history of tuberculosis, hematologic disease, and unusual occupational exposures, presented with worsening dyspnea and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 days, fevers, chills, and myalgias. He tried acetaminophen and ibuprofen without relief. He denies any history of immunocompromised diseases and is in a monogamous sexual relationship.
O: Upon examination, the patient was tachypneic with more than 50 breaths per minute and tachycardic. Chest radiograph indicated increased interstitial markings and alveolar airspace disease. Non-contrast CT of the chest showed diffuse smooth interlobular septal thickening with superimposed areas of ground glass attenuation and peribronchial airspace consolidation. Lab results indicated microcytic anemia, elevated lactate levels (2.9 mmol/L initially, increased to 3.9 mg/L in 5 hours), mildly elevated procalcitonin (1.91 ng/mL), and lactate dehydrogenase (286 u/L). HIV – 1 + 2 antigen + antibody assay was negative. An arterial blood gas showed pH 7.41, pCO2 24, and pO2 63 on FiO2 of 0.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) likely secondary to Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, alveolateral hemorrhage, or drug-induced lung disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary edema, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results.
P: The management plan included administration of fluids and initial doses of azithromycin and ceftriaxone. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and treatment, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists are planned to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the management plan as needed. Patient education regarding the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments was provided.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old Japanese woman, gravida 4, presenting with symptoms of hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and focal perineal pain persisting for twelve days. She reports a first-degree right-sided laceration on the left side of the external urethral orifice during a term delivery. She was discharged on the fifth day.
O: Physical examination revealed hypotension (88/56 mmHg), tachyness (144 beats/minute), and tachiness (23 breaths/minute). Abdominal examination was normal. Pelvic examination showed no tenderness. Laboratory tests showed neutrophilic leukocytosis (WBC 19,600/mm3), hypoproteinemia (6.6 g/dl), hypoalbuminemia, and hypoalemia (3.6 mg/dl). Serum electrolyte concentrations were abnormal: sodium 136 mEq/L, potassium 3.2 mEQ/L; chloride 97 mEsq/L. Sodium 8.2 mg/L and phosphate 3.7 mg/dL.
A: The primary diagnosis is a right-side lacerated vaginal lacerate with complications including hypotension and hypotension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of perineural pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: Initiate aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation and antimicrobial agent therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone (2 g every 12 hours) on admission. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess her condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Consider referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of her symptoms.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old male, smoker with 20 pack-years, occasional alcoholic, presenting with episodes of blood expectoration over the past 9 months, including one episode where he coughed up 400 ml of blood over the course of 2-3 days, and another one over the same period, requiring hospitalization and emergency care. He denies fever, chest pain, loss of appetite, or other symptoms of fever or chest pain. He has a history of cholecystectomy 3 years ago but no history of immune suppression or diabetes.
O: Physical examination revealed poor oral hygiene with dental caries, scattered crackles in the left lower lobe area, inhomogeneous opacity in left lower zone, raised left diaphragm, and a hypodense lesion with irregular margins in the anterior segment of the left upper lobe adjacent to the descending aorta and associated subcarinal lymphadenopathy. CT angiogram showed dilated vascular channels within the lesion without extravasations of contrast and no aortic abnormality.
A: The primary diagnosis is a left intrapulmonary vascular lesion, likely secondary to a left lower lobectomy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory symptoms such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and adherence to prescribed medications. The patient will be educated on the importance of maintaining good oral hygiene and reducing alcohol intake to improve overall health. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 6-year-old male, presented with recent abdominal pain. He reported a large retroperitoneal tumor surgically removed.
O: CT scan revealed a large, resected retroperitonal tumor. Histopathology confirmed resection of the 6.8 cm PGL tumor. MRI showed a lytic lesion in the coracoid process, treated with 2.5 gray of external beam radiotherapy over 13 fractions. CT and 68Ga-DOTATATE PET/CT scans showed liver lesions, bilateral lung lesions, multiple metastatic neck, mediastinal, retroperteritoneal lymph nodes, and a left inferior pubic ramus bone metastasis. 123I-MIBG SPECT/CT scintigraphy showed metastases to the left coracoids. Ultrasound guided liver biopsy revealed metastatic PGL. Biochemical tests showed elevated plasma NMN, MTY, and CgA. Follow-up CT and 18F-FDG scans showed an interval increase in the size of the liver lesions and recurrence of the retropeptic ulcer (PGL) in the left hepatic lobe. Embolization of the lesion was performed.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic retroperion of the PGL, complicated by liver disease and metastasis to the liver. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver disease, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the progression of the disease and the absence of DOTATATE avidity.
P: Initiated treatment with 177Lu-DotATATE therapy, followed by external beam radiation therapy to the pubic bone. The patient has undergone 2 cycles of therapy without complications. The plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the progression and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 13-month-old male, has been on oral propranolol hydrochloride for a large IH. He has no history of hypoglycemia or other medications. The mother reports a significant reduction in the size of the IH over the past 9 months. The patient missed his evening dose due to poor oral intake.
O: On examination, the patient was unresponsive, unarousable, and had a grey pallor. He was found in a deep coma with severe hypothermia (34°C), cold sweats, slow heartbeats (60-65 beats/minute), and low blood pressure (85/46 mmHg). The patient's vital signs were not provided.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe hypoglycemic episode (IH) secondary to proprolol hydrocemia. Differential diagnoses could include drug poisoning, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of propralol with food and monitoring for signs of drug poisoning. The management of the hypoglyoglycemic episodes will be crucial, and the patient will be educated on the signs of potential drug toxicity. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, previously treated with methampyrone 500 mg orally in February 2018, presented with erythematous skin, severe itching, and flaking all over the body. The patient had a history of hypertension and postprimary coronary intervention in 2011.
O: On examination, the patient was conscious and alert, with a stable hemodynamic state (24x/minutes, body temperature 37.8°C, SpO2 97–99% on supplemental oxygen with a nasal cannula). Symptoms included conjunctivitis and turbid corneal in the eyes, ulceration of the mouth, and swollen lips. Symptoms of generalized skin erythelia, irregularly shaped itchy purpuric macules, and Nikolsky's sign were noted, with detachment of the epidermis from lower layers and extension of bullae to clear skin. Epidermal detachment was noted over 30% of the body surface area (BSA).
A: The primary diagnosis is transient epidermal encephalopathy (TEN) with associated complications including conjunctivalitis, turbid eye, and mouth ulcerations. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan included treatment with methylprednisolone 125 mg TID and cyclosporine 50 mg BID, followed by antibiotic therapy. The skin lesions showed significant skin change progressions, with 32% of BSA involved, with 16% grade I and 46% grade II hemorrhagic blisters. The SCORTEN score was used to prognosticate the risk for death from TEN, indicating three in the case of TEN. The treatment plan included replacement of fluid loss, maintaining electrolyte imbalance, and antibiotic therapy, which did not significantly improve skin lesions. The plan will continue with close monitoring and regular follow-ups to manage TEN and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a 2-week history of abdominal distention and bloating, accompanied by decreased appetite, early satiety, and generalized weakness. The patient has a 55-year history of asbestos exposure and has a significant smoking history.
O: Physical examination revealed a distended abdomen with mild tenderness to deep palpation, no rebound tenderness, guarding, fluid wave test positive, and lower extremity edema. Laboratory tests were unremarkable except for low serum albumin. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed diffuse omental, peritoneal, and mesenteric nodularity with moderate to large ascites. CT chest scan with contrast showed bilateral pleural plaques. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy showed normal tumor markers. Tumor markers CEA, PSA, CA 19-9, AFP, and AFP were within normal limits. Paracentesis yielded 2.5 liters of blood-tinged fluid, indicating ascites not associated with portal hypertension. Ultrasound-guided omental biopsy confirmed malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM), epithelioid subtype.
A: The primary diagnosis is malignancy of MPM with associated pulmonary embolism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal discomfort. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options and supportive care. Treatment options will be discussed with the patient and his family to address the patient's complex medical and psychological issues. Referral to a nephrologist for specialized care and a pulmonologist for specialized management of pulmonary embollies is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a female with a ruptured ovarian cyst, presented to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain, described as severe and sudden. She reports continuous bleeding.
O: Physical examination revealed continuous bleeding in the lower abdomen. Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) was 42 seconds, above the normal range of 20-36 seconds. A mixing study suggested factor deficiency. Factor X (FX) activity was only 11%, while other factors were normal. Serum protein electrophoresis showed IgG kappa monoclonal protein at 0.4 g/dL, serum-free kappa and lambda light chain levels at 14.5 and 72.2 g/dl, respectively. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy showed 3% kappa-restricted plasma cells. Congo red staining was negative, but rectal biopsy tissue was positive. Immunofluorescent staining confirmed kappa restriction protein.
A: The primary diagnosis is amyloidosis, likely secondary to a rupture of the ovarian cysts. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bleeding such as other causes or autoimmune disorders. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the remission achieved and the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.
P: Initiated induction therapy with bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone, followed by high-dose melphalan and autologous stem cell transplantation. Post-treatment, the patient underwent stem cell collection, high-doses melphal and autologic stem cells transplantation, and PCC and platelet transfusion. The patient achieved complete remission with normalized serum lambda light chains and normal echocardiogram. Ongoing monitoring and adjustments in treatment will be necessary to manage the patient's condition effectively.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old male, presented with pain in his front teeth, particularly when exposed to cold water. He has a history of a fracture in the crown of his upper right primary central incisor, repaired with composite resin.
O: Physical examination revealed an abnormal position of the upper right permanent central incision and clouding on the labial surface, likely due to trauma to the primary teeth. Visual acuity (VAS) values were 6 for cold water and 7.5 for air blowing. Post-treatment, the patient's VAS was 4 with cold water, and 5 with air. After seven treatments, his hypersensitivity improved to 2, and his VAS improved to 1-2.
A: The primary diagnosis is a fractured primary incisoral with associated trauma to primary teeth, likely exacerbated by trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tooth pain, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of cold water treatment and continuation of air-based treatments. The patient will continue with the current regimen of four treatments once a month, with adjustments to the frequency as necessary based on response and response to treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education regarding the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and the importance for compliance with follow-ups is crucial.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old female, Gravida 3, who was evaluated in the 16th week of her pregnancy. She reports feeling "not too great" following a discovery of a breast tumour during a physical examination.
O: Physical examination revealed a breast tumor. Biopsy confirmed infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3. Axilla was clinically negative. Immunohistochemistry showed oestrogen receptor-positive (35%), progesterone receptor-negative (85%), HER2/neu-positive at 37%, and Ki67 at 37%. Whole-body nuclear magnetic resonance showed hepatic metastasis in segment V measuring 29 mm, and millimetric metastases in the right iliac bone. Genetic testing was negative for BRCA 1 and 2 mutations. The patient received chemotherapy with epirubicin 90 mg/m2 and cyclophosphamide 600 mg/mm2 for four cycles during pregnancy, which led to partial breast cancer remission and complete response of the lesion. The hepatic lesion increased in size.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast cancer with complications including hepatic and hepatic cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the aggressive nature of the cancer and the patient's aggressive nature.
P: Continue current chemotherapy regimen with trastuzumab and docetaxel for eight cycles. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring regular follow-ups.

S: The patient reports feeling a lump in the neck near the thyroid, without associated symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, pain in the area, or changes in voice. The patient denies any family history of thyroid or endocrine diseases.
O: Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. However, a 2.5 cm nodule was noted in the left thyroid. Fine needle biopsy of the lesion was performed, and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Pathology confirmed extrathyroidal extension. Pathological evaluation for metastatic disease was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is papillary gland carcinoma, confirmed by biopsy and pathology. Differential diagnosis initially included neoplasm, which was ruled out through biopsy. The prognosis is good with no evidence of recurrence.
P: The management plan includes continuation of thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy, with close monitoring of the patient's progress and potential recurrence of the tumor. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and to ensure no recurrence or metastasis. Further consultations with a thyroid specialist are recommended to ensure complete resolution of the disease and to manage any complications. Education on the nature of the diagnosis and treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports noticing masses in the left axilla and left supraclavicular area, diagnosed as poorly differentiated carcinoma (PDC) with Villin positive. The patient underwent six cycles of chemotherapy for digestive tract tumors but the cancer progressed, leading to a change in treatment.
O: Initial biopsies showed Villin-positive masses. Pathology consultation showed PDC with IHC stains (AE1/AE3+, ER–, PR–, HER-2 0, GCDFP-15–, TTF-1–, and PAX8–. Subsequent biopsied breast cancer (TNBC) showed space-occupying lesions. Core needle biopsy identified invasive breast cancer.
A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated breast cancer with Villins positive. Differential diagnosis initially included breast carcinoma, which was ruled out by biopsy and biopsy results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive gene expression profile and the successful treatment response.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-ups to assess the progression of cancer and treatment efficacy. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on the progression and response to treatment. Patient education on the importance of reporting new symptoms or concerns will be provided. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of breast cancer is recommended.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of IgG kappa MM, ISS 1, and anemia. He reports anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.3g/dl and two isolated bone lesions in his spine. He has a history including diabetes mellitus, atopic dermatitis, and Bechterew´s disease with severe arthrosis of the right hip. He denies any family history of bleeding disorders.
O: Laboratory findings show β2-microglobulin at 3.2mg/l, M-gradient at 0.26 g/dl, 4%, and 90% bone marrow infiltration with plasmatic cells. Serum free light chain ratio is 8.72. BMI is 65 kilograms. Coagulation tests show VWF: Ag 12%, VWF Act < 4%, VIII:C 13.6%, aPTT 51s, bleeding time epinephrin > 220sec, and bleeding time ADP.
A: The primary diagnosis is IgG Kappa MM with anemia and an anemia, complicated by a history with multiple chronic conditions including diabetes, atypical dermatitis and severe arthritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute bleeding such as chronic kidney disease or other chronic conditions.
P: The management plan will include initiating induction therapy for IgKappa MM. The patient will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of his chronic conditions is recommended.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old, reports focal seizures starting at 5 with a funny feeling, flushing, and head turning to the right. These episodes occur intermittently, sometimes stopping at the same point and evolving into bilateral convulsive seizures. The patient has a history of VNS implantation three years prior, which did not improve seizure frequency. The current patient reports persistent seizures despite multiple antiseizure medications.
O: MRI and EMU evaluations showed no structural brain abnormalities. An EMU evaluation showed a broad, right hemispheric onset. A second MEG scan showed MEG epileptiform discharges consistent with the simultaneous EEG recordings. The second MEGA scan showed an equivalent right frontal focus.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent seizures with associated interictal and temporal lobe abnormalities, likely secondary to VNS implants. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures such as epilepsy, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes discussing potential adjustments to the seizure treatment plan with the neurologist to better understand seizure activity and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further monitoring of seizure frequency and seizure frequency will be necessary, and the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor seizure frequency, seizure activity, and seizure activity.

S: The patient, with a history of congenital hydrocephalus and bilateral VP shunt placement, presents with a three-week history of worsening right-sided abdominal distension and pain, described as constant and dull, not related to meals. The patient denies experiencing fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, visual changes, changes in urination, constipation, melena, or bright red blood in stools.
O: Physical examination shows the patient to be comfortable, afebrile, with heart rate 84 bpm, respiratory rate 16 bpm. Blood pressure 150/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Abdominal exam shows morbid obesity and distension of the right upper and lower abdomen, dull to percussion, minimally tender in the right lower quadrants, and no erythema or other skin changes overlying VP reservoirs. Fundoscopic and neurologic exams are unremarkable. Laboratory tests including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, lipase, and urinalysis are normal. POCUS revealed a large fluid collection with septations in the soft tissue of the left abdominal wall. CT scan confirmed an abdominal pseudocyst.
A: The primary diagnosis is a large, septated fluid collection in the left abdomen, likely related to VP shunts. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and fluid retention, but these are less likely given the absence of infectious symptoms or signs of VP shut malfunction.
P: The management plan includes urgent outpatient revision of the VP shun. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, lab results, and vital signs. The consultation with neurosurgery is necessary for further evaluation and management of the hemorrhagic event. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a gastroenterologist for specialized care is recommended.

S: The patient reports a 6-month history of urinary frequency without significant urologic abnormalities. The patient denies experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting, anorexia, or bowel disturbances.
O: Physical examination revealed no palpable abdominal mass. Laboratory tests showed no specific abnormalities. Abdominal and pelvis CT scans identified a 20 × 11 cm, well-defined, fatty mass between the abdominal wall muscles and the peritoneum, compressing the bladder.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign lipoma in the abdominal cavity, likely due to the presence of a large, freely mobile, soft mass in the external peritoneal layer without connection to other organs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and urinary frequency, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the mass, preservation of the parietal peritoneally, and repair of the abdominal walls using a fixing material with a closed suction drain. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications. The surgical plan will involve a laparoscopic mass excision with preservation of both the perietal and abdominal walls, and a 5-mm port placement to preserve the mass. The resected specimen size is expected to be around 22 × 16 × 7.5 cm3, and the weight will be approximately 942 g. The pathological diagnosis will be confirmed on post-operative day 6, with a clear resection margin.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old girl, presented with a 2-month history of a right groin mass, swelling for 15 days, and occasional umbilical pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She reported no previous medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed acute facial features, malnutrition, abdominal swelling, and tenderness in the right inguinal region. Negative Grey Turner and Cullen signs were noted. Abdominal CT scan showed a significantly dilated pancreatic duct, unclear surrounding pancreatic head space, cystic low-density shadow, massive peritoneal effusion, patchy lymph node enhancement, and enlargement in the mesentery. Chest CT showed increased lung markings but no signs of TB. Laboratory tests indicated pancreatitis with serum lipase at 3167 U/L, serum amylase at 720 U/mL, and CA-125 at 484.5 U/dL. Abstinence puncture revealed red and yellow ascites, positive for acid-fast bacilli, negative for TB. Anti-TB antibody was negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatitis, likely secondary to pancreatitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal distension, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of pancreatitis effectively.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and possibly infectious disease specialists are recommended to manage the pancreatitis and prevent further complications.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male presenting with painless hematuria for a duration of 5 days. He denies any family history of cancer.
O: Physical examination and systemic examination were normal. Blood workup showed anemia. Renal function and liver function were within normal limits. Ultrasound revealed a polypoidal mass on the anterior wall of the bladder, measuring 7 x 5 cm. CT scan of the abdomen showed no lymph node or visceral metastasis. Transurethral resection of the urinary bladder mass was performed, and upper and lower GI endoscopy were within limits. Post-operative complications included fever and intestinal obstruction. Repeat CECT abdomen showed soft tissue lesions in both lungs, pleural effusion, multiple liver lesions, and ascites suggestive of disseminated metastasis, leading to death. Postoperatively, the patient developed fever and gastrointestinal obstruction. Whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis of the paired tumor-normal sample showed 558 exonic somatic mutations, including 360 missense, 26 nonsense, and 30 frameshift deletions/insertions. Ten splice site mutations were annotated.
A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade urothelial carcinoma with metastasis to the bladder and associated complications including fever and bowel obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of bladder cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the complexity of the patient's condition.
P: The management plan included conservative management of fever, intestinal obstruction, and antibiotic therapy. The patient was managed conservatively, and he succumbed to his disease. Genetic counseling was provided to the family to discuss the implications of the diagnosis and the progression of his condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the progression and response to treatment.

S: The patient reports feeling unwell and experiencing discomfort under the right rib.
O: Blood tests revealed severe leukocytosis (227 × 10^9/L) with a normal range of 4–11 × 10 µL. Lactate dehydrogenase levels were elevated to 969 U/L, and cobalamin levels were 2834 pmol/L. Blood smear indicated dominance of myeloid precursor with increased metamyelocytes and rods. Blood tests indicated a high leukocyte count (227 x 10^6/L), lactate dehydrationase levels at 969 u/L (normal range: 4–10 U/l), and cobalt levels at 2834 amol/l (normal: 0.5-1.0 mg/L). Blood smear showed dominance of Myeloid Nucleus with increased Metamyelocyte and Rods.
A: The primary diagnosis is Chronic Myelodysplastic Leukemia (CML) with complications including myelocytic Leukemia and myeloproliferative disease (GVHD). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of leukodystrophy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes initiation of hydroxyurea combined with interferon, followed by an allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) for consolidation treatment. The patient will be monitored for signs of progression post-transplant, with regular follow-ups to monitor for any signs of relapse or complications. Further consultations with a hematologist and a cardiologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to treatment and response to therapy. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a resident of Chiang Klang District, presents with a single skin nodule on the left cheek, approximately 1.0 x 1.5 cm in size, with crusting at the left angle of the mouth. The patient reports no recent travel abroad and has only traveled to Phitsanulok and Phijit provinces near Nan in Thailand.
O: Physical examination and histopathological analysis confirmed epidermal ulceration with heavy, chronic inflammation of the dermis, and presence of numerous intracellular small round or oval-shaped bodies with amastigotes of Leishmania species. A fresh skin biopsy from the nodule was cultured in Schneider's insect medium with FBS and 50 International Units penicillin/ml, 50 μg/ml streptomycin at 25°C. Motile promastigote were first observed on day 3 of the culture.
A: The primary diagnosis is cutaneous leishmaniasis, confirmed by the presence of mucile promastsigotes in the skin. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of cutaneous dermatitis, but these were ruled out based on histopathology and parasite analysis.
P: The treatment plan includes administration of oral amphotericin B at 1 mg/kg/day for 1 day and fluconazole at 200 mg/day over 45 days, with close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. The management plan will focus on symptom management and symptom monitoring, with follow-up visits to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a chief complaint of visual disturbances in the right eye, characterized by multi-colored flashes and reduced vision. The patient has a history of a road traffic accident (RTA) three weeks ago, with no injuries reported. He reports no past ocular or medical issues.
O: Examination findings include best-corrected visual acuity of 6/12 in both eyes (right eye) and 6/6 in the left eye (left eye). No anterior chamber or vitreous cells issues, and no vitreos haze. Spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) revealed hyper-reflective sub-retinal changes in the temporal retina and small, well-defined creamy white sub-Retinal lesions in the superior macular area of the right. The left eye appears unremarkable. Immunological tests for inflammatory and infective pathologies were negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is commotio retinae secondary to a car accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal changes and retinal lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis is good given the resolution of symptoms and the absence of other systemic symptoms.
P: The management plan includes a follow-up appointment in six weeks to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further diagnostic tests such as inflammatory markers, autoimmune screen, serum angiotensin enzyme, chest x-ray, and syphilis testing will be conducted to assess the extent of the retinal damage. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of the optic nerve is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes, presents with diffuse abdominal pain and a high body temperature. He reports a recent history of bile stones in his gallbladder and common bile duct, treated with endoscopic bile stone extraction, papillotomy, and laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He also reports dyspnea.
O: Physical examination revealed bilateral lower diaphragmatic excursion and decreased vocal fremitus, with attenuated sounds at the pulmonary bases. Neurological examination was normal. The patient's pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light, with normal fundi and ocular movements.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent bile-related symptoms, likely secondary to a recent surgical intervention involving a Kehr's T tube. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: Plan to perform additional diagnostic tests including chest and neurological examination to determine the cause of the current symptoms. Continue current antibiotic therapy and monitor for any worsening of symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in condition immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of long-standing heart failure due to Chagas cardiomyopathy, reports feeling weak and tired, with difficulty breathing, and a racing heart. The patient has been previously diagnosed with end-stage heart failure, confirmed by serology, and used an implantable cardioverter defibrillator for sudden death secondary prevention.
O: Recent echocardiography revealed a severely dilated left ventricle with an end-diastolic diameter of 72 mmHg, severely depressed function with an ejection fraction of 18%, and 4+ mitral regurgitation in the right ventricles. Echocardography indicated a severely depressed left ventricular function with ejection fractions of 18% and 4-mitral reguritation in both the right and left ventrials. Recent cardiogenic shock was managed with two inotropes, an intra-aortic balloon pump, and hemodialysis. Right heart catheterization revealed low cardiac output with a cardiac index of 0.9 L/min/m2, systolic pulmonary pressure of 70 mmHG, transpulmonary gradient of 16 mmH g, and pulmonary vascular resistance of 6 Wood units. Pulmonary filling pressures were elevated with central venous pressure and pulmonary wedge pressure of 30 mmHga. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was effective, but circulation was maintained with escalating doses of vasopressors.
A: The primary diagnosis is end-Stage Heart Failure with complications including severe cardiogenesis, severe dysfunction, and potential cardiac arrest. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac failure, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the condition and the complexity of the current management plan.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of cardiac function and cardiac function, with ongoing percutaneous venous arterial extracorporeal life support (ECLS) to support cardiac function. The plan includes referral to a heart transplantation specialist for further evaluation and potential consideration of a potential heart transplant. Patient education regarding the importance of adhering to the transplantation plan and the need for immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to a cardiologist for specialized care and a cardiology specialist for specialized management of cardiac issues is recommended.

S: Twin 1 and twin 2, both 6 years and 6 months old, presented with bilateral trigger thumb and trigger finger. Twin 2 presented with a trigger thumb. Twin 3 presented with trigger finger and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. The twins have been treated with an A1 pulley release, flexor digitorum superficialis slip release of the affected digit. No history of trauma related to the fingers was noted.
O: Twin 2 and twin 3 have been diagnosed with a single trigger thumb, and twin 4 has been diagnosed as having a trigger fingers. Twin 5 has been treated conservatively with a flexor-digitorum-serum-slip release. Twin 6 has been managed with a Flexor Digitorum Sip Release. No new symptoms or worsening of symptoms were reported.
A: The primary diagnosis is a single-trigger thumb in twins, with a differential diagnosis including other causes of finger issues such as trauma or sensory impairment. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the stability of the twins' condition.
P: The management plan includes conservative management of the twin's condition with conservative care. The parents are advised to monitor the twins closely and report any new or worsening symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of monitoring for any new symptoms and ensuring compliance with the care plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a history of alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, amphetamine, and methamphetamine use since age 18, affecting his behavior. He denies any neurological impairment or alcohol dependence.
O: Genetic testing revealed a genetic carrier of 5-HTTLPR (fragment 44 bp–SS genotype) and COMT (Leu136Leu) in homozygosity, suggesting a predisposition to anti-social behavior. Toxicology testing showed significant levels of cocaine (141 ng/mL), benzoylecgonine (21 ng/mg), and ethylglucuronide (30 pg/mg). Laboratory tests showed no significant drug or alcohol levels. Clinical and neuropsychological examination showed no clinical signs of neurological impairment, alcohol dependence, or alcohol dependency. 3-Tesla brain MRI and brain CT-PET imaging showed a decrease in cortical thickness with larger lateral ventricles, and significant volumetric asymmetry of the amygdalae in the right amygdala.
A: The primary diagnosis is a personality disorder, likely exacerbated by the history of drug use and drug use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psychotic symptoms such as substance use disorders or substance abuse disorders, but these are less likely given the clinical and neurobiological findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to a psychiatrist for further evaluation and management of the personality disorder. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disorder, potential treatment options, and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, a 25-year-old male, presents with vomiting for the past four days and difficulty controlling his hypertension. He has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and a past liver abscess.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient is afebrile with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg and a pulse of 160/min. The patient is alert and oriented, with no findings of respiratory or cardiovascular abnormalities. Right upper quadrant tenderness is noted but not palpable. Lab results indicate an abnormal white blood cell count with neutrophilia, elevated platelet count, creatinine, BUN, calcium, and phosphate levels, abnormal liver function tests, and abnormal liver enzymes. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 10.3 x 9.6 x 6.7 cm heterogeneous cystic lesion in the right lobe of the liver. CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows an 11.3 × 8.0 cm heterogenous mass in the adrenal gland, with normal liver and spleen function tests. Chest and abdomen CT shows a 10 x 8.7 x 8 cm heterozygous mass in right adrenal glands, with lytic lesions in the left acetabulum, sacrum, right and left iliac blades, and the lumbosacral and thoracic spine. Lactate dehydrogenase level is elevated at 1080 IU/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is a heterogeneous mass in a liver cyst, likely secondary to antihypertensive medications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Plan to conduct a 24-hour urine collection test to determine the extent of the lesion and determine the appropriate treatment plan. Continue antihybrid medications as prescribed and monitor blood pressure regularly. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments. Ensure adherence to prescribed medications and follow up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing dysphagia and significant body weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient has a history of distal gastrectomy due to a submucosal tumor 40 years ago, which resulted in significant weight loss of 10 kg over the same period.
O: Physical examination revealed a height of 158.0 cm, weight of 53.6 kg, and BMI of 21.5. Osteoporosis was noted. Upper gastrointestinal examination revealed the presence of a postoperative stomach in the thoracic cavity via delayed barium passage. Endoscopic examination showed absent esophagitis and tumor in the upper digestive tract. Enhanced computed tomography (eCT) revealed a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach, sliding through the hiatals orifice into the mediastinum, compressing the heart in the posterior mediastinal region. Echocardiography showed normal heart function. Preoperative eCT showed preserved right and left gastric arteries and gastroepiploic arteries.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe hiatalis hernia, likely secondary to a previous distal surgery due to submukosal tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as gastritis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes elective surgical repair of the hietal herniated disc. A laparoscopic approach will be used to address the slight adhesion of the greater omentum under the postoperative scar and the little adhesion with the liver and spleen. Postoperative care will include monitoring for signs of cardiac distress and ensuring proper recovery. The surgery will be scheduled as soon as possible, with the patient advised to follow preoperative instructions and reach out if any questions or concerns arise.

S: The patient, a male, was involved in a truck accident and ejected from the bed of the truck. He reports being tachycardic but normotensive upon arrival. He experienced severe pain and lacerations on his legs and hips.
O: Physical examination revealed an unstable pelvis, a foreign body in the rectal vault, laceration on the legs, and bruising on the hips. CT scan revealed an intraperitoneal bladder rupture, a complex pelvic fracture involving the right sacroiliac joint, a shattered right acetabulum, and a complete right femoral neck fracture. A CT scan identified an intra-peritoneally ruptured femoral head, a complete rectal neck fracture, a fractured femoral skull, a ruptured right sacrosanct joint, and an acetabular fracture. Intraoperative complications included a significant hematoma and fecal contamination in the right rectum and perirectal space, necessitating resuscitation.
A: The primary diagnosis is a complex femoral fracture with complications including a complete ruptured rectal skull and ruptured pelvis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic injuries such as infection or infection. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the injuries and the complexity of the fracture.
P: The management plan included an exploratory laparotomy and anoscopy to confirm the location of the femoral heads and repair the rectum. Post-operative care included a temporary abdominal closure and resuscitation, followed by a right hip disarticulation to address the ruptured and damaged rectum, which required prolonged hospitalization. The patient was transferred to a long-term care facility out of state for further debridement and sepsis control. The plan includes transfer to a facility closer to home to manage the patient's condition and address any complications.

S: The patient is gravida 7 para 3, and has a history of two normal vaginal deliveries and two cesarean sections. She reports a traumatic history of vulvar herpes simplex infection and a transverse incision on the lower uterine segment due to placenta previa. Postpartum recovery was uneventful.
O: Initial examination revealed a heterogeneous mass with perivascular flow in the cesary scar of the first cesarian section, and a heterogenous mass in the left uterine artery. Magnetic resonance imaging indicated endogenic growth of gestational products in the transverse scar, with a vertical scar in the anterior uterine wall. Three-dimensional computerized tomographic angiography indicated gestational blood supply from the right uterine and an aberrant anastomosing left ovarian artery.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent uterine hemorrhage secondary to recurrent placentas. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will include regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. The patient will be educated on the signs of complications and encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with obstetrics and gynecology may be necessary to manage her condition effectively. Referral to a pediatric endocrinologist for specialized care and a gynecologist for further evaluation and management of her condition is recommended.

S: The patient, a male, presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of painful swelling in the left hemiscrotum, described as sharp and located in the right inguinal region. The swelling began from the inguininal canal and extends through the entire left scrotum. The patient has a history of bilateral varicocele but no other comorbidities or coagulation disorders.
O: Physical examination revealed a soft mass around the left testis and spermatic cord. Laboratory tests were within normal limits. Doppler ultrasonography showed a hematoma extending from the left superficial ingueinal ring to the left extremity, partially surrounding the left Testis. MRI confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral hematomas. The scrotal swelling and ecchymosis were noted at the first hospitalization day, and the ecchysmia was noted at 4 weeks.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral variculopathy, likely due to the presence of a hematic tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scrotular swelling such as vasculitis, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate follow-up care.
P: The management plan included conservative management with bed rest, ice packs, antibiotics, and analgesics, followed by discharge on the third day of hospitalization. Post-discharge, the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the healing process and manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, abdominal and thoracic aortic aneurysm, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presents with pain and bruising in the right thigh for the past 6 days. The patient denies any history of abnormal bleeding, family history of bleeding disorders, or use of anticoagulant medications.
O: Physical examination revealed a large subcutaneous hematoma on the anterior aspect of the right leg, extending posteriorly and laterally. Ultrasound ruled out deep venous thrombosis and magnetic resonance imaging showed intramuscular bleeding into the anterior compartment of the thigh. Laboratory tests showed a low hemoglobin level of 6.8 g/dL. Coagulation profile showed a prolonged activated partial thromboemboplastin time (aPTT) of 52.5 seconds, normal prothrombin time, and normal international normalized ratio. Factor VIII assay was low at 2%, with elevated inhibitor levels at 16 Bethesda units (BU). Treatment with factor VIIa at 5 mg multiple times daily, Obizur at 15,000 units twice daily, and methylprednisone at 80 mg daily. Post-chemotherapy, factor VIII assay improved to over 5%.
A: The primary diagnosis is acquired hemophilia A (AHA) in the patient's right thigh. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of thrombroembolic hemorrhage, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the current response to chemotherapy and the absence of further bleeding.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of factor VIIIa, Obuzur, and Rituximab cycles to manage AHA. The treatment plan includes continuation of weekly rituximusab cycles, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on response and side effects. Further consultations with oncology and hematology are planned to monitor the patient and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of AHA and the importance of adherence to treatment will be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing non-radiating and dull epigastric pain for two weeks, accompanied by fever and chills during dialysis sessions. The patient has a history of ESRD, hypertension, atherosclerotic vascular disease, pending elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery, sudden cardiac arrest, and an ICD placement. He has been hospitalized previously for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterobacter cloacae bacteremia, and S. maltophilia bactèremia secondary to an infected dialysis catheter.
O: Physical examination revealed mild epiglastric tenderness but no redness, discharge, or pain around the dialysis device on the right chest. Initial blood and catheter cultures were positive for S., and Chest X-ray suggested left lower lobe pneumonia. Intravenous levofloxacin therapy was initiated. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) indicated endocarditis, with concerns for vegetation. Blood cultures were negative for S. Maltophilia. Transesophageal echocoardiogram (TEE) was performed to assess for cardiac source of infection.
A: The primary diagnosis is endocardococcal pneumonia secondary to infected dialychemic catheter, complicated by persistent troponins elevation and impaired renal function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of endocardopathy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of treatment as necessary. Further consultations with cardiology and infectious disease specialists are planned to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to infectious disease for further evaluation and management is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient reports a mass on the upper part of the right scapula, which has been achy, bothersome, and enlarging over the last few months. The patient denies any local injuries or recent surgeries on the affected side. The mass is firm, nonmobile, nonpulsatile, and overlying, with no signs of rotator cuff weakness or shoulder pain.
O: Physical examination revealed a firm, nonsmobile mass extending from the scapulmonary area to the medial to lateral dimension, with slight tenderness and deeper palpation. The shoulder was not indicated by signs of shoulder weakness or pain with provocative maneuvers. An X-ray and MRI indicated narrowing of the posterior glenohumeral joint space with sclerosis secondary to osteoarthritic changes, and an acromiohumeral interval of 8 mm without superior migration of the humeral head. MRI indicated an elongated lesion arising from the AC joint, measuring 2 cm × 13 cm × 1.8 cm, cystic with peripheral enhancement, and a full-thickness tear of the anterior fibers of the supraspinatus.
A: The primary diagnosis is a full tear of a posterior glensohuminal joint, likely secondary to arthritis, with differential diagnoses including other causes of joint pain and joint weakness. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of significant arthritis.
P: Refer the patient to a specialist for further evaluation and management of the shoulder joint. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further management and evaluation. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or progression of symptoms.

S: The patient, a male, presented to the emergency room after a high energetic accident. He reported pain in the left lower leg and foot, accompanied by multiple fractures.
O: Clinical examination revealed a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture, medial malleolus fracture, Tillaux-Chaput fracture, a nutcracker fracture of the cuboid, avulsion fracture, and multiple fractures of the third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal heads, including a mid-shaft fracture of both the third proximal phalanx and base fractures of both first and second proximal plexus. The patient preserved active extension and flexion of the toes, sensibility in the toes and forefoot, but disturbed sensibility to touch and pain at the foot sole. No signs of compartment syndrome were noted. NIRF imaging showed a head of the FluobeamTM positioned approximately 8 inches above the skin, with real-time images during 120 seconds.
A: The primary diagnosis is a high-energy accident with multiple fractures, including Gustilo Grade IIIB, Tillau grade IIIC, and base femoral fractures. Differential diagnoses could include compartment syndrome, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's healing process and potential surgical intervention if necessary. Regular follow-ups with the medical team are essential to assess recovery and manage any complications. The plan includes regular follow-up visits to monitor healing and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient reports a growing mass on the forehead following a head injury two weeks ago, accompanied by headaches. The swelling is tender and mostly on the right side of the forehead.
O: Physical examination revealed a two-centimeter, soft, pulsatile mass in the right frontotemporal region. A point-of-care ultrasound with color Doppler showed a dilated vascular structure with pulsatile, bidirectional flow, suggestive of a traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm. A CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of a ruptured superficial temporal arterial artery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic ruptured ruptured vascular artery, likely due to head injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of head injuries, but the imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes surgical ligation of the ruptured pseudoaneuronysm to prevent further complications. Post-operative care will focus on monitoring for any signs of infection or complications. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns during surgery and recovery.

S: The patient reports sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, described as sharp and sudden. He has a history of hypertension and has been diagnosed with a large left internal iliac aneurysm (IIA).
O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg, pulse 90 bpm, and temperature of 36.5°C. Laboratory findings included increased leukocytes (11,400/μL), normal serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen (20 mmol/L), and serum creatinine (1.2 mg/dl). Chest X-ray showed no cardiomegaly or abnormal findings. Contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a large right IIA (6.5 cm) with blood extravasation into the periaortic soft tissue and no signs of aneurism. CT scans showed a left IIA with no arterial signs and a left hydroureteronephrosis and leakage of iodinated urine in the left-side retroperitoneum. A ureteral double-J stent was placed, and endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was performed under general anesthesia.
A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured IIA with associated complications including a spontaneous uretheral rupture and potential for graft infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain and bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and surgical intervention. The patient will continue to be educated on the signs of potential complications and the importance of follow-up appointments. Further treatment options may be considered based on the progression of symptoms and response to treatment. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the aneuriesis is recommended.

S: Mr. Johnson, a 75-pack year smoker with a history of rare alcohol use, presented with a mass on the left side of his neck. He reported difficulty swallowing and occasional neck discomfort.
O: Biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). PET/CT scan showed hypermetabolic activity in the right aryepiglottic fold without corresponding CT findings and multiple involved ipsilateral lymph nodes. Routine endoscopy confirmed SCC with a small lesion in the carina and right/left mainstem bronchi. Biopsies of the lesions were positive for p40 and negative for TTF-1, confirming the tumor's supraglottic origin. Intravenous-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) was administered 70 Gy to the primary lesion, 60 Gy to both the ipsilaterally neck and the remainder of the larynx, and 54 Gy to most of the tracheobronchial tree. Four-dimensional computed tomography (4DCT) simulation was used to define the internal target volume and an additional 0.5 cm to form the planning target volume. Dosimetric parameters were used to select organs at risk (OARs).
A: Primary diagnosis is squamous carcinoma of the neck with complications including grade 3 esophagitis and aspiration pneumonia. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of cancer, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's response to radiation therapy and manage any side effects. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage side effects of treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for potential complications. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of SCC.

S: The patient, a 4-year-old male with a history of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), presents with fever, abdominal pain, an enlarged spleen, and hyperleukocytosis. The patient has been diagnosed with high-risk AML-MDC.
O: Physical examination revealed a massive invasion of the bone marrow with 50% myeloid leukemia cells, with no invasion in the central nervous system. Karyotype analysis confirmed a monosomy of chromosome 7, confirmed with fluorescent in situ hybridization analysis. Immunophenotypic analysis showed persistence of CD34+ CD117+ CD33− blast cells. At day -3, peripheral blood flow cytometric analysis showed 13% of leukocytes (21 blast cells/µL).
A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade AML with associated high-dose leukemia, complicated by resistance to induction and monosomatosis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of leukemia, but these are less likely given the immunophenotypical findings.
P: The management plan includes initiating a Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) and conditioning treatment. The treatment plan includes high doses of ARA-C, L-PAM, and antithymocyte globulin (6.3 mg/kg/die for three days). The patient will continue to be monitored closely and adjust the treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess response to the treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a young girl, presented with left elbow pain and swelling for the past 3 days. She reported falling while playing and injuring her elbow.
O: Physical examination revealed a proximal fracture of the ulna, associated radial head dislocation. X-ray results indicated a Monteggia fracture. The patient was treated with a manipulation and closed reduction, followed by a cast.
A: The primary diagnosis is a Monteggeria fracture, likely secondary to a fall while playing. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of elbow pain or swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes performing a manipulation, closed reduction and placing the patient in a cast for at least a few weeks. Post-treatment, the patient will be monitored closely for any complications. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to assess the healing process and ensure no complications arise. The cast will be worn for a duration of at least one week to ensure proper healing and prevent further complications. Education on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan will be provided to the patient.

S: The patient, with a history of metastatic angiosarcoma treated with doxorubicin and ifosfamide, reports a recent initiation of Pazopanib at 800 mg per day. The patient has a significant past medical history of Gilbert syndrome, which has been managed with Pazotanib.
O: Initial bilirubin levels increased to twice the upper limit of normal with minimal elevation of direct biliruberin. Subsequent treatment with a reduced dose of 400 mg per minute and a 1-week-on and 1-day-off schedule was discontinued. Pazoperib Cmin was measured at 29.9 mg/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic Angio-Gibraltar syndrome with complications including Gilbert syndrome. The prognosis is good with a partial remission of the disease.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adherence to the current treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any side effects. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to current treatment and encourage regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports feeling generally unwell, with an increased cough but mostly non-productive. The patient has a history of osteoporosis and pancreatic insufficiency, with maintenance treatment for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) with oral anti-fungal therapy and long-term low-dose oral corticosteroids. Cultures in the past year have grown non-epidemic Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
O: Physical examination revealed a drop in FEV1 from 2.39 l (65% of predicted volume) to 2.19 l (60% predicted volume). Sputum analysis from chest physiotherapy showed a positive sputum sample for P. aeruginusosa. No severe symptoms were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is non-infectious Pseudomatosis of the lung, likely secondary to the presence of bilateral upper zone bronchiectasis and a mutation in the F508del mutation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lung function decline, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical history and genetic findings.
P: Continue monitoring lung function and adjust treatment as necessary. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to reassess treatment efficacy. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and ensure understanding of the treatment process. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of COPD.

S: The patient reports pain in the abdomen and back, accompanied by a pulsating sensation in the stomach area. The patient underwent EVAR for an infrarenal aortic aneurysm treated with a Zenith® LP, which resulted in a graft diameter of 28 mm and a length of 17 mm, respectively.
O: CT imaging revealed a type IA EL with aortical neck dilatation of 30 mm and stent graft migration of 8 mm below the left renal artery. During the procedure, a proximal cuff Stent graft relining and endoanchor suture was performed using 3D-IF guidance. The procedure involved a fusion technique to align the stent scaffolding VR to the live stent-graft fluoroscopy, with stiff guides in place to offset arterial stretching. A new proximal stent cuff was deployed using Heli-FX endosanchors.
A: The primary diagnosis is type IAEL with associated complications including an antero-posterior and lateral views. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and lower back pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: Continue regular follow-ups and imaging tests to monitor the patient's progress. Maintain a healthy lifestyle including regular exercise and a balanced diet to prevent future complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up schedules to prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a 33-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation, presents with severe chest pain in the epigastric area, worsening over the past two days. Initially diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD), the patient experienced mild preeclampsia, shortness of breath, oliguria, and oliguria. The patient also reports worsening epigasophagus pain, now rated 10/10 in the right upper abdominal quadrant.
O: Initial laboratory tests at 03:52 showed unremarkable results. However, platelet count increased from 195 K/uL to "unable to perform count, platelets clumped on slide," and ALT increased from 221 u/L to 3495 U/L. A thromboelastogram indicated coagulopathy. TEG showed features of thrombocytopenia. AST increased to 4,059 u/l, and ALP increased to 3,000 u/dL. Initial blood pressure was 199/100 mm Hg.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe coagulation with complications including severe coagenopathy, severe preeclampia, and HELLP syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of preeclamatosis such as thrombus syndrome or other infectious processes.
P: The management plan includes urgent cesarean delivery with intravenous magnesium for seizure prophylaxis and treatment of HELLP. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and blood pressure during the delivery. Further management will include intravenous hydralazine and magnesium supplementation to manage hypertension and manage HELLP symptoms. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a male with a history of ulcerative colitis, steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, deep vein thrombosis in the left thigh, ecchymotic skin lesions, swelling of the left nose, ptosis, and facial nerve palsy, reports intense intestinal bleeding post-Ramadan, confirmed by clinical manifestations and a colon biopsy. He was previously on azathioprine 50 mg/day and high-dose prednisolone for 2 months prior to hospital admission, which led to a significant increase in blood sugar levels. The patient also experienced progressive periorbital echemosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, and a nasal ulcer. He also developed a 4+ light reaction, an afferent pupillary defect, no light perception, absolute blindness, ophthalmoplegia, and neurological defects of cranial nerves 2, 3, 4, and 6.
O: On examination, the patient's blood sugar was 302 mg/dL, white blood cell count 9460/µl, platelets 60×10^3µL, hemoglobin 8.9 g/dl, blood urea nitrogen 35 mg/dl. Laboratory tests showed a fast blood sugar of 302 g/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 g/L), white blood cells 9460-µls, platelet count 3.53×10 µL (normal: <10^4/L) with platelets and platelets showing a 4-light reaction, serum creatinine 2.3 mg/L, potassium 2.1 mg/l, body temperature 38°C, blood pressure 120/70 mm/Hg, pulse 80/min, respiratory rate 14/min).
A: The primary diagnosis is ulcerated colitis and diabetes, complicated by the presence of multiple inflammatory bowel diseases and the presence or worsening of inflammatory bowel disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue current medications and monitor blood sugar. Schedule regular follow-ups with the healthcare team to assess the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up schedules. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the ulceration and diabetes.

S: The patient reports a significant headache with a 10/10 intensity, lightheadedness, confusion, and loss of balance since yesterday. The patient denies any significant past medical history.
O: CT scan of the head revealed a hyperdense lesion on the right side of the brain at the peri-pontine cistern. MRI scan revealed a 4.1 x 3.3 x3.2 cm mass in the brain, causing mild tonsillar herniation and a mass effect on the brainstem, with a patchy enhancement. Physical examination revealed a positive Babinski sign bilaterally. CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed a right thyroid nodule but no lung masses, and a 2.3 cm renal cyst. A right suboccipital craniotomy was performed on Day 2 to remove the brain mass.
A: The primary diagnosis is classic medulloblastoma, WHO grade IV, based on imaging and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other neuroepithelial neoplasms, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes referral to a tertiary care center for further evaluation and management of the tumor. Treatment will involve close monitoring of the patient's neurological status and response to treatment. Patient education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing gross hematuria for about a year, which has been occurring intermittently. The patient was admitted to the Department of Nephrology in November 2002 and underwent a cystourethroscopy. The procedure was unsuccessful, and the patient was transferred to pediatric surgery for further evaluation and management.
O: Initial findings included urethral mucosa edema, mass, miliary bulging, and bleeding of the membranous urethra. Urethral biopsy showed submucosal vascular dilatation of the urethrera, consistent with the patient's condition. Two weeks post-cystouroscopy, pingyangmycin was administered. Post-operative follow-ups showed no recurrence of gross hematia, and micturition and erectile function were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is Urethroid Dysplasia ( UCH), evidenced by the presence of urethal mucosa and bleeding. Differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out through imaging and biopsy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of recurrence and normalization of micturia and erectility.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient with follow-up visits at 1 year, 12 years, and 15 years post-treatment to assess the progression of the condition. The plan includes regular monitoring of renal function and hematology to assess for any recurrence or complications. Patient education regarding the importance of regular follow-ins and the importance to report any new symptoms or changes in health status.

S: The patient, who underwent a right upper lobectomy and right S6b wedge resection for synchronous double lung cancer 5 years ago, reports difficulty breathing during exertion. The patient has a history of metachronous lung tumors in the right lower lobe (S6a and S9) and left diaphragmatic eventration.
O: CT scans revealed metachronsous double lungs in the S6a, S9, and S6B, with a diameter of 27 mm and solid and near a bulla. Pulmonary function tests (PFT) showed poor results, with FVC at 1.54 L, %FVC at 70.0%, FEV1 at 0.92 L, FEV2/FVC 59.7%, and %FEV1 58.6%. The patient's modified MRC dyspnea score was grade 2. Pulp function test (FVC) was poor, with FEV 1 at 092 L and FEV0/FV1 59.6%, respectively.
A: The primary diagnosis is metachronic double lung tumors, likely secondary to synchronous lung cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lung cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes a video-assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) Diaphragm plication with CO2 insufflation. The procedure will involve placing four air-locking trocars through the chest, with the 12-mm trocars inserted through the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line, the seventh intercostum space at posterior axillary line and other spaces as needed.
