He was diagnosed with Asperger syndrome at 10 years old, and has hyperflexia and symptoms of Tourette Syndrome, including verbal tics. He denies any history of genetic testing.
O: Genetic testing confirmed Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS) at age 25. A de novo KMT2A frameshift variant was identified through whole-genome sequencing. Neurodevelopmental assessment confirmed WSS, with abnormalities in speech rhythm, intonation, volume, borderline cognitive skills, low average adaptive skills, and average language and vocabulary skills. The patient has developed good social-communication skills but still meets criteria for ASD.
A: The primary diagnosis is WSS with associated developmental delays, cryptorchidism, hypotonia, and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Differential diagnoses could include other genetic syndromes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and genetic findings. The prognosis depends on the progression of WSS and the management of developmental delays.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with a pediatric neurodevelopmental specialist to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of maintaining communication and social skills is crucial. Referral to a social worker may be beneficial given the patient's developmental delays and the severity of ASD. Regular follow-up appointments with a developmental psychologist are recommended to assess progress and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient reports continuous abdominal pain, more intense in the orthostatic position, associated with abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting. The pain worsens with standing and has worsened with standing. The patient also experiences nausea, vomiting, and has thrown up a few times.
O: Initial clinical evaluation revealed an intraabdominal, multilocular cystic mass with liquid inside. MRI confirmed a liquid-filled multicystic structure with hypersignal in ponderate sequences T2 and T2 with fat suppression. The lesion was identified as an 8.9 cm length intestinal fragment with a 0.5-1.2 cm luminal diameter, incorporated in a soft, yellow-translucent mass, with multiple cysts and a smooth inner and outer surface, filled with a white-milky content. Post-surgery histopathologic evaluation identified an 8-cm intestinal fragment, with a wall thickness of less than 0.1 cm and a white milk-filled surface.
A: The primary diagnosis is intestinal lymphangioma, confirmed by imaging and histopathological findings. The successful surgical removal of the tumor and the absence of further complications are reassuring signs. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the successful surgical intervention.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's recovery and potential complications from the surgery. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are planned to assess the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and manage any potential complications. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of gastrointestinal symptoms is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches, nausea, fatigue, and blurred vision for about a month.
O: Physical examination and CT scan revealed pericardial inflammation and splenomegaly, with an enlargement of the spleen by 2 cm. Ophthalmoscopy of the right eye revealed papillary edema, retinal hemorrhages, known as Roth's spots, and arteriovenous nickings. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 113.2 × 10^9/l, red blood cell level of 2.53 × 10·9/mm3, hemoglobin of 9 g/dl, platelet count of 61 × 10/l. Prothrombine time was 15.1 s, partial thromboplastin time of 25.8 s, creatinine of 38.7 μmol/l (normal range: 0.4-11.2 μmol), and uric acid of 498.2 µmol/L (normal: 0-11 × 10−9/L). Post-treatment blood tests showed white blood cells 0.5 × 10^{9/ml} and 9.5 g/dL, indicating pancytopenia, anemia, and thromboembolic aciduria.
A: The primary diagnosis is Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML-M1), complicated by multiple causes including pancystic myeloid leukemia (AMH), anemia with thrombus, and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of leukemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes initiation of standard chemotherapy with Daunorubicin at 60 mg/m2 for 3 days and Cytarabine at 200 mg/M2 for 7 days. The patient will be closely monitored for response to the treatment and will be educated on the treatment process and the importance of adhering to the plan. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists will be arranged to further evaluate the patient's condition and treatment efficacy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment response and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports feeling more tired and experiencing frequent thirst and urination. The patient has a history of post-cadaveric kidney transplantation PTDM, initially treated with tacrolimus, micophenolate mofetil (MMF), steroids, and histological graft changes including sclerosis, mesangiolysis, ectasia, and microaneurysms in the kidney.
O: Initial immunosuppression with tacroslimus and MMF was ineffective. Histological graft alterations were noted in the patient's kidney, consistent with the ADA clinical practice recommendation. Post-transplant, the patient developed moderate hypertension, which was managed with doxazosin and Basiliximab, which led to good blood pressure control. BMI was within normal limits. Post transplantation, glycosuria was persistently noted, with basal glucose monitoring showing glycemia levels of 180 mg/dL.
A: The primary diagnosis is PTDM secondary to autosomal polycystic kidney disease, likely exacerbated by the deceased donor's kidney transplant. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypertension, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history.
P: The management plan includes switching to cyclosporine (CyA) and stopping steroids to minimize calcineurin inhibitors (CNI) toxicity. Regular monitoring of glucose levels is recommended to manage PTDM and prevent further complications. Further interventions may be considered based on the patient’s response to treatment and response to therapy.

S: The patient, a 39-year-old male with a history of Multiple Sclerosis (MS), initially treated with intravenous steroid therapy and interferon beta 1a therapy for a year. He decided to discontinue immunosuppressant therapy due to inability to tolerate it. He underwent chelation testing showing Gd, Cd, and Pb intoxication. The patient reported fatigue, trouble with fine motor skills in hands, and reduced foot sensitivity. He has a good general health score of 4, and his EDSS score is 0 three years post-chelation therapy.
O: Previous chelation therapy was administered weekly for 12 months, modified to two applications per month after one year. The Gd levels decreased significantly after two years of chelation treatment, with a significant drop in Gadolinium levels after two more years. He is currently on a correct diet avoiding glucose and taking 250 mg of glutathione daily and 15 drops of the antioxidant deutrosulfazyme three times daily.
A: The primary diagnosis is MS with complications including Gd intoxication, Gd toxicity, and chronic fatigue. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fatigue and foot sensitivity, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history of MS. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive response to chelation and the reduction in Gd.
P: Continue chelation with regular follow-ups to monitor the progression of MS symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and encourage regular medical follow-up visits to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing breast pain, abdominal distension, and weakness for approximately one week. The patient denies any significant personal, gynecological, or family medical history.
O: Physical examination reveals a high breathing rate of 22 breaths per minute, tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm, hypotension with a mean arterial pressure of 55 mmHg, and lethargy. The breasts are swollen and painful, and the abdomen is dilated with diffuse sensitivity to palpation and dullness on percussion. The female has a low-grade fever of 37.5°C. Ultrasound and CT scan confirm enlarged and inflammatory ovaries, pleural effusions, and a large amount of free ascitic fluid. Laboratory tests show neutrophilic leukocytosis with white blood cells at 30,000/μL, polymorphonucleocytes at 95%, and thrombocytopenia with platelets at 90,000-μL. Intraoperative findings include disseminated intravascular coagulation, increased urea and creatinine levels, bilirubin, serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase and serum glutam pyruvic transaminases, severe lactic and metabolic acidosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is inflammation and potential infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and biopsy results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of infection.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists may be necessary to manage the infection. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the infection is recommended.

S: The patient, a male, presents with a chief complaint of rapid weight gain and growth deceleration. He reports a history of hyperactivity, decreased behavior over the past 1-2 years, and significant improvement in grades. The mother reports no recent changes in appetite or concentration, and the patient has occasional dry skin. Both parents have hypothyroidism.
O: Physical examination reveals a height of 134.9 cm (69.5 inches) and weight of 50.2 kg (97th percentile), with a BMI of 27.5 kg/m2 (99th percentile). The patient's blood pressure is normal at 104/55 mm Hg, and heart rate is 84 bpm. Thyroid examination shows palpable and smooth with the right and left lobes measuring 4 cm, and no lymphadenopathy. Chest, heart, and abdomen are normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is hyperactivity with associated hypodermic and endocrine disorders. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperactive behavior, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of hypodymic conditions.
P: The management plan includes further evaluation of the thyroid and thyroid parameters. The patient will be educated on the importance of medication adherence to prevent further hyperactivity. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor growth and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to an endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of the hypodemic and other endocrine conditions is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of renal failure and currently on dialysis, was referred for a transcatheter aortic valve replacement evaluation.
O: Physical examination revealed a BMI of 28. The patient's vital signs and vital signs were not provided in the dialogue.
A: The primary diagnosis is aorta vascular disease, likely secondary to atherosclerotic disease. The imaging studies and clinical presentation support this diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes a low contrast dose protocol to visualize blood vessels more clearly during the scan, using bolus tracking technology to trigger the scan once the enhancement reaches 10 Hounsfield Units (HU) over the baseline. The scan will be reconstructed in both conventional and virtual monoenergetic images at 40 keV using low volume contrast bolus. A 3D volume rendered model of the abdominal vasculature lumen will be developed using the VMI at 40 kV. Follow-up will include discussing the results of the evaluation and the 3D model with the surgical team to determine the best approach.

S: The patient, admitted with cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue, night sweats, and a 15-pound weight loss, reports a two-month history of fever and tiredness. The patient has a history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and chronic pain, with a recent course of sulfa drugs and latex. No recent travel, drug or alcohol use, or sexual activity is reported.
O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.6oC, heart rate of 135 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 115/85 mmHg. Laboratory tests indicated marked leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated inflammatory markers, uric acid, and lactate dehydrogenase. Blood smear showed reactive lymphocytes, but flow cytometry showed no abnormal lymphoid populations. Infectious workup was negative except for Epstein-Barr virus polymerase chain reaction (PCR). CT scan indicated marked lymphadenopathies and hepatosplenomegaly. PET imaging showed widespread hypermetabolic bulky lymphadenopathic and diffuse bone, spleen, and marrow uptake without osseous lesions.
A: The primary diagnosis is suspected Epstein Barr virus infection, with differential diagnoses including other infectious etiologies and autoimmune disorders. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications. Treatment options include antiviral therapy if necessary, considering the potential for infection from the Epstein-barr virus. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. Education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, diagnosed with hepatitis C, reports right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and dark urine. The patient also experiences nausea and has been experiencing dark urine recently.
O: Physical examination revealed jaundiced and tenderness in the right quadrant. Total bilirubin was elevated to 20.2 mg/dl with a direct component of 15.0, albumin normal, and INR 1.0. AST and ALT levels were 55 and 43 units per liter, respectively. ALP was 148 international units/liter. Ultrasound indicated a thickened gallbladder wall but no stones. CT scan indicated early acute cholecystitis and common bile duct dilation of 7 mm. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) indicated dilated intrahepatic ducts and occlusion of the biliary tree, with diffuse moderate dilation and filling defects in the CBD. MRI of the abdomen showed intrahepanic biliary dilation but no pancreatic lesions.
A: The primary diagnosis is hepatitis C with complications including early acute and common hepatocellular carcinoma (CBD) dilation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver and bile dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan included administration of intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam 4 grams every six hours to manage the infection and endoscopy to address the CDD dilation, which was managed with endoscopic and retrograde ERCP. A laparoscopic converted to open right hepatectomy was performed to remove the affected area. Post-surgery, the patient was monitored closely for signs of infection or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of a painless right scrotal mass for two years, reports no current medications for the condition. The patient describes the mass as elastic and hard, with no translucency.
O: Physical examination revealed normal testis and epididymis. Blood laboratory tests were unremarkable. CT scans revealed a testicular tumor with a cystic structure in the scrotum, thickened and enhanced contrast medium, and a tumor size of 48 x 48 x 42 mm. The scrotary mass was diagnosed as uncharacteristic testicular cancer with no metastasis to lymph nodes or other organs. Hematoxylin-eosin staining indicated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the parenchyma of the testis, with the neoplasm containing a cancer pearl.
A: The primary diagnosis is squamous carcinoma of the right testis with a secondary diagnosis of intraepithelial carcinoma. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of testicular tumors, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan included emergent high radical orchiectomy followed by emergent orchestrated resection of the tumor. Postoperative care included monitoring for any signs of recurrence or metastasis and regular follow-ups to assess tumor markers and treatment efficacy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of metastasis. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a one-year history of exophthalmia in the left eye, reports no nasal symptoms. The patient underwent a rhinoscopic approach 6 months ago for marsupialization of an aneurysmal cyst, which was later recidivited for recidivism. No loss of visual acuity was noted.
O: Clinical examination revealed a well-defined mass at the level of the left ethmoidal sinus, smooth and pink, and the other side appeared normal. Tomodensitometry revealed an oval multiloculated lesion in the ethmoid cells, measuring 39×23×35mm, with multiple stalls and a liquid level realized by blood, displacing the nasal fossa without endocranial invasion, displaces the ethmicoidal roof inward, and narrows the optical channel. The frontal and sphenoidal sinuses are unaffected.
A: The primary diagnosis is a multilocalized tumor of the ethmisoid sinus with associated grade I exophththalmia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sinus swelling and inflammation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the tumor, orbital medial wall, and periorbital, using an ENT navigation system to determine the skull base, orbit, and carotid canal. Post-operative histopathology will be conducted to assess the tumor's progression and potential treatment options. The treatment plan will include surgical resection of the lesion, complete surgical removal, and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a ten-year veteran of chronic lumbar pain, reports experiencing violent low back pain and numbness in the left leg starting 4 months ago, extending from the left hip to the foot. The pain has been present for ten years.
O: Physical examination revealed tenderness of interspinal areas and hypesthesia to pinprick in the L5 and S1 dermatomal distribution, with a positive straight leg raising sign. Routine spinal X-rays showed L4 spondylolisthesis and spondolysis on both sides. CT scan confirmed disc protrusion and lumbary stenosis at L4/5 and L5/S1, compressing the left L5. A black shadow was noted on a routine X-ray 10 days post-surgery. A gas pseudocyst was identified during debridement surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a gas pseudoma of the dura sac, likely exacerbated by compression of the membranous structure and clot organization. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chronic pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and follow-up with neurology and pulmonology for any new symptoms or worsening pain. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a pulmonologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and has a history of a low-grade fever yesterday and eating a lot before bed. The patient denies experiencing palpitations, hand tremors, abdominal pain, diarrhea, body weight loss, or numbness of limbs. No history of illnesses or family members have experienced similar attacks.
O: Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 121/63 mmHg, body temperature of 36.6 °C, pulse rate of 102 beats per minute, and respiration rate of 18 breaths per minute. No flaccid paralysis or areflexia is noted. Laboratory findings indicate hypokalemia (2.2 mmol/L), mild hypomagnesemia (1.8 mg/dL), and renal potassium wasting (TTKG 7.02), with a fractional excretion of potassium (FeK 7.12). Urine potassium excretion indicates renal potassium loss with a transtubular potassium gradient (TTG) of 7.01 and a fraction of potassium (<7.12), indicating renal potassium deficiency.
A: The primary diagnosis is renal potassium dysfunction, likely secondary to a recent low-level fever. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute weakness, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the hypokalympic symptoms.
P: Initiate potassium supplementation with potassium chloride (KCl) infusion. Monitor serum potassium levels and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of monitoring thyroid function and adjusting treatment as needed. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on response and response.

S: The patient, an eight-year-old female, presented with asymptomatic swelling in the lower lip's labial mucosa. She has no significant medical history and no known allergies.
O: Physical examination revealed a 0.70 cm silver blue, translucent swelling opposite the right mandibular canine. The swelling has been present for four months, with no pain or discomfort noted. No trauma or lip biting was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is asymptic swelling in a lower lip, likely due to the presence of the swelling and the absence of trauma or habit of lip biting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lip swelling, but these are less likely given the patient's age and the history.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the swelling closely, with a follow-up appointment scheduled to reassess the situation and determine the best course of action. The patient is advised to return for a followup appointment if the swelling changes significantly or if the patient experiences discomfort. The mother is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns during this time.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old female presenting with chest distress for 11 hours, experiencing shortness of breath at rest and difficulty laying in the recumbent position. She has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus treated with oral medication.
O: Initial clinical examination revealed coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, coronary angiography, stent implantation, and heparin administration. Post-operative findings included mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant, peritoneal irritation, and a neoplasm-like mucous clot connected to the bowel in the anus. Laboratory tests showed declined hemoglobin (102 g/L), prolonged prothrombin time (13.4 s), and an international normalized ratio of 1.2. Colonoscopy revealed a submucosal mass in the sigmoid colon, covered with a partially ruptured mucous membrane and clots in the cavity, causing obstruction. Abdominal CT scan showed a sub-mucososal hematoma in the colon, with a thickened left flexure.
A: The primary diagnosis is sub-sigmoid hematomas, likely secondary to coronary artery disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematochezia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of anticoagulant medications, total parenteral nutrition, and monitoring of the patient's condition. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of worsening symptoms or complications. Further treatment options may be considered based on the response to treatment and ongoing monitoring. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of the hematologic findings is recommended.

S: 
- Patient reports feeling anxious, particularly at work.
- No history of migraines.

O:  

P: - Patient has been on Ibuprofen for headaches, which have been less severe, and has been under control for a few months.
 
1- Patient is currently on Paracetamol.
2- Patient denies any history of high blood pressure.
3- Patient's current medication regimen includes Paracetaminophen, which is effective for headaches.
4- Patient presents with headache and neck stiffness, which has been reduced to a manageable level.
5- Patient takes paracetamole for headache.
A:

S: Differential diagnosis includes migraine, given the patient's history of headaches, and the current symptoms of headache. The patient's current medications include Paracetamicin and Aspirin, which are effective for headache relief.
1. Patient is advised to self-certify for migraine relief. No other medications are currently prescribed.

S: The patient reports persistent left nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and episodes of self-resolving epistaxis. The patient has a history of presumed nasal polyps and sinusitis treated with presumed treatments but no improvement.
O: Physical examination and fiber-optic examination revealed a mass in the left nasal cavity, with no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy or neurological deficits. Cranial nerves, II to XII, were intact. CT scan and MRI showed a large, enhancing soft tissue mass (6.1 x 4.9 x 4 cm) in the sphenoid sinus, invading the left pterygopalatine fossa, extending into the left masticator space, and invading the sellar region and cavernous sinus with patent internal carotid artery canals. Transnasal biopsy showed well-vascularized sheets and cords of uniform round cells with positive synaptophysin (Syn), chromogranin A (CgA), CD56, and cytokeratin AE1/AE3.
A: The primary diagnosis is a soft tissue tumor of the left nalcocentric sinus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. The prognosis depends on the extent of the tumor and the response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the mass. Treatment options will be discussed based on the tumor's response to therapy and potential side effects. Patient education regarding the nature of the lesion, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the response and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a painless lump on the forehead that has been present for approximately 3 months. Initially thought to be a pimple, the lump has grown and turned painful.
O: Physical examination revealed hard, fixed, and tenderness on palpation. CT scan revealed the lesion involves both the outer and inner tables of the frontal bone. Core needle biopsy showed pleomorphic tumour cells with predominantly eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and cells arranged in both trabecular and solid patterns. 18F-FDG-PET scan showed a highly avid lesion with a standardized uptake value of 28 in the right lobe of the liver, multiple other avid foci involving the liver and lungs, and multiple other vertebrae. AFP level was 6889 ng ml−1. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity for HepPar1 and CD10. Seropositive for HBsAg and negative for HCV. Liver function tests, serum CEA, CA 19-9, coagulation tests, and other routine investigations were within normal limits.
A: The primary diagnosis is a pleomorphic lesion of the right liver with multiple avid focuses in the liver. Differential diagnoses could include other types of liver tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the condition.
P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options and lifestyle modifications to manage the patient's condition. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance for compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports upper abdominal pain. He has a history of hepatitis B for 10 years.
O: MRI findings revealed a mass in the left outer lobe of the liver, growing outward and invading the diaphragm. Tumour marker carcinoembryonic antigen was elevated at 10.14 μg/L. Post-surgery, the tumor was 11 cm × 9 cm × 6 cm, with no lymph node metastases. Immunohistochemistry was positive for cytokeratin 18 (CK18) and negative for Arg-1, hepatocyte, glypican-3 (GPC-3), CK7, and PD-L1 expression levels were <5%. Tumor proportion score (TPS) was <5%, and infiltrating CD8+ T cells were 10%. MRI and PET-CT scans showed a marginal lesion of 4 × 1.5 cm in the liver with enlarged hepatic hilar and retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and abnormal hypermetabolic lesions in the lymph nodes.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) staged at IIIb. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with left hemihepatectomy and hepatoduodenal ligament skeletonization to remove the tumor. Postoperative management will include intraoperative radiotherapy with 9-mV photon beams and intraoperative radiation. The patient will be educated on the signs of recurrence and the importance of regular follow-up. Referral to a hepatologist for specialized care and a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of liver cancer is recommended.

S: The patient, a 52-year-old male with a history of coronary bypass surgery, reports feeling okay and has not experienced any symptoms related to coronary artery disease. He has a stable heart function and is asymptomatic for coronary artery diseases.
O: Physical examination revealed normal heart sounds with no added sounds like S3 or S4, and no murmur on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure was 132/82 mmHg, heart rate was 72/min. 12-lead electrocardiogram showed nonspecific ST changes in precordial leads. Transthoracic echocardiography showed normal systolic contraction in all left ventricular wall segments. No left ventricle enlargement or hypertrophy was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is coronary artery dysfunction, evidenced by the presence of a right ventricular false tendon and normal cardiac function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of heart function, regular follow-ups to assess for any signs of worsening heart function or complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with cardiology may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, with a history of alcohol abuse, presented with pancytopenia a few weeks ago, accompanied by a fever and a productive cough with yellow sputum. The patient reported generalized weakness, blurry right eye, and chest tightness for the past few weeks. No other symptoms such as skin rash, joint pain, hair loss, heartburn, or Raynaud's phenomenon were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed nontender lymphadenopathy in the neck. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 1,900 counts/μL, hemoglobin of 7.2 g/dL, hematocrit of 21.2%, and platelet of 19,000 counts/mL. Urinalysis showed elevated white blood cells, dysmorphic red blood cells of 6542 ng/mL, high triglycerides at 327 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/mL), elevated ESR at 137 mm/hr, positive ANA (1 : 640), anti-dsDNA (1: 1280), IgM and IgG (positive), beta-2 glycoprotein I antibody (IgG), and Direct antiglobulin test (Coomb's). Urine studies showed nephrotic-range proteinuria. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed normal ventricular function but moderate circumferential pericardial effusion. Abdominal ultrasonography indicated hepatosplenomegaly and cirrhosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney failure with associated nephropathy, likely secondary to alcohol abuse. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injury such as liver disease or renal impairment. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the extent of liver damage.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's renal function and liver function. Adjustments to the treatment plan will be made based on clinical response and laboratory results. The family will be kept informed throughout the treatment process. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust the treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with missing teeth and was hoping to get a fixed prosthesis. He was unaware of the radiograph findings and was concerned about the possibility of an implant placement in the upper right 1st molar region.
O: Radiographic findings include an incidental finding of a bilateral bifid mandibular canal, a rare variation in the current literature, and a bifurcation on the left side at the height of an imaginary line drawn horizontally along the occlusal plane, with the biffurcation at the right side being much lower in the mandibula ramus of the mandible.
A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral Bifid Mandibular Canal, with differential diagnoses including other forms of mandibulopathy, but these are less likely given the radiographic findings. The presence of bifurs on the right and left sides of the canal suggests a more likely case of a similar canal.
P: The management plan includes careful monitoring of the patient's condition and implant placement. The patient will be educated on the anatomical features of the bifurbation and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the implant placement and adjust the treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports progressive fatigue, dyspnoea, and numbness in the soles of the feet for 15 months. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and has been diagnosed with cardiomegaly.
O: Physical examination revealed hypothyrocystic heart disease (CARD) with sinus rhythm rate of 80 bpm, low voltage complexes in limb leads, and LVH with septal hypertrophy (IVSd 1.6 cm). Echocardiogram indicated moderate concentric LVH, septetal hypertokinesis, and moderate global hypokinesi. The right ventricle was moderately dilated with mildly reduced systolic function, and both atria were mildly dilated. Cardiac MRI showed a high normal left ventricular (LV) size with severely increased LV mass, global hypocytosis, impaired biventricular systolopathy, moderate bi-atrial dilatation, normal native myocardial T1, mildly raised EECV 0.36, and diffuse subendocardial late gadolinium enhancement. Perfusion scan showed severe circumferential inducible ischaemia and transmural fibrosis in the lateral wall at the basal and mid ventricular level post-gadolinium. Coronary angiography indicated 70% stenosis over the left anterior descending artery.
A: The primary diagnosis is cardiac stenosis, likely secondary to amyloidosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the management of cardiac disease and the patient's response to treatment.
P: The management plan will include continued monitoring and evaluation of cardiac function and function, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on ongoing evaluations and clinical response. Referral to a cardiologist for further management of myopericarditis and a hematologist for cardiac management are recommended. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis and the importance of follow-up care will be provided.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old male with a history of hemophilia A, presents with swelling and pain in multiple joints, accompanied by an intermittent fever for the past 13 days. He reports a history with similar episodes of joint ache since birth, which resolved after administration of FVIII and blood transfusions. He also experiences non-traumatic episodes of epistaxis and skin bruising since birth. He has a surgical history of difficulty with blood clotting, which was managed medically.
O: Physical examination reveals the patient is oriented to time, place, and person, with a Glasgow coma scale of 15/15. Vital signs include a heart rate of 88 beats/min, blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min. No visible bruises are noted on the patient.
A: The primary diagnosis is a high-grade fever with associated complications including joint aches, epistaxis, skin bruising, and hypotension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever such as infection or infection. The prognosis depends on the response to antipyretics and management of the fever.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of antipsychotic therapy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the new immunization regimen and ensure understanding of the symptoms and treatment plan. Consider referral to a pediatric infectious disease specialist if symptoms persist or worsen. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal pain for the past 4 days, described as hypotensive, perspiring, and drowsy.
O: Physical examination revealed tenderness and rebound tenderness to palpation in the abdomen, 2 periumbilical ecchymoses 2/2 cm in the left deltoid area and on the lower limbs. Abdominal sonography showed peritoneal fluid in all spaces with fibrin. Chest X-rays were unremarkable. Hemoglobin and white blood cell count were within normal limits. Lab results showed creatinine at 4.04 mg/dL, urea at 209 mg/L, mild acidosis with lactate at 21 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mmol/l), creatininine-kinase at 1910 U/L and lactate-dehydrogenase at 451 U/dL (normal ranges: 0-1/2). Laparotomy revealed 2 perforations on the ileum and general peritonitis with pus. An enterectomy and end-ileostomy were performed, and a laparostomy was performed. The patient was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics including ertapenem and vancomycin.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) secondary to blunt trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and supportive care. The management includes supportive care with mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, and sedation. The treatment plan includes continued empirical therapy with broad antibiotics and monitoring of infection response. The plan includes regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: Mdm A, a patient with alpha thalassaemia, reports experiencing fever and chills for the past week. He denies any other symptoms or signs of infection.
O: Initial physical examination revealed pancytopenia with hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, white cell count at 1.68 × 10^9/L, and platelet count at 92 × 109/L. C-reactive protein was 24, and procalcitonin was 0.14. Renal function, liver enzymes, chest X-ray, and urinalysis were unremarkable. Blood culture and urine culture were negative. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed hepatosplenomegaly but no intra-abdominal abscesses. peripheral blood film showed marked leukopenia, thrombocytopenias, significant anisopoikilocytosis with microcytosis and target and tear drop cells. Bone marrow examination showed hypocellular marrow with erythroid hyperplasia and marked dyserythropoiesis, marked erytherroid hypoplasia with rare giant erythroblasts, and inclusion bodies.
A: Primary diagnosis is alpha thalamocytopenic purpura (HbH) disease, complicated by thalassemia intermedia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thalangiocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: Continue monitoring blood counts and adjust treatment as necessary. Maintain current medications and monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Educate MdmA on the importance of reporting new symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a 5-month history of central scotoma in the right eye, which has been bothersome. The patient denies any history of prodromic symptoms, systematic illnesses, or eye disorders.
O: The last visual acuity corrected from 8/20 to 10/20, with atypical pigmentary alterations and local serous detachment involving the central fovea. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed persistent sub-retinal fluid and FCE. The last visit showed no improvement in vision. Fungal angiograph (FA) showed typical inkblot leakage of classic CSC. Post-half-dose PDT, the patient's best-corrected visual acumum was 10/10, followed by OCT showing complete resolution of the sub-Retinal fluid. The latest fundus photo shows sub-macular hemorrhage and a round hypopigmentary site inferior-nasal to the foveal.
A: The primary diagnosis is central macular edema (CSC) with complications including sub- retinal hemorrhage, FCE, and a lesion of CNV in the retinal pigment epithelium. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal detachment and retinal dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and OCT findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and potential treatment options to address the CNV lesion. The management team will consider additional treatment options if the patient does not improve vision. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to reassess the condition and discuss any further treatment options. Education regarding the nature of the disease and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a seizure at home, accompanied by his mother, who reported feeling sick for the past two to three days. The patient was somnolent, arousable, and confused upon arrival. He also reported feeling unwell for the last two days, including cough and nasal congestion. He has a history of hypertension but no family history of seizure disorders.
O: Upon examination, the patient was unwell, with a decreased appetite and a limited diet. He was drowsy but overall well-developed. Vital signs included an oral temperature of 38° Celsius, heart rate of 108 bpm, blood pressure of 111/70 mmHg, breathing rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygenation of 97% on room air. The physical exam showed the patient to be drowsy but otherwise well developed.
A: The primary diagnosis is a postictal seizure, likely secondary to an allergic reaction to amoxicillin. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to further diagnostic tests and management of the seizure.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and seizure activity to assess for any changes in the seizure's cause. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to determine the cause of the seizures and the extent of the underlying condition. Patient education regarding seizure symptoms and the importance of hydration will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: The patient, admitted to the ICU following thoracic surgery, reports feeling weak and tired following a mitral valve replacement and CABG graft in 2017. He has a history of postoperative kidney failure and has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) dialysis since 2010. The patient has experienced atrial fibrillation, pulmonary oedema, respiratory distress, and delirium.
O: Initial respiratory status was stable with a saturation level of 95-98% on 3-5L/min of 100% oxygen for up to 7 hours per day. Subsequent interventions included surgical tracheostomy and insertion of a size 8 tracheopostomy tube. Over the next few days, respiratory status improved, maintaining a saturation (SaO2) of 98-98%, and fingering the tracheotomy tube, which was unsuccessful. However, the patient was wheezing but managing on a speaking valve with a SaO2 above 96%. Attempts at reinsertion of the tube were unsuccessful.
A: The primary diagnosis is postoperative renal failure secondary to a tracheoplasty, complicated by atrial Fibrillation and pulmonary edema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress such as pneumonia or other complications related to renal failure. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in respiratory status and successful reinsertions.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status closely. Maintain current medications and adjust as necessary based on recovery progress. Educate the patient on signs of worsening respiratory distress and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess recovery progress and manage any complications. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of tympanoplasty and endoscopic sinus surgery with septoplasty 10 years ago, presents with severe otalgia, a sensation of ear blockage in the left ear, and hearing loss. The patient has tried ear wax removal at several ENT clinics, which failed.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be comfortable and afebrile, with stable vital signs. Otoscopic examination of the left and right ear revealed impacted ear wax covering the tympanic membrane, mild ear wax, and unremarkable oropharynx examination. Nasal endoscopy showed no pathologies. Blood tests were within normal limits. Microscope-guided examination revealed a thick keratinous plug in the right ear, dilated the external auditory canal with pockets and bone remodeling, circumferentially distended ear canal with normal annulus, and intact tympane membrane.
A: The primary diagnosis is keratosis obturans (KO) of the ear, confirmed by the absence of keratin plugs. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of otalgia such as ear wax or ear blockages, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with appropriate ear care. The ear pack will be draped with antibiotics to aid in healing and prevent further infection. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor healing and detect any changes in symptoms. Patient education on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up schedules will be provided.

S: The patient reports a recurrent, itchy rash that has been present for approximately one year. The rash features red, raised bumps with minimal scaling. The patient has tried multiple therapies including topical triamcinolone, clobetasol, hydroxyzine, Oral prednisone, and oral prednisol due to steroid-induced diabetes.
O: Biopsy of the left chest showed a predominantly perivascular inflammatory infiltrate with occasional eosinophils consistent with Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction (DHR). Direct immunofluorescence test was negative. Previous treatments for DHR were ineffective.
A: The primary diagnosis is a diffuse rash of the chest, likely related to a drug-hypersensitivity reaction, given the biopsy findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dermatitis and pruritus, but these are less likely given the specific biopsy results and clinical history.
P: Continue current regimen of dupilumab injections every 14 days. Monitor the patient's response to the injections and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the potential side effects of the medication. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess treatment efficacy and manage any side effects.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of melena once a day for the past week, accompanied by vomiting, shortness of breath, and palpitations. He also reported a history of epistaxis in childhood and increased bleeding tendency.
O: Initial complete blood count showed a hemoglobin level of 5.80 g/dL, indicating severe anemia. Lab parameters from admission showed packed red blood cells (RBCs) as O positive, with a strongly positive indirect Coomb's test and negative direct Coomb. An extended 11-cell panel antibody testing showed pan-agglutination with monoclonal panel cells having anti-Kell, anti-Lub, and antiKpb antibodies. Cross match with four O negative and four O positive packed RBCs showed +4 incompatibility. The patient experienced shivering, temperature spiked to 101°F, tachycardia, and hypotension. Intravenous antihistamine and hydrocortisone were administered. Blood transfusion reaction workup revealed grade 4+ pan agglutination in serum.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe aplastic anemia, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of multiple alloantibodies in his blood. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia such as infectious etiologies, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued close monitoring of the patient and potential transfusion response, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on clinical response and laboratory results. Further consultations with a hematologist and possibly a cardiologist may be necessary to manage the anemia and manage potential complications. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to an infectious disease specialist for further evaluation and management of the anemic condition is recommended.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, presenting with fatigue and constitutional syndrome lasting for 5 months. She reports no positive findings upon physical examination. Extrainstitutional CT revealed multiple focal liver lesions with microcalcifications, interpreted as possible metastatic disease.
O: Physical examination showed no positive results. Extranstitutional paraclinical tests showed negative tumour markers and normal liver function tests. Contrast MRI with gadopentetate dimeglumine (Magnevist) showed a liver of normal size and morphology, with multiple focal lesions in the right lobe, hyperintense in T2 sequences, and hypointense with no fatty component in their interior. Cholangioresonance sequences showed very little contrast uptake. MRI's arterial phase showed multiple low-intensity lesions without contrast media uptake. Phase and out-of-phase sequences were normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic liver disease, with differential diagnoses including other forms of liver tumors or metastatic diseases. The absence of tumor markers and imaging findings suggest a benign nature. The presence of heterogeneous peripheral enhancement and heterogeneous nodular enhancement suggests a non- metastatic nature.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's liver function and liver function. The patient will be educated on the importance of regular follow-up visits to monitor for any changes in symptoms. Further diagnostic tests may be considered if there is no improvement in liver function or progression of the disease.

S: The patient, a 27-year-old Caucasian male, presents with obsessive-compulsive symptoms and suicidal thoughts, which began approximately one week ago following a nocturnal emission while camping. The patient reports feeling unable to clean himself properly and fear of contamination. He has a history of psychiatric hospitalizations but no history of suicidal behavior, physical or sexual abuse, or drug abuse. He also has a past medical history of one psychiatric hospitalization but denies suicidal behavior or substance abuse.
O: The Patient's medical history includes a past psychiatric hospital admission for trichotillomania, hair pulling from the back of the scalp, and compulsive hand washing. The current episode started around age 14, with a history starting at age 14. He reports a fear of contaminated hair, which was relieved by compulsive washing.
A: The primary diagnosis is obsessive- compulsive disorder (OCD) with a secondary diagnosis of OCD, likely exacerbated by the noctonic emission. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of obsessive compulsive disorders, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes admission to the emergency room for further assessment and treatment. The family will be involved in the care of the patient and his family, with the patient receiving support and care as needed. Further consultations with a psychiatrist and a psychologist may be necessary to manage OCD and manage his OCD. Family involvement will be provided to support the patient through the care and support.

S: The patient is a 59-year-old female employed as a rehabilitation worker, presenting with gradually enlarging swellings under both her right and left scapula over eight months. The swellings feel soft at palpation. She reports pain in the upper extremities and around her arms. She has a history of neurosurgical procedures for disc extrusion in the cervical and thoracic spine, with bilateral swellings present pre-operatively. She denies any accident or fall.
O: Physical examination revealed bilateral swelling under both the right and the left scapeula. MRI findings showed symmetrical fluid collections in the subscapular regions, with symmetrical collections on the right side and on the left. The patient's axillary lymphatic nodes are physiological size, with no inflammatory or focal changes. No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy, pleural cavities without effusion, and pleura without hypertrophy.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic post-surgical swelling in the right scapular region, likely secondary to neurosurgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bilateral swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying condition.
P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education on the signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a pulmonologist for specialized care and a physical therapist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, with a history of progressive dysphagia persisting for 2 months, reports a 40-year history of smoking 60 cigarettes daily for 40 years and heavy alcohol consumption for the same amount of time. He also has hypertension for 9 years and is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes a year ago. No prior malignant diseases or distant metastases were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed no palpable neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes. Blood count and biochemical analysis were normal. Iohexol swallowing test revealed a malignant-appearing structure in the inferior-thoracic region. Endoscopic examination revealed a lesion of mucosal hyperplasia, 36 cm from the incisor teeth, and a luminal stenosis 36 cm. Biopsy of the lesion showed an esophageal malignant enlargement (MEC) with biopsy confirming an esomorphic tumor. CT scan confirmed resectable esophagectomy, 2-field lymphadenectomy (upper abdominal and mediastinum), and esophagogastrostomy. Histopathology confirmed the presence of epidermoid cells and keratin pearl formation. Immunohistochemistry was positive for p-63 and CK5/6.
A: The primary diagnosis is esomorphic malignancy with complications including esophagus ulceration (MEL) and esomorphic stenosis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignancies or metastatic diseases. The prognosis depends on the successful resection of the esophagic malignants and the management of hypertension and diabetes.
P: The management plan includes surgical resection and management of esophagesis with appropriate anticoagulation therapy. The patient is advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption to improve overall health. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and manage any potential complications. Education on the importance of smoking cessation and lifestyle modifications to improve health will be provided to the patient.

S: The patient is a woman in her late seventies with a history of percutaneous endovascular aortic repair in 2013. She reports weakness and numbness in both lower limbs, worsening on the right side. She underwent an elective procedure in September 2019 for embolization of a type 2 endoleak, which was performed using Onyx®. She expresses concern about spinal cord ischemia.
O: Physical examination revealed a lower motor neurone pattern of weakness over bilateral lower limbs and impaired sensation for the right from L2 to S1. Sensation testing indicated normal sensation on the left but impaired sensation in the right. A lumbar spinal drain was inserted to decompress the spinal cord and allow more arterial flow. A CT aortogram and MRI thoracolumbar spine were performed. Post-interval embolizing of bilateral feeding arteries showed Onyx material within a branch of the embolized right iliolumbar artery, extending into the spinal canal at the level of L3 and exiting at L2.
A: The primary diagnosis is aortical aneurysm with complications including spinal cord injury and spinal cord involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb weakness such as spinal cord compression, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for any changes in symptoms. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the aorta.

S: The patient, a 10-year-old male horse, presented with symptoms of weakness, lack of response, and difficulty breathing 4 hours after falling ill. He was found with two living third-instar dipteran larvae near his head on the ground. The patient reported no unusual discharge or breathing problems the day before the horse fell ill.
O: Examination revealed two living larvae near the horse's head. The larvae were identified as oestrids, and the patient was unable to breathe prior to the onset of symptoms. Further examination of the larvae showed another four living larvae in the nasal cavity.
A: The primary diagnosis is a death of third-infested dipterans, likely due to the presence of oestrogen larvae. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the specific findings.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the horse closely for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. The plan includes regular follow-up visits to monitor the larvae' development and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the signs of potential complications and the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen will be provided. Referral to a veterinarian for specialized care and a veterinary specialist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: 56-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing and difficulty swallowing. He reports difficulty swallowing, difficulty breathing, difficulty swallowing during the day, and difficulty breathing. He has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure.

O: Neck exam shows no murmurs, no neck masses, no murmur, no chest pain, shortness of breath, no vomiting, no nausea, diarrhea, or other side effects from the metformin regimen.
A: The patient presents with a chief complaint of difficulty swallowing due to a narrowing in the throat, likely from a stricture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of throat obstruction such as reflux, but these are less likely given the patient's history and symptoms.
P: Initiated prilosec 20 mg once a day for reflux. The patient is advised to chew solids frequently and to avoid foods that may exacerbate the swallowing process. A referral for gastroenterology is recommended. The management plan includes discontinuing prilosesc and increasing the dose to 20 mg twice daily. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in about a month to review hemoglobin a1c and adjust the regimen as necessary.

S: The patient is a 91-year-old male who presented with discomfort and pain in his right side in November 2016. He reported no knowledge of the cause of the pain and discomfort. He underwent a laparoscopic renal resection (RN) in December 2016, which was performed using a conventional intraperitoneal approach. Postoperative complications included postoperative night delirium, which resolved after haloperidol administration.
O: The primary diagnosis is multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b, diagnosed at a relatively early stage. The patient's symptoms have largely resolved, with no new symptoms or new concerns noted.
A: Primary diagnosis is recurrent multilebular clear cell carcinomas (RCS), FH2, pP1b. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the early detection of the cancer and the patient's advanced age.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient and his condition. The management of deliria and pain will be emphasized, with regular follow-ups to assess the progression or resolution of the disease. Education on the nature of the diagnosis and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure continued health and well-being.

S: The patient reports experiencing left wrist drop, finger drop, and tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of the left hand starting 4 days ago. The patient denies any history of antecedent trauma, injury, infection, or mononeuropathy.
O: Neurological examination revealed left wrist and finger extension weakness (Medical Research Council grade II), weak finger abduction, and improved hand strength when passively extended to the neutral position. Wrist and finger flexion were intact. Sensory examination revealed hypoesthesia and ttingling sensation on the lateral lateral dorsatum of the right hand between the thumb and index finger, extending into the proximal phalanges of the 2nd finger. Skin color and edema were noted, but no changes in skin temperature or pain. Reflexes were normal at the biceps and triceps brachii muscles, but the left brachioradialis reflex was absent. Routine blood analysis showed normal white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and uric acid levels.
A: The primary diagnosis is compressive radial neuropathy, likely exacerbated by the compression of the radial nerve in the arm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin color, weakness, and aberrant sensation, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the patient's condition for approximately two weeks without specific treatment. The plan includes adjusting the treatment plan as necessary based on improvement in symptoms and improvement in muscle strength. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment as necessary. Education on the importance of avoiding excessive strain on the left arm and wrist will be provided to the patient.

S: The patient, an 8-month-old baby boy, presented with a one-month history of a mass on his right elbow, which has been gradually increasing in size. The mother reports that the child has been moving his right arm without limitations but has no past medical or surgical issues. The child was full-term during pregnancy and delivered full-time.
O: Physical examination revealed a 3 × 2 × 4 cm mobile, soft, nontender mass extending from the right proximal ulnar aspect volar surface to the elbow crease without signs of erythema. The full elbow active extension with mild restriction of full flexion is around 15 degrees. A plain radiograph showed lobular soft tissue swelling, and blood profile including complete blood count, ESR, and CRP were normal. MRI of the right elbow revealed a multiseptated, multiloculated lymphangioma with a 1.8 × 1.5 cm area with low T2 and high T1 signal intensity, and no perilesional edema or joint effusion. Pathology of the tumor showed a multilocalized lymphangia with no evidence of malignancy.
A: The primary diagnosis is an endolymphatic malformation of the elbow, likely secondary to a lobular juxta articular subcutaneous soft tissue lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of elbow swelling and tenderness, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes a radical excision of the mass to remove the tumor. Post-operative care will include monitoring for signs of infection or complications, and the patient will be educated on the procedure and post-operative expectations. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns during the surgery.

S: The patient, diagnosed with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, reports a history of consuming artificial sweeteners for approximately 14 years. The patient has a significant weight gain of 20 lbs since starting the use of artificial sweetener.
O: Initial thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) was 12.2 mIU/L, above the normal range of 0.4-4.5 m IU/L. Free T4 was 0.5 ng/dl (normal range 0.58-1.64 ng/dL), and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Anti TPO Ab) was 196 IU/ml (normal <35 IU/l). Treatment with levothyroxine 0.75 mg/day normalized TSH levels, which remained between 1.23 mIU-L and 2.16 mIU–L over three years. No autoimmune disorders were ruled out, and TSH and Anti-TPO Ab levels remained normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is Hashimoto’s hypothyrosyroidism with associated autoimmune disorders including Grave's disease, De Quervain thyroiditis, and drug-induced thyroiditis. Differential diagnoses could include other autoimmune disorders or autoimmune disorders, but these are less likely given the patient's history and treatment history.
P: Continue monitoring thyroid levels and Anti TPOAb levels. Regular follow-up visits are necessary to monitor thyroid function and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health status. Consider referral to a dietitian for further evaluation and management of thyroid dysfunction. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, born at term via natural delivery, reports a history of birth at term, unrelated and healthy parents. The patient's mother had a prenatal NT ultrasound and karyotype on amniocytes, which were normal. She started walking at 13 months and pronounced her first words at 11 months. She has mild learning disabilities including dysgraphia and obesity, normal height, hyperactivity, dysphagia, sleep disturbance, and minor dysmorphic features such as a round face, bushy eyebrows, and stubby hands.
O: Birth weight was 3950 g, length 51 cm, occipital frontal circumference 34.5 cm, and Apgar scores were 9/9. Birth height was 3940 g, height 51 cm with occipitian frontal circumference at 34.2 cm, Apgar score was 9/10. Recent neuropsychological evaluation at age 9 showed mild learning disability, specifically dysgraphias. Brain MRI and angiography indicated an altered signal near the capsular lenticular structures and the head of the caudate nucleus, suggesting a hamartoma. No molecular diagnosis was found for Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS).
A: The primary diagnosis is Smith-magenis Syndrome, characterized by obesity, dysmorphia, and dysmorphism. Differential diagnoses could include other genetic disorders, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with the healthcare provider to monitor the patient's growth and development and to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle to manage obesity and other symptoms will be provided. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of MS is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor growth and developmental progress.

S: The patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain and obstipation persisting for 24 hours, without vomiting or fever. The patient has a history of splenectomy 12 years ago due to a traumatic rupture of the spleen.
O: Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the patient is afebrile, with distended abdomen and diffuse tenderness. Blood tests show a high white blood cell count of 23040/mm³, normal hepatic and pancreatic enzymes. CT scan reveals multiple splenic nodules in the left upper quadrant with small bowel distention and air-fluid levels mostly in the jejunum. Exploratory laparotomy revealed more than 50 splenic fibres, with a splenic tissue on the mesentery of the ileum, vascularization from the splenic artery and vein, and another splenic splenule on mesosigmoid, causing external compression and obstruction of the small bowel and colon. Pathologic studies confirmed splenosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is intestinal obstruction secondary to splenoproliferative therapy (ASTPR), evidenced by the presence of splenic tissues and vascularization. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splinosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications related to splenic pathology. The plan includes regular follow-up visits to assess the resolution of the obstruction and to manage any potential complications. Education on the importance of monitoring for signs of infection or recurrence is crucial. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the intestinal obstruction is recommended.

S: The patient is an 86-year-old female presenting with dyspnea on exertion. She reports difficulty breathing when attempting to do any activity. She has a history of severe acute myocardial infarction (AS) with diffuse left ventricular hypertrophy and Maron type III hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
O: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed severe aortic valve area of 0.58 cm2, peak velocity of 4.0 m/s, diffuse left Ventricular hypertrauma, and moderate mitral regurgitation (MR). During a Valsalva maneuver, the peak velocity was 2.9 m/sec, mean pressure gradient was 32 mmHg, and a beta-blocker (bisoprolol 1.25 mg/day) was administered, reducing SAM to a mild degree. Coronary angiography confirmed the first major septal branch perfusion in the basal septum.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute mitral valve stenosis (AS), complicated by Maron Type III hypertension. The patient's severe AS and MR are likely contributing factors to her current condition.
P: The management plan includes implantation of a 23 mm SAPIEN 3 valve via transfemoral approach with general anesthesia and transesophageal echocoardiography guidance, under continuous beta-blocking. An emergent ASA will be used to manage AS and prevent further complications. Continuous monitoring of the patient's hemodynamic status will be necessary to ensure no recurrence of AS. Further consultations with cardiology and surgery may be necessary depending on the progression of AS and response to treatment.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old male, presented for routine outpatient review for monitoring of deficiency of adenosine deaminase 2 (DADA2). He reported a 24-hour history of nausea and vomiting, followed by acute, moderate right-sided testicular pain, but no fever. He has a history of transient neutropenia as an infant and hepatosplenomegaly as a viral infection. He was referred to our center with a lower limb rash considered cutaneous PAN. Genetic testing revealed homozygous c.139G > C mutation (p.G47R) of ADA2, and absent serum ADA2 enzyme activity. The patient's parents were heterozygous for the same mutation, and there was no family history of vasculitis, autoimmunity, or immunodeficiency.
O: Genetic testing for DADA2 showed homozygosity for the c.138G >C mutation, absence of undetectable ADA2 enzymes, and normal complete blood count with normal differential white cell counts, renal and liver function, and CRP levels. Laboratory tests showed SAA 8.2 mg/L (reference range [RR < 10 mg/dL]), CRP < 5 mg (RR < 20 mg/mL), ESR < 10 mm/hour, normal coagulation screen, negative viral hepatitis screen, normal immunoglobulin G, A, and M levels, and negative screening for coeliac disease.
A: The primary diagnosis is DADA1 deficiency, confirmed by laboratory results and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute symptoms such as viral hepatitis or autoimmune disorders, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the management of DADA and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of Dada2, with regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The plan includes regular monitoring of the patient's condition and laboratory results to ensure no recurrence or complications. Patient education regarding the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms is crucial. Referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Regular follow-ups with oncology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to manage DADA3 deficiency.

S: The patient, referred for progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis, reports difficulty breathing from one side of the nose and frequent nosebleeds for several months. The patient denies experiencing anosmia, nasal discharge, nasal congestion, sneezing, facial pain, or headache. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes.
O: Physical examination revealed a large, left-sided nasal polypoidal mass with smooth overlying mucosa occluding the whole left nasal cavity. Ear, nose, throat, head, neck examinations were normal. No palpable lymphadenopathy was noted. A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses with contrast showed a left anterior lobulated nasal mass of undetermined origin at the level of the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum with mild heterogeneous contrast enhancement and bone remodeling. Histological examination of the mass revealed three fragments of soft to firm tan-gray tissue, positive for vimentin and S100, negative for desmin, NSE, and SMA.
A: The primary diagnosis is schwannoma of the nasopharyngeal cavity, confirmed by histopathological examination and histopathology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal obstruction such as malignancy or malignant neoplasms. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful removal of the tumor.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-up care to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. Patient education on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular monitoring for any signs of recurrence is crucial. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the underlying conditions is recommended.

S: The patient reports no symptoms of dysphagia, epigastric fullness, or gastroesophageal reflux. The patient has a history of hepatolithiasis and underwent hepatic left lateral segmentectomy at age 50.
O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory tests including carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 were normal. Endoscopy revealed a sliding hiatal hernia and a 10 mm elevated mass at the EG junction. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed mixed echogenicity and a mass with mixed echinogenicity invading the submucosal layer. Upper gastrointestinal imaging indicated an elevated lesion at the esophageally junction. Biopsy confirmed differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. CT tomography showed no lymph node metastasis or distant metastasis.
A: The primary diagnosis is esophagal cancer, cT1bN0M0 cStage I, with a secondary diagnosis of Barrett's epithelium. Differential diagnosis initially included lymphoma, which was ruled out by imaging and biopsy.
P: The management plan includes proximal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection and jejunal interposition. Post-surgery, the patient will be monitored closely for any signs of lymphovascular invasion. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any arising complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a 32-year-old female in her 39th week of pregnancy, presented with severe dyspnoea and chest pain. She reports no similar symptoms or hospitalizations in the past.
O: Initial diagnosis was pulmonary embolic disease, treated with massive anticoagulant therapy. Due to the patient's full-term pregnancy, an emergent caesarean delivery was performed due to the urgency of her condition. Apgar index was 3, 6, and 9 at minutes 1, 3, and 5, respectively. Microscopic examination of the placenta showed less than 10% of the cotyledons had infarcts.
