P: The management plan includes continued supportive care with supportive care and supportive care for COVID19. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, and overall health. The management of COVID will include supportive care, supportive care in the ICU, and continued monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old hypertensive and diabetic Saudi male presenting with sudden bilateral painless visual loss five days ago. He reports a history of bilateral temporal headaches starting one year ago, which have been occurring intermittently. He denies experiencing diplopia, transient visual loss, jaw claudication, myalgia, or other constitutional, motor, or sensory symptoms.
O: Physical examination revealed normal blood pressure, heart rate, and temperature, with pupils dilated to seven millimeters each without reaction to light. Fundoscopy showed normal appearing discs and retina. Motor, sensory, and coordination examination was normal. CRP was elevated at 132 mg/L and ESR was 40 mm/hr. MRI of the brain showed a lesion in the right optic nerve, suggesting acute ischemia. The ophthalmic arteries were not visualized bilaterally by contrast MRI.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral Posterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (PION) due to giant cell arteritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bilateral headaches, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation.
P: Initiated treatment with intravenous Methylprednisolone 1000 mg for five days and daily prednisololone 60 mg orally. Biopsied a 2 cm segment of the left temporal artery and pathological findings confirmed GCA. Plan to continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are essential to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient, with a history of TRUS-guided extended sextant biopsy three years ago, presented with an elevated PSA of 8.98 ng/mL. The patient reports mild symptoms and an AUA urinary symptom score of 14. No history of erectile dysfunction.
O: MP-MRI revealed patchy diffuse abnormal signal in the right posterolateral peripheral zone, suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia nodularity. MRI/TRUS fusion-targeted biopsy identified GS 4+3 adenocarcinoma in 80% of specimen cores sampled from the posterior peripheral zone. The biopsy confirmed GS 4+,3 adeno-associated prostate cancer.
A: The primary diagnosis is prostate SBRT, with differential diagnoses including malignancy and metastatic disease. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the imaging results and biopsy findings.
P: The management plan includes proceeding with prostate S BRT, which will involve placing TRUS fiducial markers in the prostate, followed by radiation therapy planning CT scan two weeks post marker insertion. The treatment plan will involve CT and MRI fusion to generate target volumes of the prostate gland and high-risk intraprostatic lesion. The radiation oncologist and urologist will review the treatment simulation CT and MP- MRI, and target volumes will be determined based on imaging and target volume. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the treatment response and manage any complications.

S: The patient's mother reports a difficult gestation period with IUGR, including pre-eclampsia and hyperemesis. The patient was born at 38 weeks via cesarean section, weighing 2.49 kg, with complications including hypotonia, laryngomalacia requiring supplemental oxygen, aspiration episodes requiring Nissen and g-tube placement, and prolonged growth failure. The mother also reports dysmorphic features such as broad forehead, midface hypoplasia with prognathism, depressed nasal bridge, hypertelorism, synophrys, deep set eyes, downslanting palpebral fissures, tongue protrusion, occipital flattening, and small hands. At age 3, the patient exhibited ventricular prominence without hydrocephalus and diminutive geni and corpus callosum, moderate generalized slowing and occasional independent left and right lateralized slow waves during sleep, with bihemispheric dysfunction but no epileptiform activity. EKG and echocardiogram were normal. At 5 years of age, she was significantly delayed, smiling, and able to speak 3-5 words infrequently.
O: At age 5, she exhibited myopic astigmatism in both eyes requiring glasses, intermittent alternating exotropia, and high frequency, low amplitude horizontal nystagmus. She was unable to cooperate with eye chart testing, but was able to fix and follow an object with each eye. She also exhibits idiopathic hypertension, precocious puberty, obstructive sleep apnea, eosinophilic gastritis, seizures, hypohydrosis with overheating, recurrent fever of unknown origin, and intellectual and motor disability.
A: The primary diagnosis is idiopathy with associated conditions including idiopathsic hypertension and precocious growth apnea. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of delayed speech and motor impairments, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient and her ocular function, regular follow-ups to assess the progression of her condition, and potential treatment options. The family will be educated on the importance of regular monitoring of her ophthalmologic status and response to treatment. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for specialized care and a geneticist for further evaluation and management of her complex medical conditions is recommended. Education regarding the nature of her conditions and the implications of her diagnosis will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports difficulty breathing and chest pressure. The patient underwent echocardiography to check for cardiac tamponade. Post-surgery, the patient experienced tachycardia and dyspnea. Postoperatively, the tumor was identified as a monophasic synovial sarcoma with SYT-SSX2 transcript. Postoperative findings included no residual tumor, but imaging studies showed a recurrent pericardial tumor involving both atria and left pulmonary veins.
O: Postoperative histology confirmed the diagnosis of a monovial tumor, with no evidence of residual tumor. Postprocedure showed no residual tumors, but a recent CT scan indicated extensive regrowth of the tumor.
A: The primary diagnosis is monophasisic synvial sarcoidoma (SYT-SSSX) with complications including multiple atria, pulmonary veins, heart, great vessels, left bronchus, esophagus, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. The prognosis is guarded due to the recurrent nature of the disease.
P: The treatment plan included chemotherapy with epirubicin and ifosfamide for 6 cycles over 4 months, followed by intensity-modulated radiotherapy for 54 Gy over 25 sessions in 2 months. The plan included continuation of chemotherapy with cisplatinum and docetaxel for 6 cycle over 4 and 54 Gy for 25 sessions over 2 months, with further radiotherapy if necessary. The family was advised to discuss the patient's situation and preferences with the family and make necessary arrangements.

S: The patient reports a painless, slowly growing mass on the right hard palate that was noticed a few weeks ago. The patient denies any significant medical issues or recent medications. No family history of similar lesions or significant health problems in immediate family members.
O: Physical examination revealed a yellowish, yellowish exophytic mass extending to the soft palate, measuring approximately 5 × 4 cm and measuring oval-shaped. The mass is compressible with numerous small blood vessels, and it does not blanch or feel pulsatile upon palpation. A 5 mm incisional punch biopsy identified a benign salivary gland tumor with a significant adipose tissue component. Surgical excision of the lesion was performed, and pathology confirmed pleomorphic adenoma with significant adiposome component.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign Salivary Mammal Cancer (LSC) with associated adipose and adipose tissues. Differential diagnoses considered included lipoma, cystic lesion, soft tissue tumor, and pleomorphic tumor. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical excision and absence of recurrences.
P: The management plan includes referral to oral surgery for complete surgical removal of the salivaries. Post-operative follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and ensure no recurrence of the malignancy. Education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a recipient of a living donor renal transplant 10 years ago due to glomerulonephritis, reports recent symptoms of swelling in the legs and face, and difficulty breathing. The patient has a history of severe and difficult to control hypertension.
O: Physical examination revealed an audible bruit on the right side of the lower abdomen. Ultrasound, CT angiography, and catheter angiographic scans showed a high flow arterial venous fistula within the transplanted organ. Ultratopic ultrasound and CT angioplography showed a 12 mm diameter of the main transplant artery with relative narrowing at the origin, ectatic and tortuous iliac vessels. The arterial artery and veins were aneurysmal with extreme tortuosity, with a maximum diameter of 12 mm and relative narrowing of the arterial vessels.
A: The primary diagnosis is decompensated heart failure, likely due to high flow AVF. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute heart failure such as renal failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and biochemistry findings.
P: The management plan includes performing super-selective renal transplant embolization under general anesthesia to control haemodynamic status. Both arterial and venous punctures will be made during the procedure, with the contralateral left common femoral artery punctured under ultrasound guidance, and a 6F sheath placed in the right common artery to reduce inflow and pressure into the AVM. The procedure will involve the insertion of a 6mmx40mm angioplastasty balloon and placement of an angioplasty balloon at the arterio-venous communication site. Post-operative care will include monitoring for signs of complications and managing any potential complications.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of mild paraparesis of the lower limbs since birth, bilateral fronto-basal contusional bleedings, perifocal edema, and blood deposits along the falx and the right tentorium. He also has a subdural hematoma with subarachnoidal fractions extending along the right fronto–parieto-temporal convexity. He has a significant medical history including mild paraparesis due to birth trauma, poliomyelitis, cerebral palsy, bilateral hip dysplasia, chronic alcoholism, arterial hypertension, inguinal hernia, reflux esophagitis, bougienage of the esophagus due to cardia stenosis, right-sided hip total endoprosthesis, and deep venous thrombosis of the right lower limb, leading to bilateral pulmonary embolism at age 66 years. He experienced generalized tonic clonic seizures, respiratory insufficiency requiring intubation, and artificial ventilation. He was diagnosed with hypothyroidism, diagnosed with TSH at 6.
O: Initial treatment included antiepileptic medications (levetiracetam 2000 mg/d, midazolam 7 mg/h), norepinephrine, clonidine, ketamine, propofol, and sufentanil, which were discontinued due to increased intracranial pressure. Subsequent treatment included intravenous vitamin-B1 (300 mg/dL) and oxazepam, which led to megaloblastic anemia. The patient was transferred to another intensive care unit for further evaluation and management.
A: The primary diagnosis is traumatic brain injury with complications including bilateral frontosomal contusional bleedingings, subdurability, and bougainvillea due to cardiac arrest. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of traumatic brain injuries, but these are less likely given the history and current findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's complex medical history and the potential for complications.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the brain injury and seizure activity, supportive care, and supportive care for the patient and his family. Further consultations with a neurologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progression of the condition and response to treatment. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with intrathyroid thymic carcinoma three years ago, presented with progressive anterior neck swelling and hoarseness of voice for the past one month. Recently, the patient reports worsening voice and shortness of breath, particularly when lying flat, but no difficulty swallowing. The patient has a history of left hemithyroidectomy at another institution and refused adjuvant radiotherapy. The current symptoms include worsening voice, shortness in breath, and intermittent haemoptysis.
O: Clinical examination revealed a left supraclavicular mass measuring 2x2 cm and an irregular hard mass on the anterior aspect of the neck measuring 3x4 cm, with left vocal cord palsy and an intraluminal mass occupying a third of the tracheal lumen. Contrast computed tomography (CECT) of neck and thorax showed a lobulated hypodense soft tissue mass measuring 4.3x3.9x5.2 cm occupying the left thyroid bed from the C7/T1 to the T2/T3 vertebral level, displacing the left common carotid artery and internal jugular vein laterally, and multiple matted lymph nodes at the retrosternal area.
A: The primary diagnosis is left thyroid carcinoma with associated complications including left vocal cords palsy, intralominal mass displacement, and a soft tissue tumor at the thyroid. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neck swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the tumor's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the results of the needle aspiration cytology. Patient education regarding the nature of the tumor, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a 7-year-old with a history of diabetes diagnosed at 7 years old and treated with insulin glargine, reports experiencing vomiting and abdominal pain approximately 12 hours ago. The patient also has hypothyroidism and has had 2 previous ICU admissions due to diabetic ketoacidosis.
O: Physical examination revealed distended abdomen with diffuse pain but no peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests showed a pH of 7.25, bicarbonate of 10 mEq/dL, BE of -14.9, and blood glucose of 153 mg/dL. A positive for ketonemia was noted. Beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin levels were 98,928 IU/L. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a gestational sac with an embryo inside. Treatment included reanimation with parenteral crystalloids at 250 mL/h, isotonic saline solutions, and polyelectrolyte solutions. Total fluid intake was 7,000 mL/24 hours, and urinary volume was 2,750 mL/ 24 hours. Continuous insulin infusion was 100 IU in 48 hours, with improvement noted in pH to 7.47, bacarbonate to 22 mEQ/dL (normal range: 200-450 mE/dL), and normal blood glucose levels.
A: The primary diagnosis is normoglycemic diabetic ketoeacidosis with complications including hypothyrocystic ovary syndrome and hypothyroliferative disorder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoathletic symptoms such as hyperglycemia or hypoarthritis, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and lab results.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and blood sugar levels. The plan includes continuation of insulin glarcine therapy and regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient’s condition and overall health status. Further consultations with a hematologist and a dietitian may be necessary to manage diabetes and manage hypothyroxinemia.

S: The patient, a 10-month-old male, presents with a chief complaint of joint contractures and skin issues since birth. The patient reports dark brown and black spots on his knuckles, ankles, back, and neck. He has a history of arthrogryposis treated with physical therapy, leading to a femur fracture, persistent protein-losing enteropathy, and weight loss. He also exhibits pearly, erythematous papules and indurated plaques on his back and posterior scalp, and multiple coalescent skin-colored, indurated papules involving the perineum.
O: Physical examination revealed significant joint contracture in wrists, knees, hips, and ankles. Oral mucosa showed gingival hyperplasia and generalized sclerodermatous changes in the left lower extremity. Skin also shows pearly papules, indurate plaques, symmetrically on his posterior scalp and similar indurated papules on the posterior scalp. Perianal area showed multiple coalescence skin- colored, induration papules.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe malnutrition, evidenced by the patient's severe malnutrition and the presence of multiple electrolyte abnormalities including nonanion gap acidosis, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoalbuminemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin changes and electrolyte imbalances.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the child's condition and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Education will be provided to the parents about the condition and the importance of regular follow-up visits to monitor the condition. Referral to a pediatric orthopedic specialist for specialized care and nutritional support will be arranged. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as needed. Education regarding the condition, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be reinforced.

S: The patient reports experiencing frequent palpitations over the past 3 months, accompanied by discomfort. The patient has been on anti-arrhythmic drugs such as mexiletine, propafenone, and metoprolol, which have not been effective. No history of cardiovascular disease was reported.
O: Physical examination revealed a complete left bundle branch block, inferior frontal axis, and precordial lead transition zone greater than V3. The QRS in lead I was positive, and the R-wave in lead II was higher than that in lead III. Electrocardiography showed bigeminy with stable coupling intervals, but sometimes the coupling intervals varied and multiplied. 24-hour dynamic ECG showed more than 32,000 PVCs. Electrophysiological evaluation showed bipolar and unipolar electrograms, filtered at 30-500 Hz and 0.05-500Hz, respectively. Three-dimensional electromagnetic mapping (CARTO) and ablation using a 7-French saline-irrigated ablation catheter with 3.5-mm distal electrode and 2-5-2 mm interelectrode spacing. Activation mapping and pace-mapping were combined to identify the origin of the ventricular premature contractions.
A: The primary diagnosis is ventricular preterm labor (PVC) with associated complications including ventricular hyperthermia (VVP) and potential cardiac involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac arrhythmias, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and the effectiveness of the ablation procedure. Maintain current medications and monitor cardiac function closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of PVCs and potential heart failure.

S: The patient, a non-smoker and non-alcoholic, presents with a ten-day history of swelling in the right leg, sudden weakness in the left half of the body, worsening over the past two days. The pain is so severe that the patient cannot move his right leg properly. The patient also reports decreased urine output and red-colored urine. No history of hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, or recurrent throat infections. No family history of RHD, severe MS, and AF.
O: Physical examination shows blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 77 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and body temperature 37.1°C orally. No pallor, icterus, clubbing, splinter hemorrhages, rashes, or cyanosis. Initial heart sound (S1) is variable.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent throat infection, likely exacerbated by non-compliance with prescribed medications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain, diaphoresis, shortness of breath, loin pain, nausea, or vomiting, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes discontinuation of medications and referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the underlying conditions. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms or complications. Patient education regarding the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment plan is crucial. Referral to a pulmonologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, a 26-month-old girl, was admitted to Hazrat-E-Masoumeh Hospital in Qom in April 2017 with unknown persistent fever, anorexia, and general weakness for four months. She reported bruises on her abdomen and legs a month prior to admission. Her physicians suspected anemia and leukemia.
O: Physical examination revealed mild enlargement of the spleen and reduction in blood elements. Serological tests were negative. Bone marrow aspiration showed pancytopenia but no blast cells. Amastigotes of the Leishman-Donovan parasite were observed in bone marrow macrophages. DAT test was positive (>1:3200), leading to a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.
A: The primary diagnosis is visceral leishymaniasis, evidenced by the absence of blast cells and positive DAT tests. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and anemia, but these are less likely given the negative serological results.
P: The management plan included Amphotericin-B treatment with a dose of 1 mg/kg for 21 days, followed by a follow-up of four days. The patient's fever and general condition improved, and the patient's blood cell count increased at the next month. The plan includes regular monitoring of her condition and reporting any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old nonsmoker with no specific medical history. She reports no significant past medical history but was referred to the Thoracic Surgery Department due to an abnormal chest X-ray radiograph revealing a left pulmonary hilar nodule. Bronchoscopic biopsy confirmed SCLC (c-T2aN1M0; Stage IIA, Fig. b). The patient underwent thoracoscopic lobectomy 3 weeks post-chemotherapy. Post-surgical immunohistochemical findings of lung tissue showed yp-T1N0M0: Stage IA. Approximately 4 years post-treatment, pro-gastrin-releasing peptide (ProGRP) levels did not decrease. Pelvic MRI showed a solid tumor in the left ovary with uneven contrast effect.
O: Initial chemotherapy with chemotherapy (60 mg/m2 cisplatin (day 1) + 60 mg/M2 irinotecan (day 8, 15)] and radiotherapy (total 36 Gy) was discontinued due to low ProGRP levels. Recent PET-CT revealed an abnormal accumulation in the right ovary, with an uneven contrast in contrast.
A: The primary diagnosis is a solid ovarian tumor, likely stage IIA. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the tumor and the absence of metastasis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ovarian tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy findings.
P: The management plan includes referral to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department for further evaluation and treatment planning. The patient will be referred for further management and further evaluation. Further consultations with oncology and oncological specialists may be necessary depending on the progression and response to treatment. Patient education regarding the nature of her condition and the importance of follow-up care will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic alcoholism and cirrhosis with a Child score A, reports noticing a growing mass in the oral cavity and a mass on the left adrenal gland during surveillance. The patient also mentions a mass detected during cirrhotic controls.
O: Physical examination revealed an exophytic lesion approximately 10 cm in the left mandible. Laboratory tests including serologic tests, AFP, carcinoembryonic antigen levels, and PETT-CT scans were performed to assess liver changes. Biopsies of the adrenal and mandible lesions showed hepatoid differentiation in carcinoma, suggestive of metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic HCC with liver involvement. Differential diagnosis initially included hepatitis B and C panels, which were ruled out by imaging. The absence of a liver tumor on imaging raises the possibility of an adrenocortical carcinoma with hepatoid progression.
P: Plan to perform an exploratory laparoscopy with liver biopsy to explore the liver and histologic and immunophenotypic findings for infiltrative HCC. The plan includes monitoring the patient's response to treatment and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. Further consultations with oncology and hepatology may be necessary depending on the progression of HCC and the patient’s response to therapy.

S: The patient, admitted to the hospital for unconsciousness followed by melena, reported sudden onset of black, tarry stools. The patient was hemodynamically stable upon admission but experienced hemodynamic instability leading to intubation and polytransfusion.
O: On admission, the patient's hemoglobin level was 12 g/dl, slightly below the normal range of 14-18 g/dL. An upper endoscopy revealed a stomach full of fresh blood without esophageal varices or ulcers. An angiography showed a saccular aneurysm of 2.5 cm on the distal third of the splenic artery, with irregular contours. A CT scan identified a distal pancreatic tumor abutting the posterior gastric wall, leading to a secondary rupture of the gastric cavity. A new gastroscopy showed a posterior subcardial perforation. Histological examination confirmed invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
A: The primary diagnosis is invasive pancreatiac ductal ductal carcinoma of the gallbladder, likely secondary to the tumor. Differential diagnosis initially included spasticity, which was ruled out by imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the tumor and the potential for further complications.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and family to ensure no recurrence of the cancer. A multidisciplinary team discussion will be conducted to determine the best course of treatment, including surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, depending on the response to treatment. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a history of a high-energy multifragmentary compound fracture in a road traffic accident 4 months ago, classified as Gustilo-Anderson Type 3A. Post-accident, the patient experienced soft tissue injuries treated with a below-knee, weight-bearing Sarmiento cast. The patient has been able to walk comfortably and return to work as a carpet fitter. However, the nail fractured at the junction between the valve and metal fins, leading to the removal of the nail.
O: Initial surgical intervention included a retrograde 10 mm x 340 mm expandable nail, which was successfully removed 9 months post-procedure. Radiological examination revealed calcaneal resorption around the neck of the right distal tibial nail. Attempts to remove the nail with grabbers and large diameter crown drills were unsuccessful, and the nail split like an inverted cone. The nail was eventually removed piecemeal through a Midas Rex® burr.
A: The primary diagnosis is post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with complications including calcaneum resorptive and fracture. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful removal and resolution of the non-union.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the healing of the tibia and ensure proper healing of its tibia. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate medical attention is crucial. Referral to a specialist in orthopedic rehabilitation is recommended for further evaluation and management of PTSD.

S: The patient, a 13-month-old girl, reports a recent injury from a house fire. She has a history of third-degree injuries on 73% of her total body surface area and an open joint injury. The patient has been using the knee immobilizer for the past eight weeks.
O: Physical examination revealed third- and open joint injuries on the right knee, treated with four skin grafting procedures. At an eight-month follow-up, PT/OT showed range of motion within normal limits, and a 5/5 motor strength. Post-SEF, joint instability was noted, requiring eight weeks of knee immobilization use. No long-term complications were recorded.
A: The primary diagnosis is a third degree injury from the house fire, likely secondary to the use of a skin graft. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint instability such as infection or infection. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of complications requiring additional surgeries.
P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the healing of the knee and assess the effectiveness of the immobilizer. No additional surgeries are planned at this time, and the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with orthopedics and possibly a physical therapist may be necessary to manage the joint instability and improve mobility.

S: The patient, a 7-year-old male, presents with severe intellectual disability, speech delay, and convulsive seizures. He has been experiencing these symptoms for quite some time. There is no family history of intellectual disability in the patient's mother or other known relatives.
O: Recent blood samples from the patient were extracted using a High Pure PCR template purification kit. DNA analysis using a 2100 Bioanalyzer DNA chip was performed. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of the whole exomes of the son was performed using a NextSeq 500 System using a high-throughput kit. All exomes were sequenced with 160 × coverage, with at least 93% of the sequences having a minimum of 20 × coverage.
A: The primary diagnosis is ALS, evidenced by the presence of germ-line variants in the NGS data. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intellectual impairment, but these are less likely given the sequencing results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the sensitivity of the genetic findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient and the parent's symptoms. The patient is advised to report any changes or concerns immediately. Further diagnostic workup will be necessary to refine the diagnosis and treatment plan. Education on the nature of ALS and its implications will be provided to the parents. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient’s condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 25-year-old female, reports an increasing vulvar swelling that began as a small swelling but has been growing progressively. She also experiences dull aching pain approximately 3 months ago, accompanied by micturition and dysuria. She denies any history of genital cutting and sewing and has no family history of similar illness. She has no history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or similar illnesses.
O: Physical examination reveals a pulse of 82, respiratory rate of 18, temperature of 36°C, conjunctiva pink and sclera non-icteric. Chest is clear and resonant, and heart sounds are normal. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness, guarding, rigidity, palpable mass, or organomegaly. Genitourinary system shows an 18 cm by 12 cm, fluctuant, multi-lobulated, mobile, non-tender right labia majora mass involving the mons pubis and stretching the ventral skin of the urethra. The overlying skin is normal, and the two labial edges are fused at their cranial part. No abnormal findings in the vagina, cervix, uterus, inguinal lymph nodes, musculoskeletal and neurological examinations, and normal neurological examinations are noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is vulvar enlargement, likely secondary to a congenital malformation of the vulvar mass. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal swelling such as malignancy or other congenital anomalies. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and response to the treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the atrophied vulva mass. The patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of adhering to the surgical plan. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the procedure, expected outcomes, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, currently in the IOP Treatment Program, presents with complaints of depressed mood, lack of enjoyment of activities, sleep disturbances, poor concentration, occasional suicidal thoughts, coordination problems, ataxia, speech impairment, swallowing difficulties, spasticity, and muscle atrophy. The patient uses a motorized wheelchair due to worsening condition, with limited physical mobility due to SCA1. He reports passive death wishes at least once a week but no suicidal plans.
O: Physical mobility is a significant impact on his self-esteem and overall mood. Laboratory tests including hemogram, liver function tests, total protein, vitamin B12, folic acid, T3, T4, and TSH are within normal limits. The Beck Depression Inventory score is 23, indicating moderate depression. He has started sertraline 50 mg per day.
A: The primary diagnosis is major depressive disorder, evidenced by the patient's symptoms of depression, mood, and symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of depression such as motor neurone disease or other neurological disorders, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes continued medication for depression and cognitive behavioral therapy, including sertranine, which has been effective for managing depression and mood. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The treatment plan will be adjusted based on the progression of symptoms and response to therapy. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to treatment will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a severe injury to the right hand following a mincing machine accident. He describes the injury as severe and describes the pain as intense. No other medical history or comorbidities were reported.
O: Physical examination revealed a severed deformity at the level of the right wrist, extensive soft tissue crush, and an open wrist fracture. MESS score was 8. The patient's Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is 8, indicating a comminuted fracture of the bones in the right arm. No special medical history was reported. A wound infection with Enterobacter cloacae was identified on the fifth day post-second surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a comminaluted fracture in the left wrist, likely secondary to a mincedure machine accident, with differential diagnoses including other causes of wrist fractures and fractures. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful repair of the amputation stump and the absence of bacterial growth.
P: The management plan includes a wrist disarticulation procedure to address the comminalised fracture. The prosthesis will be designed with open-source design and customized to suit the child's needs. The child will be educated about the potential benefits of the prosthesis and the potential risks associated with it. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, referred by the neurosurgical team, reports experiencing a sudden and severe headache for about one week. The patient describes the music as familiar songs, increased volume, and distorted sounds. No hallucinations, delusions, or other changes in consciousness were reported post-surgical evacuation.
O: Physical examination and noncontrast CT brain scan showed no neurological deficits. Initial treatment with quetiapine 25 mg was initiated one year ago, and the patient has been symptom-free for one year.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent auditory hallucinations, likely related to intraventricular and intracranial haemorrhages. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of auditory hallucinations such as hallucinations or delusions, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical history and imaging findings.
P: Continue the current regimen of quetidine 25 mg, which has been effective. Monitor for any recurrence of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and potential side effects. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor for any signs of recurrence or new symptoms.

S: The patient, a male with a history of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation for glioblastoma, reports experiencing lumbago and disturbance of consciousness in the evening. He has no history of pneumonia or pneumococcal vaccination.
O: Initial treatment with 4.5 g piperazine/tazobactam every 8 hours was initiated. Blood tests revealed pneumococcus in blood culture, which led to a change in the regimen to 2 g ABPC every 6 hours. Subsequent MRI showed purulent spondylitis, which was treated with antimicrobial drug treatment for a total of 9 weeks. No recurrences were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent lumbar spondyitis secondary to antimicrobial therapy, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever and infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The treatment plan included antimicrobial treatment for the fever, followed by further monitoring and management of the infection. The patient and his wife were treated with a 13-valent vaccine and a 23-vitrocessed vaccine, which were administered over a period of time. The treatment was followed by administration of antibiotics for the infection, which have been largely successful. Further monitoring of the patient and wife's response to the treatment and potential recurrence is recommended. Further consultations with oncology and infectious disease specialists are recommended to ensure compliance and prevent recurrence.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, presented with a recent seizure and loss of consciousness. She reported no significant comorbidities prior to the seizure.
O: Physical examination revealed a vascularity-rich tumor in the head of the pancreas, measuring 20 mm in diameter. A computed tomography scan showed a 20 mm vascularity in diameter tumor, 20 cm in diameter, in the right pancreatic head. Parathyroid hormone levels were slightly elevated at 66.0 pg/ml (normal range: 0.5-1.2 pg/mL), and adjusted serum calcium level was 10.3 mg/dL (normal ranges: <0.5 mg/dl). Parathyroscopic ultrasound did not reveal any parathyroid tumors.
A: The primary diagnosis is insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism in the left pancreast, complicated by a vascularization-rich, non-surgical tumor in a pancreastic head. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pancreatic tumors, but these were ruled out through imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes extended surgical procedures like pancreatoduodenectomy and open abdominal surgery. The patient will be monitored for any signs of complications and will be educated on the importance of follow-up care. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: philip, a 13-year-old male with a history of hypertension, presents with right elbow pain, mild pain with flexion and extension, and a bruise on the elbow. He reports that the pain started about a week ago while playing lacrosse with his kids. He denies any history of injury and has been taking lisinopril for pain relief. He also mentions a recent fall during a lacrosse game.

O: Right elbow exam shows pain to palpation of the olecranon area of the posterior elbow, swelling, inflammation, bruise, and pain radiating down the forearm, radiating up the forearm. He is currently on 20 mg of metformin daily. He has been on a diet of low salt and a low salt diet.
A: The primary diagnosis is right elbow contusion, likely secondary to a fall during lacrosse. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of elbow pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Prescribe eight hundred mg of ibuprofen twice daily and ice three times daily for twenty minutes at a time to alleviate swelling and pain. Advise patient to avoid salt and avoid adding salt to food. Schedule follow-up in 2 weeks to monitor blood sugar levels and adjust medication as necessary. Educate patient on the importance of adherence to the prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications.

S: The patient, a nonsmoker with a history of asthma and Crohn's disease, presented with a four-day history of generalised abdominal pain postcolonoscopy. He reported nausea and slightly reduced stoma output. He denies any known drug allergies.
O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 117 bpm, blood pressure of 128/81 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15, and oxygen saturation of 98% on air. A large mass overlying the hernia to the left of the midline was noted, with a mass ballotable with crepitus, slightly tenderness, and a cough impulse. Chest was clear to auscultation, and GCS was 15/15. Blood tests showed elevated C-reactive protein at 219 mg/L (normal 0–5 mg/dL).
A: The primary diagnosis is a complex hernia with complications including sepsis, abdominal wall breakdown, and abdominal compartment syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of vital signs and blood counts. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progression of symptoms and response to treatment. Patient education on signs of potential complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, recently diagnosed with stage IIIA (pT2N2M0) poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, underwent a McKeown minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE) for middle third esophageal cancer. Postoperative complications included cervical esophagogastric anastomotic leak, dysphonia, and swallow dysfunction, leading to aspiration pneumonia. The patient reports difficulty swallowing and speaking.
O: Initial histological examination revealed stage III poorly differentiated cell carcinomas with multiple recurrences in the right paratracheal lymph node, anterior chest wall, and right adrenal gland. Post-surgery, the patient experienced severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspnea, followed by acute onset of severe abdominal pain and weakness. A CT scan showed a hernia and lung collapse, with a large defect (8.5 x 5 cm) of the left hemidiaphragm leading to an ipsilateral massive lung collapse.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIIIIA poorly differentiated carcinoma of the esophagus, with complications including aspiration pneumonia and a herniation of the small bowel, transverse colon, and greater omentum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain or dyspneuritis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and adherence to prescribed therapies will be provided. Referral to a gastroenterologist for specialized care and a pulmonologist for ongoing management of esophagesis is recommended.

S: The patient is a 24-year-old autistic nonverbal male presenting with increasing lethargy and frequent urination over the past few days. He reports several episodes of nonbloody vomiting. He denies any history of fall, prolonged immobilization, medication overdose, or increased physical activities.
O: Upon admission, the patient's vitals were stable. Physical examination revealed confusion, dehydration, and letharginess. Laboratory tests revealed hypernatremia, highly elevated blood glucose levels, elevated serum creatinine (5.29 mg/dl), low bicarbonate (13 mmol/L), hyperphosphatemia, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, and large amounts of urine blood. Serum osmolality was 395 mmol/kg (reference range 275–295 mmol/ kg), and serum acetone was negative. Urinalysis was significant for ketones, proteinuria, high glucose, and dark tea-colored urine. Urine blood analysis showed significant amounts of red blood cells. CT of the abdomen was consistent with pancreatitis, with amylase and lipase levels normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with complications including acute pancreatitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperglycemia such as pancreatitis or other metabolic disorders, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient and his condition, adjusting insulin and diabetic diet as necessary, and supportive care for diabetes type 2. The patient will continue to be monitored in the ICU with regular follow-ups to manage his condition and adjust his diet as needed. Education on recognizing signs of pancreatitis and the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports experiencing epigastric pain and bloating in the upper part of the stomach. The patient has a history of pancreatitis.
O: Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a 6 x 5 cm cystic lesion without a solid component in the pancreatic tail, with no pancreatitis history in the anamnesis. An upper abdomen MRI showed a cyst lesion with calcified walls and a hypointense corpus lesion invading the splenic vein. CA 19-9 was elevated at 1012 IU/ml. PET-CT scan showed a focally increased FDG metabolization with a maximum SUVmax of 11.8, indicating a Type V hydatid cyst. Pathology confirmed an intermediate grade ductal pancreatic adenocarcinoma with a clear surgical margin.
A: The primary diagnosis is a type V hydatinid pancreatic cyst with associated pancreatitis and associated carcinoma. Differential diagnosis initially included other cystic pancreatic lesions, but these were ruled out based on imaging and pathology. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the tumor and the absence of other cyst lesions.
P: The management plan includes referral to medical oncology for further evaluation and management. The treatment plan includes surgical intervention to remove the cystic and carcinoma, with a referral to oncological oncologic consultation. The management team will continue to monitor the patient's recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a bilateral Class I canine relationship and left Class I molar relationship in permanent dentition, with a crossbite of tooth 12. The patient expresses a desire to resolve the anterior crossbite using an invisible orthodontic appliance.
O: The treatment plan includes using a lingual orthodentic appliance with CAD/CAM digital workflow for the resolution of the anterior Crossbite and retention of the case over time. The procedure will involve polish of dental surfaces with pumice powder, intraoral scan using a 3D intraoral scanner, and placement of virtual brackets on 3D virtual models. The software will create a virtual setup, and the brackets will be placed on the 3D models.
A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral class I canine-left Class I Molar relationship, with associated crossbite. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dental crossbite, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the effectiveness of the orthodental treatment and the patient's compliance with the treatment plan.
P: The management plan includes the application of a lingually orthododontical appliance, followed by the preparation of an intraoral scanning using NemoCast software, which will be used to identify the shape of each tooth and the gum. The treatment will involve the placement of the virtual brackets and the creation of a virtual transfer tray for indirect bonding. A prototype of the digital transfer tray will be manufactured using a rapid-prototyping machine. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and smoking, presents with a nine-month history of epigastric pain, decreased appetite, and significant weight loss of 30 pounds. The patient has a family history of pancreatic cancer and breast cancer.
O: Initial abdominal CT scan revealed a 4 cm x 3.8 cm x 2.6 cm mass encasing the superior mesenteric artery. Hepatic panel results showed elevated alanine transaminase at 160 IU/L and alkaline phosphatase at 256 IU/mL. Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 was elevated at 177 U/mL, indicating an acute pancreatic mass. Endoscopic ultrasound (EGD) revealed an ill-defined, hypoechogenic lobular area between the head and body of the pancreas, with no lymph nodes. Pathology confirmed adenocarcinoma positive for CK7, CK20, DPP4, and CDX2, with microsatellite stability. Pathological examination confirmed adensocarcination with mucinous features, microsatellites, KRAS amplification, and genomic alterations.
A: The primary diagnosis is a double primary of the pancreatic masses, with differential diagnoses including pancreatic carcinoma and pancreatic malignancy. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the progression of the disease.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and treatment response. Treatment will include surgical intervention to address the adenoma, possibly including chemotherapy or radiation therapy, depending on the progression and response to therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression or resolution of the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the diagnosis and treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further management of the cancer is recommended.

S: The patient, admitted in April 2016, reported a 5-day fever and a bad cough. The patient recalls taking cephalothin and azithromycin for fever and cough.
O: On admission, a pulmonary CT indicated inflammatory consolidation with atelectasis. Initial biopsy confirmed fibrinoid formation in the right upper lobe. Initial treatment included cephelothin, azithromcin, and cepalothin. Arterial blood gas showed PaCO2 at 43 mm Hg, PaO2 at 56 mm HG, and an oxygenation index of 266. Vital signs included a temperature of 38.0°C, heart rate of 135 bpm, respiration rate of 32 times/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm HGs, and transcutaneous oxygen saturation of 90% without oxygen administration. Physical examination revealed a temperature 38.5°C with a heart rate rate of 134 bpm and respiration rates of 32/min. Laboratory tests showed Hb 132 g/l, WBC 12.2 × 10^9/L, N 73.3%, and L 27.1%. biochemical examination showed AST at 2,031 U/L (normal range: 0.5-1.2 U/l), ALT at 1,595 U/ L (normal ranges: 1.6-2.0 U/dL), CK-MB at 41 U/LL (normal), triglyceride at 1.33 mmol/l (normal: <0.5 mmol/L), CRP at 38.8 mg/l (<0.1 mg/L) and ferritin at 4,355 ng/ml (normal <0." mmol/dL). Pulmonary CT indicated substantial pulmonary consolidation in the upper and middle lobes of the lungs.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe infection with atelinemia, complicated by inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and pulmonary complications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of inflammation and respiratory symptoms. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the infection.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments. Consider consultation with a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management. Consider referral to a pulphologist for specialized care and a pulminologist for management of pulmonary complications and management for potential complications.

S: The patient, previously treated for non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, community-acquired pneumonia, and Staphylococcus hominis mitral valve endocarditis, reports feeling weak and tired. The patient recalls experiencing whole-body itching and pruritus on Day 32 of treatment, which was described as uncomfortable. Symptoms included an erythematous macular rash on the torso, which spread to the extremities, including palms and soles, and desquamation, intense pain, and intermittent fevers. The rash covered 80% of the BSA without bullae. There was no evidence of ageusia.
O: Vital signs during the hospitalization included a white blood cell count of 23.6 x 10^3/UL, peripheral blood eosinophilia at 12%, erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 27 mm/hr, C-reactive protein at 6.385 mg/L, and serum creatinine at 2.3 mg/dL. Blood cultures were negative. Serum alanine transaminase (ALT) and AST concentrations were within normal limits. Hemoglobin oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry remained above 95% throughout the hospital course.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe case of non-sterectomy with complications including severe allergic reactions to vancomycin, severe skin irritation, and a severe allergic reaction to the drug. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin irritation and dermatitis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: Continue monitoring hemoglobin oxygen levels and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of skin and skin irritation. Consider consultation with a pulmonologist for specialized care and possibly a cardiologist for dermatology consultation if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, a 62-year-old male with a history of obstructive jaundice and pancreatitis due to locally advanced pancreatic head cancer, presents with severe abdominal pain and tenderness starting four months post-treatment. He also reports slight epigastric pain a week before arrival.
O: Vital signs include blood pressure 91/67 mmHg, pulse 113/min, and temperature 37.0 °C. Laboratory tests show elevated leukocytes at 10,100/μl, elevated C-reactive protein at 13.92 mg/dl. CT scan shows the tip of the pancreatic stent protruding from the pancreatal body, with fluid collection around the pancreas, omental bursa, and Douglas cavum.
A: The primary diagnosis is panperitonitis secondary to pancreatic perforation, complicated by percutaneous transgastric drainage. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: Plan to perform an emergency emergency operation to address the perforated pancreatic duct. The patient will be treated with pancreatic tube insertion and suturing, followed by percipatetic drainage. Postoperative recovery will be uneventful, with adjustments to internal drainage as necessary. The plan includes monitoring the patient's recovery and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary based on recovery progress. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology may be necessary depending on the recovery and response to treatment.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old male, presented with severe respiratory distress following a pneumothorax on the right chest and underwent a tube thoracostomy. He reported no prior symptoms of chronic disease or smoking.
O: On examination, the patient's vital signs were within normal limits except for a high respiratory rate of 45 per minute. Laboratory tests including total blood count, liver, and renal function were unremarkable. A CT scan of the chest revealed bilateral air cysts in varying sizes with a ground glass appearance. Biopsy confirmed Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) confined to the right salivary gland, with histopathologic features including polymorphonuclear leukocytes and atypical histocytes with oval nucleus and pale granular cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical staining with CD1a and S100 were positive. Post-treatment, the boy was unresponsive to medical treatment.
A: The primary diagnosis is LCH with complications including bilateral air and lung cysts. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the absence of significant systemic involvement.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the boy's respiratory status and potential complications from the thoracoscopic bullae excision. The patient will be educated on signs of worsening respiratory distress and advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports a small lump on the left thumb, approximately 1 by 1 cm, located proximal to the base of the nail and on the dorsal aspect of the distal phalanx of the thumb, growing slowly. The patient denies any discharge or infection.
O: Physical examination revealed a small, non-infectious lump measuring 1.5 x 1.2 cm, proximal proximal at the base and dorsal aspect, on the proximal dorsal aspect. X-ray of the finger showed no signs of a bony spur. An excision of the lesion under local anesthesia was performed, and histopathology evaluation confirmed the lump as an inflamed pilar cyst.
A: The primary diagnosis is an inflaming pilar lesion lined by squamous epithelium. The absence of bony spurs suggests a benign nature. Differential diagnoses could include other types of cystic lesions, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings.
P: The management plan includes monitoring the area for signs of recurrence and scheduling a follow-up appointment in 3 months to assess the operative site and ensure no recurrence of the cancer. The plan includes regular monitoring of the area to ensure no signs recurrence. The management team will continue with regular follow-ups to assess for any signs of infection or recurrence, and the patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old male on hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease, presenting with cough, fever, altered mental status, and lethargy. He reports difficulty breathing and chest pain.
O: Vital signs include a temperature of 103°F, pulse 68, blood pressure 124/69, respiratory rate 22, and O2 saturation 96% on 2 L of O2 by nasal cannula. Physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles. Laboratory tests show a WBC count of 20,100 cells/mm3, plasma procalcitonin of 1.1 ng/mL, and sputum culture showing Corynebacteria with P. aeruginosa. Blood cultures and viral PCR are negative.
A: The primary diagnosis is bacterial pneumonia, likely secondary to C. propinquum, given the presence of Corynebs and Gram-positive rods. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pneumonia, but these are less likely given the specific findings.
P: The treatment plan includes starting vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole, with a 10-day course of linezolid. The patient will be discharged to complete the course of the antibiotic regimen. Follow-up will be scheduled to reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing discomfort in the groin area. The patient has a 3-year-old boy with a normal penis phenotype.
O: Physical examination revealed a palpable testis in the left groin and a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side. MRI findings indicated a mild hydrocele in the ipsilateral side of the left inguinal canal. Both testes were located on the same side, one above the other. Exploration revealed the presence of both testes within the same area.
A: The primary diagnosis is mild hydrocemia in the right groin, with a differential diagnosis initially considered but ruled out based on MRI findings and imaging. The presence of the testes and the absence of the other testes suggests a possible underlying condition.
P: The management plan includes performing a herniotomy to address the ectopic testis. Post-procedure, the patient will be monitored closely for any long-term effects of the procedure. Follow-up care will be provided to ensure the patient's recovery and to manage any complications.

S: The patient reports persistent diarrhea with 4-5 watery stools without blood and mucus and fever up to 39 °C for 14 days. The symptoms appeared 1 year prior to hospital admission. The patient was treated symptomatically and empirically with amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and cefuroxime, with periodic improvement but no resolution of symptoms. He also lost 10 kg of weight. No medical history of chronic diseases or significant previous travels was reported.
O: Physical examination revealed numerous enlarged cervical lymphatic nodes, tenderness to palpation in the left subcostal region, and intensive bowel movements. Laboratory tests showed elevated CRP, ESR, leukocytosis, monocytos, neutrocytosis and thrombocytotic levels. bacteriological stool tests were negative. Parasitological stool tests including Ziehl-Neelsen staining showed Cryptosporidium spp. oocysts, 20-50 oocyst/10 fields (magnification 1000×). FOBT was positive. Colonoscopy revealed intensive inflammatory mucosal lesions, polyps narrowing the bowel bore, stool-purulent content, and different-shaped ulcers. CT scans showed extraperitoneum lymphadenopathy and intestine wall inflammation with mucosa thickening, and histopathologic sections showed incorrect lamina propria architecture with cryptitis.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute bowel inflammation, likely secondary to a parasite infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of inflammatory bowel disease, but these are less likely given the specific findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the infection.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up visits to assess for any recurrence of symptoms or complications. Treatment options will be adjusted based on response to the treatment and response to therapy. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan. Referral to a gastroenterologist for specialized care is recommended.

S: The patient, an 80-year-old female, reports bleeding from her prolapsed uterus. She has a history of 3 vaginal births and a last menstruation at age 52. She denies any past or current chronic diseases, addictions, or other health concerns. She is in a 1-year relationship with a male obstetrician.
O: Physical examination revealed a large part of the vagina containing the cervix and a uterine body below the vaginal introits, classified as International Continence Society grade 3. Exophytic infiltrating lesions covering the entire surface of the hypertrophic cervix, spreading to the vaginal fornices. Bimanual vaginal examination showed a small myoma of 2 cm in diameter, impalpable adnexa, and a tumor in the anal canal. Rectal examination showed an impalperated tumor. Histopathology confirmed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the cervical specimen, with a strong immunohistochemical p16 reaction in neoplastic cells.
A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated SCC, with high risk of cancer spread. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the cancer.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. Further treatment options may be considered based on the findings and clinical response. Patient education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports blurred vision, hyperemia, and pain in the right eye. The patient denies experiencing fever, asthenia, anorexia, arthralgia, myalgia, ulcers, abdominal pain, lower back pain, or urinary symptoms.
O: Physical examination and laboratory tests reveal bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis without complications. The presence of hypertension and elevated inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein 2.6 mg/dL, erythrocyte sedimentation rate 96 mm/first hour) are noted. Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is 48 ml/min/1.73m2, indicating hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, and raised urine β2-microglobulin levels. No other infections were ruled out. Chest X-ray and kidney biopsy indicate diffuse mononuclear cell interstitial infiltrates consistent with acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. Blood pressure, serum creatinine, and tubular function are normal.
A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral Nongranulointerstitial uveis, with differential diagnoses including Hepatitis B and C, toxoplasmosis, brucellosis, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), and cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of complications from previous infections.
P: The management plan includes ocular dexamethasone and mydriatics for the eye, oral prednisolone (5 mg/m2/day), amlodipine, potassium citrate, and methotrexate (10 mg/mm2/week) to prevent recurrent uveititis. Two months post-procedure, the patient will be started on methotroxate (12.5 mg per week) for recurrent uves. Adjustments in methotrostate dosage will be made as needed based on response to treatment and response to therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports discomfort in the mouth and concerns it could be something serious. The patient expresses concern about the presence of growth near the corner of the mouth, causing pain.
O: Physical examination revealed stage II buccal SCC involving the labial commissure. A-EF flap was drawn along the nasolabial fold, resulting in a triangular total thickness flap. The inner and outer dimensions of the AEF skin paddle measured 1.8 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm, respectively. At 3 months follow-up, the esthetic result for the cheek and lip was rated 3, indicating normal speech. The orbicularis oris function was rated as 3.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage II bccal septal carcinoma (SCC) with complications including a local recurrence. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of mouth discomfort such as malignancy or malignant tumor, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention to remove the tumor and reconstruct the affected area. Post-surgery, the patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Education on signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, who underwent a transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) in 2004, reports continuous pain and bleeding from the residual vagina for some time. The patient underwent a radical cystectomy and carcinoma in situ (CIS) in the surgical specimen, with no cancer cell infiltration in the resected uterus or anterior wall of the vagina. Imaging studies including MRI and biopsy revealed a tumor in the residual vaginal area.
O: Recent MRI showed no metastasis. Biopsy confirmed a primary adenocarcinoma on the residual sigmoid colon. Pathological examination of the tumor showed adenoma and SCC, with immunohistochemistry positive for SCC markers CD56, chromogranin A, synaptophysin, and negative for urothelial carcinoma markers GATA-3, p63, uroplakin, thrombomodulin, and 34βE12. The tumor was partially resecting the sigmoidal colon, and local recurrence and pelvic bone metastasis were detected via MRI 3 months post-surgery.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent bladder tumor with recurrent bladder cancer. Differential diagnoses initially included other bladder tumors, but these were ruled out based on biopsy results and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the recurrent nature of the bladder cancer and the patient's history of multiple metastases.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient and the tumor's response to radiation therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Patient education on the nature of bladder cancer, treatment expectations, and potential side effects of radiation therapy will be provided. Referral to a rheumatologist for specialized care and a rhabdomyologist for management of bladder cancers is recommended.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old neutered male miniature Poodle, was hit by a car 4 days prior, suspected spinal trauma. The owner reports that the dog has been struggling with difficulty breathing and difficulty moving around, particularly when touched by the neck.
O: Initial examination revealed tachypneic and laterally recumbent with a body condition score of 5/9. On palpation of the neck, the dog vocalized and pain was assessed at 2/4 using the Canine Acute Pain Scale. Neurologic examination showed the dog to be laterally reumbent, quiet, and alert with intact cranial nerve function but nonambulatory with paresis of thoracic limbs and plegia of pelvic limbs. Muscle tone increased in the thoracics and absent in the pelvic limbs, with decreased conscious proprioception in thoracacic and pelvic limbs and absent panniculus reflexes. Neurolocalization was T3-L3 with suspected C6-T2 involvement. Blood work showed elevated alanine aminotransferase (185U/L), normochromic normocytic anemia (35.7%), leukocytosis (15.69K/uL), neutrophilia (5.7-8.9K/UL), and monocytositis (2K-1.12K/UIL).
A: The primary diagnosis is T2-T4 injury with cervical involvement, likely exacerbated by spinal injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal injury such as infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the dog's neurological status, regular neurological assessments, and potential surgical intervention to address the underlying causes of his neurological deficits. Further diagnostic tests such as an MRI or CT scan may be necessary to further assess the extent of the injury and determine the best course of treatment. Further consultations with an infectious disease specialist may be considered to further evaluate the nature of the injuries and potential complications. Patient education regarding the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for potential complications is crucial.

S: The patient reports severe neutropenia persisting for the last 6 months, which has not responded to granulocyte-colony stimulating factor at a maximum dose of 20 mcg/kg daily. The patient has a history of recurrent infections of the upper respiratory tract and stomatitis during the first years of life, which have been managed with granulocytes-colone stimulating factor.
O: Physical examination revealed splenomegaly with an 11.5 cm long axis on an ultrasound scan. Blood count showed profound neutropenic neutropensia with an absolute neutrophil count of 0.02 × 10^9/L, but no anemia or thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow examination showed rare myeloid precursors with normal growth of erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages, but growth of myeloids was below the normal range, and bone marrow progenitors showed normal growth. Anti-neutrophil IgG levels were elevated at 171.1 mg/dL, significantly higher than the normal value of less than 33 mg/L.
A: The primary diagnosis is autoimmune neutrophenia, with differential diagnoses including Kostmann disease, Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. The elevated IgG level suggests a misdiagnosed form of autoimmune neutrocytosis.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's neutrophils and immunocompromised state. Treatment options will be discussed with the management team, which will include further diagnostic work-up to rule out other potential causes of neutropeneuria. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a history of right L4-L5 disc herniation treated 15 years ago, followed by a right L5-S1 disc herniation. The patient experienced moderate pain initially but developed severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and motor dysfunction in June 2014. The pain has been moderate but has progressed to severe bilateral l5 scatalgy and mictional delay.
O: Physical examination and MRI findings revealed a disc Herniation originating from the L4 L5 disc, perforating the common longitudinal ligament and anterior aspect of the dura, entering the thecal sac. The intradural part of the disc fragment is large, extending downwards and reaching the level of the upper sacrum, surrounded by rootlets. The disc fragment appears compact, with peripheral contrast enhancement post-gadolinium injection, and is less compact with a crumbled appearance, irregular borders, and no contrast enhancement.
A: The primary diagnosis is a discheriation from L4, with associated complications including a disc fragment surrounded by roots. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of disc hernia, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the successful management of the hernia and the patient's response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention to address the disc hernariation. Post-operative care instructions will include follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any new or worsening symptoms. Rehabilitation and physical therapy may be recommended to regain strength and mobility. Further consultations with a pain specialist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care is crucial.

S: The patient, diagnosed with papillary serous adenocarcinoma and uterine masses, reports feeling nervous but is otherwise okay. The patient has a history of hypertension, hemorrhoids, morbid obesity with a BMI of 46.8, and a pulmonary embolism three months prior to surgery. He has a moderate to excellent functional capacity, can cycle three to five miles daily, and is capable of climbing two flights of stairs. He is a non-smoker and consumes one alcoholic beverage about four times per month.
O: Physical examination reveals moderate to good functional capacity. The primary diagnosis is papillary Serous adenaoma and uterus masses, complicated by a history including pulmonary embolic surgery and a colonoscopy. The prognosis is guarded due to the patient's chronic conditions and the presence of chronic conditions.
A: The primary assessment is a moderate-to-excellent functional capacity with moderate to poor functional ability. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other chronic conditions, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of prochlorperazine 10 mg post-chemotherapy, dexamethasone 4 mg for three days only, rivaroxaban 20 mg daily, enoxaparin 120 mg/0.8 mL solution subcutaneous, hydrochlorothiazide-valsartan 12.5-320 mg daily for essential hypertension control. The plan includes monitoring vital signs in the operating room with non-invasive blood pressure measurement, electrocardiogram, peripheral oxygen saturation, and temperature-sensing Foley catheter. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications. Patient education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old male with a 3-year history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and end-stage renal disease, currently under continuous ambulatory PD treatment. He reports cloudy dialysate and diffuse abdominal pain persisting for 2 hours. He was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia two weeks ago and treated with 400-mg oral moxifloxacin daily for 10 days.
O: Physical examination revealed epigastric tenderness without guarding or rebound pain.
