A: The primary diagnosis is severe atypical stroke with complications including acute thalomomesencephaly and comatosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stroke such as cardiac arrhythmia or stroke, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's neurological status, supportive care for symptoms, and supportive treatment for potential complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Patient education regarding the nature of the stroke and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with a history of type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cerebrovascular accident, anoxic brain injury, and a PEG tube and tracheostomy connected to a ventilator. The patient reports increased resistance during the change of the trachostomy tube.
O: Upon examination, the patient was hypertensive with a blood pressure of 160/74 mmHg, heart rate of 80 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, O2 saturation of 100% on 100% FiO2 fraction of inspired oxygen, and temperature of 37.8°C. Physical examination revealed edema, crepitus, and swollen upper arms. A stat chest X-ray indicated extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and right chest wall. A tracheoscopy through the stoma showed the tracheal tube was in place.
A: The primary diagnosis is sub-cutaneous pulmonary embolism (PM) in the chest and neck. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of PM, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the patient's condition.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of vital signs and vital signs, with appropriate treatment for PM. The management will include close monitoring in the hospital for monitoring and management of the sub-continent. A multidisciplinary team will be involved to manage the patient and his condition. The nursing home will be closely involved in the management of PM and monitoring for any complications. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a five-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of fever, pallor, and a rash over the past five days, accompanied by two episodes of non-projectile, blood-stained vomitus and a non-progressive, black lesion over the nose. The mother reports that the fever started two months ago, with a fever of 103-104°F, which was high-grade and continuous, leading to earache and ear discharge. The left ankle joint was swollen, painful, and limited movement four days after the onset of fever.
O: Initial treatment with intravenous antibiotics was ineffective. Recent labs showed slightly elevated platelet count (451,000/microliter), elevated CRP (22.7mg/L), elevated ESR (42 mm/hr), and negative ANA (negative antinuclear antibody test).
A: The primary diagnosis is oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), complicated by the patient's prolonged history of fever and symptoms of joint pain and fever. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever such as infectious or inflammatory conditions. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy.
P: The management plan includes starting sulfasalazine (30 mg/kg/day, in two divided doses) and naproxen for JIA. The patient will be closely monitored for response to the treatment and any new symptoms. Regular follow-ups with the pediatric rheumatologist will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment. Education on the importance of adherence to the prescribed regimen and the potential side effects of the medication will be provided.

S: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis, treated with proctocolectomy, small bowel resections, and colonoscopic biopsies. He reports a history of anal fistulas, perianal abscesses, and villous adenoma treated with a proctoclectomy and ileostomy. He has a significant weight loss of 90 cm of small intestine due to adhesion complications. He also has multiple infections and has had multiple changes in the Hickman line.
O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 108, respiration rate of 24, SpO2 93%, temperature of 38.9° C, blood pressure of 154/94 mmHg, and GCS score of 15/15. The patient's stoma is in the right iliac fossa, with no signs of swelling, bruising, pain, or bleeding. Blood tests showed anaemia and raised inflammatory markers.
A: The primary diagnosis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (CBI) with complications including colitis and ulceration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of colitis such as infection or infection, but these are less likely given the history and current findings.
P: The management plan includes administration of anti-motility and anti-secretory medications, including Loperamide, Codeine phosphate, and Omeprazole, to reduce stoma output. The management of the Crohn's disease and the need for close monitoring of the patient's condition are recommended. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the progression of the disease and response to treatment. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments will be provided.

S: The patient, a male, presented with sudden onset right lower extremity pain following crack cocaine use. He denied experiencing chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or neurologic symptoms. He has a history of unremarkable medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be alert and oriented but in obvious distress. Vital signs were within normal limits except for blood pressure at 180/100 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations were benign with notably equal radial pulses. Neurologic examination showed normal and symmetric strength in bilateral upper and lower extremities without sensory deficits. Point-of-Care Ultrasound (POCUS) indicated a large, undulating intimal flap in the abdominal aorta. A CT scan confirmed a Stanford Type B dissection.
A: The primary diagnosis is a congenital Stanford Type A dissection, confirmed by CT imaging. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute limb pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan includes initiating aggressive blood pressure control and initiating aggressive bleeding control. The patient underwent thoracic endovascular aortic repair. Follow-up care will include monitoring vital signs, blood pressure, and cardiac function. The treatment plan will include aggressive management of the patient's cardiac symptoms and supportive care for any complications.

S: RC, initially diagnosed with T3N2M0 midrectal cancer, reports feeling weak at times following neoadjuvant chemoradiation treatment. He underwent laparoscopic low anterior resection with a diverting loop ileostomy and elective reversal of ileoproliferative colitis nine months postoperatively. He recalls a colonoscopy revealing exclusion colitis treated with gastrografin enema and CT imaging. Postoperatively, RC experienced persistent small bowel obstruction, which was managed conservatively.
O: Initial CT abdomen and pelvis showed no recurrence, obstruction, or distant metastases. Subsequent diagnostic laparoscopy showed multiple adhesions around the previous reversal site, with normal-appearing proximal and collapsed distal small bowel. Subsequently, CT abdomen showed a new side-to-side primary anastomosis. CT imaging and small bowel series showed narrowing of the ileum distal to the previous anastoma. Initial exploratory laparotomy revealed persistent collapsed bowel loops distal, which were resected without stricture. Gross examination showed thickened distal ileums without strictures. Pathology post-second revision showed submucosal fibrosis with hyalinization of the lamina propria and atherosclerotic changes in adjacent vessels.
A: Primary diagnosis is T3M0 Midrectal Cancer with complications including secondary anastomy and a secondary distal obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include metastatic disease or other gastrointestinal malignancies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and recovery.
P: Continue monitoring RC's health closely with regular follow-ups with the medical team. Maintain a balanced diet to support bowel function and tolerance of diet. Educate RC on signs of recurrence or obstruction and ensure regular follow up with the oncology team. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of metastatic cancer. Encourage RC to maintain a healthy diet and maintain a balanced lifestyle.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of Type 2 diabetes presenting with a non-healing ulcer on his left heel, which has been bothering him for a while.
O: Initial radiograph of the left calcaneus showed no evidence of osteomyelitis. MRI findings confirmed a non–displaced insufficiency fracture of the calcaneum, with no evidence for osteomyelsitis.
A: The primary diagnosis is a non non-displaced ulcer in the left heel. The absence of osteopathy and absence of bone infection are favorable findings for the ulcer and the heel.
P: The management plan includes treatment with offloading pressure on the affected area and possibly immobilizing the foot to allow the fracture to heal. The patient will continue with diabetes management to ensure proper blood flow and healing. The management of diabetes will focus on managing diabetes to promote overall health. The ulcer will be wound and dry, and the patient will adhere to wound care instructions. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports instability and issues with the left knee for the past 6 months. The patient has a history of trauma to the knee 6 months ago, which was not treated for.
O: Physical examination revealed an anterior defect on the left side with visibility of the intercondylar articulating surfaces of the tibia and femur, swelling in the anterior aspect of the left distal third thigh, and a superior fragment of the patella at the lower pole of the lower patellal tuberosity. An X-ray confirmed the presence of the superior fragment in the distal aspect and the lower fragment close to the tibial tuberosity, with a neutralization hole at the tiber tuberosity and a retinaculum repaired.
A: The primary diagnosis is a posterior patellar defect with associated swelling and instability. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee instability and instability, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with quadricepsplasty and tension band wiring, followed by continuous passive motion post-surgery. Postoperative recovery will include gradual improvement in knee motion from 5 degrees of extension lag to 40 degrees of flexion, with gradual improvement to 5- to 90-degree knee motion by 3 months. Post-operative care will focus on dynamic quadricep strengthening and active straight-leg-raising exercises, with adjustments to knee motion as necessary. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports intermittent distending pain on the right side of the head, near the back, which has been worsening over the last 10 days. The patient has not experienced any positive symptoms in the nervous system, such as numbness, tingling, or weakness.
O: A CT scan showed no abnormal brain tissue alterations but indicated right fungal sphenoid sinusitis. A paranasal sinus CT indicated abnormal intensity of soft tissue in the right sphenoidal sinus, calcification, and bone damage on the sinus wall. Post-transnasal endoscopic surgery, histopathological examination of the tissue identified the infection as SSFB, with no further recurrence of headache.
A: The primary diagnosis is right fungliocarcinoma (SSFB) of the brain, with differential diagnoses including other forms of fungal infections. The prognosis is generally favorable with no recurrence.
P: The management plan includes referral to the Otolaryngology Department for further evaluation and management of the infection. The treatment plan includes a transnasal sphenoidsotomy to address the infection and to manage the pain effectively. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, bipolar disorder, hepatitis C, hysterectomy, and tracheostomy, presents with recent difficulty breathing. He has been admitted to the CT-ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and IV anti-impulse control. During his ICU stay, he experienced respiratory failure requiring intubation and revision of the trachostomy. He also experienced sick sinus syndrome, diagnosed during hospitalization.
O: CT angiogram confirmed acute transient adenocarcinoma (TAAD) with true and false lumens and a dissection flap extending from the junction of the right- and noncoronary cusps of the aortic valve to the inferior mesenteric artery and left renal artery. During ICU admission, the patient experienced respiratory distress and required intubations. He is currently on IV anti pulse control.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute transient acute adenoma ( TAAD) secondary to cardiac catheterization and stenting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac arrest and cardiac arrest, but these are less likely given the patient's history and comorbidities. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful management of his condition.
P: The management plan includes transitioning to oral medication to support recovery and regain strength. The patient will continue to be monitored closely in the ICU, with instructions to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are recommended to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on recognizing signs of respiratory distress or worsening symptoms will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing absolute constipation, abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting. The patient was diagnosed with intestinal Schistosomiasis in Egypt a year prior to admission. No follow-up investigations were conducted.
O: On examination, the patient's abdomen was distended with tenderness in the lower part and absent bowel sounds. Digital rectal examination revealed a collapsed rectum. Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed dilated bowel loops. An exploratory laparotomy was performed, revealing localized turbid fluid collection, dilated small and large bowel loops, paralytic ileus, and a gangrenous appendix. Histopathology confirmed extensive necrosis of the appendix with multiple viable schistosomal ova. A single dose of praziquantel therapy was administered, and the patient was discharged after one week.
A: The primary diagnosis is intestinal Schismosoma with complications including intestinal obstruction, necrosis, and necrosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intestinal obstruction such as malignancy, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and the absence of ova in stool analysis.
P: The management plan includes continued prazicel therapy to manage the infection and ensure complete recovery. The plan includes regular follow-ups with gastroenterology to monitor the condition and manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the condition is recommended.

S: The patient, a young boy, presented with febrile symptoms and abdominal and joint pain. He reported anemia, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis. The patient also experienced fever, joint pain, and abdominal pain.
O: Clinical investigation revealed anemia with splenomaly and leukaemia. White blood cells count was elevated at 19.6 × 10^9 /L with 72% lymphoblast. Bone marrow aspiration showed 92% lymphoblasts infiltration. Immunophenotyping showed nTdT, cCD10, CD20, CD22, CD38, CD45(low) positive, and cCD9, CD19, c CD79, and CD58(interm)-positive cells in 45% blast cells. Myeloid and T-cell markers were negative. The prognosis was poor with a relapse diagnosis of leukemia.
A: The primary diagnosis is leukemia with complications including CNS infiltration and lymphoblastic infiltration. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the immunophenotype profile and karyotype.
P: Initiated a relapse treatment-rescue plan, which was adjusted based on the patient's response to prednisone. The plan includes close monitoring of response to the current regimen, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The family was informed about the patient’s condition and the potential for complications related to relapse.

S: The patient reports a history of a motorcycle accident in July 2016, treated with open reduction and internal fixation with a locking plate and single compression screw, and a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria. The patient has been experiencing painful mobilization due to an unstable osseous situation.
O: Initial diagnostic tests including plain radiographs and pan CT/MRI scan revealed septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, a large abscess zone with contrast agent capturing 30 cm in the dorsal compartment, necrotic avascular muscle areas, loss of the anterior tibial artery, and an anterolateral soft tissue defect covered with necrosis. Laboratory tests showed elevated infection parameters with CRP at 2.7 mg/dl and leukocytes at 6.9 G/l. Acinetobacter baumannii and Enterobacter cloacae complex were found in wound smears from the anteroleateral defect zone and intrammedullary in the distal third of the tibal shaft.
A: The primary diagnosis is septic Pseudarthrosis with associated complications including anterollateral osteomyelia and anteral nerve loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of infection such as infection or infection-related complications. The prognosis depends on the response to surgical intervention and response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the osteosynthesis material and necrosis graft, followed by aggressive extensive osseosous debridement and resection of necrotical muscles of the posterior lower leg. The graft will be resected and the patient will be monitored closely for any signs of infection or complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The owner reports a chief complaint of mental changes over the past year, including confusion, decreased awareness of surroundings, difficulty recognizing humans, and loss of previously learned abilities. The owner also notes a recent generalized tonic-clonic seizure two days ago, leading to poor appetite, lethargy, and circling and signs of ataxia.
O: Clinical examination revealed acute right-sided abnormalities, including postural reaction deficit, circling, head and neck turn, left-sided head tilt, positional nystagmus, and ataxias. The patient also developed lateral recumbency and was unable to feed herself. No MRI was performed due to the poor prognosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe neurological disorder characterized by acute right–sided abnormalities including posturinary reaction deficits, head-to-neck turn, and associated ataxian symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other neurological disorders, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes euthanasia and necropsy, with the patient to undergo immunohistochemistry for the detection of specific proteins. The cat will be treated in 10% buffered formalin and stained with hematoxylin and eosin, with further histology to confirm the presence of APP and GFAP. Postoperative care will include monitoring of neurological status, feeding, and monitoring for any signs of worsening symptoms. Education on the importance of follow-up care will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a female, presented to the emergency department with symptoms of weakness, disorientation, and generalized weakness. She reported feeling weak and disoriented upon arrival. The patient also reported generalized weakness and confusion.
O: Upon examination, the patient was somnolent but arousable, diaphoretic, and pale, with a chest clear and regular cardiac rhythm. Radial pulses diminished in both upper extremities, mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and a firm mass in the pelvis were noted. Rectal examination revealed brown stool. Point-of-care ultrasonography showed moderate free fluid and a well-circumscribed mass adjacent to the uterus. Laboratory analysis showed venous lactate at 2.5 mg/L (mmol/L), WBC at 11.46 cubic milliliter (K/uL), hemoglobin at 9.0 g/dL, and negative urine chorionic gonadotropin test.
A: The primary diagnosis is suspected hemoperitoneum secondary to a mass near the uterus, likely secondary to the mass. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential complications, including potential complications from the mass and potential infection. Further treatment options will be considered based on the response to treatment and response to therapy. Referral to gynecology and general surgery is recommended for management of suspected hemopitoneum. Patient education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, gout with extensive tophi, chronic lymphocytic leukemia on ibrutinib, and venous thromboembolism on rivaroxaban, reports feeling like his ICD fired the other day.
O: Vital signs and ICD site are within normal limits. No arrhythmia or shock therapy on device interrogation was noted. Blood cultures grew MSSA in 2 sets. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed no vegetations. TEE showed drainage of white cheesy material from an elbow tophus, and cultures from the infected toophus grew MSA. Blood culture was negative 2 days after starting the antibiotic.
A: The primary diagnosis is infection with complications including infection with bacteremia and absent vegetation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of infection, but these are less likely given the negative TEE and TEE findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful management of infection and absence of infection.
P: The management plan includes discharge to a skilled nursing facility for 2 weeks of intravenous antibiotics. The patient is advised to continue monitoring his health and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient reports a history of bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures sustained during an accident with a bark stripping machine at the sawmill. The patient has no other injuries or co-morbidities.
O: Initial surgical intervention included a temporary fixator and debridement using a Hoffmann Express Stryker® with four half pins and a standard two-bar configuration. A soft tissue defect equivalent to a Gustilo-Anderson IIIB was noted, necessitating a flap. Post-surgical complications included a 270-degree circumferential skin wound from the postero-lateral aspect of the middle third of the leg, with intact muscle bellies and distally distal motor function. Subsequent surgery involved sub-muscular elevation, creating a soft tissue envelope, and applying a standard hexapod frame. The wound was treated with an OrthoFix TL-Hex® frame.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe wound from a tibial bayonet procedure to the right ankle, with complications including a severe circumfusion of the skin wound. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tibia fracture, but these are less likely given the surgical history and surgical history.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's recovery and post-operative care. The second surgery will be performed to remove the frame, with the patient advised to follow post-operatively care instructions and contact the healthcare provider if any concerns or questions arise. Further consultations with orthopedic surgery may be necessary depending on the progress and response to the second surgery.

S: The patient, a 2-year-old male, presented with recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures for more than 2 years. He started experiencing hypoglycemic convulsions starting at just a few days old. He was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit after episodes on days 5 and 13. He has been hospitalized multiple times for these episodes.
O: Physical examination at 2 years and 7 months showed decreased activity and weakness, hypertelorism, narrow palpebral fissures, epicanthus, low-set ears, auricular malformation, and a transverse palmar crease in the right hand. Neurological examination revealed normal IQ and no disturbances in neuro-psycho-motor development. Laboratory tests showed total bilirubin at 316.6 μmol/L and indirect bilirubsin at 303.9 μmol-L, with jaundice on the 6th day. Laboratory investigations showed low plasma cortisol and ACTH concentrations, no circadian rhythm of ACTH and cortisol levels, and normal ACTH levels. ACTH test failed to stimulate the production of cortisol. Thyroid function tests, kidney function, electrolytes, and electrolytes were normal. Abdominal pituitary hormone concentrations were normal under non-stress conditions. Blood sugar was 4.7 ± 0.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent hyperglycemia with associated seizures, hypoglycoidemia, and neuropsychiatric disturbances. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycosis and seizures, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and blood glucose levels. The patient will be educated on the signs of potential complications and advised to report any changes or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to the treatment regimen will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing vomiting for a few weeks, which has become more frequent recently.
O: Endoscopic upper gastrointestinal imaging revealed a type 3 tumor at the EGJ with a circumference of 56 mm, stenosis, and narrowing of the area. CT scan indicated lymph node metastases along the lesser curvature of the stomach and the proximal splenic artery.
A: The primary diagnosis is a cT4aN2M0, cStage IIIC lesion of the EGH, cT3 in the TNM classification. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings suggest a complex tumor with metastatic spread to nearby lymph nodes.
P: The management plan includes discussing the treatment options with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best treatment plan for the tumor. The plan includes surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and a combination of these. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient's current condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment response and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a persistent cough that persists for a while. The patient has a history of uterine leiomyoma treated with hysterectomy 13 years ago.
O: Physical examination revealed multiple pulmonary bilateral nodules, with no FDG uptake in the PET scan. A CT-guided biopsy of a pulmonary nodule was performed. Histopathology of a low-grade, benign appearing, smooth muscle tumor was identified as Benign Metastasizing Leiomyoma (BML). Immunohistochemical profiles were positive for SMA, desmin, estrogen, progesterone receptors, and negativity for HMB-45, CD31, CD34, and EMA. Staining for ki-67 showed low mitotic activity. Cytogenetic analysis revealed a shared profile of 19q and 22q terminal deletions. After 6 months of follow-up, the remaining lesions were stable.
A: The primary diagnosis is Benign Meningococcal Lymphoma (BML) with a secondary diagnosis of Benign metastasized Leiomyomatosis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of leukocytosis, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and imaging findings.
P: The management plan included surgical castration of BML, which was performed after 6 months. Post-operative care included monitoring for any signs of recurrence or progression of the disease, and regular follow-ups were scheduled to assess the disease's response to treatment and manage any complications. Further consultations with oncology and possibly a pulmonologist were recommended to manage the patient's condition.

S: 
- Patient reports right knee pain that occurs occasionally less than once a day.
- Reports a slight systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

O: - Examination shows a temperature of ninety eight .2, pulse of seventy two, and a low blood pressure of one twenty two over seventy.
 

A:

P:
- Examination of the right knee shows no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to the left knee. No decreased range of motion in the left medial knee.
1:  
2: Right knee exam shows no swelling or pain in the knee, no decreased range in motion.
3: Left knee x-ray shows no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.
4: Left medial knee xray shows a slight decrease in range of movement.
5: Right medial knee X-ray indicates no fracture or edema.
6: Right hip x-rays show no decreased motion. 
7: Right lateral knee xerography shows no fracture.
8: Left hip xerogram shows no fractures.
10: Right side right knee Xerography indicates no swelling.

S: The patient, an 11-year-old thin-built, anemic girl, presents with a chief complaint of pain in the upper abdomen and recurrent vomiting for one week. She reports a nontender lump in the epigastric region, moving with respiration, and has noticed unusual habits such as chewing on her hair. She was admitted to another hospital for similar issues, but conservative management was ineffective.
O: Physical examination revealed a non-nontender lump. Laboratory tests showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Other parameters were normal. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) revealed a large blackish mass in the stomach, mostly hairs, with a sample taken from the stomach showing mostly hairs. The patient's history and examination post-surgery confirmed trichobezoar.
A: The primary diagnosis is trichobacillus, a type of gastric tumor, with differential diagnoses including other causes of abdominal pain and gastrointestinal disturbances. The prognosis is favorable post-surgical recovery, with no immediate complications from the surgery.
P: The management plan includes performing an anterior gastrotomy to remove the large hairball mass. Postoperative care will include a psychiatric consultation to address the hair-chewing behavior. Post-operative, the patient will be discharged from the hospital and scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 6 months to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Education on the nature of the condition and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, who was involved in a motor vehicle collision, was fully oriented with a GCS of 15 upon arrival. He reported mild cervical pain and was concerned about the possibility of cervical pain. The patient was initially treated with primary and secondary trauma care, with diagnostic studies including Brain CT scan, cervical and chest radiography, and FAST examination. He was discharged after 8 hours under observation. He experienced left hemiplegia two days later.
O: Vital signs were within normal limits. Neurological examination showed no focal neurological deficits. Brain CT and cervical radiography were unremarkable. FAST was performed, and Doppler sonography of the right vertebral artery confirmed the occlusion. CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis. Warfarin was initiated at 5 mg per day, followed by atorvastatin 40 mg due to dyslipidemia. Physiotherapy for left extremities was initiated.
A: The primary diagnosis is occlusive vertebral arteries, likely secondary to motor vehicle accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful management of the stroke.
P: Continue warfarin at 5mg per day to reach a target INR of 2-3, and atorvanastatin is prescribed for dyslipidsemia. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the prescribed medications and ensure compliance with the treatment regimen.

S: The patient reports a history of nyctalopia since childhood, which has progressively worsened. The patient has been experiencing decreased visual acuity and visual fields since the twenties.
O: Visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/63 in the left eye. ERG examination was unsuccessful due to inability to tolerate the examination. Funduscopy revealed bone spicule pigmentation and attenuated retinal vessels characteristic for Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP). Fundus AF and OCT imaging showed increased and decreased Autofluorescence (AF) in both eyes and a fine pattern of radial lines radiating from the fovea. OCT imaging revealed widespread thinning of the photoreceptor layer in both eye, foveal sparing in the Left eye, and thickening of the inner retina around the optic disc. Genetic analysis confirmed a de novo RPGR mutation in the mother.
A: The primary diagnosis is retinitis pigmentosa with associated visual impairment and retinal dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal impairment, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the retinal condition and the patient's response to treatment.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring and supportive care in the low vision specialist to manage symptoms and prevent further retinal damage. The management of retinopathy and retinoid retinoma will be based on genetic testing and clinical response. The family will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments to monitor the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a retinal specialist will be arranged to address the patient’s retinal symptoms and adjust the management plan as needed.

S: The patient reports bilateral visual impairment for approximately one year, progressive general fatigue for the past 3 months, and no history of epileptic seizures.
O: Neurological examination revealed bilateral visual impairments in the left eye, half-blindness in the right eye on the ear side, and cognitive dysfunction. Mini Mental State Examination score was 21 out of 30. Fundus examination showed no papilledema. MRI revealed a 77 × 63 × 85-mm pituitary tumor extending bilaterally through the anterior skull base, the clivus, and the cavernous sinus, causing compression of the optic chiasm and bilateral frontal and temporal lobes. The patient's hormone profile showed hyperprolactinemia at 25,270.0 ng/ml, significantly higher than the normal range of 3.6–12.8 ng/mL. Other pituitarian hormones were also affected, including testosterone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, thyroid, hormone, free thyroxine 4, growth hormone, and adrenocorticotropic hormone.
A: The primary diagnosis is a giant prolactinoma (PRLoma) and hypopituitarism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment and cognitive impairment. The prognosis depends on the response to antiepileptics and the management of other pituitaries.
P: Initiate treatment with dopamine agonists (DA) to address the PRLoma and promote cognitive function. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and the potential side effects of medication. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment as needed. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports severe injuries sustained in a tractor rollover crash, including fractures in the left 1st to 12th ribs, right 1st-to-6th ribs and the left clavicle, and spine fractures including a displaced T12 spinous process fracture, L1 burst fracture, and L2, 3, and 5 transverse process fractures. The pain in the thorax and back is particularly severe. The patient has been treated with multimodal analgesia, including acetaminophen 1000 mg 4 times daily, gabapentin 300 mg 3 times daily and hydromorphone PCA with an average 24-hour hydromoric consumption of 4.7 mg/day, and lidocaine patches. Postinjury day 3, the patient presented for surgical repair of the L2 burst fracture with T11-L3 posterior spinal instrumentation.
O: Postoperative management included intraoperative placement of bilateral ESP catheters, followed by surgical intervention using a right-sided ESP block using ultrasound guidance with a high-frequency linear ultrasound probe targeting the right T5 transverse. Post-operative care includes monitoring pain levels and adjustment of pain management plans as necessary.
A: The primary diagnosis is traumatic spine fractures, complicated by traumatic spine fracture and spinal cord injuries. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal cord injury such as spinal cord compression, but these are less likely given the patient's history and surgical history.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of pain levels, adjustment of analgesia as necessary, and regular follow-ups to assess recovery progress and adjust the pain management plan as needed. Patient education regarding the risks of surgical intervention and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan will be provided. Referral to a pain management specialist for ongoing management of pain and potential complications is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of low backache for one year, presents with symptoms of claudication symptoms, left-sided numbness, and paresthesia of the foot, but no radicular pain. The patient also reports progressive reduction in claudications distance and a sudden onset of urinary incontinence following a trivial fall.
O: Physical examination revealed bilateral high-stepping gait due to foot drop, symmetrical weakness of both the L4 and L5 roots (MRC grade 0/5), and partial weakness of the S1 root. Nondermatomal sensory disturbances and absent deep tendon reflexes were noted in the lower limbs. Anal tone was normal, but saddle anesthesia was present. Postvoidal ultrasonogram showed a residual urine volume of 250 ml, confirming a neurogenic bladder. MRI of the lumbar spine showed a solitary intraspinal posterior epidural lesion of 1.8 × 1.5 × 0.5 cm at the L2-L3 level, adjacent epidural fatty hypertrophy, severe canal stenosis (3 mm), and severely compressed cauda equina. CT revealed an osseous lesion attached to the right L2 inferior articular process causing severe secondary canal stenotic.
A: The primary diagnosis is a neurogenetic bladder with complications including severe canal and epidural stenosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal cord injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings.
P: The management plan includes surgical decompression and excision biopsy of the lesion at the earliest, using a standard midline posterior approach, exposing L2 and L3 lamina, and removing the spinous process. Postoperative care will focus on monitoring the patient's neurological status and managing any arising complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the procedure and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 2.3-year-old male with a history of microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. He is from a South American ethnical background. He has no prenatal exposures or risk factors.
O: Physical examination revealed hyperintense lesions in both "corona radiata" on the right side. MRI findings indicated hyperintension in the frontal lobe, parietal areas, and basal nuclei. EEG studies indicated abnormal activity with a generalized slow pattern and theta and delta bursts bilaterally in temporal regions. No alterations were found in genes LIS1, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PFAH3, FGF8, and PAX2.
A: The primary diagnosis is a severe neurological disorder, likely exacerbated by prenatal exposure to ethanol. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delay, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes initiating valproic acid for seizure management. The patient will be monitored for response to the medication and adjust as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed. Education regarding the nature of the condition and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of the neurological disorder is recommended.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old married woman with two children presenting with a 4-5 soft stools daily for the past 4 months. She reports unintentional weight loss of 3 kg over the past month, despite eating normal or more than usual. She has a significant family history of coeliac disease diagnosed at age 20.
O: Physical examination revealed heartburn, frequent regurgitations, fatigue, and a change in bowel movements. The patient's weight loss was noted as 3 kg in a month. Biochemical investigations including immunoglobulin A anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) and stool parasitological and cultural analysis showed normal IgA levels, negativity for anti-TTG levels, and antiendomysial antibodies (Ema). The patient was also diagnosed with Helicobacter Pylori (HP) pan-gastritis. Gastric biopsies indicated a Helicobacterial Pylor infection, with villous atrophy associated with an increase in intraepithelial T lymphocyte counts up to 40 IEL/100 epithelial cells (EC).
A: The primary diagnosis is Helicobacteria pan-Gastritis, likely caused by the Helicobactylori infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and clinical presentation.
P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's symptoms and potential treatment options. The treatment plan will focus on addressing the underlying cause of the symptoms, including potential surgical intervention or chemotherapy to address the gastritis. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the underlying conditions will be arranged.

S: The patient reports a lump in the left breast that has been increasing for 14 months. The patient denies any history of cancer.
O: Physical examination revealed a large, fixed 10 cm mass adherent to the chest, with no invasion of the skin, no ulceration, nipple discharge, or retraction, and no palpable lymph nodes. Preoperative unenhanced CT scan showed a well-defined round heterogeneous soft tissue density with hypo dense areas, necrosis, and peripheral and central calcifications in the 4th and 5th anterior thoracic rib. Core-needle biopsy indicated a chondrosarcoma grade II tumor. Post-surgery histopathology showed a blue-grey mass attached to the bone on one margin and covered by the breast on one surface. Histological sections showed mesenchymal proliferation organized in a lobulated architecture with abundant cartilaginous matrix and myxoide areas.
A: The primary diagnosis is chondrocytoma grade II of the breast. The tumor is localized to the anterior chest wall, with a surgical margin of more than 2.0 cm. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of sarcoma, but biopsy confirmed the diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes surgical excision of the tumor with a wide excision and resection of the ribs. Postoperative care instructions will include monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. Postoperatively, the patient will be extubated one day after surgery and discharged in 10 days if there are no complications. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any arising complications.
